title: La Casa Blanca fustiga el fallo judicial sobre los aranceles de Trump
content: La Casa Blanca fustig√≥ este jueves el fallo de un tribunal federal estadounidense que bloquea la mayor parte de los aranceles generalizados impuestos por el presidente Donald Trump.
resumen:
Una corte de apelaciones estadounidense mantuvo temporalmente los aranceles del presidente Donald Trump hasta pronunciarse sobre el fondo del caso, menos de 24 horas despu√©s de que otro tribunal los bloqueara.

Trump anunci√≥ en abril aranceles para casi todos sus socios comerciales, con un m√≠nimo generalizado de 10%, adem√°s de grav√°menes m√°s elevados para decenas de econom√≠as, incluidas China y la UE, que desde entonces se han suspendido.

El Tribunal de Comercio Internacional, compuesto por tres jueces, dictamin√≥ el mi√©rcoles que Trump se ha extralimitado en sus funciones y prohibi√≥ la mayor√≠a de los aranceles anunciados desde que asumi√≥ el cargo.

Trump calific√≥ la decisi√≥n de ¬´horrible¬ª y ¬´muy pol√≠tica¬ª, al tiempo que dijo que la Corte Suprema de Justicia deber√≠a revertirla ¬´r√°pidamente y con decisi√≥n¬ª.

El dictamen se aplicaba a los impuestos aduaneros a Canad√°, M√©xico y China -que Trump impuso para incentivarlos a combatir el tr√°fico de fentanilo- y a los grav√°menes adicionales del 2 de abril sobre todos los productos que entran en Estados Unidos, de un m√≠nimo de 10% y de hasta el 50% dependiendo del pa√≠s de origen.

Sin embargo, el tribunal manten√≠a intactos los aranceles del 25% para las industrias automotriz, del acero y del aluminio.

Los abogados de la administraci√≥n Trump presentaron un recurso contra la sentencia y el Departamento de Justicia dijo que ten√≠a la intenci√≥n de solicitar una medida de emergencia a la Corte Suprema este viernes.

Un tribunal de apelaciones acept√≥ la solicitud del gobierno y, adem√°s, uni√≥ en uno los dos casos presentados por peque√±as empresas, por un lado, y por una coalici√≥n de estados estadounidenses por el otro. Ambas partes estiman que el presidente viola el poder del Congreso.

Kevin Hassett, el principal asesor econ√≥mico de Donald Trump, dijo en Fox News: ¬´Estamos muy contentos con esta decisi√≥n, la esper√°bamos¬ª.

Peter Navarro, asesor comercial de Trump y art√≠fice de estas barreras aduaneras, declar√≥ a los periodistas en la Casa Blanca que Trump se mantendr√° firme, pase lo que pase con el caso en general.

Un juez federal de Washington ha dictaminado este jueves que los aranceles de Trump son ilegales pero los mantiene 14 d√≠as para que las partes puedan apelar.

La portavoz de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, dijo a periodistas que los jueces ¬´abusaron descaradamente de su poder judicial para usurpar la autoridad del presidente Trump¬ª.

Trump argumenta que el d√©ficit comercial y la amenaza que representa la afluencia de drogas constituyen una ¬´emergencia nacional¬ª que justifica los aranceles generalizados rechazados por la corte.

El tribunal no cree que ¬´la IEEPA confiera tal autoridad ilimitada y anula los aranceles impugnados impuestos en virtud de ella¬ª, sostiene el fallo.

China, castigada con aranceles adicionales del 145% antes de que se redujeran temporalmente para dar margen a las negociaciones, inst√≥ a Estados Unidos a ¬´escuchar las voces racionales de la comunidad internacional y las partes interesadas nacionales y a cancelar por completo las medidas arancelarias unilaterales injustificadas¬ª, declar√≥ la portavoz del Ministerio de Comercio, He Yongqian.

El primer ministro canadiense, Mark Carney, advirti√≥ que las relaciones comerciales siguen ¬´profunda y negativamente amenazadas¬ª por los grav√°menes restantes.

*   Leavitt inst√≥ a la Corte Suprema a ‚Äúponer fin a esto por el bien de nuestra Constituci√≥n y nuestro pa√≠s‚Äù, y luego se√±al√≥ que la administraci√≥n planea cumplir con las √≥rdenes del tribunal pero tiene la intenci√≥n de ‚Äúganar sobre el fondo de estos casos‚Äù.

**Protestas en Bolivia:**

*   Decenas de manifestantes leales a Morales (2006-2019), que portaban la bandera Wiphala, marcharon por el centro de La Paz.

*   Bolivia celebrar√° elecciones presidenciales el 17 de agosto y, a pesar de los fallos del Tribunal Constitucional que inhabilitan la inscripci√≥n de Morales, sus seguidores han convocado a varias marchas este mes para exigir su candidatura.
*   Morales cuestion√≥ a la justicia, se√±al√≥ al Gobierno de abuso de poder y dijo que no respeta la voluntad del pueblo, sino que reprime la protesta y ‚Äúencarcela inocentes‚Äù.

El Gobierno Trump calific√≥ de ‚Äúerr√≥neo‚Äù el fallo judicial que suspendi√≥ sus aranceles. La Casa Blanca y voceros de la administraci√≥n cuestionaron la decisi√≥n y aseguraron que ‚Äúnada cambia‚Äù.

El Tribunal de Comercio Internacional, compuesto por tres jueces, dictamin√≥ que Trump se ha extralimitado en sus funciones y prohibi√≥ la mayor√≠a de los aranceles anunciados desde que asumi√≥ el cargo.

El dictamen se aplica a los impuestos aduaneros a Canad√°, M√©xico y China y a los grav√°menes adicionales del 2 de abril sobre todos los productos que entran en Estados Unidos, de un m√≠nimo de 10% y de hasta el 50% dependiendo del pa√≠s de origen.

El fallo mantiene intactos los aranceles del 25% para las industrias automotriz, del acero y del aluminio.

El Departamento de Justicia pidi√≥ la paralizaci√≥n administrativa inmediata del fallo a la espera de la apelaci√≥n y prev√© solicitar una medida de emergencia a la Corte Suprema.

La Corte Suprema ‚Äúdebe poner fin‚Äù al desaf√≠o a los aranceles, pero Trump dispone de otros medios legales para imponerlos.

El asesor comercial de Trump, Peter Navarro, declar√≥ que ‚Äúnada ha cambiado realmente‚Äù.

El director del Consejo Econ√≥mico Nacional, Kevin Hassett, declar√≥ que tienen otras opciones que tardar√≠an un par de meses en implementarse pero por ahora no las usar√°n.

Hassett estima que los ‚Äúcontratiempos‚Äù por las decisiones de ‚Äújueces activistas‚Äù no afectar√°n a las negociaciones con socios comerciales y dijo que hay tres acuerdos a punto de concretarse.

Trump argumenta que el d√©ficit comercial y la amenaza que representa la afluencia de drogas constituyen una ‚Äúemergencia nacional‚Äù que justifica los aranceles generalizados rechazados por la corte.

El primer ministro canadiense, Mark Carney, advirti√≥ que las relaciones comerciales siguen ‚Äúprofunda y negativamente amenazadas‚Äù por los grav√°menes restantes.

En las primeras operaciones, el Dow Jones se dispar√≥ 0,20%. El Nasdaq subi√≥ un 1,51% en su apertura. El √≠ndice S&P 500 se recuperaba 0,87%.

resumen:
Una Corte de Apelaciones en EE.UU. suspendi√≥ el bloqueo de los aranceles decretados por Trump, lo que revive la incertidumbre comercial.

El fallo inicial del Tribunal de Comercio Internacional consider√≥ que Trump se excedi√≥ en sus facultades al usar la Ley de Poderes Econ√≥micos en Emergencias Internacionales (IEEPA) para imponer aranceles globales.

El fallo judicial no ha anulado los aranceles, pero tampoco los hace definitivos.
La Corte de Apelaciones estableci√≥ un cronograma:
-Los demandantes deben responder antes del 5 de junio.
-El Gobierno de Trump tiene plazo hasta el 9 de junio.

resumen:

La isla sufre una profunda crisis energ√©tica, agravada desde agosto de 2024, con cortes que alcanzan las 20 horas diarias en amplias regiones del pa√≠s.

Expertos independientes se√±alan que la crisis energ√©tica responde a una infrafinanciaci√≥n cr√≥nica de este sector, completamente en manos del Estado cubano desde el triunfo de la revoluci√≥n en 1959.

El Gobierno cubano destaca por su parte el impacto de las sanciones.

content: Companies welcomed a court decision striking down President Trump‚Äôs tariffs. Then a stay of that ruling left no one breathing easy.
resumen:
Emma Mcilroy‚Äôs apparel company, Wildfang, had been working overtime to move its production out of China in the months since President Trump launched his trade war.
A federal court had ruled most of Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs illegal.
A three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of International Trade ruled that the Trump administration had acted illegally in using an emergency powers law to impose 30 percent tariffs on goods from China, 25 percent tariffs on most goods from Mexico and Canada, and 10 percent on everyone else.
The court gave the White House 10 days to halt the new duties.
A higher court stayed the decision.
If the initial ruling sticks, it will preclude the return of steeper ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs that Mr. Trump paused for 90 days in early April.
It might even allow companies that have paid the emergency tariffs over the past several months to claim refunds.
It could result in the reinstatement of the de minimis exemption on goods from China.
Mr. Trump closed the loophole, which had for years allowed Chinese shipments worth $800 or less to enter the country tariff-free.
The Trump administration quickly appealed the ruling and received the stay ‚Äî keeping the tariffs in place ‚Äî while the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit considers the case.
Appeals could continue all the way to the Supreme Court.
Companies that process customs paperwork and payments on behalf of importers said they would keep collecting the tariffs struck down by the court.
Adam Lewis, a co-founder of Clearit, a customs broker, said, ‚ÄúWith nothing official coming down the pipeline from U.S. Customs, I am advising the status quo.‚Äù
Matt Hassett, the chief executive of Loftie, a company that makes lamps and alarm clocks in China, said he had to raise prices significantly, and was preparing to pay as much as 70 percent on a shipment that would depart soon.
Loftie plans to keep working to move production out of China.
The Retail Industry Leaders Association, a trade group for large retailers, also cautioned its members that the White House could try to impose tariffs through other avenues.
Blake Harden, the association‚Äôs vice president for international trade, said, ‚ÄúThe constant on-and-off-again nature of the tariffs has made business planning incredibly difficult.‚Äù
Kohl‚Äôs chief financial officer, Jill Timm, said on the company‚Äôs earnings call, ‚ÄúI would say it is a fluid situation, given the news last night and this morning.‚Äù
Miriam Tuerk, chief executive of Clear Blue Technologies, a Canadian manufacturer of solar equipment, said, ‚ÄúSo I just decided last night the only thing I can do is say to customers: ‚ÄòHere‚Äôs the number. We‚Äôll take the risk.‚Äô‚Äù
E.L.F. Beauty, a drugstore cosmetics line that makes most of its products in China, had announced plans to raise prices by $1 in August ‚Äî its third price increase in 21 years ‚Äî to partly cover tariffs that reached a high of 170 percent of the value of a shipment that arrived in April.
Tarang Amin, the company‚Äôs chief executive, said, ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt have a choice but to continue to bring product in; otherwise, there won‚Äôt be anything on the shelf.‚Äù
Trim-Tex, which makes drywall construction accessories in Lincolnwood, Ill., and Miami, exports 20 percent of its output, including to Canada.
Sales at the company, which has 250 employees, are down 10 percent year over year, said its chief financial officer, Matt Totsch.

title: Trump allies expect he‚Äôll double down on tariffs after sweeping court block
content: Perhaps more importantly for his administration's agenda, Trump is currently in the middle of negotiations with countries that will likely be less pressed to ink deals until the court battle fallout ...
resumen: A federal court ruled that Donald Trump can't impose tariffs at his whim, permanently blocking some of the most controversial tariffs. The ruling, from a three-judge panel at the US Court of International Trade, found the tariffs were implemented unconstitutionally under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). The blocked tariffs included those designed to stop drug and human trafficking, as well as retaliatory tariffs on countries to end US trade deficits. The judges, including Trump-appointed Timothy Reif, Barack Obama-appointed Gary Katzman, and Ronald Reagan-appointed Jane Restani, agreed that Trump can't declare a "national emergency" and impose tariffs when there is no "unusual and extraordinary" threat and tariffs aren't targeted to "deal with" that specific threat. Trump has immediately appealed the ruling and is expected to take the case to the Supreme Court. White House spokesperson Kush Desai said Trump remains "committed to using every lever of executive power to address" the "crisis" of trade deficits. The Consumer Technology Association forecasted that Americans could pay more than $123 billion more annually for just 10 common gadgets that would be hit with tariffs. Oregon Attorney General Dan Rayfield criticized Trump's previously "unchecked authority" and celebrated the win for "working families, small businesses, and everyday Americans." Trump allies expect he‚Äôll double down on tariffs. White House National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett claimed that Trump is so confident that his appeal will be successful that he's not even looking into alternatives to impose similar tariffs.

title: Chaos vs. Hope: America‚Äôs Trading Partners React Cautiously to Tariff Block
content: President Trump‚Äôs threat to impose big charges ‚Äî including 50 percent on the European Union ‚Äî was in question after judges blocked his across-the-board levies.
resumen: The Trump administration‚Äôs threat to impose 50 percent tariffs on the European Union and steep tariffs of varying sizes on other critical American trading partners is in limbo. A panel of U.S. federal judges blocked a set of across-the-board levies on Wednesday. The U.S. Court of International Trade handed down the decision. On Thursday evening, another court temporarily froze the first court‚Äôs decision. The initial decision offered a fragile chance at reprieve for economies like those of Australia, Britain, Canada, the European Union and India. Georgina Wright, a senior fellow at the German Marshall Fund who specializes in policy in Europe, said, ‚Äúthis is just another episode.‚Äù Mark Carney, prime minister of Canada, said that he welcomed the news of the initial decision to block the tariffs. Don Farrell, Australia‚Äôs trade minister, said his nation would ‚Äústudy this ruling.‚Äù A government spokesman in Britain said that the court ruling was a domestic issue for the United States. A spokesman for India‚Äôs foreign ministry told reporters at a briefing that ‚Äúthis is an ongoing matter, so you will have to bear with us.‚Äù The European Commission, the executive arm of the European Union, declined to comment altogether. The initial court‚Äôs decision, announced Wednesday, does nothing to roll back sector-specific tariffs on steel and aluminum and on cars or to forestall future tariffs on pharmaceuticals. Ignacio Garc√≠a Bercero, a nonresident fellow at the think tank Bruegel who was formerly a top trade negotiator at the European Commission, said, ‚ÄúThe question about trying to find a solution is still there.‚Äù The court decision would have blocked ‚Äî if not for the stay ‚Äî a set of across-the-board tariffs that Washington enacted on a range of trading partners after an early April announcement. Those tariffs are now set to 10 percent, but they are poised to ratchet up to higher levels that vary by country in early July, after a 90-day ‚Äúpause‚Äù that the Trump administration enacted to allow for negotiations. President Trump has been using a novel interpretation of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, a 1977 law, to impose those sweeping levies. The initial court said the legislation did not grant him ‚Äúunbounded authority‚Äù to enact tariffs. Analysts at Goldman Sachs wrote that the administration could ‚Äúquickly replace‚Äù the 10 percent tariffs with a tariff of up to 15 percent for 150 days using another trade rule. Alec Phillips, an economist at Goldman, wrote in his firm‚Äôs analysis, ‚ÄúWe expect the Trump administration will find other ways to impose tariffs.‚Äù Brando Benifei, chair of the delegation for relations with the United States at the European Parliament, said that the court challenge underscored that waging a trade war via large, presidentially imposed tariffs may not be sustainable. Derren Nathan, head of equity research at the financial services company Hargreaves Lansdown, wrote in a report that ‚Äúthe latest development is unlikely to be the last twist in the tale.‚Äù

title: Gold will stay firm as trust in US frays amid Trump‚Äôs tariffs and ‚Äòbig, beautiful Bill‚Äô
content: Buoyant demand for gold in Singapore mirrors the global view. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen:
Gold's appeal as a safe haven remains strong.

Total bar and coin demand in Singapore in the three months to the end of March shot up 35 per cent over the same period in 2024, marking the strongest quarter on record, said the World Gold Council (WGC).

Global demand reached its highest first-quarter level since the first quarter of 2016, according to Mr Shaokai Fan, head of Asia-Pacific (ex-China) and global head of central banks at the WGC.

Jewellery sales volume here fell 20 per cent in the first quarter of 2025 compared with a year earlier, while the value rose 9 per cent year on year.

US President Donald Trump‚Äôs Liberation Day tariffs on major trading partners on April 2 jolted gold prices from below US$3,000 an ounce to almost US$3,500 by late April.

Gold prices are now hovering around US$3,250 an ounce.

Mr Heng Koon How, head of markets strategy at UOB, expects a near-term consolidation in prices.

He expects the pace of stockpiling to be less intense than earlier in 2025 because the 10 per cent universal tariffs the US charges as a baseline remain in place.

He is keeping his gold price forecast for the third quarter at US$3,400 an ounce and for the fourth quarter at US$3,500 an ounce.

Ms Lina Thomas, a commodities strategist at Goldman Sachs Research, predicts gold will rise to US$3,700 an ounce by the end of 2025.

Central banks own about 17 per cent of all the gold ever mined.

China holds less than 10 per cent of its reserves in gold, compared with about 70 per cent or more for the US, Germany, France, and Italy.

Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine in 2022, and the freezing of Russia‚Äôs foreign assets by Western countries, marked a turning point for central banks‚Äô stance on gold. Their purchases on the London over-the-counter market have since increased fivefold, said Ms Thomas.

Mr Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúbig, beautiful Bill‚Äù passed the House of Representatives and now awaits the Senate.

The Bill will make permanent huge tax cuts for the wealthy and cost the government US$4.6 trillion (S$5.93 trillion) over the next 10 years.

The sweeping tax and spending Bill would increase the US deficit to about 125 per cent of the economy‚Äôs output.

Goldman Sachs is recommending a higher than usual allocation to gold.

If concerns about the US fiscal position and Federal Reserve‚Äôs independence intensify, a flight to gold could drive prices beyond US$3,700 an ounce by the end of 2025, the investment bank said.

WGC senior markets analyst Louise Street noted that investors have been piling into gold ETFs from the third quarter of 2024. Inflows in Asia in April 2025 stormed past their first quarter 2025 total.

Global gold ETF holdings sitting 10 per cent below their 2020 high.

title: How 2025 Tariffs Are Changing China‚Äôs Export Landscape
content: Facing rapid US tariffs hikes in 2025 China's export saw front-loaded shipments in March, leading to a surge ahead of steadier April volumes.
resumen:
In 2025, China's exports faced rapid US tariff hikes, leading to front-loaded shipments in March and a surge ahead of steadier April volumes. A mid-May rollback added uncertainty, driving China to diversify markets, upgrade products, and reconfigure supply chains.

As of mid-2025, the average US tariff on Chinese imports stands at 51.1 percent, covering nearly 100 percent of Chinese goods.

In January 2025, the Trump administration dramatically intensified tariffs.

February 4 and March 4, 2025: The administration imposed a blanket 10 percentage point increase on all imports from China.

March 12, 2025: Tariffs on global steel and aluminum imports were raised further.

April 3 and May 3: Targeted duties were introduced on automotive imports, parts, and electric vehicles.

April 5, 9, and 10: A rapid series of tariff hikes culminated in cumulative increases of up to 125 percentage points. The average US tariff rate on Chinese goods skyrocketed to 126.5 percent by early May.

China retaliated in kind, extending tariffs to cover 100 percent of US goods, with average duties hitting 147.6 percent by April 10, 2025.

On May 14, 2025, negotiators from both countries reached an agreement to scale back the April escalations.

Under the deal: Both sides converted the April tariff increases into a uniform 10 percent tariff on all bilateral trade. The average US tariff on Chinese imports dropped from 126.5 percent to 51.1 percent. China‚Äôs average tariff on US goods fell from 147.6 percent to 32.6 percent.

In March 2025, China‚Äôs exports reached US$314 billion, a 12.4 percent year-on-year (YoY) increase. The total export value amounted to RMB 2.39 trillion, with a monthly trade surplus of US$103 billion (exports: US$314 billion; imports: US$211 billion).

Export performance was strong across several key product categories: Mechanical and electronic products: +7.6% YoY, Home appliances: +8.7%, LCDs: +8.4%, Fertilizer: +42.7%, Agricultural products: +5.7%.

On a geographical basis, exports increased to a wide range of major trading partners: United States: +4.5%, Japan: +2.8%, Hong Kong: +8.3%, India: +13.8%, United Kingdom: +6.2%, European Union: +3.7%, ASEAN countries: +8.1%.

In April 2025, China‚Äôs exports totaled US$314.1 billion (RMB 2.3 trillion), marking an 8.1 percent year-on-year (YoY) increase in US dollar terms. China‚Äôs total foreign trade reached US$532.5 billion (RMB 3.6 trillion), up 5.6 percent YoY, while the country registered a trade surplus of US$95.7 billion (exports: US$314.1 billion; imports: US$218.4 billion).

Export strength was concentrated in key product categories: Mechanical and electrical products: +9.5% YoY, Integrated circuits: +14.7%, Automatic data processing equipment and components: +5.6%, Automobiles: +4.0%.

Several regional markets saw accelerated growth: European Union: +8.3%, ASEAN countries: +20.8%, India: +21.7%, Hong Kong SAR: +8.8%, Japan: +7.8%, Canada: +15.0%, Taiwan (China): +15.5%.

Exports to Russia (-2.7 percent) and the United States (-21.0 percent) declined markedly.

In March, US-bound exports enjoyed a modest +4.5 percent YoY bump, but once tariffs took effect on April 9, those shipments plunged 21.0 percent year-on-year in April.

Exports to the EU gathered momentum, rising from +3.7 percent in March to +8.3 percent in April.

ASEAN destinations jumped from +8.1 percent in March to +20.8 percent in April.

Exports to India surged from +13.8 to +21.7 percent.

High-tech goods: Growth in mechanical, electrical, and ICT products rose from +7.6 percent in March to +9.5 percent in April.

Intermediate goods: Fertilizer exports still expanded by +35.2 percent in April.

Consumer goods: Durable goods such as home appliances and LCD panels eased slightly.

China is leaning into higher-value, technology-intensive exports.

China‚Äôs exporters are diversifying their geographic footprint to mitigate the US-driven downturn.

Diversification of markets: Exports to ASEAN surged 20.8 percent YoY in April. Shipments to Europe rose 8.3 percent. Exports to the US swung from +4.5 percent in March to -21.0 percent in April.

Product upgrading and value-addition: In April, high-tech goods grew 9.5 percent YoY, compared to 7.6 percent in March.

Supply-chain reconfiguration: China‚Äôs processing trade grew 14.2 percent in April, while bonded logistics trade expanded 22.3 percent.

Special customs zones dedicated to e-commerce saw remarkable growth.

Chinese Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs) have been quicker to reorient toward emerging markets and digital channels.

State-backed initiatives have provided crucial liquidity and market intelligence to both SMEs and larger firms.

The May 14 Geneva agreement to roll back the April tariffs offered some respite.

China will continue redirecting exports toward ASEAN, the Middle East, and Latin America.

Greater use of RMB-denominated trade and bilateral currency agreements will help buffer against dollar-centric fluctuations and policy shocks.

We can expect accelerated near-shoring and localized production through outbound investment.

title: Export Controls Are Endangering the Fragile U.S.-China Truce
content: Just two-and-a-half weeks after agreeing to suspend tariffs, both countries are using export controls to disrupt each other‚Äôs key industries.
resumen:
After stepping back this month from an escalating and dangerous war of tariffs, the United States and China are now threatening to undermine their uneasy truce.

On May 12, the countries announced after weekend meetings in Geneva that they would suspend most of their recently imposed tariffs.

China has restricted its exports of rare earth magnets, which are crucial for cars, semiconductors, aircraft and many other applications. Close to 90 percent of the world‚Äôs rare earth metals, including magnets, are produced in China.

And the United States on May 13 banned the latest semiconductors from Huawei, a Chinese electronics giant. And in recent days, President Trump has suspended the sale of some American semiconductor technology and aerospace equipment needed for China‚Äôs commercial aircraft, the C919.

The increasing use of export controls by both countries amounts to supply chain warfare, interrupting the flow of key components that the other country must have to operate huge industries that employ large numbers of workers.

Last week, Ford Motor temporarily closed a factory in Chicago that makes Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles after one of its suppliers ran out of the magnets. In most new cars, the magnets are used in dozens of electric motors that operate brake and steering systems, fuel injectors and even power seats.

On Monday, China granted some export licenses for rare earth magnets to be shipped to the United States and Europe, according to two industry executives. But many more factories in both regions will have to close in the coming days and weeks if China does not resume full exports of rare earth metals, corporate executives and business leaders said.

‚ÄúHundreds of E.U. companies are impacted, and we expect that this may lead to production stoppages already this week for some companies,‚Äù said Jens Eskelund, the president of the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China.

American companies are feeling the effect even more. Several companies in Europe, including Volkswagen, were granted permission by Beijing to continue procuring rare earth magnets soon after China began enforcing export controls on them in April. American companies have been juggling factory schedules, reassigning their dwindling magnet supplies to continue making their most profitable products.

A Ford spokesman confirmed that the Explorer factory had been closed last week because of a disruption in rare earth magnet supplies, but said it had reopened this week. Ford had been planning to not run the factory for a week anyway in the coming months, and shifted that downtime to last week when the magnet supply ran short, he said.

The agreement reached in Geneva by U.S. and Chinese officials to de-escalate their confrontation over tariffs has been cheered by investors. The two sides said they would take a 90-day pause on tariffs and set up working groups of top officials to try to reach agreements on trade.

That made the timing of the U.S. Commerce Department‚Äôs decision a day later to bar Americans from using or financing Huawei artificial intelligence chips noteworthy. The department contended that the A.I. chips were based on a prohibited export of American technology, which Huawei has denied.

The restrictions were the latest in a long series of American blows aimed at Huawei, which is one of China‚Äôs best-known success stories. Its hundreds of thousands of workers produce everything from cellphone base stations to autonomous driving systems for cars.

Chinese officials have reacted with growing anger at the U.S. use of export controls.

‚ÄúChina once again urges the U.S. to immediately correct its wrong practices, stop discriminatory restrictive measures against China and jointly maintain the consensus reached at the Geneva high-level talks,‚Äù He Yongqian, the Ministry of Commerce spokeswoman, said at a news briefing on Thursday.

American restrictions on sales to COMAC, a state-owned enterprise, represent a setback to the Chinese government‚Äôs long-term project to shed its dependence on Boeing and Airbus. The C919 aircraft is heavily dependent on American and European components, with the company‚Äôs miles-long complex of hangars and design labs in Shanghai mainly installing components from foreign companies in Chinese-built air frames.

In a reply to questions early Thursday, Kush Desai, a White House spokesman, said: ‚ÄúThe Geneva agreement was a major first step towards securing a final, comprehensive trade deal with China. Discussions continue, and the administration is monitoring compliance with the agreement.‚Äù

The United States has been gradually tightening export controls on semiconductors for a decade, contending that China has used American computer chip technology to improve a wide range of military hardware. Chinese government officials and industry executives have denied this, and contend that the United States is trying instead to limit China‚Äôs economic development.

Two days after Mr. Trump imposed steep tariffs on April 2 on imports from China and many other countries, China imposed its own export controls on some kinds of rare earths and heat-resistant magnets made from them.

The Geneva trade agreement had also called for China to ‚Äúadopt all necessary administrative measures to suspend or remove the non-tariff countermeasures taken against the United States since April 2, 2025.‚Äù

But China‚Äôs Commerce Ministry has contended that rare earths have military applications, and it has avoided describing its export controls as a trade countermeasure. Although most rare earth magnets are used in civilian industries, they are also essential for electric motors in advanced fighter jets and the guidance systems of intercontinental ballistic missiles.

‚ÄúIt is a common international practice to impose export controls on items with obvious dual-use military and civilian attributes,‚Äù Ms. He said on Thursday.

Experts in China have begun defending export controls on rare earth magnets as appropriate while the United States maintains export controls on semiconductors.

‚ÄúChina sees export controls on rare earths as a counterstrike to U.S. export controls on semiconductors,‚Äù said Zhu Ning, deputy dean at the Shanghai Advanced Institute of Finance.

Yet if China maintains export controls on rare earths, many multinational companies may conclude that their supply chains are too reliant on China, Mr. Eskelund said. ‚ÄúThe risk of production stoppages due to export controls will only increase calls in Europe for de-risking from China.‚Äù

The question now is how much longer both sides maintain their export controls.

‚ÄúIt would be unfortunate if one or both sides overestimates its own leverage and feels like it needs to prove that to the other side,‚Äù said Chris Adams, a former Treasury official who is now a partner at the Covington and Burling law firm.

title: Trade disputes threaten US-EU relations, even as court blocks Trump tariffs
content: As a court ruling interrupts President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariff plans, the U.S.-Europe trade relationship continues to chafe under his bully-to-bargain style.
resumen: Trade disputes threaten US-EU relations, even as courts weigh Trump tariffs. Two federal courts have blocked major portions of President Donald Trump‚Äôs trade agenda, but that doesn‚Äôt mean his tariffs ‚Äì or his efforts to extract concessions from trade partners like the European Union ‚Äì are over. For now, his tariffs stay in place, a federal appeals court ruled Thursday, until it can review one of the cases. The legal drama began Wednesday, when the U.S. Court of International Trade ruled that President Trump had exceeded his authority under a 1977 law to impose tariffs on other nations. Then on Thursday, U.S. District Judge Rudolph Contreras came to the same conclusion, although his ruling only applies to the two companies that filed the suit. The trade court‚Äôs decision was paused by the federal appeals court while the arguments are being reviewed. While courts review the legality of President Trump‚Äôs tariff threats, the longer-term risks of America‚Äôs chaotic trade policy include lost confidence of longtime allies. Even if the earlier rulings are upheld, they wouldn‚Äôt block all of Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs, such as on steel and aluminum imports. These include initial tariffs against Mexico, Canada, and China due to fentanyl imports, as well as his Liberation Day tariffs of 10% or higher on all nations‚Äô imports to the U.S. In both cases, the administration invoked a 1977 law, the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The IEEPA Act does not ‚Äúdelegate an unbounded tariff authority to the President,‚Äù the trade court wrote Wednesday. The ruling has thrown a wrench in President Trump‚Äôs continued rollout of aggressive trade actions. The European Union is a front-burner case study of how U.S. trade policy is in flux. In the past week alone, Mr. Trump threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European goods entering the U.S., and then pushed back his June 1 deadline to July 9 after positive talks with EU leaders over the weekend. At stake is nearly $1 trillion worth of trade in mostly high-value goods. If a transatlantic trade war breaks out, it could prove different from, but as far-reaching as, the U.S.-China conflict. American consumers and companies could see higher prices on European pharmaceuticals, cars, specialized industrial machinery and electric goods, and parts flowing to the U.S. And if Europe retaliates, as it has threatened to do, the U.S. could see reduced sales of oil and gas, pharmaceuticals, aerospace goods, medical equipment, and cars flowing in the other direction. That‚Äôs far more total trade in terms of value than the diminished U.S.-China trade flows. Perhaps the biggest long-term casualty would be political rather than economic: the loss of trust and cooperation between longtime allies. The administration‚Äôs pattern of big threats followed by negotiations has created uncertainty for businesses and roiled markets in the past. The administration retains many options to get its way on trade. It has already appealed the trade court ruling. It could use authority other than the 1977 IEEPA to impose tariffs. The U.S. negotiating position is to impose tariffs and then ask for something in return for lifting those tariffs. American threats and counterthreats don‚Äôt inspire cooperation. It‚Äôs not clear what the EU can offer to satisfy President Trump. He has pushed for reform of European taxes that hurt sales of U.S. goods. He has also targeted agriculture. For decades, Europe has resisted American demands that it reduce farm subsidies and allow imports of crops infused with genetically modified organisms into the European market. The only U.S. trade deal negotiated so far, with the United Kingdom, doesn‚Äôt offer much guidance. British Prime Minister Keir Starmer had little economic leverage and was eager for a deal, so he acceded earlier this month to most of America‚Äôs demands. That includes better access for some U.S. farm and commercial aviation goods while allowing America‚Äôs 10% tariff on British goods to remain in place. Stickier issues, such as Britain‚Äôs tax on digital services and its restrictions on U.S. chicken imports, remain unresolved. Smaller countries are more likely to kowtow to the U.S. The EU and China are different, they‚Äôre very large trading blocks. Several analysts believe the two sides will reach some kind of deal. The most likely scenario is one in which cooperation between the U.S. and Europe on all kinds of issues is going to be less, it‚Äôs going to be harder to achieve.

title: Why do they call Trump TACO? How president responded to TACO question, what it means
content: President Donald Trump erupts over TACO trade question. Here's what TACO means and what he said about the new nickname.
resumen:
The term TACO, which stands for "Trump Always Chickens Out,‚Äù describes President Donald Trump's trade war tactics. It was first coined by Financial Times commentator Robert Armstrong to describe Trump‚Äôs pattern of announcing heavy tariffs on countries causing economic shock, panic and stock market hits and then later reversing course with pauses or reductions that create a market rebound.

When asked about TACO on Wednesday by a reporter, Trump responded, ‚ÄúI chicken out? Oh, I‚Äôve never heard that. You mean because I reduced China from 145% that I set down to 100... and then to another number?‚Äù He went on to defend his decisions to slash his tariffs on China for the next 90 days and extend his deadline for a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union until July 9.

Trump said "because I gave the European Union a 50% tax tariff, and they called up and they said 'please lets meet right now, please let's meet right now,' and I said OK, I'll give you until July." He then clarified that they weren't willing to meet initially, "And after I did what I did, they said, 'we'll meet anytime you want.' You call that chickening out?"

Trump said, "Six months ago, this country was stone cold dead. We had a dead country. We had a country that people didn't think it was going to survive," Trump said. "And you ask a nasty question like that. It's called negotiation."

"Don't ever say what you said because that's a nasty question," Trump said.

title: Here are the White House's tariff options after losing key court case, according to Goldman Sachs
content: The White House losing a key tariff court case at the Court of International Trade isn't the end of the story with respect to the sweeping levies the Trump administration has imposed over the last two ...
resumen: The White House is appealing the three-judge ruling announced in New York on Wednesday that struck down the 10% baseline tariff on all countries, the 20% tariff on imports on China as well as the 25% tariff on Canadian and Mexican imports that are not compliance with the USMCA free-trade pact. These tariffs were all issued under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). Sector tariffs - the 25% levy already imposed on steel, aluminum and auto imports - are unaffected, as they were issued under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act. Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974 authorizes the president to address a balance-of-payment deficit, and the administration could use it and apply tariffs of up to 15%, right away. Section 122 tariffs can only be used for 150 days. That 150-day authority could then be used as a bridge to subsequently issue tariffs under Section 301 of the Trade Act, which would require investigations. There is no limit on the level or duration of tariffs under Sec. 301. The White House could instead focus less on countries and more on industries. Section 338 of the Trade Act of 1930 allows the president to impose tariffs of up to 50% on imports from countries that discriminate against the U.S. It's never been used.

title: Pharma, chips, other sectors look set to get hit with new tariffs soon, even as courts wrestle with other Trump levies
content: The ING strategists said the sectors that could face new tariffs due to these investigations include pharmaceuticals PJP, semiconductors SMH, shipbuilding, medium- and heavy-duty trucks, critical ...
resumen: Federal courts have blocked and then reinstated the bulk of U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs. The rulings don't affect the import taxes that he's slapped on particular sectors. The pace of sector-based tariffs is expected to accelerate, with additional measures likely to be announced soon. The main U.S. stock gauges SPX DJIA COMP opened higher Thursday and ended with modest gains. If the country-focused levies end up going away, the average effective U.S. tariff rate will be around 7%, down from about 18%, according to estimates from the Budget Lab at Yale. Trump's existing sector-based tariffs - his 25% duty on imported steel and aluminum and his 25% levy on imported automobiles and many auto parts - are unaffected by this week's court rulings. A number of other sectors are also expected to get hit with Section 232 tariffs, and the required investigations for such levies have been under way for weeks or months. Additional sectors look set to face new tariffs as well as a result of ongoing investigations based on a rule related to unfair trade practices - Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974. The sectors that could face new tariffs due to these investigations include pharmaceuticals PJP, semiconductors SMH, shipbuilding, medium- and heavy-duty trucks, critical minerals, seafood, cranes, copper (HG00), lumber and aircraft. Apple Inc. (AAPL), Samsung Electronics Co. (KR:005930) and other makers of smartphones appear likely to get caught up in the much-anticipated Section 232 tariffs for semiconductors. Trump last week warned these companies that they could face import taxes of at least 25%. Trump's tariffs: Apple, Samsung and their competitors could face a 25% tariff at the end of June. Section 232 tariffs of 25% are in effect for China, Canada and Mexico (with exemptions for USMCA-compliant goods), and the E.U. and many other U.S. trading partners (facing a 10% tariff). The U.S. kept a 10% tariff in place on most U.K. imports.

title: Tariffs impacting production along the border
content: BY EDUARDO GARCIA AND SANRA SADEK PUENTE NEWS COLLABORATIVE Edited by Dudley Althaus As the head of a mid-sized auto parts company, √ìscar C√°zares had long considered how to respond if President Donald ...
resumen: √ìscar C√°zares, head of Industrias Cazel, considered moving production to the United States due to potential tariffs on Mexican-made components. C√°zares, whose factories in Mexico produce automotive components, dismissed the idea due to the high costs of relocating. His decision reflects a reality check for President Donald Trump's strategy of using tariffs to bring back industrial jobs to the U.S. A panel of federal judges blocked President Trump from imposing most of his tariffs on China and other U.S. trading partners. The Santa Teresa Port of Entry facilitates over $31 billion in trade annually. Hota, a Taiwanese auto parts supplier, announced a 30-acre campus in Santa Teresa in late 2023, with a $99 million investment and 350 new employees, but the project's progress is uncertain due to tariffs. Jerry Pacheco, president of the Border Industrial Association, stated that many projects are on hold or canceled due to the uncertainty of tariffs. C√°zares' company, Industrias Cazel, employs nearly 1,000 people at plants in Tultitl√°n, Quer√©taro, and Monterrey, serving car manufacturers like Stellantis, Nissan, Honda, and Volkswagen. Top operators at his plants earn between $25,000 and $30,000 a year, while the same job in the U.S. would cost at least $80,000. Mexico has about 2,500 auto parts makers, employing nearly 900,000 workers. The Tesla Gigafactory in Austin employs fewer than 3,000 assembly line workers to produce as many as 300,000 passenger cars and Cybertrucks annually. The fully automated Togg factory in Turkey produces 175,000 electric SUVs annually with only 500 manufacturing workers. The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) raised the threshold of North American content required for tariff-free trade to 75% and mandated that 40% to 45% of a vehicle be produced by workers earning at least $16 an hour. Tesla suspended construction of a new Monterrey plant, citing uncertainty over U.S. tariff policy. U.S. purchases of industrial robots have more than doubled in the past decade. U.S. automakers had deployed 1,287 robots per 10,000 manufacturing workers as of 2023.

title: Bank of Mexico cuts 2025 economic growth forecast to just 0.1%
content: The Bank of Mexico has cut its 2025 and 2026 economic growth forecast citing sluggish domestic activity and U.S. protectionism.
resumen: The Bank of Mexico (Banxico) has cut its 2025 economic growth forecast to 0.1%. For 2026, Bank of Mexico cut its economic growth forecast to 0.9%. The central bank cited expectations of ‚Äúsluggish‚Äù domestic activity and ‚Äúsignificant challenges‚Äù related to U.S. protectionism. In its previous report, the forecast for 2025 was 0.6%. The quarterly report was published on Wednesday. The report mentioned that the global economy faces significant challenges stemming from the changes in U.S. trade policy. The United States has imposed tariffs of varying magnitude on most of its imports. Banxico said there is uncertainty regarding the effects that these actions could have on Mexico‚Äôs external demand. More than 80% of Mexico‚Äôs exports go to the United States. Duties currently apply to Mexican steel, aluminum, cars and goods not covered by the USMCA. The Mexican economy expanded 0.2% in the first quarter of 2025 compared to the final quarter of last year. The economy contracted 0.6% on a sequential basis in the final quarter of 2024. The International Monetary Fund is now forecasting a 0.3% contraction while the World Bank is predicting 0% growth. The most recent 2025 forecast from Mexico‚Äôs Finance Ministry was growth in the range of 1.5% to 2.3%. Gabriel Cuadra, a deputy governor of the Bank of Mexico, said Wednesday that in 2025 they are forecasting an economic growth variation close to zero. Banxico mentioned a range of ‚Äúdownside risks throughout the forecast horizon.‚Äù They included uncertainty ‚Äúdriven by the policies that could be implemented in the United States‚Äù increases and ‚Äúnegatively affects external demand as well as consumption and investment spending in Mexico.‚Äù Also, that economic growth in the U.S. is lower than expected, that the reduction in public spending in Mexico ‚Äúhas a stronger impact on economic activity,‚Äù and that ‚Äúsevere weather phenomena, such as extreme temperatures, cyclones, or droughts, adversely impact the Mexican economy.‚Äù Banxico also cited various ‚Äúrisks to the upside throughout the forecast horizon.‚Äù They included that ‚Äúincoming data regarding U.S. trade policy mitigates uncertainty and signals a favorable resolution that will benefit economic activity in the region,‚Äù that growth in the U.S. is ‚Äúgreater than expected, favoring Mexico‚Äôs external demand,‚Äù that ‚Äúunder the USMCA, the global reconfiguration of production processes provides a greater-than-expected boost to investment,‚Äù and that ‚Äúpublic spending provides a greater-than-expected boost to economic activity.‚Äù Banxico‚Äôs forecast range is -0.5% to 0.7%. Banxico Governor Victoria Rodr√≠guez Ceja said Mexico is not entering a recession. Rodr√≠guez asserted that strengthening of the rule of law in Mexico and promoting competition in the market are essential to support economic growth. The Bank of Mexico has cut its key interest rate by 50 basis points after all three monetary policy meetings this year.

title: Trump Makes a New Push to ‚ÄòDecouple‚Äô U.S. From China
content: Trump administration officials are getting a second chance to try to sever ties with China by starting a trade war, imposing export controls and revoking student visas.
resumen:
The Trump administration has threatened to revoke the visas of many of the 277,000 or so Chinese students in the United States and to subject future applicants from China, including Hong Kong, to extra scrutiny. The Trump administration is suspending sales of some critical U.S. technologies to China, including those related to jet engines, semiconductors and certain chemicals and machinery. These actions amount to an aggressive campaign to ‚Äúdecouple‚Äù the United States from China.

In Mr. Trump‚Äôs second term, U.S. officials are seeking more aggressively to break the close commercial ties between the two nations.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio threatened on Wednesday night to revoke the visas of many of the Chinese students in the United States, suggesting that they could be threats. The students whose visas will be revoked, he said, include those with ties to the Chinese Communist Party or who study in ‚Äúcritical fields.‚Äù He did not indicate how many people would be affected, or define ‚Äúcritical fields.‚Äù He also did not say what kinds of ties to the party would be deemed risky, or how the officials would pinpoint those ties.

Xi Jinping, China‚Äôs leader, said during a visit to the United States in November 2023 that China would like to welcome 50,000 American students over five years. Last year, about 800 Americans studied in China. In 2019, before the pandemic, there were about 11,000.

In April, Mr. Trump imposed 145 percent tariffs on Chinese goods but brought those down to a still-significant 30 percent after U.S. and Chinese officials agreed to a temporary truce this month. China lowered tariffs on U.S. goods to 10 percent from 125 percent.

On Thursday, the Trump administration announced new export controls, including limits on the sale of chip design software.

title: What else can Trump do on global tariffs after US court ruling?
content: A U.S. trade court blocked most of President Donald Trump's tariffs in a sweeping ruling on Wednesday that found the president had overstepped his authority by imposing across-the-board duties on ...
resumen:
El Tribunal de Comercio Internacional de EE. UU. bloque√≥ la mayor√≠a de los aranceles del presidente Donald Trump en una decisi√≥n general el mi√©rcoles, que determin√≥ que el presidente se hab√≠a extralimitado al imponer aranceles generales a las importaciones de los socios comerciales de EE. UU.

El tribunal invalid√≥ con efecto inmediato todas las √≥rdenes de Trump sobre aranceles desde enero que se basaban en la Ley de Poderes Econ√≥micos de Emergencia Internacional (IEEPA), una ley destinada a abordar amenazas "inusuales y extraordinarias" durante una emergencia nacional.

La constituci√≥n otorga al Congreso la autoridad exclusiva para regular el comercio con otros pa√≠ses.

Otras leyes:

SECCI√ìN 122: La administraci√≥n podr√≠a reemplazar los aranceles generales del 10% con aranceles similares de hasta el 15% seg√∫n la Secci√≥n 122 de la Ley de Comercio. Durar√≠an hasta seis meses, despu√©s de lo cual Trump requerir√≠a la aprobaci√≥n del Congreso para extenderlos. La ley autoriza al presidente a abordar un d√©ficit de la balanza de pagos o a evitar una depreciaci√≥n inminente y significativa del d√≥lar, pero no requiere ninguna investigaci√≥n o proceso formal, por lo que la administraci√≥n podr√≠a implementarla en cuesti√≥n de d√≠as si se considera necesario.

SECCI√ìN 301: El Representante Comercial de EE. UU. (USTR) podr√≠a iniciar investigaciones en virtud de la Secci√≥n 301 sobre pr√°cticas comerciales desleales de la Ley de Comercio de 1974, sobre socios comerciales clave, sentando las bases para los aranceles en una fecha posterior. Requerir√≠a una investigaci√≥n y comentarios p√∫blicos, lo que puede llevar meses. No hay l√≠mite en el nivel o la duraci√≥n de los aranceles. En su primer mandato, Trump invoc√≥ el mismo estatuto de pr√°cticas comerciales desleales para imponer aranceles de hasta el 25% a unos 370.000 millones de d√≥lares en importaciones chinas en 2018 y 2019, lo que desencaden√≥ una guerra comercial de casi tres a√±os con Beijing.

SECCI√ìN 232: Trump ya ha utilizado la Secci√≥n 232 por motivos de seguridad nacional para los aranceles de autom√≥viles, acero y aluminio y ha iniciado investigaciones sobre las importaciones de productos farmac√©uticos y semiconductores como parte de una oferta para imponer aranceles a ambos sectores. Una opci√≥n ser√≠a ampliar su uso a otros sectores, dijeron analistas de Deutsche Bank y Goldman. Al igual que la Secci√≥n 301, requiere tiempo para comentarios p√∫blicos y puede llevar meses. Los analistas de Goldman se√±alaron que Trump no ha enfatizado los aranceles sectoriales con tanta frecuencia como lo hizo a principios de este a√±o, pero si la Casa Blanca tiene menos flexibilidad en los aranceles aplicados a los pa√≠ses, los aranceles sectoriales podr√≠an recibir m√°s atenci√≥n nuevamente.

SECCI√ìN 338 DE LA LEY DE COMERCIO DE 1930: Trump tambi√©n podr√≠a desempolvar una ley comercial de 1930 en gran medida olvidada durante d√©cadas, que le permite imponer aranceles de hasta el 50% a las importaciones de pa√≠ses que se considera que discriminan contra el comercio de EE. UU. La autoridad, que ha sido amenazada pero nunca utilizada para imponer aranceles, es similar a la de la Secci√≥n 301, excepto que limita el tama√±o de los aranceles. Pero no requiere una investigaci√≥n formal, dijeron analistas de Goldman.

Canadian companies are beginning to seek opportunities elsewhere, notably a renewed interest in the trade deal between Canada and the European Union, known as the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement, which was signed in 2016.
A similar pact that governs trade between Canada and Britain came into force in 2021.
Trade numbers for March showed a drop in Canadian trade with the U.S., while Canadian exports to other countries, including the Netherlands, Germany, and Britain, climbed sharply, offsetting most of the decline from exports into the U.S.
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said to the Canadian contingent at the opening of the Hannover trade fair, ‚ÄúCanada is not someone else‚Äôs federal state. Canada is a proud, independent nation.‚Äù
Companies such as Canadian Pacific Kansas City Ltd. (TSX: CP), which is the only railway with a transportation network that flows from Canada to Mexico.
The Trump Administration is staring at a short timeline with U.S. 2026 mid-term elections around the corner.
At the May 7 meeting of the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), the data-dependent Fed decided to remain on the sidelines by keeping its overnight lending rate unchanged.
The Fed finds itself between a rock and a hard place.
The Fed will not cut rates based on soft economic data. It will need to see tangible hard data that definitively indicate slowing economic growth.
Historically, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell has epitomized patience.
According to The Wall Street Journal, ‚Äútariffs could force them into the latter course. Taxes on imports could push up prices in the short run while the uncertainty generated by their abrupt implementation could slow economic activity, delivering a whiff of stagflation. The risks of higher prices could make the Fed reluctant to preempt economic weakness by cutting rates. Instead, officials could focus initially on making sure a one-time rise in prices doesn‚Äôt fuel more-persistent increases.‚Äù

title: Trump tariffs to remain in effect after appeals court grants stay
content: A federal appeals court temporarily reinstated the most sweeping of President Donald Trump's tariffs on Thursday, a day after a US trade court ruled that Trump had exceeded his authority in imposing ...
resumen: A federal appeals court temporarily reinstated President Donald Trump's tariffs on Thursday. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington said it was pausing the lower court's ruling to consider the government's appeal, and ordered the plaintiffs in the cases to respond by June 5 and the administration by June 9. The trade court's three-judge panel ruled that the Constitution gave Congress, not the president, the power to levy taxes and tariffs, and that the president had exceeded his authority by invoking the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Trump has used the threat of charging US importers costly tariffs for goods from almost every other country in the world as leverage in international trade talks. The trade court ruling had not interfered with any negotiations with top trading partners that are scheduled in the days ahead, Trump's administration said. Trump himself wrote in a statement shared on social media that he hoped the US Supreme Court would "reverse this horrible, Country threatening decision" of the trade court. Many US trading partners offered careful responses. The British government said the trade court's ruling was a domestic matter for the US administration. Both Germany and the European Commission, the European Union's executive arm, said they could not comment on the decision. Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney said the trade court's finding was "consistent with Canada's longstanding position" that Trump's tariffs were unlawful. Analysts said broad uncertainty remained regarding the future of Trump's tariffs, which have cost companies more than US$34 billion in lost sales and higher costs, according to a Reuters analysis. Some sector-specific tariffs, such as on imports of steel, aluminum and automobiles, were imposed by Trump under separate authorities on national security grounds and were unaffected by the ruling. The Liberty Justice Center, the nonprofit group representing five small businesses that sued over the tariffs, said the appeals court's temporary stay was a procedural step. Jeffrey Schwab, senior counsel for the center, said the appeals court would ultimately agree with the small businesses that faced irreparable harm of "the loss of critical suppliers and customers, forced and costly changes to established supply chains, and, most seriously, a direct threat to the very survival of these businesses." A separate federal court earlier on Thursday also found that Trump overstepped his authority in using the International Emergency Economic Powers Act for what he called reciprocal tariffs of at least 10 percent on goods from most US trading partners and for the separate 25 percent levies on goods from Canada, Mexico and China related to fentanyl. Following a market revolt after his major tariff announcement on April 2, Trump paused most import duties for 90 days. The trade court ruling would have lowered the overall effective US tariff rate to about 6 percent, but the appellate court's emergency stay means it will remain at about 15 percent, according to estimates from Oxford Research. The effective tariff rate had been between 2 percent and 3 percent before Trump returned to office in January. Drinks company Diageo and automakers General Motors and Ford are among those that have abandoned forecasts for the year ahead. Non-US companies including Honda, Campari, Roche and Novartis have said they are considering moving operations or expanding their US presence to mitigate the impact of tariffs.

title: Tariff Tug-of-War: Trump's Trade Battle Faces Court Challenges
content: A federal appeals court has momentarily reinstated President Trump's sweeping tariffs following a trade court's decision against them. The legal tussle impacts U.S.-Canada-Mexico-China tariffs and ...
resumen: A federal appeals court has temporarily reinstated President Donald Trump's extensive tariffs, just a day after a trade court ruled that Trump had overstepped his authority. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit is reviewing the government's appeal, with responses due early next month. The original ruling threatened the imposition of what Trump calls Liberation Day tariffs, affecting imports from various nations, with added levies on Canada, Mexico, and China over allegations related to fentanyl trafficking. The trade court emphasized Congress's constitutional power to levy taxes, challenging Trump's application of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Analysts and global trading partners are watching closely as the appeal process unfolds. Financial markets remain volatile, with the prospect of lengthy legal proceedings adding to the uncertainty. Meanwhile, trade negotiations continue, with significant talks with Japan and India imminent.

title: Tariff Rulings Inject New Uncertainty Into Trump Trade Strategy
content: A court ruling invalidating President Trump‚Äôs sweeping tariffs was halted hours later, throwing into question the administration‚Äôs overall approach to trade.
resumen:
A series of court rulings over President Trump‚Äôs signature tariffs left Washington, Wall Street and much of the world trying to discern the future of U.S. trade policy on Thursday.

The U.S. Court of International Trade blocked steep tariffs that Mr. Trump had imposed on trading partners using emergency powers. A separate court temporarily paused that decision.

The extent to which the legal wrangling may ultimately lower tariffs hinges on the next steps from the Trump administration and a series of judges who will further parse the president‚Äôs exact powers.

At the heart of the fight is the president‚Äôs use of a decades-old economic emergency law to impose some of his most eye-watering duties, including the minimum 10 percent levy he has placed on nearly every U.S. trading partner.

A panel of judges on the nation‚Äôs leading trade court found Mr. Trump had misapplied the law, ruling that Congress did not grant him ‚Äúunbounded authority‚Äù to wage a global trade war.

The decision would have forced the Trump administration to unwind many of the president‚Äôs steep tariffs over the next 10 days, but the government quickly petitioned a federal appeals court to intervene.

The appeals court ultimately issued a temporary, administrative pause Thursday afternoon that allowed the government to keep its tariffs in place.

The legal setbacks still did not deter the White House, where top aides signaled the president would not abandon his campaign to use tariffs as a political cudgel.

The administration hinted about other powers at its disposal on trade, a reference to the nearly half a dozen other laws it could use to impose levies.

One of those laws could allow the United States to impose a 15 percent tariff on countries with which it has a trade deficit.

Kevin Hassett, the director of the National Economic Council, appeared to allude to some of these legal pathways early Thursday. He told Fox Business that the president had ‚Äúmeasures‚Äù at his disposal. He acknowledged those approaches would ‚Äútake a couple of months,‚Äù later adding the White House is ‚Äúnot planning to pursue those right now.‚Äù

The early battery of court rulings cast legal doubt over the centerpiece of Mr. Trump‚Äôs trade strategy, which hinges on a novel use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. That 1977 law grants the president a set of special powers to confront urgent threats, though it doesn‚Äôt explicitly mention tariffs.

Mr. Trump this year became the first president to use that statute to impose a wide range of duties on global imports, including 25 percent tariffs on many goods from Canada and Mexico, and a 30 percent tariff on imports from China.

Mr. Trump framed those tariffs as a response to a series of emergencies, including the flow of fentanyl into the United States, which allowed him to invoke the law, known as I.E.E.P.A. He cited the law again when he announced his ‚Äúreciprocal tariffs‚Äù on a wider set of countries, including U.S. allies, citing an urgent need to close the nation‚Äôs trade deficit with the rest of the world.

Mr. Trump paused those levies almost as soon as he announced them in April after financial markets recoiled.

The White House press secretary said President Trump had not lost the upper hand in global trade wrangling, saying Thursday that countries ‚Äúhave faith in the negotiator in chief.‚Äù

Many trade experts said the conflicting court rulings could undercut Mr. Trump‚Äôs vision by neutering his key source of leverage.

Mr. Trump said on Wednesday, referring to his recent threat to impose a 50 percent tariff on the European Union.

Trump officials have said they were negotiating trade terms with 18 other countries.

Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, dismissed concerns Thursday that the president had lost the upper hand, arguing that other nations ‚Äúhave faith in the negotiator in chief‚Äù and would keep negotiating because they ‚Äúprobably see how ridiculous this ruling is.‚Äù

The administration has managed to reach only one ‚Äúframework‚Äù for a trade deal, with Britain. As part of that deal, Britain agreed to open its markets to U.S. beef and ethanol, and the Trump administration said it would pare back tariffs on British cars and steel. But it left in place a 10 percent tariff on British products.

The administration has been in discussions for limited trade deals with other nations, including Vietnam and India. Negotiators from the European Union were also in Washington this week.

Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative, said in a filing to the Court of International Trade last week that a move to prevent the president from imposing tariffs would inflict ‚Äúserious damage‚Äù on the country‚Äôs ability to address national and economic security.

Mr. Trump still has ‚Äúother legal authorities he could potentially use‚Äù to enact his trade agenda, said Timothy C. Brightbill, the co-chair of the international trade practice group at the law firm Wiley Rein.

Mr. Trump invoked one set of powers, known as Section 232, to establish his tariffs on steel, aluminum and cars earlier this year. Since then, he has sought to use these authorities again to tax imports of pharmaceuticals, semiconductors and other critical products.

On Wednesday, the trade court pointed specifically to another law that it said gave the president authority to impose global tariffs to address trade deficits. Called Section 122, the law permits the president to impose a tariff up to 15 percent on imports for 150 days, a period that can be extended by Congress.

Ilya Somin, a professor at George Mason University School of Law who helped represent businesses in one of the tariff lawsuits, said the court struck down Mr. Trump‚Äôs claims of ‚Äúunlimited power‚Äù ‚Äî but left it ‚Äúambiguous‚Äù as to whether ‚Äúsome tariffs could potentially be done‚Äù under the statute known as I.E.E.P.A.

Dan Rayfield, the attorney general of Oregon, which led states in one of the lawsuits filed in the Court of International Trade, said, ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt like the limits in place. That is why he became the first president ever to try and push these tariffs under the emergency powers. He was trying to skirt what Congress had intended.‚Äù

title: Trump‚Äôs tariffs to remain in effect after appeals court grants stay
content: A federal appeals court temporarily reinstated the most sweeping of President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs on Thursday, a day after a trade court had ruled ...
resumen: A federal appeals court temporarily reinstated President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs on Thursday. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington said it was pausing the lower court‚Äôs ruling to consider the government‚Äôs appeal, and ordered the plaintiffs in the cases to respond by June 5 and the administration by June 9. Wednesday‚Äôs surprise ruling by the U.S. Court of International Trade had threatened to kill or at least delay the imposition of Trump‚Äôs so-called Liberation Day tariffs on imports from most U.S. trading partners and additional tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico and China. The trade court‚Äôs three-judge panel ruled that the Constitution gave Congress, not the president, the power to levy taxes and tariffs, and that the president had exceeded his authority by invoking the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Senior Trump administration officials said they were undeterred by the trade court‚Äôs ruling. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in a Fox News interview that U.S. trading partners ‚Äúare coming to us in good faith and trying to complete the deals before the 90-day pause ends.‚Äù Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney welcomed the trade court‚Äôs finding, saying it was ‚Äúconsistent with Canada‚Äôs longstanding position‚Äù that Trump‚Äôs tariffs were unlawful. Financial markets had reacted with cautious optimism to the trade court ruling, though gains in stocks on Thursday were largely limited by expectations that the court‚Äôs ruling faced a potentially lengthy appeals process. Analysts said broad uncertainty remained regarding the future of Trump‚Äôs tariffs, which have cost companies more than $34 billion in lost sales and higher costs, according to a Reuters analysis. Jeffrey Schwab, senior counsel for the Liberty Justice Center, said the appeals court would ultimately agree with the small businesses that faced irreparable harm. A separate federal court earlier on Thursday had also found Trump overstepped his authority in using the International Emergency Economic Powers Act for what he called reciprocal tariffs of at least 10% on goods from most U.S. trading partners and for the separate 25% levies on goods from Canada, Mexico and China related to fentanyl. Following a market revolt after his major tariff announcement on April 2, Trump paused most import duties for 90 days. George Lagarias, chief economist at Forvis Mazars international advisers, said, ‚ÄúAssuming that an appeal does not succeed in the next few days, the main win is time to prepare, and also a cap on the breadth of tariffs - which can‚Äôt exceed 15% for the time being.‚Äù The trade court ruling would have lowered the overall effective U.S. tariff rate to about 6%, but the appellate court‚Äôs emergency stay means it will remain at about 15%, according to estimates from Oxford Research. The effective tariff rate had been between 2% and 3% before Trump returned to office in January. Drinks company Diageo and automakers General Motors and Ford are among those that have abandoned forecasts for the year ahead.

title: How Trump‚Äôs trade war is already effecting California‚Äôs ports
content: Chinese goods account for 40% of the imports at the Port of Los Angeles, 63% at the Port of Long Beach and 45% at the Port of Oakland.
resumen: California‚Äôs port traffic is beginning to look worse now, under the effects of President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariff policy, than it did at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. Mario Cordero, chief executive of the Port of Long Beach, said in an interview with CalMatters in early May, ‚ÄúThe vessel calls, or cancellations, that we‚Äôre seeing today (are) starting to exceed the number that we saw in COVID-19.‚Äù At Port of Los Angeles, Executive Director Gene Seroka said during a media briefing last week that the port expected 80 ships to arrive in May, but 17 have been canceled. Last year through May there were a total of 12 cancellations. There are 10 cancellations for June already. The Port of Oakland saw a 15% month-over-month drop in container activity in April. Martha Miller, executive director of the California Association of Port Authorities, said at a business roundtable last week that the unpredictability of Trump‚Äôs edicts means there won‚Äôt be a surge of cargo; many businesses are waiting to act, including to order goods for import. Data for the state‚Äôs three biggest ports confirm that jobs are dwindling for longshore workers up and down the state. Gary Herrera is president of the International Longshore Workers Union Local 13, which represents port workers in both Long Beach and Los Angeles. Part-time workers are not getting any hours right now. Full-time workers may not be getting 40 hours a week, either. Herrera was also speaking on behalf of a couple of other locals; altogether they represent about 9,000 full-time and 6,000 part-time port workers. Luisa Gratz is the president of International Longshore Workers Union Local 26, which represents most of the security on the docks in Los Angeles and Long Beach. Eric Tate is secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 848, which represents about 8,000 truck drivers in Southern California. He said truckers, especially part-timers who aren‚Äôt guaranteed any hours, are seeing less work, though he did say truckers saw a bit of a pickup in work after Trump temporarily reduced tariffs on China. The Port of Oakland is seeing a possible pickup in activity in June ‚Äî as of last week, the planned canceled ships for that month have been reduced from 12 to five. The Trump administration reached with China on May 12, which lowers the tax on imports from China from 145% to 30% for 90 days. Stephanie Magnien Rockwell, chief of staff at the Port of Los Angeles, said in mid-May that California farmers are taking a hit. Chinese goods account for 40% of the imports at the Port of Los Angeles, 63% at the Port of Long Beach and 45% at the Port of Oakland. Seroka said to CalMatters, ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt generalize here, because of those 125,000 importing companies (whose) goods come through the Port of Los Angeles, but safe to say, if there was a little bit of a shortage on stock, or if some felt that the 30% average tariff might go higher, sure, people jump back in.‚Äù On May 23, Trump complained about not being able to reach a deal with Europe on tariffs and threatened a 50% tariff on European goods ‚Äî which he said over the weekend would be delayed to July 9. He also threatened a 25% tariff on iPhones unless Apple begins to make the devices in the United States. Port of Long Beach CEO Cordero said a 10% decline in cargo could mean a 10% decline in jobs. He told CalMatters, ‚ÄúIf you use a round figure of a million jobs stemming from the port operations, that‚Äôs a 100,000 job reduction.‚Äù The port supports jobs worth tens of billions of dollars in income in the five surrounding counties. In 2023, port activity contributed $84.4 billion in local, state and federal taxes. Kimberly Ritter-Martinez, the port‚Äôs manager of economics and funding, said during the Long Beach media briefing.

title: U.S. Court of International Trade Strikes Down Trump Tariffs as Beyond Presidential Authority, Illinois Leads Legal Victory
content: The U.S. Court of International Trade ruled Trump's sweeping tariffs exceeded presidential powers, a stance backed by a coalition of attorneys general.
resumen: La Corte de Comercio Internacional de EE. UU. declar√≥ que la imposici√≥n de aranceles generalizados excede los poderes presidenciales. El Fiscal General de Illinois, Kwame Raoul, lider√≥ una coalici√≥n de 13 fiscales generales en un desaf√≠o legal contra los aranceles. La corte determin√≥ que se trataba de una extensi√≥n excesiva de la autoridad presidencial en virtud de la Ley de Poderes Econ√≥micos de Emergencia Internacional (IEEPA). Raoul dijo: "Una vez m√°s, un tribunal ha evaluado el intento de la administraci√≥n Trump de gobernar por decreto. Y una vez m√°s, un tribunal ha dictaminado que el presidente excedi√≥ su autoridad en virtud de la ley". La acci√≥n legal, presentada por fiscales generales de estados como Arizona, Colorado y Nueva York, argument√≥ que la imposici√≥n de impuestos y aranceles es una prerrogativa del Congreso, postura que el tribunal mantuvo. Seg√∫n la IEEPA, la autoridad presidencial para imponer tales aranceles se limita a emergencias que presenten una "amenaza inusual y extraordinaria" del extranjero, criterio que el tribunal consider√≥ no cumplido por las acciones de la administraci√≥n Trump. Raoul reiter√≥ su compromiso con la defensa del gobierno constitucional, afirmando: "No somos una naci√≥n gobernada por decreto real. El estado de derecho s√≠ importa, y no dejar√© de defenderlo".

title: China sets up sets up international mediation body in Hong Kong
content: The mediation body aims to cement Hong Kong's presence as a top centre to resolve disputes between countries. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: China signed a convention setting up an international organisation for mediation in Hong Kong on May 30. Beijing hopes it will be on par with the International Court of Justice and bolster the financial hub's international credentials. The mediation body aims to cement Hong Kong's presence as a top centre to resolve disputes between countries. Its status would be on par with the International Court of Justice and the Permanent Court of Arbitration of the United Nations in The Hague. It would help bring ‚Äúsubstantial‚Äù economic benefits and job opportunities and stimulate various sectors including hospitality and transport. Indonesia, Pakistan, Laos, Cambodia and Serbia are among the countries attending the ceremony. Representatives from 20 international bodies including the United Nations were also expected to join. The scope of cases that would be handled include disputes between countries, between a country and nationals of another country and between private international entities. The new body would help Hong Kong cope with challenges that arise when ‚Äúhostile external forces are attempting to de-internationalise and de-functionalise‚Äù the city. The new organisation‚Äôs headquarters will be located at a former police station in the bustling Wan Chai district, and is due to open by the end of this year or early 2026.
