title: US trade court blocks tariffs in major setback for Trump
content: A US federal court on Wednesday blocked most of Donald Trump's sweeping import tariffs from going into effect, ruling that the president had overstepped his authority with the across-the-board global ...
resumen: A US federal court on Wednesday blocked most of Donald Trump's import tariffs from going into effect. The court ruled that the president had overstepped his authority with the across-the-board global levies. The opinion marks a significant setback to the Republican leader. The three-judge Court of International Trade barred most of the restrictions that the president has announced since taking office. The White House slammed the ruling. Trump's spokesman Kush Desai said the administration is committed to using every lever of executive power to address this crisis and restore American greatness. Trump unveiled sweeping tariffs on most trading partners on April 2, with a baseline 10 percent, plus steeper duties on dozens of economies, including China and the European Union. The ruling also quashes duties that Trump imposed on Canada, Mexico and China separately using emergency powers. The federal trade court was ruling in two separate cases -- brought by businesses and a coalition of state governments -- arguing that the president's actions violated the power of purse given to Congress under the constitution. The three-judge panel wrote that the court does not read IEEPA to confer such unbounded authority and sets aside the challenged tariffs imposed thereunder. The court said that any interpretation of the IEEPA that "delegates unlimited tariff authority is unconstitutional". The IEEPA authorizes the president to impose necessary economic sanctions during an emergency "to combat an unusual and extraordinary threat". Trump cited the IEEPA when he said trade deficits and the threat posed by the ingress of drugs into the United States justified widespread tariffs. The decision revoking that move gave the White House 10 days to complete the bureaucratic process of halting the tariffs, although the administration is almost certain to appeal. The Justice Department has defended Trump's trade strategy in court. Trump has claimed that Americans will reap the benefits of his "America First" trade posture, pointing to early successes in deals struck with Britain and with China. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the lower 10 percent tariff rate was "contingent on countries or trading blocs coming and negotiating in good faith". Trump threatened to hit EU goods with a 50 percent tariff from June 1. Brussels recently threatened to hit US goods worth nearly 100 billion euros (US$113 billion) with tariffs. Gregory W. Meeks, the top Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said the ruling confirmed that "these tariffs are an illegal abuse of executive power."

title: Binish Ahmed
content: EconoTimes is a global, independent publication that delivers comprehensive news, analysis, and insights on the economy, finance, and markets. Based in Korea, we offer a unique perspective on global ...
resumen:
*   **Binish Ahmed:** PhD candidate at Ryerson University. Received an MA in Public Policy from Brock University, and a BA Hon. with a major in Political Science, and double minors in History and South Asian Studies from University of Toronto (St George). Her writings have appeared in Rabble, Feral Feminisms Journal, and has an upcoming peer reviewed piece in The Himalaya Journal's special issue on Kashmir. She works as a researcher, writer, educator, community connector, and artist. She is the founder and director of Kashmir Gulposh, a praxis hub and an intellectual / arts lab. Her scholarship has intersected with topics including Indigenous self-government, self-determination, settler colonialism, decolonization, reconciliation, transnational and post-colonial feminism, secularism, racialization, anti-Muslim racism/Islamophobia, nationalism, multiculturalism, immigration, migration, immigrant and refugee settlement and retention. Her scholarship examines governance and policy issues critically at the municipal, provincial, trans-/national, as well international level, and places policy issues and questions within a critical multi-level governance framework. She has taught at the Politics Department at Brock University and at Ryerson University‚Äôs Politics and Public Administration, Urban and Regional Planning, and Sociology. title: Thank Switzerland for the China-US Tariff Truce ‚Äì Then Copy Its Playbook
content: Most analysis missed the role of Switzerland as host in the China-U.S. trade talks, but its quiet mediation should serve as a role model for other states.
resumen:
En mayo de 2025, delegaciones de Estados Unidos y China, lideradas por el Secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, el Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, y el Viceprimer Ministro chino, He Lifeng, se reunieron para conversaciones comerciales en Ginebra, Suiza.

Estados Unidos impuso un arancel del 145 por ciento a casi todas las importaciones chinas, y Beijing respondi√≥ con aranceles del 125 por ciento.

Yale‚Äôs Budget Lab estim√≥ que el aumento de aranceles de abril de 2025 reducir√≠a las importaciones globales en aproximadamente $540 mil millones en 2025.

La diplomacia suiza transform√≥ una villa de Ginebra en la sala de negociaci√≥n m√°s valiosa del mundo, lo que podr√≠a haber evitado una recesi√≥n impulsada por aranceles en la econom√≠a global.

La Canciller√≠a suiza contact√≥ tanto a China como a Estados Unidos para convencerlos de reunirse en Ginebra.

La presidenta Karin Keller-Sutter vol√≥ a Washington para impulsar a Bessent hacia el di√°logo. El ministro de Relaciones Exteriores Ignazio Cassis realiz√≥ una visita de dos d√≠as a Beijing.

Suiza ofreci√≥ un territorio genuinamente neutral: la Villa Saladin del siglo XVIII, normalmente reservada para su embajador ante las Naciones Unidas.

El 9 de mayo, Keller-Sutter y el ministro de Econom√≠a Guy Parmelin se reunieron por separado con las delegaciones, primero con He Lifeng de China, luego con Bessent y el Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos Jamieson Greer, para establecer la agenda y la log√≠stica de las conversaciones.

Los funcionarios suizos no se sentaron a la mesa ni redactaron textos, simplemente crearon el espacio pol√≠tico en el que las superpotencias pod√≠an negociar sin perder la cara.

Despu√©s del primer d√≠a de conversaciones entre China y Estados Unidos, ambas partes hablaron de "progresos sustanciales". Al final del segundo d√≠a, los negociadores lograron un acuerdo innovador: Estados Unidos reducir√° sus aranceles sobre los productos chinos del 145 por ciento al 30 por ciento, mientras que China reducir√° sus aranceles sobre los productos estadounidenses del 125 por ciento al 10 por ciento.

Greer dijo a los periodistas que "las discusiones m√°s importantes sobre los temas m√°s dif√≠ciles tuvieron lugar al aire libre, con vistas al lago Ginebra".

El 21 de mayo, en el Consejo General de la Organizaci√≥n Mundial del Comercio (OMC) en la ciudad, Suiza y Singapur copatrocinaron una declaraci√≥n de 47 naciones instando a que la pausa bilateral se "reintegrara" en las reglas de la OMC.

Suiza ayud√≥ a estabilizar los flujos comerciales globales que apoyan tanto los empleos estadounidenses como los chinos, las ganancias corporativas y la resiliencia de la cadena de suministro.

title: Annex this: Canada chases energy superpowerdom
content: To be competitive, Canada‚Äôs oil has to be ‚Äúproduced responsibly,‚Äù the country‚Äôs new energy minister, Tim Hodgson, said during a speech last week. He has proposed building carbon capture systems for ...
resumen:
Canada hopes to shake off its dependence on the United States by becoming an energy ‚Äúsuperpower.‚Äù The new government‚Äôs pursuit of dominance through both fossil fuels and clean power could ultimately undermine its climate goals.

Newly elected Prime Minister Mark Carney built his campaign around opposition to U.S. President Donald Trump. He also entered office with climate cred: the former central banker once served as the United Nations‚Äô special envoy on climate action and finance and has long promoted a clean energy transition.

His Liberal government is now pledging to battle a brewing trade war with the U.S. by boosting exports of oil and natural gas, burning more fossil fuels domestically, and easing barriers to east-west flows of fuel and electricity.

King Charles III opened the Canadian Parliament with a speech that left climate activists disillusioned. Charles‚Äô address, which was written by members of Carney‚Äôs government, emphasized both clean and ‚Äúconventional‚Äù energy and heralded a new effort to speed up permitting for major projects.

Caroline Brouillette, executive director of Climate Action Network Canada, said Charles missed an opportunity to clarify Canada‚Äôs energy future.

Canada is the largest source of U.S. energy imports, and the U.S. is by far Canada‚Äôs largest buyer. With Trump‚Äôs threat of increasingly severe tariffs, Canada wants to build out its energy infrastructure to enable it to more easily export to other countries.

Canada‚Äôs new energy minister, Tim Hodgson, said during a speech last week that Canada‚Äôs oil has to be ‚Äúproduced responsibly.‚Äù He has proposed building carbon capture systems for the nation‚Äôs oil sands.

Canada is already lagging in meeting its climate target for 2030. The country set a new goal for 2035, but analysts say the target is too weak to comply with the Paris Agreement.

Charles‚Äô speech still drew a major distinction between the Canadian government and the United States by mentioning the need to combat climate change.

title: Book review: A Danish diplomat‚Äôs view of Taiwan
content: The author‚Äôs call for solidarity with Taiwan is laudable, as is his view that Taiwan‚Äôs liberty and democracy is vital to ‚Äúall of us freedom-minded people‚Äù in the fight against a global creep toward ...
resumen:
Jonas Parello-Plesner spoke at the Czech Hub in Taipei, hosted by the Taiwan office of the European Values Center, a Prague-based think tank.

Parello-Plesner is the head of foreign policy at the Danish Embassy in Washington from 2013 to 2017.

His book is titled The Battle for Taiwan.

The English edition was released in February last year.

Parello-Plesner is the executive director of the Copenhagen-based Alliance of Democracies Foundation.

Trump‚Äôs ambitions for Greenland were discussed at the event, as was his attitude towards Taiwan.

Trump had recently accused of pilfering American chip know-how.

Parello-Plesner warned that Taiwan should be ready for the worst-case scenario.

Parello-Plesner‚Äôs view that Biden‚Äôs commitment to Taiwan‚Äôs defense puts a potential cross-strait conflagration ‚Äúin a different league from the Ukraine war, where the US only supports from the sidelines with military equipment.‚Äù.

Mike Pompeo, who was US secretary of state during Trump‚Äôs first term, advocate officially recognizing Taiwan.

Parello-Plesner calls Trump ‚Äúmore pragmatic.‚Äù

Parello-Plesner writes that revelations from Trump‚Äôs first presidency, ‚Äúshow that he was ready to ‚Äòsell‚Äô Taiwan to China‚Äù for a better trade deal.

Parello-Plesner adds that if Trump returns, it could be fateful for Taiwan.

Parello-Plesner calls a declaration of support for an independent Taiwan without the US having ‚Äúfirst secured its military superiority to China‚Äù as his ‚Äúother extreme.‚Äù

Parello-Plesner advises monitoring US foreign policy development and Republican Party decision-making in particular.

Parello-Plesner observes that China‚Äôs President Xi Jinping (ÁøíËøëÂπ≥) visited Putin in April 2023 ‚Äúeven though Russia‚Äôs leader was simultaneously being indicted for war crimes at the International Criminal Court.‚Äù

Taiwan‚Äôs legislature passed a resolution recognizing China‚Äôs actions as crimes against humanity and genocide.

Parello-Plesner‚Äôs remarks on the chip industry as ‚Äúunambiguously security policy‚Äù are on point.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation (TSMC) announced a further US$100 billion investment in its Arizona plant.

Parello-Plesner fears that ‚Äúholes will appear in Taiwan‚Äôs chip shield‚Äù and ‚Äúthis shift in production could make a future administration much less willing to defend Taiwan militarily.‚Äù

Parello-Plesner worries about the end of Moore‚Äôs Law.

Parello-Plesner claims in chapter two that ‚ÄúSpain and the Netherlands ‚Ä¶ held colonial settlements on southern and northern Taiwan respectively throughout the seventeenth century‚Äù.

Parello-Plesner calls the Chinese Nationalist Party (KMT) and Republic of China (ROC) flags ‚Äúquite identical with white stars‚Äù.

Parello-Plesner refers to Hualien as ‚Äúa small town‚Äù and Taipei‚Äôs Liberty Square as ‚ÄúFreedom Square.‚Äù

Parello-Plesner mentions a meeting at the former residence of KMT general Sun Li-jen (Â≠´Á´ã‰∫∫) in Taipei, which, he writes, was where the war hero was held ‚Äúunder house arrest‚Äù for decades.

Parello-Plesner says that ‚Äúthe one-China policy‚Äù is ‚Äúreferred to as the One-China principle‚Äù by Beijing and that ‚Äúthe Taiwanese took the initiative‚Äù when Taiwan was ceded to Japan in 1895 to establish the Republic of Formosa.

Parello-Plesner says that a lack of civil society resilience was ‚Äúa lesson [for Taiwan and the US] of Afghanistan‚Äôs collapse in 2021‚Äù.

Parello-Plesner attributes to a former admiral writing for a KMT think-tank that former president Tsai Ing-wen (Ëî°Ëã±Êñá) endangered the general population by placing ‚Äúlandmines everywhere ‚Äî even in the cities‚Äù around Taiwan.

The book is written by Jonas Parello-Plesner.

The book has 170 pages.

The book is self-published in Denmark.

title: Tariffs Prompt Mexican Companies to Export Via USMCA, Central Bank Says
content: The Trump administration imposed a 25% tariff on Mexican goods on grounds the government wasn't doing enough to contain drug smuggling and illegal migration into the U.S., although exports that comply ...
resumen:
The exemption from U.S. import tariffs for goods exported under the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement is prompting Mexican companies to make greater use of the pact, and encouraging others to start using it, the Bank of Mexico said Wednesday.

The central bank in April conducted a survey of manufacturing companies with more than 100 workers.

Before President Trump took office, 57.8% used the USMCA for all of their exports, 25.1% used it for some exports, and 17% didn't use it.

Most of those that exported some of their goods under USMCA said they had started or planned to start using it for other goods.

Of those that hadn't been using the pact, 40% expressed the desire or the intention of doing so, and 60% said they had already begun or would begin soon.

The Trump administration imposed a 25% tariff on Mexican goods on grounds the government wasn't doing enough to contain drug smuggling and illegal migration into the U.S., although exports that comply with the USMCA are exempt.

Mexico pays a global U.S. tariff on steel, aluminum and automobiles.

In 2024, nearly all trucks, around 80% of cars and light trucks, and half of the auto parts that Mexico exported to the U.S. were under the USMCA, as were all fruits and vegetables, dairy products and eggs, the Bank of Mexico said.

Mobile phones, computers, and medical instruments, on the other hand, didn't use the pact to export to the U.S. as they had a zero tariff under the most favored nation mechanism.

The implementation of the tariffs, and the fact that goods exported under the USMCA are up until now exempt, means the cost of not using the USMCA has increased, the central bank said.

title: Guerra comercial
content: La tregua de 90 d√≠as declarada por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, para negociar en ese lapso nuevos pactos arancelarios alcanz√≥ este s√°bado su ecuador con escasos avances m√°s all√° de un a ...
resumen: La tregua de 90 d√≠as declarada por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, para negociar nuevos pactos arancelarios alcanz√≥ su ecuador con escasos avances m√°s all√° de un acuerdo de m√≠nimos con Reino Unido y una necesaria tregua paralela con China, a lo que hay que sumar nuevas amenazas del neoyorquino contra la Uni√≥n Europea (UE). El viernes, despu√©s de que unos d√≠as antes Washington y Bruselas hubieran acordado intensificar las negociaciones t√©cnicas para llegar a un acuerdo, Trump volvi√≥ a endurecer su envite diciendo que las conversaciones ‚Äúno est√°n yendo a ning√∫n lado‚Äù y que por ello activar√° grav√°menes del 50 % sobre todos los bienes de la UE a partir del 1 de junio del a√±o en curso. El neoyorquino se mostr√≥ convencido de que est√° nueva amenaza har√° que Europa quiera lograr un acuerdo con todas sus fuerzas, pero no est√° claro el efecto que pueda tener el bufido de Trump, ya que horas despu√©s la Uni√≥n Europea anunci√≥ que est√° dispuesta a defender sus intereses. Por otro lado, lo acordado en la reuni√≥n de hace dos semanas en Suiza entre representantes estadounidenses y chinos es probablemente la mejor noticia que se ha producido en el tiempo transcurrido desde el pasado 9 de abril, d√≠a en el que Trump, hostigado por las reacciones de los mercados y los rendimientos de la deuda estadounidense, decidi√≥ pausar su bater√≠a de lo que ha dado en llamar ‚Äúaranceles rec√≠procos‚Äù para todos sus socios comerciales. Las dos principales econom√≠as del mundo, enfrascadas desde abril en un agresivo conflicto arancelario, lograron sentarse a la mesa y acordar una tregua paralela de 90 d√≠as que entr√≥ en vigor el 14 de mayo y que logr√≥ apaciguar en cierta medida a las bolsas, pero no acabar con la incertidumbre que se ha apoderado de muchos inversores y empresas desde el retorno de Trump a la Casa Blanca. La tregua con Pek√≠n implica, entre otras cosas, que China reducir√° del 125 % al 10 % los aranceles sobre productos estadounidenses y que EE.UU. rebajar√° los suyos del 145 % al 30 %.

title: Aranceles rec√≠procos de Trump dan ‚Äòempuj√≥n‚Äô a la BMV y alcanzan m√°ximo hist√≥rico
content: Las acciones mexicanas han tenido un fuerte impulso tras el anuncio de los aranceles rec√≠procos de Donald Trump, al punto de alcanzar un m√°ximo hist√≥rico.
resumen:
Las acciones mexicanas alcanzaron un m√°ximo hist√≥rico el martes, impulsadas por un repunte posterior al D√≠a de la Liberaci√≥n y extendiendo una recuperaci√≥n m√°s amplia de la renta variable latinoamericana.

El hecho de que M√©xico haya salido relativamente indemne de los aranceles rec√≠procos del presidente Donald Trump ha sido un factor favorable.

La presidenta mexicana, Claudia Sheinbaum, destac√≥ recientemente el trato preferencial que ha recibido M√©xico en las negociaciones y se mostr√≥ confiada en la relaci√≥n de trabajo con los funcionarios de Estados Unidos.

Los activos de los pa√≠ses en desarrollo se han beneficiado en gran medida de la rotaci√≥n que se ha producido en los mercados estadounidenses en medio de la agitaci√≥n provocada por los aranceles.

La ca√≠da del d√≥lar ‚Äîel √≠ndice del d√≥lar ha bajado alrededor de un 7 por ciento este a√±o y se mantiene cerca de su nivel m√°s bajo desde 2023‚Äî ayuda a los responsables pol√≠ticos a reducir los costos de los pr√©stamos, lo que impulsa a√∫n m√°s las acciones, seg√∫n Greg Lesko, gestor de carteras de Deltec Asset Management, especializado en acciones de mercados emergentes.

El √≠ndice de referencia Mexbol subi√≥ hasta un 2.2 por ciento, hasta alcanzar los 59,735.43 puntos, su nivel intradiario m√°s alto jam√°s registrado.

Las acciones de los pa√≠ses en desarrollo, que han subido m√°s de un 8 por ciento en lo que va de a√±o, superando con creces al S&P 500, que se mantiene estable en lo que va de a√±o.

Este mes, los mercados burs√°tiles de Brasil, Per√∫ y Chile tambi√©n alcanzaron nuevos m√°ximos hist√≥ricos.

Las acciones mexicanas se cotizan a 12.2 veces sus ganancias combinadas a 12 meses, todav√≠a por debajo de su promedio hist√≥rico de 10 a√±os de 13.6 veces, seg√∫n datos recopilados por Bloomberg.

Albert lament√≥ que estas medidas costar√°n entre 900 y 1.500 euros a cada madrile√±o "para gestionar la fiesta independentista y que el se√±or [Pedro] S√°nchez siga estando un d√≠a m√°s en La Moncloa". title: Remesas: ¬øestrategia fallida?
content: Nos dicen que en Palacio Nacional ya no hallan a qui√©n echarle la culpa por la fallida estrategia que se organiz√≥ para defender a las remesas y evitar que sean castigadas con el impuesto del president ...
resumen:
Banxico y sus proyecciones.

Nos dicen que en Palacio Nacional ya no hallan a qui√©n echarle la culpa por la fallida estrategia que se organiz√≥ para defender a las remesas y evitar que sean castigadas con el impuesto del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump.

Usar el argumento de que ese cobro representa una violaci√≥n a los tratados entre M√©xico y EU para evitar una doble tributaci√≥n revel√≥ un desconocimiento sobre el tema.

El Instituto Mexicano de Contadores P√∫blicos, encabezado por H√©ctor Amaya, le corrigi√≥ la plana al gobierno federal, al se√±alar que dicha medida es para gravar s√≥lo las transferencias de los paisanos indocumentados, es decir, el dinero producto de su trabajo, que no representa un ingreso directo para el Estado mexicano.

El desaf√≠o del Hot Sale.

En el arranque del Hot Sale 2025, se mantienen las expectativas de un consumo resistente en el pa√≠s, pese a los pron√≥sticos de un mal desempe√±o de la actividad productiva en los pr√≥ximos meses.

Las promociones bancarias, principalmente de meses sin intereses, pueden ser una opci√≥n para los consumidores que deseen aprovechar la semana de descuentos en compras en l√≠nea.

Todas las instituciones bancarias se han volcado a ofrecer opciones de pago, sin importar el panorama pesimista.

Los grupos financieros, representados por Emilio Romano en la Asociaci√≥n de Bancos de M√©xico (ABM) est√°n conscientes de que, a√∫n con un panorama retador, el consumo puede hacer frente a los aranceles del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump.

Inversi√≥n en almacenes.

En el transporte de carga es competitivo el Aeropuerto Internacional Felipe √Ångeles (AIFA).

La empresa Talma, que dirige Vladimir Mu√±oz, acaba de invertir 9 millones de d√≥lares en un segundo almac√©n de carga en esta terminal, que se suman a los 2.3 millones de d√≥lares que invirti√≥ en 2024 para ampliar su primer almac√©n.

La peruana es de los principales operadores de la regi√≥n.

En M√©xico, Talma est√° en tres aeropuertos, y el a√±o pasado gestion√≥ m√°s de 202 mil toneladas de carga a√©rea.

Con presencia adem√°s en Colombia y Ecuador, ya planea ingresar a Argentina.

title: Wall Street sube con fuerza con el foco en las negociaciones arancelarias
content: Wall Street sube con fuerza este martes, en una sesi√≥n de vuelta al parqu√© tras el festivo del D√≠a de los Ca√≠dos. Los futuros sobre los √≠ndices cotizan al alza animados por la tregua comercial de ...
resumen:
Wall Street sube con fuerza este martes, en una sesi√≥n de vuelta al parqu√© tras el festivo del D√≠a de los Ca√≠dos. Los futuros sobre los √≠ndices cotizan al alza animados por la tregua comercial de Donald Trump a la Uni√≥n Europea (UE), al retrasar hasta al 9 de julio su anuncio de aranceles del 50%.

Ipek Ozkardeskaya, analista s√©nior de Swissquote Bank, valora que la situaci√≥n es peor que hace un mes y que los aranceles no bajar√°n del nivel ‚Äòuniversal‚Äô del 10%.

Kathleen Brooks, directora de investigaci√≥n de XTB, menciona que el mercado espera noticias sobre el progreso en las negociaciones comerciales entre la UE y EEUU y que Donald Trump ha dado marcha atr√°s tantas veces en los aranceles que el mensaje ha perdido fuerza.

Ozkardeskaya considera que los nuevos acuerdos entre EEUU y sus principales socios comerciales podr√≠an impulsar a√∫n m√°s la confianza del mercado y llevar los √≠ndices a ambos lados del Atl√°ntico a nuevos m√°ximos hist√≥ricos, pero a√∫n est√° por verse si este optimismo perdura. Los datos econ√≥micos, especialmente las m√©tricas de inflaci√≥n, ser√°n cruciales.

title: U.S. Oil Giants Fight Over Guyana‚Äôs 11-Billion Barrel Treasure Trove
content: This week, a private arbitration panel in London began hearing the arguments of U.S. supermajors ExxonMobil and Chevron regarding their rights to one of the world‚Äôs most lucrative oil projects.
resumen: U.S. oil giants are fighting over Guyana‚Äôs 11-billion barrel treasure trove. Chevron‚Äôs bid to buy Hess‚Äôs stake in the Guyana projects is being challenged by Exxon and CNOOC. A private arbitration panel in London began hearing the arguments of U.S. supermajors ExxonMobil and Chevron regarding their rights to one of the world‚Äôs most lucrative oil projects. Guyana‚Äôs Stabroek block has an estimated 11 billion barrels of oil in place discovered so far by the consortium of ExxonMobil, U.S. Hess Corp, and CNOOC of China. The high-volume, low-cost development offshore the South American country, which started production just five years ago, is already pumping more than 660,000 barrels per day (bpd) of crude. Exxon is the operator of the block with a 45% stake. Hess holds 30%, and CNOOC has the remaining 25% stake. In 2023, Chevron proposed a $53-billion deal to buy Hess Corp and thus take Hess‚Äôs assets in the Bakken in North Dakota and the 30% stake in Guyana‚Äôs offshore oil field. Production capacity in Guyana is expected to surpass 1.7 million barrels per day, with gross production growing to 1.3 million barrels per day by 2030, Exxon says. Guyana is now the third-largest per-capita oil producer in the world. The Guyana Stabroek block is estimated to have a breakeven oil price of about $30 per barrel. Chevron‚Äôs bid to buy Hess‚Äôs stake in the Guyana projects is being challenged by Exxon and CNOOC, who claim they have a right of first refusal for Hess‚Äôs stake under the terms of a joint operating agreement (JOA) for the Stabroek block. The arbitration initiated by Exxon and CNOOC has delayed the closing of Chevron‚Äôs bid to buy Hess by more than 18 months. The three-judge arbitration panel began hearings on Monday behind closed doors and is expected to rule within 90 days from the end of the hearings. Chevron‚Äôs deal to buy Hess has stalled. ExxonMobil finalized the $60-billion acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources. In 2023, ExxonMobil, Hess, and CNOOC booked a combined $6.33 billion in net profit for their joint oil operations offshore Guyana. Hess‚Äôs share was $1.88 billion of this income. The combined net margin of the Stabroek block co-venturers was 56% in 2023. The Stabroek block co-venturers are expected to gain as much as $182 billion over the next 15 years from Guyana‚Äôs oilfields.

title: Trump dice que UE quiere negociar ‚Äúr√°pidamente‚Äù tras amenaza de arancel del 50%
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, dijo este martes que representantes de la Uni√≥n Europea (UE) han pedido "fijar r√°pidamente las fechas de la reuni√≥n" para llegar a un acuerdo comercial, ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, dijo este martes que representantes de la Uni√≥n Europea (UE) han pedido ‚Äúfijar r√°pidamente las fechas de la reuni√≥n‚Äù para llegar a un acuerdo comercial, tras la amenaza del gobernante de imponer un arancel del 50 % al bloque por no ver avance en las negociaciones.

Trump escribi√≥ en su plataforma Truth Social: ‚ÄúMe acaban de informar que la UE ha llamado para fijar r√°pidamente las fechas de la reuni√≥n. Este es un evento positivo, y espero que, FINALMENTE, al igual que mi exigencia a China, abran las naciones europeas al comercio con los Estados Unidos de Am√©rica‚Äù.

Trump advirti√≥ el pasado viernes que impondr√≠a un arancel del 50 % a la UE a partir del 1 de junio por considerar que las conversaciones bilaterales no estaban ‚Äúyendo a ninguna parte‚Äù.

Tambi√©n afirm√≥ que se librar√≠an del impuesto aquellas empresas que fabriquen sus productos en Estados Unidos.

El domingo el mandatario acord√≥ en una llamada por tel√©fono con la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, extender el plazo para lograr un pacto hasta el 9 de julio.

Trump dijo este martes en su mensaje de Truth Social: ‚ÄúMe sent√≠ sumamente satisfecho con la asignaci√≥n del 50 % del arancel a la Uni√≥n Europea, especialmente porque estaban siendo ‚Äúlentos‚Äù (¬°por decirlo suavemente!) en nuestras negociaciones con ellos. Recuerden, tengo la facultad de ‚ÄúLLEGAR A UN ACUERDO‚Äù para el comercio con EE.UU. si no logramos llegar a un acuerdo o si recibimos un trato injusto‚Äù.

Desde su regreso al poder, Trump ha adoptado medidas arancelarias contra sus socios comerciales, varias de las cuales puso en suspenso temporalmente hasta el pr√≥ximo 9 de julio, en medio de la reacci√≥n negativa de los mercados.

Entre las que est√°n en vigor se incluyen aranceles del 25 % sobre el acero, el aluminio y sus derivados, del 25 % sobre los autom√≥viles y determinadas piezas de coches importados, junto a un arancel de base del 10 % aplicable a todos sus socios comerciales.

En el caso de la UE, ese arancel del 10 % podr√≠a llegar al 20 % una vez que expire en julio la actual pausa estadounidense.

Tras la imposici√≥n de los aranceles, EE.UU. ya alcanz√≥ tratos comerciales con Reino Unido y China para rebajar los grav√°menes y aumentar el acceso a esos mercados.

title: Estas empresas estadounidenses e internacionales -con presencia en Chile- ya subieron sus precios por los aranceles de Trump
content: Los aranceles del mandatario estadounidense ya est√°n afectando a los usuarios, quienes ya est√°n pagando m√°s por sus productos.
resumen:
Los aranceles del mandatario estadounidense ya est√°n afectando a los usuarios, quienes ya est√°n pagando m√°s por sus productos.

El jueves trajo una avalancha de datos que apuntan a un mismo resultado: los precios est√°n subiendo.

Walmart declar√≥ el jueves que los aranceles estadounidenses son demasiado altos, y en respuesta, est√° subiendo los precios. El director ejecutivo de Walmart, Doug McMillon, declar√≥ en una conferencia telef√≥nica sobre resultados: ‚ÄúDada la magnitud de los aranceles, incluso con los niveles reducidos anunciados esta semana, no podemos absorber toda la presi√≥n dada la realidad de los estrechos m√°rgenes minoristas. El aumento de los aranceles se traducir√° en precios m√°s altos‚Äù.

El 6 de mayo, Mattel anunci√≥ que subir√≠a los precios debido a los aranceles. Su director ejecutivo, Ynon Kreiz, declar√≥ a los inversores que, ‚Äúen los escenarios actuales que estamos considerando‚Äù, en respuesta a los aranceles, prev√© que entre el 40 % y el 50 % de sus productos se mantengan a 20 d√≥lares o menos.

Trump amenaz√≥ a Mattel, diciendo que ‚Äúimpondr√≠a un arancel del 100% a sus juguetes y no vender√≠a ni un solo juguete en Estados Unidos, y ese es su mayor mercado‚Äù.

Nintendo retras√≥ la fecha de reserva de su consola Switch 2 debido a la preocupaci√≥n por los aranceles. Posteriormente, la compa√±√≠a declar√≥ que el precio de la consola no cambiar√° de los 450 d√≥lares iniciales, pero que los accesorios ‚Äúsufrir√°n ajustes de precio con respecto a los anunciados el 2 de abril debido a las fluctuaciones del mercado‚Äù.

Lin Tao, director financiero de Sony, fabricante de PlayStation, dijo ‚Äúpodr√≠amos trasladar el precio‚Äù durante una presentaci√≥n de resultados.

Las cadenas minoristas chinas Shein y Temu subieron los precios de algunos productos.

Dos sillas de patio publicadas en Temu y rese√±adas por CNN ten√≠an un precio de $61.72 el 24 de abril. Al d√≠a siguiente, cuando entraron en vigor los cambios de precio, su precio era de $70.17. En Shein, CNN indic√≥ que un conjunto de traje de ba√±o costaba $4.39. Al d√≠a siguiente, costaba $8.39, un aumento del 91%.

La directora financiera de Ford, Sherry House, dijo que la empresa espera aumentar los precios de sus autom√≥viles en Estados Unidos hasta un 1,5% en la segunda mitad de 2025 debido a los aranceles.

El fabricante japon√©s de autom√≥viles Subaru tambi√©n ha anunciado que aumentar√° los precios en Estados Unidos para compensar el aumento de costos, alegando las condiciones actuales del mercado.

Un portavoz de Subaru of America declar√≥: ‚ÄúLos cambios se implementaron para compensar el aumento de costos, manteniendo al mismo tiempo una s√≥lida propuesta de valor para el cliente. Los precios de Subaru no se basan en el pa√≠s de origen de sus productos‚Äù.

resumen: Una delegaci√≥n del Departamento de Agricultura de Estados Unidos (USDA) visitar√° M√©xico en los pr√≥ximos d√≠as para evaluar las medidas adoptadas contra el gusano barrenador del ganado, plaga que provoc√≥ la suspensi√≥n de importaciones ganaderas desde territorio mexicano. La inspecci√≥n ser√° decisiva para determinar si se levanta el bloqueo, vigente desde el 11 de mayo de 2025 por orden del expresidente Donald Trump. La presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum calific√≥ la decisi√≥n estadounidense como ‚Äúinjustificada‚Äù y carente de fundamentos s√≥lidos. Estados Unidos anunci√≥ una inversi√≥n de 21 millones de d√≥lares para modernizar una planta en Chiapas que producir√° moscas est√©riles, herramienta clave para combatir la plaga. El par√°sito en cuesti√≥n, Cochliomyia hominivorax, consume tejido vivo de mam√≠feros. Reapareci√≥ en 2024 y ha avanzado desde Centroam√©rica hasta el sur de M√©xico, acerc√°ndose peligrosamente a la frontera con Texas. Su propagaci√≥n se ha visto favorecida por el comercio ilegal de animales, el calentamiento global y fallas en la producci√≥n de insectos est√©riles. Seg√∫n datos de la Secretar√≠a de Agricultura, los casos han disminuido un 51.8 % desde abril. M√©xico y Estados Unidos han retomado la T√©cnica del Insecto Est√©ril (TIE), pero la limitada producci√≥n, antes concentrada en Panam√°, ha frenado la respuesta. M√©xico solicit√≥ a EE.UU. construir una nueva planta. En 2024, M√©xico export√≥ m√°s de un mill√≥n de reses a su vecino del norte. Autoridades estiman p√©rdidas por hasta 1,900 millones de d√≥lares si la plaga alcanza el sector ganadero de Texas.

content: Martes, 27 de mayo de 2025.- Daniel Lacalle: La oportunidad de oro de Europa, el mercantilismo de Trump y el despertar de Milei En este programa de Money & Markets, Daniel Lacalle, explica que, ...
resumen:
Daniel Lacalle: La oportunidad de oro de Europa, el mercantilismo de Trump y el despertar de Milei.
En este programa de Money. & Markets, Daniel Lacalle, explica que, aunque muchas personas perciben las decisiones arancelarias de Trump como ca√≥ticas o aleatorias, existe una estrategia clara detr√°s: generar presi√≥n para eliminar trabas comerciales a las empresas estadounidenses y, por extensi√≥n, tambi√©n a las europeas.
Compara esta t√°ctica con la disuasi√≥n nuclear: se anuncian medidas fuertes (como los aranceles) no para aplicarlas necesariamente, sino para forzar una negociaci√≥n.
Lacalle afirma que la Uni√≥n Europea tiene una oportunidad √∫nica de alcanzar un acuerdo comercial con Estados Unidos, m√°s sencillo incluso que con Reino Unido o Jap√≥n, si elimina barreras regulatorias, fiscales y arancelarias, tal como propuso Mario Draghi en su informe.
Subraya que los principales obst√°culos son agricultura, ganader√≠a y autom√≥viles, y que es il√≥gico imponer barreras a EE. UU. mientras se eximen a pa√≠ses como China, Marruecos o Turqu√≠a.
Esta nota ha sido le√≠da aproximadamente 1436 veces.

title: Ante nueva era arancelaria, actitud estrat√©gica, no reactiva
content: Estas teclas han levantado su voz para advertir que el mundo ha entrado en una nueva era de protecci√≥n arancelaria, impulsada por pa√≠ses y regiones.
resumen:
El mundo ha entrado en una nueva era de protecci√≥n arancelaria, impulsada por pa√≠ses y regiones.

Los aumentos arancelarios dispuestos por Donald Trump durante su primer mandato, mantenidos por la administraci√≥n Biden, y la embestida de aumentos prevista por una eventual Administraci√≥n Trump 2.0, junto con sus consecuentes retaliaciones, reafirman el giro de la pol√≠tica comercial estadounidense.

La amenaza de Trump de imponer un arancel del 50 % a los productos europeos con destino al mercado estadounidense, cuya entrada en vigencia fue aplazada del 1 de junio al 9 de julio para dar tiempo a negociaciones.

O hay acuerdo entre las partes, o la Administraci√≥n Trump impondr√° unilateralmente sus aranceles, a pesar de las posibles retaliaciones. Y esto se repetir√° con los dem√°s socios comerciales de Estados Unidos.

En el nuevo escenario comercial, la Rep√∫blica Dominicana quedar√≠a en una posici√≥n competitiva favorable, siempre y cuando se despejen algunas dudas, especialmente en relaci√≥n con la posibilidad de que productos mexicanos puedan posicionarse a√∫n mejor, dado que M√©xico ser√≠a el √∫nico pa√≠s de la regi√≥n al cual no se le aplicar√≠a el arancel rec√≠proco del 10 %, aunque s√≠ se le aplicar√≠an otros aranceles altos a productos espec√≠ficos.

Al ser incluido en la lista de pa√≠ses con los menores aranceles, los productos dominicanos tendr√≠an una ventaja competitiva en el mercado estadounidense frente a muchos otros pa√≠ses que enfrentar√°n aranceles mucho m√°s elevados.

La posici√≥n del pa√≠s debe ser estrat√©gica y equilibrada, no reactiva ni sesgada por criterios ideol√≥gicos.

La meta debe ser crear las condiciones para aprovechar esa ventaja competitiva:

*   Expandir las exportaciones hacia el mercado estadounidense, ganando cuota frente a competidores m√°s afectados por los aranceles.
*   Consolidar relaciones comerciales con empresas estadounidenses, mostrando confiabilidad y estabilidad como socios.
*   Diversificar mercados, porque, aunque Estados Unidos sea nuestro principal socio comercial, es prudente no depender exclusivamente de √©l.

Es clave que el pa√≠s se constituya en un destino atractivo para inversiones que emigrar√°n desde los pa√≠ses m√°s castigados por los aranceles hacia aquellos que sean premiados. Esto requiere una buena oferta de recursos humanos calificados y de infraestructuras que respondan a los cambios tecnol√≥gicos.

Lo importante no es centrarse en la inconveniencia inicial que pueda provocar el cambio arancelario, sino en la oportunidad que representa para fortalecer el crecimiento del pa√≠s.

Mario Mendez, Licenciado en Econom√≠a, del Instituto Tecnol√≥gico de Santo Domingo (INTEC), con m√°s de 40 a√±os de ejercicio en el Peri√≥dico HOY.

title: Techno-nationalism and 21st century economic warfare
content: Conceptually, competition is as axiomatic as it is phenomenal. Afterall, life would be extremely pedestrian if it was all drudgery ...
resumen:
The article discusses techno-nationalism and 21st-century economic warfare. Competition is a fundamental aspect of life, with motivations varying across contexts. Nations have historically weaponized strategic duplicity for geo-national and geoeconomic interests, leading to wars like WWI (1914-1918), WWII (1939-45), the Biafra/Nigeria War (1967-1970), the Russia/Ukraine War (2022 to present), and the Israel/Palestinian War (2023 to present). Competition can also be viewed optimistically, stimulating creativity, innovation, and productivity. However, the real world is complicated by unhealthy competition, economic isolationism, and espionage. These volatilities are evident in trade wars, such as those between China and the United States, and the pursuit of geostrategic interests by powerful states, driven by technological pre-eminence and techno-nationalism.

Techno-nationalism is a phenomenon where a sovereign power seeks economic independence and competitive advantage in the technological space. Robert Reich's 1987 piece in The Atlantic Monthly highlighted the importance of microelectronics for industries, productivity, and living standards, and the potential consequences of losing competitive advantage. Over the last 38 years, geopolitics have changed, with China's rise as a major economic rival to the United States, leading to a shift from unipolarism to multipolarism. China's exports increased by 3.4% to reach 3.88 trillion Yuan ($535.25 billion) in the first two months of 2025. The Trump administration imposed global tariffs in 2025, with the U.S. increasing tariffs against Chinese goods to 124.1% and China retaliating with 147.6% tariffs on U.S. goods. A moratorium on retaliatory tariffs was later imposed.

Techno-nationalism involves the economic 'militarisation' of supply chains, decoupling, reshoring, government interventions, technological diplomacy, and trade realpolitik. Cybersecurity threats are growing, with the USA, China, Russia, India, UK, Germany, France, Brazil, South Korea, and United Arab Emirates being among the most targeted countries in 2024. The battleground for techno-nationalism includes advanced minerals, defense weaponry, AI, aerospace, biotechnology, 5G and 6G, IoT, space-based internet, energy, propulsion, quantum, robotics, and semiconductors. China, the European Union, and the United States allocated approximately $6 trillion for technology-based programs in the three years to 2023. The fragmentation of global supply chains and bifurcation of markets towards pro-China or pro-West countries is evident. The UK's trade deals with the European Union, India, and the United States in 2025 are worth circa $60 billion by 2040. The U.S. and its allies have banned Huawei. China responded with the Made in China (MIC) 2025 industrial policy and the Belt and Road Initiative. BRICS, Global South, and Latin American countries face a challenge of choosing between China or the West. Nigeria's bilateral trade with China exceeded $20 billion in 2024, and China will establish electric vehicle factories in Nigeria. The African Development Bank has a pivotal function in the continent‚Äôs industrialisation.

title: I‚Äôm a farmer, and I back Trump‚Äôs tariffs even if they will hurt me
content: The turmoil surrounding tariffs is just another factor in the mess of variables that will determine the success or failure of my enterprise.
resumen: Tim Keegan, a farmer in Mount Vernon, Iowa, and a member of the Global Farmer Network, is planting soybeans and corn this spring. He also has a small cattle operation. He is ready to put up with a trade war. About one-third of his soybeans, or byproducts of them, will leave his landlocked state, float down the Mississippi River on barges, and ship to customers abroad. A portion of his corn will also be exported. The worldwide hunger for beef is enormous. The prices they earn will depend on everything from precipitation in South America to the levels of consumer demand in China. Trump used tariffs aggressively during his first term and promised to use them again as he campaigned for his current one. He is encouraged by news of a limited trade deal with the United Kingdom as well as the apparent recent headway with China. Since the Great Depression, the federal government has supported farmers through direct payments, crop insurance subsidies, and loans. There are also subsidies for conservation improvement practices. 2005 government payments totaled almost $32 billion but were half that amount five years later. Total subsidies in 2019 were just under $23 billion, with $14.5 billion of that being authorized by the Trump administration due to tariffs (not including crop insurance subsidies). He accepted trade interruption payments last time and will accept them if they are offered again.

Este acuerdo, negociado desde marzo de 2024 y finalizado en enero de 2025 tras seis rondas, abrir√° el acceso a un mercado de 39,8 millones de consumidores. La presencia de delegaciones de pa√≠ses como China, Corea del Sur, Marruecos y Emiratos √Årabes Unidos refleja el inter√©s en fortalecer lazos con Ecuador. Turqu√≠a est√° interesada en sectores como turismo, energ√≠a y educaci√≥n en Ecuador. Ecuador busca fortalecer sus relaciones diplom√°ticas con Marruecos mediante la apertura de una embajada. El objetivo es incrementar el comercio bilateral y las inversiones, as√≠ como la cooperaci√≥n en seguridad, tecnolog√≠a e informaci√≥n. Se han iniciado conversaciones para negociar un acuerdo comercial con Emiratos √Årabes Unidos, lo que abrir√≠a la puerta para productos ecuatorianos premium como flores, banano, cacao, camar√≥n, pescado y caf√©.

title: ASEAN Launches Historic Summit with China And Gulf States Amid Rising US Trade Tensions
content: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, in his opening remarks at the ASEAN-GCC summit, emphasized the importance of deepening cooperation between the two regional groupings.
resumen:
Southeast Asian nations have opened a landmark summit with China and the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC).

The summit marks the first-ever trilateral talks between the three blocs.

The talks seek to bolster economic resilience amid growing global trade uncertainties and rising US protectionism.

The meeting is hosted in Kuala Lumpur as part of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations' (ASEAN) annual summit.

The 10-member ASEAN bloc includes Malaysia, Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.

Malaysia is currently chairing ASEAN and is playing host to the gathering.

The summit follows bilateral meetings between ASEAN leaders and members of the GCC‚ÄîBahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates‚Äîbefore culminating in the trilateral summit with China on Tuesday.

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, in his opening remarks at the ASEAN-GCC summit, emphasized the importance of deepening cooperation between the two regional groupings.

Chinese Premier Li Qiang is joining the summit in a show of Beijing‚Äôs commitment to expanding trade and investment ties with both ASEAN and the GCC.

title: Trump just re-declared trade war on the EU. Here's where his trade talks stand around the world.
content: President Donald Trump threatened a new tariff on the European Union on Friday. The 90-day pause on his "reciprocal tariffs" will run out on July 9. Trump has touted some initial deals ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump paused a larger trade war with the EU. His 90-day pause has two months remaining. Trump said he's in no hurry to sign a trade deal.

On May 23, Trump said he would impose a 50% tariff on the EU starting on June 1. He later told reporters he felt no need to cut a deal. By May 25, the president said he had agreed to the EU's request to pause the additional tariff until July 9.

Trump's 90-day pause on his "reciprocal tariffs" is also set to end July 9th.

European Union: Trump said on May 23 that discussions with the EU "are going nowhere!". Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told Fox News, "the EU proposals have not been of the same quality that we've seen from our other important trading partners." As a result, Trump moved to impose the 50% tariff. Days later, the president said that talks had improved. US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and EU Trade Commissioner Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç are expected to meet in Paris next month.

China: US-China trade tensions have cooled considerably. On May 12, both sides announced a 90-day period where US tariffs were slashed from 145% to a base of 30%, while China cut its tariffs from 125% to 10%. The breakthrough came after Bessent and Greer held face-to-face talks with Vice Premier He Lifeng. Before the interim agreement, Trump had already softened the US stance by granting exemptions on iPhones, computers, and other electronics imported into the US from China.

Canada: Trump met with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney in the Oval Office on May 7. During a public portion of their Oval Office meeting, Trump and Carney both said that there needs to be changes made to the US-Mexico-Canada agreement. The United States continues to impose a 25% tariff on non-USMCA-compliant Canadian goods and a 10% tariff on energy imported from Canada. Canada retaliated by imposing a 25% tariff on US goods.

United Kingdom: The White House announced an agreement with the UK on May 8. In the trade agreement, Trump will reverse tariffs on British steel and automobiles. British steel and aluminum won't be subject to US-imposed 25% tariffs. And tariffs for UK cars imported into the United States will be cut from 27.5% to 10% for the first 100,000 vehicles. US farmers will also get more access to UK markets. Trump's 10% tariff ‚Äî still in effect for most countries ‚Äî will remain in place for the UK.

India: Vice President JD Vance said on May 1 that a US-India trade deal would "be among the first deals" the administration will reach. Indian Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal recently traveled to the US. Trump announced a 27% tariff on Indian goods at the White House. His 90-day pause on those tariffs ends on July 9.

Vietnam: The US and Vietnam have held two rounds of trade talks, but a deal is still no quite done. Trump imposed a 46% tariff on Vietnam as part of his "Liberation Day" announcement ‚Äî it, too, is subject to the 90-day pause.

Japan: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba told reporters that he spoke with Trump directly. Japan and the US have held three rounds of talks thus far. Trump imposed a 24% tariff on Japanese goods before announcing his 90-day pause.

South Korea: South Korea sent representatives to the US early on, but it's unlikely to be one of the first countries to strike a deal. South Korea is holding snap elections on June 3.

La operaci√≥n termin√≥ con dos detenidos acusados de delitos de contrabando, contra la salud p√∫blica y pertenencia a organizaci√≥n criminal. Las investigaciones comenzaron en 2023, detectando importaciones de catalizadores procedentes de Brasil con sospechas de droga escondida. Se centraron en una empresa implicada por incongruencias en su actividad econ√≥mica, identificando a miembros de un presunto grupo criminal en Callosa del Segura (Alicante). Se descubrieron naves industriales como centro de distribuci√≥n y un entramado empresarial alquilando instalaciones para importaciones. Se identific√≥ a los administradores y socios de estas empresas como integrantes del grupo criminal, al servicio del responsable de la organizaci√≥n, en paradero desconocido en Sudam√©rica. A principios de abril de este a√±o se detect√≥ un contenedor llegado de Brasil con destino Alicante. Se verific√≥ la existencia de coca√≠na oculta en los catalizadores. El valor de la coca√≠na incautada superar√≠a los cinco millones de euros (5,7 millones de d√≥lares) en el mercado negro.

title: China‚Äôs Soft Spot in Trade War With Trump: Risk of Huge Job Loss
content: A chronic housing slowdown and high youth unemployment rate have made China more vulnerable than it was in President Trump‚Äôs first term.
resumen:
President Trump, in his first term, claimed his tariffs led to the loss of five million jobs in China. In a 2019 tweet, he said his trade policies had put China ‚Äúback on its heels.‚Äù

Four months into Mr. Trump‚Äôs second term, the United States and China are again negotiating over tariffs, and the Chinese labor market, especially factory jobs, is front and center.

A persistent property slowdown has wiped out jobs. New university graduates are pouring into the labor pool at a time when the unemployment rate among young workers is in the double digits.

Alicia Garcia-Herrero, chief economist for the Asia-Pacific region at the investment bank Natixis, said the importance of preserving China‚Äôs 100 million manufacturing jobs has grown.

Chinese and U.S. officials agreed to temporarily reduce the punishing tariffs they had imposed on each other.

Natixis said that if U.S. tariffs stayed at their current levels of at least 30 percent, exports to the United States would fall by half, resulting in a loss of up to six million manufacturing jobs. If the trade war resumes again in full, the job losses could surge to nine million.

China‚Äôs economy has struggled to recover from the pandemic, expanding more slowly than in the years of Mr. Trump‚Äôs first term, when growth was more than 6 percent a year. The Chinese government is targeting growth of around 5 percent this year, but many economists have predicted that the actual figure will not reach those levels.

In early 2018, China said its urban jobless rate had fallen to 15-year lows and the country had created a record number of new jobs.

Unemployment climbed especially among young people. The jobless rate among 16-to-24-year-olds was 15.8 percent in April. However, the figure is expected to surge again when 12 million new college graduates join the work force this year.

In 2023, when youth unemployment figures reached a record 21.3 percent, the Chinese government suspended the release of the figures. Beijing started distributing the figures again last year with a new methodology that lowered the jobless rate.

Fewer companies are offering full-time employment, turning instead to gig workers.

American industry is deeply dependent on rare earth metals and critical minerals controlled largely by China.

Diana Choyleva, chief economist at Enodo Economics, said China has an advantage in ‚Äútrade war endurance.‚Äù

In April, before the United States and China agreed to suspend the heaviest tariffs, new export orders from China fell to their lowest level since 2022.

In Guangzhou, businesses had closed as orders from foreign buyers dropped before the ultrahigh tariffs were paused.

Jane Hu, an office worker in Shanghai, lost her job last month because of China‚Äôs countermeasure to raise duties on American imports to 125 percent. Her former employer, a construction equipment company, could not afford the tariffs. Sales declined about 40 percent, making layoffs unavoidable.

Yu Jiadong, a top official at China‚Äôs Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security, said the government had prepared a number of measures to keep employment stable, especially for Chinese exporters.

One factory owner in southern China said he had planned to lay off staff but held off when customers rushed to fill orders after the tariff truce. A government official had told him that if he needed to cut his work force, he should do so properly and quietly to avoid creating a stir.

Han Dongfang, the founder of China Labor Bulletin, said factory owners who employ salaried workers are required by law to compensate them in a layoff, usually paying one month‚Äôs salary for every year of employment.

Employment activity outside the manufacturing sector has contracted for more than two years.

Laura Wang, 23, a graduate student studying accounting in Chongqing, said that more than 80 percent of her classmates were struggling to find jobs.

content: En pleno terremoto por la guerra arancelaria desencadenada por Donald Trump, el president de la Generalitat, Salvador Illa, considera que, sea cual sea el desenlace, Estados Unidos ya no es un socio f ...
resumen:
En plena guerra arancelaria, el president de la Generalitat, Salvador Illa, anunci√≥ desde Tokio que el Govern aprobar√° a finales de a√±o el 'Plan Asia', una estrategia para convertir Catalunya en un "socio fiable y estable" de Asia, con foco en China e India.

El Executiu considera que Catalunya debe aprovechar el potencial de Asia, que concentra el 60% de la poblaci√≥n mundial y se estima que hacia 2030 aportar√° m√°s de la mitad del crecimiento global.

title: Ganancias del grupo propietario de Temu sufrieron una ca√≠da del 47% en el primer trimestre
content: El grupo chino PDD Holdings, matriz de la plataforma de comercio electr√≥nico Temu, obtuvo un beneficio neto atribuido de 14.742 millones de yuanes (1.799 millones de euros) al cierre del primer ...
resumen:
El grupo chino PDD Holdings, matriz de la plataforma de comercio electr√≥nico Temu, obtuvo un beneficio neto atribuido de 14.742 millones de yuanes (1.799 millones de euros) al cierre del primer trimestre de 2025, lo que representa una ca√≠da del 47% en comparaci√≥n con el resultado contabilizado en el mismo periodo del a√±o anterior.

Los ingresos del grupo chino, que no desglosa la evoluci√≥n del negocio de Temu, sumaron 95.672 millones de yuanes (11.677 millones de euros), un 10% m√°s que entre enero y marzo del a√±o anterior.

La facturaci√≥n de PDD Holdings en el negocio de servicios de marketing online aument√≥ un 14,7%, hasta 48.722 millones de yuanes (5.947 millones de euros), mientras que los ingresos por servicios de transacciones subieron un 5,8%, hasta 46.950 millones de yuanes (5.730 millones de euros).

Lei Chen, presidente y co-consejero delegado de PDD Holdings, afirm√≥ que en el primer trimestre, se realizaron inversiones sustanciales en el ecosistema de plataforma para apoyar a comerciantes y consumidores ante los r√°pidos cambios del entorno externo, lo que afect√≥ la rentabilidad a corto plazo, pero reforzar√° la solidez de la plataforma a largo plazo.

Jiazhen Zhao, co-consejero delegado de PDD Holdings, afirm√≥ que un mayor apoyo a los comerciantes es esencial para construir un ecosistema comercial s√≥lido que pueda ofrecer experiencias de compra satisfactorias a los consumidores.

La compa√±√≠a prev√© una desaceleraci√≥n del crecimiento a medida que surjan nuevos desaf√≠os, lo que se ha visto ‚Äúa√∫n m√°s acelerado por los cambios en el entorno externo durante el primer trimestre‚Äù, declar√≥ Jun Liu, vicepresidenta de Finanzas de PDD Holdings.

Lei Chen subray√≥ que, ‚Äúen un entorno externo que cambia r√°pidamente, nuestro negocio global est√° colaborando con vendedores de diversas regiones para ofrecer precios estables y un suministro abundante a los consumidores de todo el mundo‚Äù.

El grupo chino PDD Holdings, matriz de la plataforma de comercio electr√≥nico Temu, obtuvo un beneficio neto atribuido de 14.742 millones de yuanes.

title: Friedrich Merz se opone a la semana laboral de cuatro d√≠as
content: El canciller de Alemania, Friedrich Merz, se pronunci√≥ en contra de la idea de introducir una semana laboral de cuatro d√≠as en el pa√≠s. 'Los alemanes necesitan ...
resumen: El canciller de Alemania, Friedrich Merz, se pronunci√≥ en contra de la idea de introducir una semana laboral de cuatro d√≠as en el pa√≠s. "Los alemanes necesitan trabajar m√°s. Con una semana laboral de cuatro d√≠as y un equilibrio entre trabajo y vida personal, no podemos sostener la prosperidad de este pa√≠s", sostuvo Merz durante su intervenci√≥n en la conferencia del Consejo Econ√≥mico de la Uni√≥n Dem√≥crata Cristiana, en Berl√≠n. Datos de la Organizaci√≥n para la Cooperaci√≥n y el Desarrollo Econ√≥mico (OCDE) muestran que de sus treinta y ocho pa√≠ses miembros, Alemania es donde menos horas se trabaja en promedio. Los expertos pronostican que la econom√≠a alemana se contraer√° un 0,2% este a√±o y que entrar√° en recesi√≥n por tercer a√±o consecutivo. A fines de 2023 se aplic√≥ por seis meses la semana laboral de cuatro d√≠as en 45 compa√±√≠as alemanas. El experimento mostr√≥ una mejora en la satisfacci√≥n de los empleados. Un 50% report√≥ un bienestar significativamente mayor, muchos durmieron 38 minutos m√°s por semana, hicieron m√°s ejercicio y experimentaron menos estr√©s. Esto ayud√≥ a incrementar unos 8 puntos el nivel de retenci√≥n del personal.

title: El animal que Estados Unidos lava con cloro antes de venderlo en supermercados: por qu√© es importante en las negociaciones con Europa
content: Emilio Gonz√°lez, economista, se√±ala en La Linterna uno de los puntos clave de la tensi√≥n por los aranceles y que tiene que ver con el sector alimentario ...
resumen: El lavado de pollo con soluciones cloradas, pr√°ctica habitual en Estados Unidos pero prohibida en la UE desde 1997, ha vuelto al centro de la guerra comercial entre ambos bloques. Donald Trump amenaza con aranceles del 50% a productos europeos. El economista Emilio Gonz√°lez, profesor de la Universidad Nebrija, alerta en La Linterna de COPE sobre la estrategia estadounidense: "Trump usa estos conflictos para debilitar al adversario y obtener concesiones, pero detr√°s hay un choque de filosof√≠as: ellos priorizan la desinfecci√≥n final; Europa, la prevenci√≥n desde la granja". La Uni√≥n Europea defiende su veto por riesgos sanitarios y ambientales, Washington insiste en que es una medida "proteccionista". El proceso, denominado Tratamiento de Reducci√≥n de Pat√≥genos, implica sumergir las canales de pollo en agua con compuestos clorados (hipoclorito de sodio, di√≥xido de cloro) tras el sacrificio. Su objetivo declarado es eliminar bacterias como Salmonella o E. coli. Seg√∫n el Consejo Nacional del Pollo de EE.UU., "es seguro, no altera el sabor y reduce enfermedades". La Agencia Europea de Seguridad Alimentaria (EFSA) lo rechaza: "El cloro enmascara la suciedad acumulada en granjas industriales, donde los pollos viven hacinados entre heces y amon√≠aco". Un informe de 2008 a√±ade que puede generar subproductos cancer√≠genos como cloratos, persistentes en el organismo. La FDA y USDA (Estados Unidos) aprueban concentraciones de hasta 60 ppm de cloro, consider√°ndolo inocuo, la Comisi√≥n Europea establece un l√≠mite de 0.01 mg/kg de clorato en alimentos, alertando de da√±os en la tiroides infantil. Consumer Reports (2014) detect√≥ bacterias en el 97% de muestras de pollo estadounidense, pese al cloro. El 50% conten√≠a materia fecal, mientras que la Universidad de Southampton reflej√≥ en 2018 que el cloro pone bacterias en "modo hibernaci√≥n", haci√©ndolas indetectables en laboratorio pero activas al consumirse. Emilio Gonz√°lez lo resume: "Es un parche qu√≠mico para un sistema productivo insalubre. Europa exige vacunaci√≥n y espacios limpios; EE.UU. prefiere soluciones baratas al final". Estados Unidos export√≥ el 16.5% de su producci√≥n av√≠cola en 2016, principalmente a M√©xico, Canad√° y Cuba, y Trump busca romper el veto europeo para ampliar mercados. Trump necesita √©xitos comerciales para compensar su ca√≠da en las encuestas. Monique Goyens, de la Organizaci√≥n Europea de Consumidores: "No tememos al cloro, sino a que sea un pretexto para ocultar pr√°cticas inhumanas".

title: White House says tariff power deters conflict
content: The Trump administration told the U.S. Court of International Trade that narrowing the president‚Äôs emergency tariff powers will weaken U.S. global influence and threaten a fragile India-Pakistan ...
resumen:
The Trump administration told the U.S. Court of International Trade that narrowing the president‚Äôs emergency tariff powers will weaken U.S. global influence and threaten a fragile India-Pakistan ceasefire.

White House officials are warning the U.S. Court of International Trade that a decision to throw out Trump‚Äôs tariffs would degrade the ability of the U.S. to uphold deals and negotiate on the world stage.

Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer, Secretary of State Marco Rubio, and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent filed comments late last week backing Trump‚Äôs use of an emergency law to impose tariffs.

Their filings came in response to a lawsuit from a group of small businesses.

Trump was the first president to use the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act to impose tariffs during what he deemed ‚ÄúLiberation Day.‚Äù

The court could rule on this or any of the more than half-dozen legal challenges brought over Trump‚Äôs tariffs in the coming weeks or months.

Lutnick said that IEEPA has played a key role in the Trump administration‚Äôs ability to deter violent conflict too, pointing to a tenuous ceasefire between India and Pakistan reached May 10.

Lutnick said, ‚ÄúThis ceasefire was only achieved after President Trump interceded and offered both nations trading access with the United States to avert a full-scale war.‚Äù

Lutnick said, ‚ÄúAn adverse ruling that constrains presidential power in this case could lead India and Pakistan to question the validity of President Trump‚Äôs offer, threatening the security of an entire region and the lives of millions.‚Äù

Greer underscored IEEPA as a ‚Äúcrucial tool‚Äù the president should be able to access to address extraordinary threats.

Greer added that negating Trump‚Äôs ability to use the measure would effectively undo deals reached with the United Kingdom and China to delay or reduce tariffs, and nullify negotiations with other countries.

Greer said, ‚ÄúA decision enjoining the President from imposing tariffs under IEEPA would create a foreign policy disaster scenario.‚Äù

The lawsuit was filed last month by Princess Awesome LLC, a Maryland-based shop that sells apparel, as well as table-top game-makers and other small businesses.

The lawsuit contends that Trump‚Äôs invocation of IEEPA is unlawful because federal law does not explicitly authorize presidents to impose tariffs.

California Attorney General Rob Bonta said Friday he‚Äôs prepared to sue if appropriate to defend the companies based in his state, such as Apple, after Trump threatened tariffs on the iPhone maker unless it moves production fully to the United States.

Trump on Friday said his threat to impose a 25 percent tariff on Apple smartphones applies to other manufacturers as well.

Europe‚Äôs trade commissioner shared phone calls with Lutnick and Greer on Monday, as both sides of the Atlantic seek to reach a trade deal and head off Trump‚Äôs sweeping tariff threats.

Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç wrote on X, ‚ÄúThe @EU_Commission remains fully committed to constructive and focused efforts at pace towards an [EU,U.S.] deal.‚Äù

Trump lashed out at European negotiators last Friday, promising 50 percent tariffs starting at the beginning of June.

A Sunday phone call with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen led Trump to push back the tariffs start date from June 1 to July 9.

A delegation of eight members of the European Parliament, including the chair of the international trade committee Bernd Lange, is in Washington this week.

Four days after Trump said he had approved a deal for Nippon Steel to buy U.S. Steel, industry executives and lawmakers are still waiting for more information about what exactly the president has agreed to.

Trump in a post on Truth Social on Friday said there will be a ‚Äúplanned partnership‚Äù between the Pittsburgh-based steel giant and the Japanese company, which ‚Äúwill create at least 70,000 jobs and add $14 Billion Dollars to the U.S. Economy.‚Äù

Trump added the ‚Äúbulk‚Äù of the investment will take place over the next 14 months.

The action effectively reverses former President Joe Biden‚Äôs decision to block the transaction just weeks before leaving office in January.

Trump opposed the takeover on the campaign trail.

Trump has taken a warmer view, telling reporters in February he ‚Äúwouldn‚Äôt mind greatly‚Äù if Nippon Steel took a minority stake in the company.

title: Trade crime is soaring, US firms say, as Trump‚Äôs tariffs incentivize fraud
content: As President Trump‚Äôs tariffs have ratcheted up in recent months, so have the mysterious solicitations some US companies have received, offering them ways to avoid the taxes. Shipping companies, many ...
resumen: As President Trump‚Äôs tariffs have increased, so have the solicitations some US companies have received, offering ways to avoid the taxes. Shipping companies, many of them based in China, have reached out to US firms that import apparel, auto parts, and jewelry, offering solutions that they say can make the tariffs go away. The proposals reflect a new flood of fraudulent activity, according to company executives and government officials. As US tariffs on foreign products have increased dramatically, so have the incentives for companies to find ways around them. The Chinese firms advertising these services describe their methods as valid solutions. For a fee, they find ways to bring products to the United States with much lower tariffs. Experts say these practices are methods of customs fraud. The companies may be dodging tariffs by altering the information about the shipments that is given to the US government to qualify for a lower tariff rate, or they may physically move the goods to another country that is subject to a lower tariff before shipping them to the United States, a technique known as transshipment. The Trump administration said this month that it would focus more on fighting trade fraud, including tariff evasion. The administration is also trying to convince other countries to step up their own enforcement efforts, including in trade talks with Vietnam, Mexico, and Malaysia. Many US companies say the scale of illicit activity now far outweighs the ability of these governments to thwart it.

title: Will Trump's tariffs on China raise prices at Ross? CEO says maybe. Here's what to know
content: Ross said President Donald Trump's tariffs could impact its profitability this year, potentially leading to price hikes. Find out more.
resumen:
Ross withdrew its fiscal 2025 forecasts on May 22, saying President Donald Trump's tariffs could impact its profits this year, according to Reuters.

The store said more than half its goods are made in China, which could lead it to potentially raising some of its prices if "inflationary pressures persist in the retail industry."

Ross' Chief Executive Officer Jim Conroy said the tariffs are expected to reduce earnings per share by 11-16 cents in the second quarter, according to the Wall Street Journal.

The Trump administration and China reached an agreement on May 12 to slash tariffs for the next 90 days while the two sides negotiate a long-term deal. This comes just weeks after the president raised more than 100% tariffs on China in a "tit-for-tat" reciprocal tariff battle originally intended to shift focus to American-made products.

Under the temporary new deal, Trump lowered the 125% reciprocal tariffs imposed on Chinese imports to just 10%. Trump's 20% tariff on Chinese fentanyl products will remain, meaning the U.S. tariffs on China will total 30% overall.

The deal does not apply to the universal 25% tariffs the president imposed on automobiles, auto parts, steel and aluminum.

Trump said he would raise the tariffs against China again if it does not agree to a final resolution after 90 days, but not back to the previous level of 145%.

title: Trump said his tariffs would ‚ÄòNEVER CHANGE‚Äô. Here‚Äôs a list of the times they changed.
content: Crikey does its best to keep up with the changes to policies that Trump said, in all caps, would 'NEVER CHANGE'.
resumen:
US President Donald Trump announced this week that the implementation of a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union would be delayed from its initially proposed start of June 1 until July 9 to allow for negotiations with the bloc.

February 1, 2025: US President Donald Trump signs three executive orders imposing 25% tariffs on all goods from Mexico and Canada (with some exceptions for Canada subject to a 10% tariff) and a 10% tariff on imports from China, to be imposed from February 4.

February 3: Trump agrees to a one-month pause on tariffs with the leaders of Mexico and Canada.

March 4: US tariffs on imports from Canada, China, and Mexico come into effect.

March 7: Trump once again delays tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico.

March 26: The White House announces a series of tariffs on foreign-made cars and foreign car parts.

March 31: White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt insists there will be ‚Äúno exemptions at this time‚Äù to the impending tariffs.

April 2: Trump announces ‚Äúreciprocal tariffs‚Äù on all of the USA‚Äôs trading partners. This includes Australia, as well as the Heard and McDonald Islands, uninhabited Australian external territories that are home to our only active volcanoes.

April 4: Trump posts to Truth Social: ‚ÄúTO THE MANY INVESTORS COMING INTO THE UNITED STATES AND INVESTING MASSIVE AMOUNTS OF MONEY, MY POLICIES WILL NEVER CHANGE.‚Äù

April 8: In response to retaliatory tariffs from China, the White House announces an additional 50% tariff levied on top of previously imposed tariffs of 20% and 34%, bringing the total tariff on Chinese goods to 104%.

April 9: Trump announces he will pause the harshest of his tariffs for 90 days. A baseline tariff of 10% stays in place for most nations, and tariffs on China remain.

April 11: Trump confirms that tariffs on China will now be 145%.

April 14: Trump announces that he is considering a temporary exemption for automakers from the tariffs he‚Äôd previously imposed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt change my mind, but I‚Äôm flexible,‚Äù he tells reporters.

April 22: Trump says American tariffs on Chinese imports will come down ‚Äúsubstantially‚Äù. ‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt be that high, not going to be that high,‚Äù he tells an Oval Office press conference.

May 12: Trump agrees to a three-month cut on US tariffs on Chinese goods, down 115 percentage points to 30%. China drops its tariffs on US goods to 10%.

May 23: On the same day he proposes a 50% tariff on the EU, Trump threatens a 25% tariff on Apple‚Äôs iPhone unless the company brings its manufacturing jobs to the US.

May 25: Trump announces a pause on the proposed EU tariffs. The threat of tariffs on Apple, for now, remains.

title: Trade Crime Is Soaring, U.S. Firms Say, as Trump‚Äôs Tariffs Incentivize Fraud
content: President Trump‚Äôs steep global tariffs have supercharged efforts to evade them. Some U.S. companies say the government is ill equipped to keep up.
resumen: U.S. companies are receiving solicitations offering ways to avoid tariffs, with shipping companies, many based in China, offering solutions to U.S. firms that import apparel, auto parts, and jewelry. These proposals reflect a new flood of fraudulent activity, as U.S. tariffs on foreign products have increased sharply. Chinese firms describe their methods as valid solutions, but experts say these practices are methods of customs fraud, such as altering shipment information or moving goods to countries with lower tariffs (transshipment). The Trump administration said it would focus more on fighting trade fraud, but many American companies say the scale of illicit activity outweighs the government's ability to thwart it. These schemes are costing the U.S. government billions of dollars in tariff revenue annually. David Rashid, the executive chairman of Plews, said that unfairly traded products had filtered into supply chains throughout the United States. As Mr. Trump has raised tariffs to levels not seen in a century, companies say customs fraud is also reaching new heights. In his first months in office, Mr. Trump put a 10 percent tariff on most products globally, as well as a 25 percent tariff on steel, aluminum, and cars. Leslie Jordan, an apparel manufacturer, said fraudulent schemes were becoming "rampant" in her industry. Kush Desai, a White House spokesman, said that "instead of trying to find illegal workarounds to tariffs, foreign exporters would be better off telling their governments to negotiate a trade deal with the United States." John Foote, a customs lawyer at Kelley Drye & Warren, described the uptick in fraud as "a sign of entering a high tariff era." The U.S. government charges tariffs based on the item, its declared dollar value, and its country of origin. Schemes to evade tariffs include reporting a lower value for a product, misclassifying the item, and sending products to another country before they go to the United States. In April, Chinese exports to the United States fell 21 percent from a year earlier, but Chinese exports to Southeast Asian countries rose by the same percentage. An analysis by Exiger found that more than 3,000 companies in Mexico depended on Chinese shipments for 75 percent or more of their supply chain. Chinese companies are also marketing a method, "delivered duty paid," or D.D.P., that ostensibly reduces the U.S. importers‚Äô legal liability for tariff fraud. Christopher Carney, an auto industry executive, said companies offering these schemes were operating with "a sense of impunity." The Department of Justice said trade and customs fraud would be a new priority under the Trump administration. Brad Muller, the vice president of marketing and government affairs at Charlotte Pipe and Foundry, said that the U.S. government was unable to stop Chinese companies from transshipping their products. Trish Driscoll, a spokeswoman for Customs and Border Protection, said that the department used enforcement tools, intelligence, and partnerships to combat tariff evasion, and, as a result of recent presidential actions, was now imposing the most severe penalties permitted by law. During the week of May 5 through May 9, Customs and Border Protection took in more than $630 million by reviewing more than 2,000 shipments detected for duty evasion. Importers are urging Congress to give the government more resources to go after fraud.

content: Guatemala inicia negociaciones con EE. UU. para reducir aranceles impuestos por Trump a productos guatemaltecos. El pa√≠s entreg√≥ hoja de ruta a USTR.
resumen: Una delegaci√≥n del Gobierno de Guatemala se reuni√≥ con funcionarios de la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR) para iniciar conversaciones dirigidas a una reducci√≥n arancelaria.
