title: India now leads iPhone exports to the U.S. as trade war reshapes supply chains
content: Apple is now exporting more iPhones to the U.S. from India than China for the second month running, a clear sign of shifting production priorities.
resumen:
India now leads iPhone exports to the U.S. as trade war reshapes supply chains.
Apple is now exporting more iPhones to the U.S. from India than China for the second month running.
Apple hit a major supply chain milestone in April 2025.
For the second consecutive month, more iPhones bound for the U.S. were shipped from India than from China.
Shipments from India surged 76% year over year to an estimated three million units.
Shipments from China fell 76% to about 900,000.
The export milestone is a clear shift in Apple's manufacturing strategy, but it comes outside the peak season for Pro iPhone models.
The surge in Indian exports reflects progress in Apple's plan to diversify.
The most advanced iPhones remain tied to Chinese production.
Previous years non-Pro iPhones came from China at this time of year.
The reversal reflects Apple's accelerated effort to reduce reliance on Chinese manufacturing.
The company began building out its Indian supply chain during the pandemic, but renewed U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports have added urgency.
In early May 2025, Apple CEO Tim Cook reiterated that most iPhones sold in the U.S. will eventually be assembled in India.
The ramp-up in Indian exports follows President Trump's latest round of tariffs, introduced in early April 2025.
Although iPhones were exempted from the initial measures, Apple moved quickly to shift final assembly operations to avoid supply chain risk.
Analysts believe Apple may have also front-loaded shipments in March, stockpiling U.S.-bound units ahead of policy changes.
India first surpassed China in iPhone exports to the U.S. that month, with the April figures reinforcing the trend.
Apple's Indian manufacturing operation, which now accounts for around 20% of its global iPhone output, still depends heavily on Chinese sub-assemblies.
Daniel Newman, CEO of Futurum Group, said the shift to India covers only the final step of the production process.
The vast majority of the sub-assemblies are all still in China.
India's current production capacity also remains limited.
U.S. iPhone demand averages 20 million units per quarter, and analysts at Omdia don't expect India to meet that scale before 2026.
President Trump recently imposed a 25% tariff on iPhones made in India.
China has also pushed back by restricting the export of high-end manufacturing equipment and engineering talent needed by Apple's Indian suppliers.
Manufacturing in India is also more expensive.
In April 2025, costs were estimated to be 5% to 8% higher than in China.
Apple has worked to offset that with tax incentives and streamlined logistics, including airlifting hundreds of tons of iPhones to the U.S. through "green corridor" programs earlier in 2025.
A green corridor is a fast-track export route that speeds up customs clearance.
Dan Ives of Wedbush Securities called the idea of shifting full iPhone production to the U.S. a "fairy tale," noting that Apple will continue investing in India regardless of short-term political pressure.

title: Retailers pummeled by Trump's trade war entertain more 'take-private' offers
content: Retailers have been hard-hit by Trump's rapidly shifting tariff announcements, and are frustrated with an inability to provide earnings guidance.
resumen:
Investment bankers expect more retailers to go private amid trade policy instability. Retailers with controlling shareholders are prime targets for take-private deals. 3G Capital's long-term investment strategy suits volatile market conditions.

Boards and the owners of retailers whose shares have been pummeled by U.S. President Donald Trump's trade war are increasingly warming to offers to sell ‚Äì and to escape the market chaos that has caused company valuations to seesaw in recent months.

Following sneaker-maker Skechers' take-private deal earlier this month, dealmakers expect other retailers to clinch their own agreements to go private in the near-term, especially if Trump does not soon settle on a more stable trade policy, according to interviews with 10 investment bankers and M&A lawyers.

Retailers in particular have been hard-hit by Trump's rapidly shifting tariff announcements, and are frustrated with an inability to provide earnings guidance.

Skechers was in talks with investment firm 3G Capital long before its market value began a precipitous drop from an all-time high of around $11.85 billion on January 30 - the day before the White House announced its first round of tariffs against China - according to two people familiar with the matter. The flood of tariff announcements beat the company's value down to about $7.4 billion by the end of April. Skechers, which manufactures most of its goods in China and Vietnam, pulled its 2025 earnings guidance around that time, citing ‚Äúmacroeconomic uncertainty stemming from global trade policies."

Skechers is majority-owned by the Greenberg family. The tariff turmoil made the idea of going private all the more attractive to the Greenbergs, said the sources, who asked not to be named because the negotiations were private. The company announced plans on May 5 to sell to 3G Capital in a so-called take-private deal for about $9.4 billion.

Selling to a privately held firm like 3G removes the company's shares from public exchanges, which effectively shields its earnings from public scrutiny and protects its valuation from unpredictable market swings.

Other retailers are already in talks to sell to investment firms and other companies, the sources said.

Kurt Anthony, head of consumer and retail investment banking for the Americas at UBS, said: ‚ÄúThe breakneck pace of the instability, the volatility, and the macro changes have made board members start thinking, ‚ÄòWould it be better to manage this business in private where we don‚Äôt have to report out to the street with the same quarterly cadence and where we can control operational, financial, and capital allocation decisions in private?‚Äô‚Äù

Few industries have been hit harder by Trump's tariffs than retailers, many of which manufacture most of their goods overseas and have had to pull earnings guidance amid fickle foreign policy. The S&P Retail Select Industry index had fallen by 6% year-to-date as of Friday's market close, while the broader S&P 500 Index (.SPX) had fallen 1.1% in the same period.

Jamie Salter, CEO of Authentic Brands Group, said: ‚ÄúThere are a lot of CEOs that reached out to me and said 'I‚Äôm tired, I love what I do, but maybe it‚Äôs time I go private,'‚Äù The company, which owns the intellectual property of several apparel companies including Reebok and Champion, acquired Dockers' IP from Levi's (LEVI.N) last week. ‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre going to see good companies either stay private, or go private.‚Äù

And companies where a family - as in the case of Skechers - or a single investor has a controlling stake can sign these deals faster and more easily than those that need broad shareholder approval.

Investment bankers and advisers pointed to other retailers with similar ownership structures as potential take-private targets: Under Armour where founder and CEO Kevin Plank has majority voting control, Columbia Sportswear Company (COLM.O) where chairman and CEO Timothy Boyle and his family are the biggest shareholders, and Birkenstock (BIRK.N) with private equity firm L Catterton holding a majority stake.

In Skechers' case, navigating the market uncertainty in private made sense to father-son duo Robert Greenberg, chairman and CEO, and Michael Greenberg, president, said the two people familiar with the family's thinking. And a buyer like 3G, which has held some investments for over a decade, can afford to ride out short-term tariff and market volatility compared with traditional private equity firms that tend to hold their investments for a handful of years, the people said.

title: Armas econ√≥micas de China
content: China es objeto de aranceles por parte de Estados Unidos y una de las formas de responder es con la misma medicina. Por ejemplo, China coloc√≥ un arancel de un 125% a los productos estadunidenses.
resumen: China abarca varios campos que le permiten competir con las dem√°s potencias mundiales. En el campo econ√≥mico, pol√≠tico, tecnol√≥gico y militar China tiene elevada presencia. China es objeto de aranceles por parte de Estados Unidos y una de las formas de responder es con la misma medicina. China coloc√≥ un arancel de un 125% a los productos estadunidenses, espec√≠ficamente al ma√≠z y productos similares. China ha cancelado o eliminado la compra de soja y trigo a Estados Unidos y ha establecido lazos para esos fines con Brasil, donde se construir√° el mayor puerto agroexportador del mundo. China puede poner trabas administrativas a las empresas Estadunidenses establecidas en su territorio. China es el segundo tenedor de deuda de EEUU (760,000,000,000 millones de d√≥lares). China tiene a su favor recursos estrat√©gicos. China domina el 80% del refinamiento de recursos como el Galio, Germanio y el Grafito. China tiene en sus manos la diversificaci√≥n de alianzas y comercios con otros horizontes.

title: Canad√° dice est√° acabando su 'sobredependencia' de EEUU, pero Trump ofrece lo contrario
content: Trump afirm√≥ el martes que Canad√° est√° considerando la oferta de convertirse en el estado n√∫mero 51 de EEUU. y unirse al codiciado sistema Golden Dome de defensa. El comentario se produjo tras la visi ...
resumen:
El primer ministro canadiense, Mark Carney, declar√≥ que Canad√° est√° sufriendo "los peligros de la sobredependencia econ√≥mica y en materia de seguridad" de EEUU por lo que est√° en proceso de aumentar su integraci√≥n con la industria de defensa europea, pero Donald Trump dijo que el pa√≠s vecino m√°s bien sigue considerando ser el estado n√∫mero 51.

En una entrevista con la radiotelevisi√≥n p√∫blica canadiense CBC, Carney reiter√≥ su idea de que la tradicional relaci√≥n de Canad√° con EEUU se ha acabado con el regreso de Trump a la Casa Blanca y que es el momento para que Ottawa recalibre sus alianzas.

Carney destac√≥ que por cada d√≥lar que Canad√° gasta en defensa, el 75 % va a parar a Estados Unidos.

Carney afirm√≥ que su Gobierno diversificar√° su gasto y dirigir√° m√°s hacia sus socios europeos.

Carney tambi√©n rechaz√≥ la afirmaci√≥n que realiz√≥ este martes el secretario de Econom√≠a de M√©xico, Marcelo Ebrard, de que las negociaciones del T-MEC entre Canad√°, EE.UU. y M√©xico se iniciar√°n en septiembre de este a√±o.

Trump afirm√≥ el martes que Canad√° est√° considerando la oferta de convertirse en el estado n√∫mero 51 de EEUU y unirse al codiciado sistema Golden Dome de defensa. El comentario se produjo tras la visita del rey Carlos III a Canad√°.

Trump alert√≥ que Canad√° podr√≠a perder mucho dinero si no acepta unirse a la uni√≥n y unirse gratuitamente a su sistema de defensa antimisiles "C√∫pula Dorada".

Trump anunci√≥ planes para construir el sistema "C√∫pula Dorada" hace una semana. Calcula que costar√° unos 175.000 millones de d√≥lares y estar√° operativo al final de su mandato, en 2029.

Trump declar√≥ que Canad√° est√° interesado en unirse al sistema de defensa y el primer ministro canadiense confirm√≥ que su pa√≠s ha mantenido conversaciones de "alto nivel" sobre el tema, pero cort√©s y firme desestim√≥ los llamados de Trump para que Canad√° integre Estados Unidos.

De no ser as√≠ y pasar a formar parte del sistema le costar√≠a a Canad√° 61.000 millones de d√≥lares, afirm√≥ Trump, quien insiste en que su vecino del norte se convierta en el estado n√∫mero 51.

Ambos pa√≠ses, miembros de la OTAN, son socios en defensa continental a trav√©s del Comando de Defensa Aeroespacial de Am√©rica del Norte (NORAD).

Los comentarios parec√≠an ser una respuesta a un discurso pronunciado por el rey Carlos III durante su visita a Canad√° este mismo d√≠a. El rey abog√≥ por la soberan√≠a canadiense.

El rey Carlos III y la reina Camila concluyeron su visita a Canad√° este martes.

El BQ anunciar√° un proyecto de ley para eliminar la obligaci√≥n de todos los diputados de jurar lealtad al rey como requisito para asumir el esca√±o.

Trump ha intentado 'borrar' la frontera entre los dos pa√≠ses al cuestionar su legitimidad y calificarla de "l√≠nea artificial" dibujada en el pasado por desconocidos "con una regla".

Ante la agresividad incontenida de Trump, que ha acompa√±ado sus palabras con aranceles a sectores clave de la econom√≠a canadiense que suponen una grave amenaza al bienestar del pa√≠s, el primer ministro canadiense Carney solicit√≥ a Carlos III que acudiese a Ottawa para reforzar la soberan√≠a canadiense.

Robert Fife, columnista de The Globe and Mail, dijo este martes que la lectura del Discurso del Trono por parte del rey ha logrado a la perfecci√≥n el objetivo buscado por el Gobierno canadiense.

El mensaje para Trump: Carlos III es el rey constitucional de Canad√° y el pa√≠s no necesita ni quiere sustituirlo por otro monarca.

El acad√©mico Philippe Lagass√©, experto en la monarqu√≠a brit√°nica y su relaci√≥n constitucional con Canad√°, lo explic√≥ en un art√≠culo de opini√≥n publicado en el peri√≥dico The National Post.

title: La guerra comercial de Trump reduce las previsiones de crecimiento de √Åfrica, dice el BAfD
content: Abiy√°n, 27 may (EFE).- El Banco Africano de Desarrollo (BAfD) espera que el producto interior bruto (PIB) de √Åfrica crezca un 3,9 % en 2025, por encima del 3,3 % registrado el pasado a√±o, si bien la i ...
resumen: El Banco Africano de Desarrollo (BAfD) espera que el producto interior bruto (PIB) de √Åfrica crezca un 3,9 % en 2025, por encima del 3,3 % registrado el pasado a√±o. La incertidumbre causada por la guerra arancelaria del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, ha llevado al organismo a reducir sus previsiones de crecimiento del continente desde enero. Las expectativas de un 3,9 % de crecimiento del PIB para 2025 y un 4,0 % para 2026 suponen, respectivamente, una rebaja de 0,2 y 0,4 puntos porcentuales respecto a las proyecciones del BAfD a principios de a√±o. Se espera que 21 pa√≠ses africanos vean sus econom√≠as crecer m√°s de un 5 % en 2025 y cuatro de ellos -Etiop√≠a, N√≠ger, Ruanda y Senegal- podr√≠an alcanzar el 7 %. El BAfD subray√≥ en su informe que, "desde enero de 2025, el mundo ha experimentado nuevas perturbaciones que han agravado un panorama macroecon√≥mico ya de por s√≠ complejo", incluyendo "una pl√©tora de nuevos aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos y medidas de represalia anunciadas e implementadas por sus socios comerciales". La inmensa mayor√≠a de los 54 estados soberanos de √Åfrica se han visto afectados por las tarifas de Trump, mientras la congelaci√≥n de ayuda internacional ordenada en enero por el mandatario ha puesto en peligro millones de vidas en el continente, seg√∫n el banco. El banco denunci√≥ tambi√©n en la nueva edici√≥n de su informe anual, el alto coste que tiene que asumir √Åfrica para acceder al capital y reclam√≥ una "reforma de c√≥mo se hacen las calificaciones de riesgo". "El pago de la deuda exterior est√° desviando nuestros recursos fiscales de la gobernanza habitual de los pa√≠ses, para impulsar la educaci√≥n, la sanidad y todo lo dem√°s", alert√≥ Urama. "La financiaci√≥n en condiciones favorables y el acceso a subvenciones que ayudan a muchos pa√≠ses africanos a desarrollarse est√°n disminuyendo", agreg√≥, al se√±alar que los anuncios recientes por parte de diferentes pa√≠ses que suelen proporcionar ayuda oficial al desarrollo podr√≠an indicar una p√©rdida estimada de 4.200 millones de d√≥lares para √Åfrica. La reuni√≥n se celebra en Abiy√°n, donde se encuentra la sede del banco, entre este lunes 26 de mayo y hasta el pr√≥ximo d√≠a 30. Se espera la asistencia de unos 6.000 delegados de 91 pa√≠ses, incluyendo jefes de Estado africanos, ministros de Finanzas, gobernadores de bancos centrales y representantes del sector privado y del sector humanitario y del desarrollo, as√≠ como l√≠deres de la sociedad civil, acad√©micos y medios de comunicaci√≥n.

En el mismo periodo de 2024, se registr√≥ el paso de 7 mil 849 migrantes en situaci√≥n irregular, lo que implica un decremento de 76.7 por ciento.

En el 76 por ciento de los casos, las personas fueron presentadas ante la autoridad migratoria en Piedras Negras.

Durante el primer trimestre de 2025, se realizaron 11 deportaciones de personas migrantes, lo cual implic√≥ un decremento de 72 por ciento en comparaci√≥n con el mismo periodo del a√±o anterior, cuando se registraron 40 retornos.

content: Washington. El mandatario estadunidense, Donald Trump, calific√≥ el martes de positiva la medida de la Uni√≥n Europea (UE) de establecer reuniones comerciales y dijo que espera que Europa ‚Äúse abra‚Äù al ...
resumen:
El mandatario estadunidense, Donald Trump, calific√≥ el martes de positiva la medida de la Uni√≥n Europea (UE) de establecer reuniones comerciales y dijo que espera que Europa ‚Äúse abra‚Äù al comercio con Estados Unidos, aunque reiter√≥ su amenaza de imponer unilateralmente condiciones si no se logra un acuerdo.

title: Want to destroy American business? Protect it, writes Carl Benedikt Frey
content: D ONALD TRUMP insists that tariffs will bring back jobs and revitalise American industry, and that short-term pain would be worth it for long-term gain. Yet history suggests they are more likely to ...
resumen:
Donald Trump insists that tariffs will bring back jobs and revitalize American industry, and that short-term pain would be worth it for long-term gain.

History suggests tariffs are more likely to steepen America‚Äôs slide into stagnation.

Oren Cass argues that the United States transformed from colonial backwater to continent-spanning industrial colossus behind some of the world‚Äôs highest tariff barriers.

Thomas Jefferson‚Äôs trade embargo in 1807, followed by the war of 1812 with Britain, jump-started American industrialization.

America‚Äôs early industrial gains owed far more to pirated British technology and welcoming European talent than to protectionism.

Trade restrictions ensured that small-scale textile mills were persistently inefficient.

These mills collapsed once trade resumed because they could not compete with superior British imports.

Samuel Slater, an immigrant from Britain, memorized the country‚Äôs textile-machinery designs and established America‚Äôs first cotton mills.

Francis Cabot Lowell secretly replicated British power-loom technology.

By 1980, Ford and General Motors recorded combined annual losses exceeding $1.3bn (over $5bn today).

Japanese car workers had become 17% more productive than American ones.

America‚Äôs share of global semiconductor production dropped from 57% in 1977 to just 40% by 1989, while Japan‚Äôs share almost doubled to 50%.

Japan‚Äôs manufacturing edge came not from unfair trade practices but from innovation: lean production techniques (like Toyota‚Äôs just-in-time system) and a talent for refining foreign inventions (Sony‚Äôs Walkman and VCR were adaptations of Western innovations).

Silicon Valley pivoted to innovation, design and software development.

It offshored assembly to low-cost East Asian manufacturers, especially in China.

Britain remained out of the European Economic Community until 1973, shielding domestic industries from competition.

Weak competition policy enabled widespread cartelisation, resulting in persistently low productivity growth.

Britain fell behind more open and competitive economies like West Germany and France, both of which had overtaken Britain‚Äôs GDP per person by the 1970s.

Three-quarters of American industries had become more concentrated than they were in the highly competitive era of the 1990s computer boom.

Spending on corporate lobbying has risen by almost two-thirds in real terms since the late 1990s.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs selective, sector-specific tariffs have set off a scramble for exemptions.

America may dominate electronic-design-automation software but Japan produces 56% of global silicon wafers, Taiwan makes 95% of advanced chips and China processes over 90% of critical minerals and magnets.

The tariffs in Mr. Trump‚Äôs first term ultimately caused a net loss in American jobs.

Duties on essential inputs, such as Canadian steel, only drive up costs and weaken American competitiveness.

About half of American imports directly support domestic manufacturing, and hence American exports.

In America, the five biggest companies average just 39 years old, and are all technology firms.

In Japan, the five biggest companies are, on average, 84 years old, 116 in Britain, 120 in Germany and 152 in France.

title: Why Japan sees President Trump's tariffs as a 'national crisis'
content: Although largely paused, President Trump's tariffs present a major threat to Japan's already flagging economy.
resumen: Robert Ward, the Japan chair at the London-based think tank the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS), states that since President Trump's "Liberation Day" tariffs, there has been alarm in Japan. Japan sees the U.S. as its most important export market, accounting for around 20% of all Japanese exports. Trump's tariffs present a major threat to Japan's already flagging economy. Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has described the situation as a "national crisis." Ishiba has come under pressure from Japan's opposition parties. Two important elections loom in July: the Tokyo assembly poll and the upper house of Japan's parliament. The LDP with its coalition partner, Komeito, has been a minority government since its poor performance in last year's general election. Japan's room for maneuver in tariff negotiations with the U.S. is limited. Japan's gross domestic product is only just over a 10th the size of the U.S. The U.S. is a major supplier of food, raw materials and mineral fuels to Japan, accounting for some 30% of Japan's overall import bill from the U.S. Japan needs to preserve its security relationship with Washington. The U.S. is Japan's only security treaty ally. Japan is unlikely to seek warmer ties with China. Tokyo's concerns about Beijing's intentions toward Taiwan have been mentioned. Intensifying Chinese intrusions into waters around Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands are also causing alarm in Tokyo. Japan could agree to increase imports of U.S. agricultural goods. Resource-poor Japan could also agree to import more liquefied natural gas (LNG) from the U.S., or to help fund an LNG project in Alaska. Some concessions on non-tariff barriers to the imports of U.S.-made cars into Japan also look likely. Ishiba promised to raise Japan's investment in the U.S. to "an unprecedented amount" of $1 trillion. Japan is the largest economy in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) mega trade bloc. Japan's membership of Asia's other mega trade bloc, the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), is also strategically important for Tokyo.

El 14 de mayo, el mandatario izquierdista firm√≥ la adhesi√≥n de Colombia a la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta, un multimillonario programa comercial y de inversiones de Pek√≠n en el extranjero.

title: Los aranceles de Trump tendr√°n un impacto negativo en la balanza energ√©tica argentina

resumen:
El presidente de Ecuador, Daniel Noboa, ratific√≥ a la mayor√≠a de sus ministros para el inicio del nuevo mandato 2025-2029.

En el nuevo Gobierno ecuatoriano repiten pr√°cticamente todos los ministros salvo excepciones como el ministro de Salud, Edgar Lama, reemplazado por Juan S√°nchez, y la ministra de Ambiente, Agua y Transici√≥n Ecol√≥gica, Mar√≠a Cristina Recalde, reemplazada por Mar√≠a Luisa Cruz.

title: ‚ÄúMisiles, patriotas y mercados: el mundo entra en su zona roja‚Äù
content: La guerra en Ucrania entra en una fase cr√≠tica: Alemania habilita ataques dentro de Rusia y Trump impulsa un discurso b√©lico. ¬øC√≥mo responder√° Mosc√∫? ¬øQu√© lugar ocupa Am√©rica Latina ante un tablero gl ...
resumen:
La guerra en Ucrania ha cruzado un umbral cr√≠tico. El "fuego de largo alcance" es una luz verde geoestrat√©gica. Alemania ha dado v√≠a libre para que Ucrania ataque dentro del territorio ruso. Europa ya no busca paz, sino una victoria a cualquier precio.

Esta escalada se ve alimentada desde Estados Unidos, donde el regreso de Donald Trump y su secretario de Defensa, Pete Hegseth, se ha visto acompa√±ado de un discurso brutalmente frontal. En el D√≠a de los Ca√≠dos, desde el Cementerio de Arlington, la nueva c√∫pula del poder norteamericano no habl√≥ de contenci√≥n, sino de prepararse para la guerra. Trump apel√≥ al ‚Äúsacrificio eterno‚Äù y la necesidad de mantener viva la llama nacionalista.

La decisi√≥n alemana genera un quiebre estrat√©gico: por primera vez desde el inicio del conflicto, un pa√≠s del G7 respalda oficialmente ataques contra Rusia en su propio territorio. Mosc√∫ ha anunciado que toda Europa occidental podr√≠a ser considerada zona de retorsi√≥n militar. Vladimir Putin ha endurecido su narrativa.

La OTAN se mueve con ambig√ºedad peligrosa. La pol√≠tica exterior europea est√° cada vez m√°s supeditada a su relaci√≥n comercial con Estados Unidos. Alemania, el principal exportador europeo al mercado norteamericano (161.200 millones de euros en 2024), se convierte en una bisagra entre la guerra y el comercio.

Am√©rica Latina, atrapada entre el fuego cruzado de potencias nucleares, vuelve a ser espectadora de una guerra que podr√≠a desatar consecuencias econ√≥micas y sociales sin precedentes. La tensi√≥n b√©lica ha provocado un nuevo desbalance en el comercio internacional. Las exportaciones europeas a Estados Unidos, dominadas por medicamentos, autos y maquinaria, desangran el equilibrio global. Los precios de alimentos, energ√≠a y materias primas se disparan, afectando particularmente a las econom√≠as m√°s vulnerables.

Pa√≠ses como Argentina, Brasil, Colombia o M√©xico deber√°n enfrentar esta tormenta con estrategias de contenci√≥n social, planificaci√≥n energ√©tica y autonom√≠a tecnol√≥gica. La regi√≥n necesita un nuevo proyecto: ni vasallaje financiero ni aislamiento, sino integraci√≥n solidaria y soberan√≠a productiva.

La historia del h√©roe colectivo que resiste una invasi√≥n invisible se vuelve met√°fora perfecta para estos tiempos. La guerra no necesita ej√©rcitos en nuestras calles: su fuego nos alcanza v√≠a inflaci√≥n, dependencia tecnol√≥gica y fuga de capitales.

Los ingresos tributarios en Latinoam√©rica disminuyeron como proporci√≥n del PIB hasta el 21,3 % en 2023, como consecuencia de la desaceleraci√≥n econ√≥mica en la regi√≥n y de la ca√≠da en los precios globales de las materias primas, seg√∫n la Comisi√≥n Econ√≥mica para Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe (Cepal).

La cifra representa una disminuci√≥n de 0,2 puntos porcentuales respecto al nivel de 2022 y se sit√∫a ligeramente por debajo del nivel previo a la pandemia (21,4 % en 2019) y lejos del promedio en los pa√≠ses de la Organizaci√≥n para la Cooperaci√≥n y el Desarrollo Econ√≥micos -OCDE- (33,9 % en 2023).

En el informe "Estad√≠sticas Tributarias en Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe 2025", la Cepal se√±al√≥ que los ingresos tributarios como porcentaje del PIB en la regi√≥n oscilaron entre el 11,6 % en Guyana y el 32 % en Brasil. La cifra disminuy√≥ en 14 de los 26 pa√≠ses incluidos en el informe, siendo Chile y Per√∫ los que registraron las mayores ca√≠das, con 3,2 y 2,1 puntos porcentuales, respectivamente.

La disminuci√≥n general de los ingresos tributarios como proporci√≥n del PIB en la regi√≥n se debi√≥ a una ca√≠da en los ingresos por impuestos sobre la renta, especialmente en algunos de los principales pa√≠ses productores de hidrocarburos y minerales.

Los ingresos por impuestos sobre la renta disminuyeron en promedio 0,1 % del PIB en 2023, mientras que las contribuciones a la seguridad social aumentaron en 0,1 puntos porcentuales y los ingresos por impuestos sobre bienes y servicios se mantuvieron sin cambios como proporci√≥n del PIB.

Los ingresos relacionados con hidrocarburos descendieron a un promedio de 3,9 % del PIB en 2023 (desde 4,4 % del PIB en 2022) entre los diez principales pa√≠ses productores de petr√≥leo de la regi√≥n, mientras que los ingresos derivados de la miner√≠a bajaron a 0,59 % del PIB (desde 0,74 % del PIB en 2022).

La Cepal recort√≥ a finales de abril en cuatro d√©cimas su previsi√≥n de crecimiento regional para este a√±o y redujo su estimaci√≥n al 2 % debido a la guerra comercial.

Latinoam√©rica cerr√≥ 2023 y 2024 con un crecimiento del 2,3 %.

title: ASEAN leaders agree tariff deals with US should not harm fellow members
content: Southeast Asian leaders reached an understanding on Tuesday that any bilateral agreements they might strike with the United States on trade tariffs would not harm the economies of fellow members, ...
resumen:
Southeast Asian leaders reached an understanding on Tuesday that any bilateral agreements they might strike with the United States on trade tariffs would not harm the economies of fellow members, Malaysia‚Äôs premier Anwar Ibrahim said.

Anwar, the current chair of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, said there was consensus during an ASEAN summit in Kuala Lumpur that any deals negotiated with Washington would ensure the interests of the region as a whole were protected.

The ASEAN meeting came at a time of global market volatility and slowing economic growth, and amid uncertainty over a trade war that has ensued since U.S. President Donald Trump‚Äôs announcement of sweeping ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù tariffs.

Southeast Asia is among the regions hardest hit by the tariffs, with six of its countries facing levies of between 32% and 49% in July if negotiations on reductions fail.

‚ÄúWhile proceeding with bilateral negotiations ‚Ä¶, the consensus rose to have some sort of understanding with ASEAN that decisions should not be at the expense of any other country,‚Äù said Anwar, who on Monday said he had written to Trump requesting an ASEAN-U.S. meeting on the tariffs.

‚ÄúSo we will have to protect the turf of 650 or 660 million people,‚Äù he said of ASEAN.

ASEAN, a region with combined gross domestic product of more than $3.8 trillion, is in a precarious position in relation to the United States, which is the biggest market for the region‚Äôs exports, key drivers of its growth.

The 10-member bloc on Tuesday released a five-year strategic plan to better integrate its economies, citing challenges that meant ‚Äúcarrying on business as usual will not suffice‚Äù.

Tuesday‚Äôs meetings also included an economic gathering of leaders of the ASEAN, Gulf countries and China, which was represented by Premier Li Qiang.

One absentee was Brunei‚Äôs 78-year-old ruler, Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah, who was admitted to a Kuala Lumpur hospital after feeling tired, but was in good health according to his office.

At a dinner event late on Tuesday, China‚Äôs Li urged Gulf and ASEAN countries to remove trade barriers and expand liberalization in the face of rising protectionism and unilateralism.

ASEAN leaders also called for a temporary ceasefire in army-ruled Myanmar to be expanded nationwide, to enable warring sides to build trust and work towards convening dialogue.

Myanmar has been in crisis since its military overthrew an elected civilian government in 2021, triggering pro-democracy protests that morphed into a widening rebellion, with more than 3.5 million people displaced.

A devastating earthquake in March that killed more than 3,800 people led to a series of temporary ceasefires in affected areas of Myanmar, but the military government has continued air strikes and artillery attacks.

‚ÄúWe further called for the sustained extension and nationwide expansion of the ceasefire in Myanmar, as an initial step towards the cessation of violence,‚Äù ASEAN leaders said in a statement.

‚ÄúWe encouraged all relevant stakeholders in Myanmar to build trust towards convening an inclusive national dialogue.‚Äù

Anwar hailed ‚Äúsignificant‚Äù engagement steps on Myanmar on Monday after last month holding a closed-door meeting in Bangkok with junta chief Min Aung Hlaing and virtual talks with the rebel-aligned shadow National Unity Government.

On Tuesday, Anwar said ASEAN leaders had agreed that the path forward was to engage all sides in Myanmar.

title: El drag√≥n chino seduce a LAC
content: La IV Reuni√≥n Ministerial del Foro China-CELAC marca un hito en las relaciones econ√≥micas bilaterales. Objetivo del gigante asi√°tico: consolidarse como socio estrat√©gico. Tras siete a√±os sin encuentro ...
resumen: La IV Reuni√≥n Ministerial del Foro China-CELAC marca un hito en las relaciones econ√≥micas bilaterales. El objetivo del gigante asi√°tico es consolidarse como socio estrat√©gico. Tras siete a√±os sin encuentros presenciales, esta reuni√≥n se celebr√≥ en Pek√≠n el 13 de mayo. En un contexto de proteccionismo global y tensiones con EE. UU., la reuni√≥n ofrece alternativas a inversi√≥n e intercambio. En 2024, el comercio bilateral alcanz√≥ un r√©cord de USD 518 400M. China proporcionar√° l√≠neas directas de cr√©dito de m√°s de USD 9000M, inversiones directas y expansi√≥n de la cooperaci√≥n en sectores clave. Aboga por la reconfiguraci√≥n de las cadenas de suministro y el impulso a un multilateralismo en crisis. El presidente Xi Jinping subraya la importancia de la interconexi√≥n el√©ctrica y las energ√≠as renovables. Ello se alinea con los objetivos de la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI, por sus siglas en ingl√©s), para integrar a los miembros de CELAC en una red global de comercio e infraestructura. China pretende aparecer como un socio m√°s estable y predecible que EE. UU. Critica las pol√≠ticas proteccionistas y conductas intimidatorias que, seg√∫n Xi, conducen al aislacionismo. Este enfoque sirve a Pek√≠n para atraer a pa√≠ses del √°rea que anhelan diversificar las relaciones, reduciendo su dependencia de mercados tradicionales. Se fortalecen los v√≠nculos en comercio agr√≠cola, infraestructura y tecnolog√≠a. Brasil, Argentina y Uruguay podr√≠an beneficiarse del aumento de las exportaciones agr√≠colas. Algunos de los ejemplos m√°s visibles de colaboraci√≥n pr√°ctica son los m√°s de 200 proyectos de infraestructura, millones de puestos de trabajo creados y los TLC con varias naciones latinoamericanas. Existen preocupaciones sobre el riesgo de endeudamiento excesivo y la dependencia econ√≥mica de Pek√≠n. La presi√≥n de EE. UU. para restringir la cooperaci√≥n a√±ade complejidad a las decisiones clave de la regi√≥n. Washington ha logrado que Panam√° se retirara de la BRI. Adem√°s, ha expresado su oposici√≥n a la posible adhesi√≥n de Colombia. Guatemala enfrenta una situaci√≥n particular, entre la diplomacia tradicional y las oportunidades econ√≥micas. Es uno de los pocos en la regi√≥n que mantiene relaciones diplom√°ticas con Taiw√°n. La CIG, junto con otras organizaciones empresariales regionales, ha expresado su preocupaci√≥n de que una mayor cercan√≠a con China pueda afectar las relaciones comerciales con EE. UU. Se intensifica el nexo China-CELAC lo que constituye un reto para la influencia econ√≥mica de EE. UU. Pek√≠n est√° dispuesto a invertir en el desarrollo de la zona, si bien persisten preocupaciones sobre los riesgos aludidos. La respuesta proteccionista de la administraci√≥n Trump, imponiendo aranceles de hasta un 50 % a productos de China es una amenaza real. De generalizarse y prolongarse, una guerra comercial podr√≠a reducir hasta un 7 % el PIB global. Los pa√≠ses de CELAC se√±alizan su voluntad de reducir dependencias y diversificar mercados.

title: Delegaci√≥n de Guatemala inicia reuniones en EE. UU. por tema arancelario

UU., Donald Trump. title: Guatemala negocia con EE. UU. eliminaci√≥n de arancel del 10% y delegaci√≥n oficial se reuni√≥ con Jameson Greer, representante del USTR
content: La delegaci√≥n del gobierno de Guatemala inici√≥ oficialmente este 27 de mayo las conversaciones con las autoridades de comercio de Estados Unidos para que se elimine el arancel del 10% para la ...
resumen:
El 27 de mayo de 2025, la delegaci√≥n del gobierno de Guatemala inici√≥ oficialmente las conversaciones con las autoridades de comercio de Estados Unidos para que se elimine el arancel del 10% para la importaci√≥n de productos guatemaltecos a ese pa√≠s.

Los funcionarios de Guatemala como la ministra de Econom√≠a, Gabriela Garc√≠a; el ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, Carlos Ramiro Mart√≠nez; y el Embajador de Guatemala en Washington, Hugo Beteta, se reunieron con el Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR), embajador Jameson Greer, para negociar eliminaci√≥n de aranceles del 10%.

La reuni√≥n se llev√≥ a cabo con el Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR), embajador Jameson Greer y su equipo.

En la reuni√≥n con USTR el Gobierno de Guatemala confirm√≥ la solicitud formal para iniciar el di√°logo con el objeto de abordar los temas relacionados con el arancel del 10% y las barreras no arancelarias.

La comitiva de Guatemala es encabezada por el ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, Carlos Ramiro Mart√≠nez y la ministra de Econom√≠a, Gabriela Garc√≠a, quienes participaron en la reuni√≥n junto al Embajador de Guatemala en Washington, Hugo Beteta.

El gobierno de Guatemala entreg√≥ el informe que responde a las √°reas identificadas en el m√°s reciente reporte anual de barreras comerciales que fue elaborado por el USTR, que incluyen acciones en materia de modernizaci√≥n aduanera, facilitaci√≥n del comercio, mejora de est√°ndares y fitosanitarios, protecci√≥n a la propiedad intelectual y modernizaci√≥n portuaria.

El embajador Greer reconoci√≥ la estrategia planteada por Guatemala y expres√≥ satisfacci√≥n de contar, desde el inicio, con una hoja de ruta y resultados concretos obtenidos a la fecha.

La comitiva de Guatemala est√° acompa√±ada por alrededor de 15 delegados del sector privado del pa√≠s, que incluye directivos del Comit√© Coordinador de Asociaciones Agr√≠colas, Comerciales, Industriales y Financieras (Cacif) y diferentes c√°maras empresariales.

En reuni√≥n entre funcionarios de ambos pa√≠ses Guatemala present√≥ el informe de acciones ‚Äúque da respuesta a las preocupaciones expresadas en el m√°s reciente reporte de barreras comerciales‚Äù y una carta de respaldo firmada por empresas guatemaltecas y estadounidenses que apoyan la solicitud de restablecer el acceso preferencial a productos de exportaci√≥n de Guatemala.

La delegaci√≥n de los sectores p√∫blico y privado sostendr√°n alrededor de 20 reuniones durante esta semana con asociaciones empresariales, agencias del Gobierno de Estados Unidos y representantes del Congreso de dicho pa√≠s.

title: La confianza del consumidor en EEUU repunta tras 5 meses de ca√≠das y tensiones arancelarias
content: La confianza del consumidor en Estados Unidos registr√≥ un aumento de 12,3 puntos en mayo, alcanzando un √≠ndice de 98. Este repunte se da tras cinco meses de ca√≠das por el impacto de los aranceles.
resumen:
La confianza del consumidor en Estados Unidos registr√≥ un aumento de 12,3 puntos en mayo, alcanzando un √≠ndice de 98. Este repunte se da tras cinco meses de ca√≠das por el impacto de los aranceles.

El √≠ndice de confianza del consumidor, seg√∫n el informe de The Conference Board publicado el martes, se increment√≥ 12,3 puntos en mayo, alcanzando un valor de 98 en comparaci√≥n con 85,7 en abril, el m√°s bajo desde mayo de 2020, durante el punto cr√≠tico de la pandemia.

La medida que refleja las expectativas a corto plazo de los estadounidenses con respecto a sus ingresos, las condiciones empresariales y el mercado laboral creci√≥ 17,4 puntos, posicion√°ndose en 72,8.

El porcentaje de consumidores que consideran que una recesi√≥n es probable en Estados Unidos dentro de los pr√≥ximos 12 meses tambi√©n se redujo con respecto a abril.

Las medidas de pol√≠tica agresiva implementadas por Trump, incluidas las altas tasas de importaci√≥n, han oscurecido las perspectivas de la econom√≠a y el mercado laboral, intensificando los temores sobre una posible recesi√≥n.

Trump hab√≠a anunciado previamente un arancel del 145% sobre la mayor√≠a de los bienes provenientes de China, pero acord√≥ un paro de 90 d√≠as para llevar a cabo negociaciones. Adem√°s, Estados Unidos alcanz√≥ acuerdos con el Reino Unido y la Uni√≥n Europea.

The Conference Board destac√≥ que el incremento en la confianza de este mes se sinti√≥ en todos los grupos de edad e ingresos.

Las opiniones de los consumidores sobre la situaci√≥n econ√≥mica actual tambi√©n mostraron mejoras, aunque las percepciones sobre la disponibilidad de empleo se deterioraron por quinto mes consecutivo, pese a que se report√≥ un s√≥lido informe laboral reciente en el pa√≠s.

Menos del 25% de los consultados expresaron inquietudes sobre perder su empleo, en contraste con el 50% que manifest√≥ su preocupaci√≥n por no poder adquirir los productos necesarios o deseados.

El Departamento de Trabajo inform√≥ que los empleadores estadounidenses incorporaron 177.000 nuevos puestos de trabajo en abril, manteniendo una tasa de desempleo del 4,2%.

title: Trump pospone aranceles del 50% a la Uni√≥n Europea hasta julio
content: Donald Trump anunci√≥ la postergaci√≥n de los aranceles del 50% a productos europeos hasta el 9 de julio, luego de una llamada con Ursula von der Leyen.
resumen: Donald Trump anunci√≥ la postergaci√≥n de los aranceles del 50% a productos europeos hasta el 9 de julio, luego de una llamada con Ursula von der Leyen. La decisi√≥n busca evitar una escalada en la guerra comercial y ha generado alivio en los mercados financieros. El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, decidi√≥ retrasar la implementaci√≥n de aranceles del 50% a las importaciones de la Uni√≥n Europea, inicialmente previstos para el 1 de junio. La nueva fecha l√≠mite es el 9 de julio, otorgando a ambas partes un margen para avanzar en las negociaciones comerciales. La decisi√≥n se produjo tras una conversaci√≥n telef√≥nica entre Trump y la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, quien solicit√≥ m√°s tiempo para alcanzar un acuerdo. ‚ÄúTuvimos una llamada muy agradable y acord√© retrasarlo‚Äù, declar√≥ Trump, destacando la disposici√≥n de la UE para entablar negociaciones serias. Por su parte, von der Leyen expres√≥ en redes sociales que la Uni√≥n Europea est√° lista para avanzar r√°pidamente en las conversaciones, subrayando la importancia de la relaci√≥n comercial transatl√°ntica. La decisi√≥n de Trump fue recibida con alivio por parte de los l√≠deres europeos. El primer ministro italiano, Giorgia Meloni, propuso una cumbre entre l√≠deres de la UE y Trump durante la pr√≥xima reuni√≥n de la OTAN en junio, buscando consolidar un acuerdo antes de la nueva fecha l√≠mite. Los mercados financieros reaccionaron positivamente al anuncio. Las bolsas europeas registraron alzas, con el DAX alem√°n subiendo un 1,5% y el CAC 40 franc√©s un 1%. En Estados Unidos, los futuros del S\&P 500 y el Nasdaq tambi√©n mostraron incrementos, reflejando el optimismo de los inversores ante la posibilidad de evitar una escalada en la guerra comercial.

title: La movida de Christian y Yuyo Daes para que Tecnoglass siga imparable con sus ventanas en la Florida

title: Trump's tax bill jeopardises clean power factory plans
content: Tax credit cuts in President Trump's budget bill have slowed the expansion of U.S. clean energy manufacturing, risking efforts to establish a fully American supply chain.
resumen:
Cuts to tax credits in President Trump's House budget bill are curtailing the rapid expansion in U.S. clean energy manufacturing capacity.

Biden's 2022 Inflation Reduction Act accelerated solar, wind and battery storage deployment and spurred new clean energy manufacturing projects. The act provides tax credits to clean power developers, incentives to buy domestic content and offers 45X advanced manufacturing production tax credits to suppliers that build factories in the United States.

Trump‚Äôs House budget bill proposes to speed up the expiry of the tax credits for developers and block the 45X manufacturing tax credits from going to foreign entities of concern (FEOC). The bill was narrowly approved by the House of Representatives on May 22.

Manufacturers have spent more than $321 billion in clean technology manufacturing since the inflation act was introduced in 2022. A total of 2,369 new clean energy manufacturing, utility-scale clean electricity and industrial decarbonisation facilities have opened since 2022, creating nearly 13,000 jobs in Texas and 12,500 in Georgia.

Many manufacturers are pausing expansion plans until the final bill is approved by Congress.

The proposed block on manufacturing credits for foreign entities of concern seems to apply to Chinese-owned companies and also companies ‚Äúthat have a licensing agreement with or receive any material assistance from a Chinese-owned company‚Äù and this would impact a significant amount of existing and planned U.S. solar manufacturing capacity.

For solar manufacturer Heliene, major amendments to the 45X production tax credits are the first concern, but the accelerated expiry of other tax credits would "also directly affect demand.‚Äù Heliene and Indian partner Premier Energies plan to develop the first module manufacturing chain to use U.S.-made polysilicon, wafers and cells but the final decision is still pending.

Manufacturers have already held back investments following Trump‚Äôs appointment as President, due to looming tax credit cuts and a raft of import tariff announcements.

Almost $8 billion in investment and 16 new large-scale clean energy factories and other projects were cancelled, closed, or downsized in Q1 2025.

President Trump has raised import tariffs to boost American manufacturing and gain leverage in international trade but volatile trade policies have deterred investors and U.S. clean energy manufacturers will likely face increased costs if the tariffs are implemented as proposed.

China dominates the global supply of solar components and imports into the United States from China and Southeast Asian countries, where many Chinese companies have relocated production, are subject to tariffs and antidumping and countervailing duties. President Trump has imposed an additional 30% tariff on imports from China as well as a 25% tariff on all steel and aluminium imports.

The inflation act led to a rapid increase in U.S. module production capacity, reaching 55 GW in May 2025, compared with just 8 GW in 2022. The U.S. is forecast to install around 40 GW of solar capacity per year in the coming years.

U.S. solar cell production capacity was just 8 GW/year in Q1 2025.

U.S. polysilicon capacity is currently around 26 GW/year but there is minimal wafer production capacity.

President Trump waylaid the burgeoning U.S. offshore wind sector by pausing the review of leases and permits and ordering the review of approved projects.

The Department of Interior rescinded a stop work order on Equinor's $5 billion Empire Wind project off New York.

Empire Wind will consist of 54 large offshore wind turbines of capacity 15 MW and the manufacturing facility will create up to 550 direct jobs.

title: Proactive approach to trade talks in a shifting global economy
content: The global trade landscape is witnessing significant disruptions following Trump's tariffs, with countries navigating the fallout and rearranging trade relations in a post-American world trade order.
resumen:
The global trade landscape is witnessing significant disruptions following Trump's tariffs. Countries are navigating the fallout and rearranging trade relations in a post-American world trade order.

United States President Donald Trump's aggressive tariff offensive, initiated on April 2, has sent shockwaves through the global trade system. Rooted in the Grievance Doctrine, these tariffs have ushered in a period of uncertainty and instability. This approach lacks a sound economic rationale and risks upsetting the multilateral trade system. The Grievance Doctrine underscores a shift toward protectionism in US trade policy.

The actions of nations in response to the disruptions from these tariffs have led to a reshaping of global trade dynamics, revealing new political economic pressures at play. Trump's tariff-driven approach also risks undermining long-term investments, disrupting supply chains and straining relationships with trading partners, including Indonesia. The erratic decision-making and lack of a coherent strategy have put the US on a path away from a rules-based global trade system toward protectionism, with repercussions felt globally.

Indonesia finds itself at a critical juncture in the shifting global trade landscape following the aftermath of Trump's tariff offensive and the resultant recalibration in international trade dynamics. As the country adapts to a post-American world trade order fraught with new political and economic pressures, it faces substantial challenges outlined in the US Trade Representatives (USTR) Report 2025, which underscore areas of improvement across various trade-related aspects such as tariffs, non-tariff barriers, technical barriers, intellectual property protection and more.

The recent developments in the US-China Trade War, featuring a temporary 90-day "ceasefire" agreement, add another layer of complexity to Indonesia's trade strategies. The conflict, initiated by Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum in March 2018, triggered retaliatory actions from China, leading to escalating tensions and subsequent negotiations. Despite signing a Phase One Deal aimed at reducing tariffs and boosting US exports to China, disagreements over compliance have reignited friction, leaving Indonesia in a delicate balancing act amid threats of reciprocal tariffs and sovereignty concerns.

title: European Midday Briefing: Stocks Edge Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
content: Consumer prices were 0.6% higher on year this month, down from 0.9% in April, according to EU-harmonized figures published Tuesday by France's statistics agency Insee. Economists had expected May's ...
resumen:
European stocks ticked higher Tuesday on easing trade tensions, with Germany's DAX hitting a record high. The European Union agreed yesterday to fast-track talks with the U.S., after President Trump on Sunday pushed back plans to impose a 50% tariff on the bloc.

Stock futures rose as markets returned following the Memorial Day holiday. All eyes will be on a consumer confidence survey for May. Another preliminary survey from University of Michigan released earlier pointed towards further weakening in consumer sentiment in early May.

The euro slipped against the dollar. The dollar fell as uncertainty over U.S. tariffs remains elevated. The DXY dollar index could fall to 98.000.

The 10-year Bund yield fell, and is expected to hover around 2.5% for now amid trade difficulties between the U.S. and Europe. A fall to 2.2% is possible "if there is lasting re-escalation". UniCredit expects eurozone government bond supply to decline in June but to remain above 100 billion euros. Eurozone sovereigns have issued 660 billion euros in government bonds year-to-date, equivalent to more than 50% of their total issuance objectives for the year. Yields on U.K. government bonds fell, tracking moves in eurozone bonds, as trade tensions ease. Long-end Treasury yields dropped as investors returned to the market with caution, awaiting May's consumer confidence survey.

Oil prices slipped with investors looking ahead to OPEC's meeting on Sunday to review its supply agreement. Lower prices in 2025 through 2026 could lead to an earlier and lower peak for U.S. shale production, Goldman Sachs said.

Gold futures slumped, extending losses seen on Monday. Signs that Trump is easing his stance on trade with the EU has dented safe-haven demand, ANZ said.

The U.S. Marines recently took position in a field on this sleepy Swedish island about 200 miles from the Russian city of Kaliningrad and fired their mobile rocket system.

Thyssenkrupp plans to make all of its divisions independent and open to outside investment, a major overhaul that aims to turn the German industrial group into a holding company after more than two centuries as a manufacturer. The company said Monday that it would start preparations to separate its materials-services and automotive-technology segments in the coming years and that its decarbonization-technologies unit would follow suit. It aims to retain a majority interest in its businesses in the medium term.

Consumer sentiment in Germany improved a little as wage expectations grew and views of the economic outlook calmed, despite the uncertainty provoked by President Trump's tariff policies, a monthly survey said Tuesday. The consumer-climate index published by research groups GfK and the Nuremberg Institute for Market Decisions ticked up for a third straight month to minus 19.9 in June's forecast, 0.9 points higher than in May. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected the measure a little stronger, at minus 19.6.

French inflation cooled more than expected in May, likely clearing the way to an expected European Central Bank interest-rate cut next month. Consumer prices were 0.6% higher on year this month, down from 0.9% in April, according to EU-harmonized figures published Tuesday by France's statistics agency Insee. Economists had expected May's rate to stay at 0.9%, according to economists polled by The Wall Street Journal.

To weather a trade war with the U.S., China is looking to its own consumers to keep the economy churning. Beijing has made bolstering domestic consumption a top policy priority for the first time, promising efforts to boost household spending. In one initiative this year, the government allocated 300 billion yuan, equivalent to around $42 billion, to expand a program that pays shoppers to trade in old vehicles or electronics for new ones.

Europe must maintain a steadfast commitment to open trade and bolster its legal and institutional foundations to raise the profile of the euro currency as confidence in the dominance of the U.S. dollar wanes, according to European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde.

President Trump on Monday said he was considering taking billions in grant money away from Harvard University and redistributing it to trade schools across the U.S.

President Trump posted on his Truth Social platform early on Memorial Day: "I am considering taking Three Billion Dollars of Grant Money away from a very antisemitic Harvard, and giving it to TRADE SCHOOLS all across our land".

Years before longtime Rep. Charlie Rangel became Harlem's longtime Democratic representative in Congress, he was an artillery specialist in the Korean War. In November 1950, near the North Korean village of Kunu-ri, the Chinese army encircled Rangel's unit. After being hit with shrapnel and leading dozens of soldiers to safety in a nighttime escape, Rangel was awarded a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star with valor.

The Air Force C-130 transport plane dipped down on the sun-baked airfield of this remote island in the northern Philippines, delivering a weapon system designed to give the U.S. an edge in the intensifying superpower standoff in the Pacific. The Navy-Marine Expeditionary Ship Interdiction System, or Nmesis, is an antiship missile launcher mounted on a remote-controlled truck. The dumbbell-shaped islet where it landed lies just 120 miles south of Taiwan.

title: Carney invites Mexico‚Äôs President to G7 summit, raising hopes for sideline tariff talks with Trump
content: Prime Minister Mark Carney has invited Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum to attend the Group of Seven Leaders‚Äô Summit in Kananaskis, Alta., next month, two sources familiar with the matter say.
resumen:
Prime Minister Mark Carney has invited Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum to attend the Group of Seven Leaders‚Äô Summit in Kananaskis, Alta., next month, according to two sources.
Ms. Sheinbaum‚Äôs inclusion would provide an opportunity for talks with U.S. President Donald Trump on his protectionist tariffs and the future of North America‚Äôs trilateral trade agreement.
It would be the first three-way meeting between the leaders of Canada, Mexico and the United States since Mr. Trump took office.
The Globe and Mail is not naming the two sources because they are not authorized to discuss the matter publicly.
Mexico‚Äôs embassy in Canada declined to confirm the invitation or to offer comment.
Goldy Hyder, president of the Business Council of Canada, has been pushing the Carney government to invite Ms. Sheinbaum to Kananaskis.
Mr. Hyder said that Mr. Trump has fondness for Ms. Sheinbaum.
The U.S. President‚Äôs trade war on Canada and Mexico, which began in March, is discouraging capital investment in Canadian industry and has driven up costs for consumers and businesses.
The G7 summit is being held just outside Calgary.
On May 6, during a face-to-face visit in Washington with Mr. Carney, Mr. Trump told journalists he‚Äôs not sure the trilateral United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) is still relevant.
In an interview with CBC‚Äôs Power and Politics on Tuesday, Mr. Carney said there have been intensive discussions since then to work out a trilateral trade deal.
He indicated that a deal could be struck before September.
Flavio Volpe, president of the Auto Parts Manufacturers Association, said he thinks the fact that Mr. Carney has invited Ms. Sheinbaum to the G7 indicates that continuing trade talks between Canada and the United States are going well.
Fen Hampson, a professor of international affairs at Carleton University, said he thinks future trade talks with the U.S. might lead to a set of sectoral agreements ‚Äì on autos, or steel ‚Äì that could potentially even replace the USMCA.
Mr. Hyder said the Prime Minister‚Äôs invitation to his Mexican counterpart will help repair strained relations because of mismanagement by former prime minister Justin Trudeau and comments of Premier Doug Ford.
Mr. Hyder has meet Ms. Sheinbaum on two recent occasions.
Mr. Hyder expects Mr. Trump will push hard for a common position on how to deal with China and its unfair trade practices.
Canada and Mexico have each been holding bilateral talks in Washington with the Trump administration on defence and security matters as well as critical minerals.
Mr. Hyder said International Trade Minister Dominic LeBlanc was in Washington last week for talks on these issues with U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick.
Canada‚Äôs ambassador to Washington, Kirsten Hillman, said earlier this month she sees discussions on security ‚Äì including the illegal distribution of fentanyl ‚Äì and matters such as critical minerals taking place separately from the renegotiation of the USCMA, which is up for renewal in 2026.
The current U.S. levies on Canada that remain in effect include 25-per-cent tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum, as well as a 25-per-cent tariff on Canadian-made vehicles, which applies only to the non-U.S. content in those cars and light trucks.
There is also a 25-per-cent tariff ‚Äì which drops to 10 per cent on critical minerals, energy and potash ‚Äì for goods that don‚Äôt comply with rules of origin in USMCA.
Canada responded with a series of countertariffs on tens of billions of dollars of U.S. imports.

title: Donald Trump steals Xi Jinping‚Äôs favourite foreign policy
content: In February Mr Trump halted graft investigations under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, blaming the law for erecting ‚Äúexcessive barriers to American commerce‚Äù. Though Mr Trump loves economic ...
resumen: China, a major economic and military power, often adopts a cautious and transactional approach to foreign policy, particularly in regions like the Middle East. This approach, focused on business deals and self-interest, has persisted under Xi Jinping, who presents China as a peace-loving giant to the world while emphasizing its global pre-eminence at home. China promotes prosperity through trade, technology, and infrastructure as a solution to regional conflicts, as seen with the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). China's foreign policy is often praised as "Chinese wisdom" by scholars. China has vetoed UN Security Council resolutions to impose sanctions on Syria. China's primary interest in Syria's civil war was the presence of Uyghur militants. China's response to problems is to call for mediation and suggest that Western intervention is the root cause. China favors opaque contracts and is a stingy aid donor. Donald Trump, the American president, shares a transactional approach to foreign policy, and is scornful of overseas aid. Trump praised Gulf Arab rulers for focusing on commerce rather than chaos. Trump halted graft investigations under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. China's economy is slowing, and BRI lending has peaked. China remains a major energy buyer and offers green technologies. Trump has given China cause to amp up the ideology, and push harder.

title: Tired of tariffs? 5 investments to step off the Trump tariff merry-go-round
content: Investors have seen a lot of volatility so far in 2025, as they try to grapple with the impact of new tariffs from the Trump administration on the economy. The S&P 500 rose to start the year, but fell ...
resumen:
In 2025, investors have seen volatility due to the impact of new tariffs from the Trump administration. The S&P 500 rose to start the year, but fell sharply, entering a bear market, following the announcement of the new tariffs on ‚ÄúLiberation Day.‚Äù The market has since recovered much of its losses.

Five tariff-resistant investments:

1.  **Gold:** Up more than 25 percent so far this year, and has risen about 6 percent since the tariffs were announced.
2.  **Real estate:** Real estate tends to be impacted more by local issues.
3.  **International stocks:** The Vanguard FTSE All-World ex-US ETF (VEU) is up about 14 percent this year as of mid-May, compared to a roughly 1 percent increase for the S&P 500.
4.  **Bonds:** Bonds may provide some protection during times of uncertainty.
5.  **Individual stocks or industries:** Tech companies such as Uber Technologies (UBER) and Netflix (NFLX) are up more than 45 and 30 percent, respectively, in 2025. Traditional defensive sectors such as consumer staples, health care and utilities may also be places to ride out the tariff storm.

title: iPhone exports from India to US surge 76% in April, but trade policies remain tricky
content: Omdia reports iPhone exports from India to the US rose 76% in April as Apple shifts assembly to India amid US-China trade tensions.
resumen:
iPhone exports from India to the US rose 76% in April.
Apple is shifting assembly from China to India amid trade tensions.
Apple plans to manufacture most US-sold iPhones in India.
Exports of iPhones from India to the United States rose by an estimated 76% year-on-year in April, according to data from Canalys, now part of Omdia.
Omdia estimates that 3 million iPhones shipped from India to the US in April, compared with 900,000 units from China‚Äîa 76% fall from the previous year.
The shift reflects Apple's long-term strategy to diversify production amid increasing tariffs.
Apple began strengthening its manufacturing presence in India during the Covid-19 pandemic.
India first overtook China in US-bound iPhone shipments in March.
Apple‚Äôs shipment volumes spiked ahead of the tariffs' introduction on April 2.
An exemption for iPhones and other consumer electronics was introduced on April 11.
Apple CEO Tim Cook confirmed in early May that most iPhones sold in the US will be manufactured in India going forward.
Tariffs on Chinese-made iPhones remain in effect, currently subject to an additional 30% duty, while imports from India face a 10% baseline rate.
Growth in iPhone exports from India is expected to slow in the coming months.
India‚Äôs manufacturing infrastructure is still developing and may not be able to meet full US demand before 2026.
Current quarterly demand for iPhones in the US stands at around 20 million units.
Most sub-assembly processes still take place in China.
Trump threatened to impose a 25% tariff on all iPhones sold in the US unless they are manufactured domestically.
China has also reportedly imposed restrictions on the transfer of machinery and skilled labour to India.

title: Trump shock: Here‚Äôs a 4-D formula for policymakers to track it
content: As uncertainty rules high for companies, investors and governments, how matters move in terms of diversification, defence, debt and the dollar could help us gauge the impact of the Trump shock on the ...
resumen:
The article discusses a 4-D formula for policymakers to track the impact of the "Trump shock" on the Indian economy over the medium term, focusing on diversification, defence, debt, and the dollar.

Diversification: Countries may diversify their economic structures amid geopolitical uncertainty through bolstering manufacturing, depending more on domestic demand, increasing domestic savings, and restricting trade within regional economic zones. A higher share of wages in national income may be needed to support local consumer spending.

Defence: Global military spending increased in real terms at the fastest rate since the end of the Cold War in 2024. India may need to increase its military budget, potentially doubling it to 4% of GDP.

Debt: Bond markets are threatening action against countries with high public debt. India's public debt-to-GDP ratio is projected to decrease marginally between 2024 and 2030, with most government debt held by domestic investors.

Dollar: The US dollar has been the pivot of the global financial system. Concerns about the sustainability of US public finances are important. If the US dollar is toppled from its perch as the global reserve currency, it will impact every open economy that uses the US dollar as its main currency for international trade, whose central bank holds its reserves primarily in US dollar assets and whose exchange rate is maintained in some fixed or crawling leg to the US currency. India is one of those countries.

The author is Niranjan Rajadhyaksha, executive director at Artha India Research Advisors.

title: Japan Will Spend $6.3 Billion to Shield Its Economy From Trump‚Äôs Tariffs
content: Lawmakers approved a plan to help companies and consumers as officials bargain in Washington for relief from debilitating auto levies.
resumen:
Japan aprob√≥ un paquete de gastos de $6.3 mil millones para "apoyar plenamente" a las empresas y los hogares afectados negativamente por los aranceles, dijo el secretario del gabinete Yoshimasa Hayashi en una sesi√≥n informativa. Los fondos reforzar√°n las finanzas de las peque√±as y medianas empresas y subsidiar√°n los costos de energ√≠a de los hogares.

El sector automotriz del pa√≠s, la columna vertebral de la econom√≠a, ya se est√° tambaleando por un arancel estadounidense del 25 por ciento sobre autom√≥viles y autopartes terminados.

Toyota Motor, la empresa m√°s grande de Jap√≥n, ha proyectado un impacto de $1.3 mil millones en sus ganancias solo para abril y mayo debido a los aranceles. Honda Motor y Nissan Motor han pronosticado de manera similar fuertes ca√≠das en sus ganancias. Nissan est√° considerando cerrar dos plantas en Jap√≥n como parte de sus esfuerzos de reestructuraci√≥n. El fabricante de autom√≥viles tambi√©n planea trasladar parte de la producci√≥n de Jap√≥n a Estados Unidos para evitar los aranceles.

Los economistas han estimado que los aranceles automotrices m√°s altos por s√≠ solos podr√≠an reducir significativamente la econom√≠a de Jap√≥n este a√±o. Teniendo en cuenta las interrupciones m√°s amplias causadas por las tensiones comerciales mundiales, los funcionarios han advertido que el crecimiento general podr√≠a reducirse a m√°s de la mitad.

Antes de Jap√≥n, varios pa√≠ses reunieron fondos para ayudar a sus econom√≠as a hacer frente a la escalada de los aranceles. Espa√±a dio a conocer un paquete de ayuda arancelaria de $15 mil millones el mes pasado. Canad√° tambi√©n ha destinado miles de millones de d√≥lares para ayudar a sus trabajadores y empresas a capear el comercio turbulento con Estados Unidos.

El principal negociador de aranceles de Jap√≥n, Ryosei Akazawa, se reuni√≥ la semana pasada en Washington con sus hom√≥logos de la administraci√≥n Trump. Las conversaciones se han movido lentamente, estanc√°ndose al menos en parte porque los funcionarios de Trump han se√±alado que la principal demanda de Jap√≥n, una exenci√≥n de los aranceles automotrices, no est√° sujeta a negociaci√≥n.

El art√≠culo fue escrito por River Akira Davis y Hisako Ueno.

title: Republican senator admits Trump is Canada‚Äôs ‚Äòadversary‚Äô as DC delegation grovels in Ottawa
content: Months of provocative statements about the Great White North joining America as the 51st state in the Union, however, led the delegation‚Äôs lone Republican member to admit to reporters that the US ...
resumen:
Washington‚Äôs delegation to Canada seemed to have one message in mind: please keep taking us seriously.

The delegation was split between four Democrats and one lone Republican senator representing a border state ‚Äî North Dakota. Other Republicans stayed home.

Kevin Cramer, the GOP ‚Äúco-leader‚Äù, told reporters that Prime Minister Mark Carney centered him in his conversation with the group, given the senator‚Äôs relationship with the Republican US president.

He told reporters that he sought to encourage Canadian officials to reach a trade deal with the United States.

Cramer said after the meetings Friday, according to Punchbowl News: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to get in Donald Trump‚Äôs way. There‚Äôs no [trade] deal that happens without his involvement. But at the same time [I want to] be an encourager to Canada and their officials and try to be a partner in some way.‚Äù

Cramer did not take a beating on Truth Social, even though he did lay the blame for the fraying of ties squarely on Trump‚Äôs shoulders.

‚ÄúWe have an obligation to stop the offenses,‚Äù the Republican senator told reporters, speaking of the United States.

‚ÄúFor the moment, the United States has become an adversary to the Canadian people because of the offense that so many have felt,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúWhat I would stress with the president would be, let‚Äôs keep our eye on the common adversary and how much stronger we can be.‚Äù

Cramer said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just here to say thank you, and then to encourage Canadians to take another look and give us another chance.‚Äù

Tim Kaine pitched Carney on his bill to block US sanctions on Canada.

Senator Jeanne Shaheen said that she hoped some of the ‚Äúcracks‚Äù in the bonds between the US and Canada could be healed.

Carney, elected on a Liberal Party mandate to stand up to the US president, flew to Washington in early May after telling the BBC in an interview that Canada would negotiate with America ‚Äúon our terms‚Äù.

The Canadian prime minister reportedly invited Claudia Sheinbaum to the upcoming G7 summit in Kananaskis next month.

Carney told Trump that Canada was ‚Äúnot for sale‚Äù during their meeting at the White House in early May.

The US president wrote on Truth Social that he presented Canada‚Äôs government with a $61bn price tag to be involved with the US‚Äôs proposed ‚ÄúGolden Dome‚Äù missile defene system, adding that it would be free if Canada relented and became a state.

‚ÄúThey are considering the offer!‚Äù Trump said.

In an address scripted by the Canadian government, Charles declared that Canada, under Carney‚Äôs government, would bond with ‚Äúreliable trading partners and allies‚Äù ‚Äî a clear warning shot for Washington.

He‚Äôd add that Canada‚Äôs government was determined to protect the right to ‚Äúself-determination‚Äù for the country.

Charles said on Tuesday: ‚ÄúWe must be clear-eyed: the world is a more dangerous and uncertain place than at any point since the Second World War. Canada is facing challenges that are unprecedented in our lifetimes.‚Äù

title: Tech‚Äôs Trump Whisperer, Tim Cook, Goes Quiet as His Influence Fades
content: Apple‚Äôs chief executive has gone from winning President Trump‚Äôs praise to drawing his ire, deepening the company‚Äôs woes in a very bad year.
resumen:
In the run-up to President Trump‚Äôs recent trip to the Middle East, the White House encouraged chief executives and representatives of many U.S. companies to join him. Tim Cook, Apple‚Äôs chief executive, declined.

During his speech in Riyadh, Mr. Trump paused to praise Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, for traveling to the Middle East along with the White House delegation. Then he knocked Mr. Cook.

At an event attended by chief executives like Larry Fink of the asset manager BlackRock, Sam Altman of OpenAI, Jane Fraser of Citigroup and Lisa Su of the semiconductor company AMD, Mr. Trump said to Mr. Huang, ‚ÄúI mean, Tim Cook isn‚Äôt here but you are.‚Äù

Later in Qatar, Mr. Trump said he ‚Äúhad a little problem with Tim Cook.‚Äù The president praised Apple‚Äôs investment in the United States, then said he had told Mr. Cook, ‚ÄúBut now I hear you‚Äôre building all over India. I don‚Äôt want you building in India.‚Äù

On Friday morning, Mr. Trump caught much of his own administration and Apple‚Äôs leadership off guard with a social media post threatening tariffs of 25 percent on iPhones made anywhere except the United States. The post thrust Apple back into the administration‚Äôs cross hairs a little over a month after Mr. Cook had lobbied and won an exemption from a 145 percent tariff on iPhones assembled in China and sold in the United States.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs new tariffs followed a report by The Financial Times that Apple‚Äôs supplier Foxconn would spend $1.5 billion on a plant in India for iPhones. The president said the tariffs would begin at the end of June and affect all smartphones made abroad, including Samsung‚Äôs devices.

During an appearance on Fox News on Friday, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the administration considered overseas production of semiconductors and electronics components ‚Äúone of our greatest vulnerabilities,‚Äù which Apple could help address.

Kush Desai, a White House spokesman, said the administration ‚Äúcontinues to have a productive relationship with Apple.‚Äù

Last month, the company suffered a stinging defeat in an App Store trial. The judge in the trial rebuked Apple executives, saying they had ‚Äúoutright lied under oath‚Äù and that ‚ÄúCook chose poorly,‚Äù and ruled that Apple had to change how it operates the App Store. Jony Ive, Apple‚Äôs former chief designer who became estranged from Mr. Cook and left the company in 2019, joined OpenAI last week to build a potential iPhone competitor. Its Vision Pro mixed reality headset, released in January 2024 to fanfare, has been a disappointment. And in March, Apple postponed its promised release of a new Siri, raising fresh doubts about its ability to compete in the industry‚Äôs race to adopt artificial intelligence.

Apple‚Äôs market value has increased by more than $2.5 trillion under his leadership, or about $500 million a day since 2011. And Apple remains a moneymaking machine, generating an annual profit of nearly $100 billion.

In 2019, Mr. Trump said Mr. Cook was a ‚Äúgreat executive because he calls me and others don‚Äôt.‚Äù

During an appearance at a conference for Fortune magazine in late 2017, Mr. Cook explained that the company would love to make things in the United States but that China had more engineers and better skills. He appeared before a live audience on MSNBC a few months later and criticized the president‚Äôs policy on immigration.

Apple has stopped short of committing to making the iPhone, iPad or Mac laptops in the United States. Instead, the company has moved to assemble more iPhones in India.

Apple has tried to head off Mr. Trump‚Äôs criticisms of its overseas manufacturing by promising to spend $500 billion in the United States over the next four years. Mr. Cook also has emphasized that the company will source 19 billion chips from the United States this year, and will start making A.I. servers in Houston.

He wants iPhones made in the United States badly enough to create what amounts to an iPhone tariff. It would increase the cost of shipping an iPhone from India or China to the United States by 25 percent.

‚ÄúIf they‚Äôre going to sell it in America, I want it to be built in the United States,‚Äù Mr. Trump said on Friday. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre able to do that.‚Äù
