title: NATO Wants a Cordial Summit, but Trump or Zelensky Could Disrupt It
content: But two things could leave the alliance‚Äôs secretary general, Mark Rutte, presiding over a more difficult event: President Trump, who is expected to attend, is at odds with allies over Ukraine‚Äôs future ...
resumen: The head of NATO, Mark Rutte, wants the alliance‚Äôs annual summit meeting next month, set for June 24-25 in the Netherlands, to be short and sweet. President Trump, who is expected to attend, is at odds with allies over Ukraine‚Äôs future, and Ukraine itself wants to join NATO, an outcome Mr. Trump opposes. Trump administration officials have warned their European counterparts that major changes in American troop rotations are imminent even as they seek to reassure allies that the United States is committed to NATO. Mr. Trump is winding down support for Ukraine, has abandoned efforts to reach a cease-fire in the war and seeks to normalize relations with Russia. Ukraine‚Äôs role in the summit is uncertain, not least because of Mr. Trump‚Äôs dismissiveness toward President Volodymyr Zelensky, who is also expected to attend. It is not even clear that Mr. Zelensky will be invited to the main opening dinner. Matthew G. Whitaker, the new American ambassador to NATO, said at a conference this month in Tallinn, Estonia, ‚ÄúI fully expect Zelensky to be at The Hague.‚Äù Officials suggested that this summit will not include a meeting of the NATO-Ukraine Council. After the dinner on the first evening, NATO leaders will meet for only a few hours the next day, to ratify new spending goals that can help European allies replace the United States over time as the prime guarantor of the continent‚Äôs conventional defense. NATO is also planning a parallel defense industry forum, which Mr. Zelensky might attend. Under President Joseph R. Biden Jr., Mr. Zelensky had important roles in the past two NATO summit meetings. In 2008, NATO agreed that both Ukraine and Georgia ‚Äúwill become members of NATO‚Äù but did not specify a date or a path. Last year‚Äôs version of the communiqu√© that NATO issues at the end of each summit promised continuing aid to Kyiv, but about membership simply said that Ukraine was on an ‚Äúirreversible path to full Euro-Atlantic integration, including NATO membership.‚Äù This year‚Äôs communiqu√© would be short and concise. European allies have vowed to continue supporting Ukraine to reach an equitable peace settlement and then provide security guarantees to prevent Russia from further incursions. Mr. Trump has not interfered with shipments of American weapons under the $61 billion in aid approved while Mr. Biden was in office. Nor has Mr. Trump again interrupted U.S. satellite and intelligence information supplied to Ukraine. President Vladimir Putin of Russia has made it clear that he is in no rush to end the war, but Mr. Trump has notably not followed through on threats to increase economic pressure on Russia. Mr. Whitaker worked hard in Tallinn to reassure allies that the United States was committed to the alliance, to collective defense and to its nuclear umbrella over Europe. An ongoing review of American troop posture, scheduled to finish later this year, could mean the withdrawal or repositioning of some of the 84,000 American troops in Europe. Mr. Whitaker assured officials that ‚Äúwe are not going to allow any security gaps‚Äù to emerge in NATO before European forces could replace key American capabilities. The United States wanted to move as quickly as possible. Uncertainty about the future of U.S. troops in Europe will complicate NATO‚Äôs efforts to revise its countries‚Äô military requirements, said Torrey Taussig, a senior fellow at the Atlantic Council, as well as European planning for how to replace American support for both NATO and Ukraine. Michael Kofman, a military and Ukraine expert at the Carnegie Endowment, said that it would be difficult for Europeans to both meet NATO targets for their own defense and support Ukraine indefinitely. Trump administration officials appear to care little about precisely how other allies invest their military spending, so long as the total reaches 5 percent of their annual economic output. Mr. Rutte has proposed a compromise: that allies agree to spend 3.5 percent of their economic output on hard military power and another 1.5 percent on what he has termed ‚Äúmilitary-related‚Äù expenses by 2032. Mr. Rutte has said that agreement on the new spending goal, which replaces the old one of 2 percent of economic output on the military, will be the centerpiece of this year‚Äôs summit meeting. In the latest official figures, 23 of NATO‚Äôs 32 member states currently meet or surpass the current threshold. The United States will also commit toward the same spending goal of 5 percent as other NATO members, Mr. Whitaker said in response to a question in Estonia. Currently the United States spends about 5 percent of its defense budget on Europe, not counting nuclear and space spending, according to estimates by the International Institute for Strategic Studies. That represents roughly $50 billion out of the Pentagon‚Äôs 2024 budget of $997 billion. The institute estimates that Europe would need to spend roughly $1 trillion over time to replace U.S. capabilities engaged in Europe. NATO is stronger, fairer and more lethal than it was before the invasion, said Radmila Shekerinska, NATO‚Äôs new deputy secretary general.

Trump's new tariff threats may shake stocks' rally as investors brace for a long, hot summer.

Investors Pile Into ETFs at Record Pace Despite Market Turmoil. U.S. exchange-traded funds have collected some $437 billion in new assets so far this year.

The 90-Day Rush to Get Goods Out of China. With a cease-fire declared in the U.S.-China trade war, firms are racing to rebook canceled orders and find space on containerships while they can.

Ships are canceling crossings to U.S., and Trump's new 50% E.U. tariff threat isn't likely to help. The spotlight. is back on U.S. supply chains after President Trump threatened new E.U. and smartphone tariffs.

Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Focus on Trade News, PCE Inflation Data and Fed Minutes. President Trump's threat of hefty tariffs on EU goods will raise further fears about high U.S. inflation and weak economic growth.

3 Political Fights Are Brewing This Summer. Prepare for Volatility.. The tariff battle, the tax bill, and the debt ceiling are scheduled to come to a head soon.

title: Ahead of ASEAN Summit, Malaysian FM Calls for Regional Action on US Tariffs
content: Along with the conflict in Myanmar, the issue of trade is likely to be high on the agenda at the 46th ASEAN Summit in Kuala Lumpur.
resumen:
Malaysia‚Äôs foreign minister has called on Southeast Asian nations to deepen regional economic integration and present a united front in their attempts to address the current global trade uncertainties resulting from sweeping U.S. tariffs.

Mohamad Hasan said that the bloc‚Äôs member states were among the nations ‚Äúmost heavily affected‚Äù by the ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs announced by President Donald Trump last month.

President Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúliberation day‚Äù tariff announcement on April 2, Southeast Asian nations were slapped with rates ranging from 17 percent (the Philippines) to 49 percent (Cambodia).

Several nations, including Vietnam and Thailand, have already begun negotiations with the Trump administration over a possible reduction of the tariffs.

The tariffs are likely to be high on the agenda during today‚Äôs 46th ASEAN Summit in Kuala Lumpur.

ASEAN leaders are set to express ‚Äúdeep concern‚Äù over the Trump administration‚Äôs tariff policy at today‚Äôs 46th ASEAN Summit.

ASEAN will reaffirm its ‚Äúcollective commitment to a rules-based, open, inclusive, transparent, and non-discriminatory multilateral trading system,‚Äù with the World Trade Organization at its core.

Malaysia, the current ASEAN chair, has vowed to shepherd the creation of a united regional response to the Trump tariffs.

Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said that his government ‚Äúwill lead efforts to present a united regional front, maintain open and resilient supply chains, and ensure ASEAN‚Äôs collective voice is heard clearly and firmly on the international stage.‚Äù

On April 10, Malaysia chaired a meeting of ASEAN economic ministers that affirmed the bloc‚Äôs support for ‚Äúmaintaining a predictable, transparent, non-discriminatory, fair, inclusive, and open regional economic environment which has underpinned growth in regional trade and development.‚Äù

Anwar called on ASEAN to ‚Äúrely more on itself.‚Äù He said, ‚ÄúThis means strengthening intra-ASEAN trade. We must move beyond rhetoric to execution.‚Äù

Mohamad said that Malaysia has requested the convening of a special summit with the U.S. in order to discuss tariffs and said that it was hopeful that this could happen later this year.

Intra-bloc trade made up just 21 percent of the ASEAN total in 2024.

In 2024, China accounted for 20 percent of regional trade, with heavy ASEAN imports. The U.S. followed with 12 percent, made up mostly of exports from ASEAN member states. The European Union made up 8 percent, while trade with the six GCC members made up around 3.5 percent.

ASEAN has concluded negotiations on upgrading the ASEAN Trade in Goods Agreement, first signed in 2010, and the China-ASEAN Free Trade Area, which was agreed in 2002.

The enhanced deals are expected to be signed in October.

Malaysia‚Äôs Investment, Trade, and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz said, ‚ÄúWe remain confident that these milestones will serve as a pivotal enabler for ASEAN‚Äôs sustained growth and competitiveness.‚Äù

Tengku Zafrul warned the bloc against inaction as it seeks ‚Äúto navigate an increasingly volatile global economic landscape.‚Äù

‚ÄúASEAN would need to break away from a business-as-usual approach,‚Äù Tengku Zafrul added. ‚ÄúWe need to adopt bolder, more agile and more forward-looking strategies. We need to safeguard and advance ASEAN socioeconomic interests.‚Äù

Tengku Zafrul said every ASEAN member is a ‚Äúsovereign nation‚Äù and should be supported in pursuing bilateral tariff negotiations with Washington.

Today‚Äôs ASEAN Summit will be followed by the second summit between ASEAN and the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), which comprises Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates. This will then be followed by the first-ever meeting between ASEAN, China, and the GCC.

title: Interview: Economic Decline & the Death of the American Empire ‚Äì A Reckoning with Global Realities
content: Death of the American Empire. Einar Tangen analyzes Trump‚Äôs trade war collapse, America‚Äôs economic decline, and the Global South‚Äôs rise. Discover the end of the American empire.
resumen:
In an interview with Professor Glenn Diesen, Einar Tangen, a senior fellow at the Taihe Institute and chairman of Asia Narratives, discusses the U.S. economic strategy under President Donald Trump's trade war and its implications for America‚Äôs global dominance. Trump‚Äôs tariffs, briefly imposed on nearly every nation before being paused or reversed, were declared a victory despite achieving little. Tangen argues that this erratic approach, coupled with a $38 trillion debt and domestic economic woes, signals the decline of the American empire.

Trump‚Äôs tariffs, targeting 180 countries, including allies like Canada and adversaries like China, were a reckless ‚Äúbroadside‚Äù lacking an endgame. China refused to negotiate under pressure. The 90-day reset, with talks now in Geneva at the World Trade Organization (WTO), reflects China‚Äôs strategic push for neutral ground and multilateral order, contrasting Trump‚Äôs unilateral bullying.

The tariffs were based on flawed logic, targeting trade deficits without addressing their root cause: a strong U.S. dollar and domestic policy failures. Importers, not foreign exporters, bear tariff costs, passing them to U.S. consumers, who face rising prices. 70% of Americans live paycheck to paycheck. China‚Äôs proposed ‚ÄúPhase Two‚Äù deal‚Äîreviving a failed Phase One agreement for U.S. agricultural and energy purchases‚Äîaims to lock Trump into a transactional pact, ensuring stability until his term ends.

America‚Äôs economic woes are traced to a strong dollar, which fuels cheap imports but stifles exports, and a failure to reinvest corporate profits into workers or infrastructure. Since 2001, U.S. corporations reaped trillions by outsourcing to low-wage countries like India ($3/day labor) and China ($20/day), but wages stagnated, shrinking the middle class from 61% in 1971 to 40% today. The U.S.‚Äôs $38 trillion debt is a ‚Äúdebt bomb,‚Äù with $2 trillion borrowed annually to cover a $1 trillion interest bill. Credit downgrades by S&P (2011), Fitch (2023), and Moody‚Äôs (2025) signal eroding confidence, raising borrowing costs. Trump‚Äôs $4 trillion unfunded tax cut exacerbates the crisis.

Trump‚Äôs push to re-industrialize America is futile. U.S. labor costs cannot compete, especially with only 40% of Americans reading above a sixth-grade level. The Manufacturers Association‚Äôs reported 100,000 job vacancies underscore this skills gap. Trump‚Äôs dismantling of the Department of Education and failure to invest in STEM further undermines competitiveness. Tariffs raise costs for components in supply chains, making American products like cars less competitive. Recent layoffs, such as FedEx‚Äôs 20,000 job cuts, signal broader economic strain.

China plays the ‚Äúadult in the room,‚Äù avoiding confrontation to preserve global stability. Beijing seeks a Phase Two deal to manage Trump‚Äôs volatility. China diversifies, redirecting exports to Europe, Southeast Asia, and Latin America, and strengthening BRICS institutions like the New Development Bank. Initiatives like grain corridors and commodity exchanges with Russia reduce reliance on U.S.-dominated systems.

The U.S.‚Äôs unreliability has alienated allies. Canada‚Äôs election of a nationalist leader and Europe‚Äôs hesitation signal a global pivot away from U.S. hegemony. Tangen sees BRICS nations‚ÄîChina, Russia, Brazil‚Äîas inheritors of a broken Western-led order, tasked with stabilizing global trade and finance.

America‚Äôs isolation is self-inflicted, driven by Trump‚Äôs rejection of international norms. Its $38 trillion debt, coupled with a shrinking middle class and educational deficits, portends collapse. Tangen warns of a potential military escalation as Trump‚Äôs last card to unify a fracturing nation, risking global catastrophe. The bond market‚Äôs looming hammer‚Äîhigher interest rates‚Äîcould trigger bankruptcy. Tangen sees no easy fix.

Einar Tangen‚Äôs analysis paints a dire portrait of America‚Äôs economic decline, accelerated by Trump‚Äôs incoherent trade war and systemic failures. China‚Äôs strategic patience and global diversification contrast with the U.S.‚Äôs isolation, signaling the death of its empire. The Global South, led by BRICS, emerges as a stabilizing force.

title: ASEAN leaders to show concern over U.S. tariffs, Myanmar
content: Leaders of the Association of Southeast Asia Nations are set to show their deep concern over "unilateral tariff measures" without mentioning the United States at their meeting in Malaysia on Monday, ...
resumen:
Southeast Asian leaders held a summit in Kuala Lumpur on Monday under the shadow of sweeping new U.S. tariffs. Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim expressed concern over "increasingly complex and sobering global developments."

Anwar, whose country currently chairs the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, said at the meeting's outset that the global trading system is "under further strain, with the recent imposition of U.S. unilateral tariffs," with the duties ranging from 10 percent to 49 percent to hit the regional grouping's 10 members.

ASEAN has displayed resilience amid "increasingly complex and sobering global developments," he said.

Anwar said he had written to U.S. President Donald Trump to propose an ASEAN-U.S. meeting.

According to a draft of the summit chairman's statement obtained by Kyodo News, the leaders showed their deep concern over "unilateral tariff measures" without explicitly mentioning the United States, as their countries, like others, are facing Trump's so-called reciprocal tariffs.

The leaders warned that unilateral tariffs pose "complex and multidimensional challenges to ASEAN's economic growth, stability and integration," reaffirming the regional bloc's commitment to a "nondiscriminatory multilateral trading system, with the World Trade Organization at its core, according to the draft statement.

Following Trump's announcement of the tariffs, ASEAN trade ministers held a special virtual meeting in April and said they would not retaliate.

The ASEAN trade and foreign ministers met separately on Sunday in the Malaysian capital.

Besides tariffs, the ongoing civil war in Myanmar, following a coup in February 2021 that ousted the elected government led by Aung San Suu Kyi, was on the summit agenda, according to the draft.

Anwar said at Monday's summit that ASEAN has been able to take "positive steps" within an informal advisory group that he launched by requesting former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra to serve as an adviser.

Further humanitarian assistance for Myanmar, the central region of which was hit by an earthquake on March 28 that killed over 3,700 people, was stressed, according to the draft statement, including a call by the leaders for greater international financial support.

From Myanmar, Aung Kyaw Moe, permanent secretary of its Foreign Ministry, participated in the summit as ASEAN has only allowed attendance by a nonpolitical representative from the country since October 2021, effectively excluding the junta chief.

Other issues discussed included East Timor's accession to ASEAN. The leaders agreed the country, currently an observer, will gain full membership in October, Milena Rangel, vice minister for ASEAN affairs of East Timor's foreign ministry, told reporters after the summit.

ASEAN groups Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.

title: EU readying apt response to US tariffs
content: On Friday, US President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on EU imports starting from June 1, saying negotiations with the trading bloc of 27 nations "are going nowhere".
resumen:
Mutual trust between the European Union and the United States has been "severely undermined" by the recent tariff dispute, and the outlook for relations remains fraught, despite claims of a soothing of tensions over the weekend.

US President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on EU imports starting from June 1, saying negotiations with the trading bloc of 27 nations "are going nowhere".

He spoke with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, which resulted in any possible tariffs being delayed until July.

Zhang Haiyan, a professor specializing in international trade at the Hangzhou, Zhejiang province-based Zhejiang Financial College, has warned that the European perception that it had been "betrayed by its ally" meant it was ready to punch back if necessary.

The EU's preparations and countermeasures for the latest US tariff policy move will be more thorough and comprehensive than in previous trade conflicts, enabling it to retaliate if negotiations fail in the following days.

The EU has previously threatened to hit the US back with tariffs of its own, including a list of US exports viewed as possible targets, including cars and aircraft.

It has also long been wary of the activities and market dominance of major US-based tech firms, which could potentially be an area for it to target if trade tensions are ramped up further.

Beyond the digital sector, financial services provided by US banks within the EU are also seen as likely candidates for countermeasures.

Trump said "let's be honest, the EU was formed in order to screw the US ‚Ä¶that's the purpose of it, and they've done a good job of it".

Lars Klingbeil, finance minister in Germany's newly-formed government, has said that "serious negotiations" with Washington are needed, rather than "further provocations", and that he has spoken to his US counterpart Scott Bessent about the issue.

Oliver Oehms, executive director and board member of the German Chamber of Commerce in China-North China, said that the ongoing lack of certainty about what would happen next would inevitably cause anxiety, which could have global consequences.

Zak Stambor, an analyst at eMarketer Inc, a New York City-based market research company, said that "ever-shifting trade policies" meant "navigating an increasingly unpredictable landscape", making life and any attempts at financial planning harder for manufacturers and consumers.

title: Trump threatens Apple with 25% tariff: Is now a good time to buy an iPhone?
content: In addition to promising a 50% tariff on the European Union, unless E.U. leaders come to an agreement with the Trump administration within approximately nine days, the president threatened Apple with ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened Apple with 25% tariffs on any iPhone sold, and not made, in the U.S.

Trump posted on Truth Social, his social-media platform, on Friday: "I have long ago informed Tim Cook of Apple (AAPL) that I expect their iPhone's [sic] that will be sold in the United States of America will be manufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else."

Ming-Chi Kuo, TF International Securities analyst, said the costs would likely make such a move prohibitive.

Prices for the iPhone product line start at $799 and go as high as $1,599 for the iPhone 16 Pro Max.

The iPhone 16 is powered by an "A18 Bionic" chip, integrates artificial intelligence into its camera control and has 85% recycled content.

Alex Kidman, who writes Alex Reviews Tech, said the iPhone 16's 60Hz screen at this price is "indefensible," and cited "inconsistent battery life and overly hot Qi2 charging." (60Hz means the screen updates 60 times every second.).

Some 36% of iPhone buyers in the 12 months ending December 2024 reported having their previous phone for two years or less, compared with 31% in the prior year.

The household savings rate in the U.S. fell to 3.9% in March from 4.1% in February. It averaged 8.4% from 1959 until 2025, reaching an all-time high of 32% in April 2020 and a record low of 1% in July 2005, according to Trading Economics.

Andrzej Skiba, head of U.S. fixed income at RBC Global Asset Management, said the environment surrounding Trump's trade approach may also ensure that borrowing costs remain elevated. "The Fed," he said, "won't likely be able to cut rates in this environment."

title: The problem with US foreign policy is the overshooting
content: The test of intelligent analysis of American foreign policy under President Donald Trump is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function.
resumen:
The test of intelligent analysis of American foreign policy under President Donald Trump is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function. The first idea is that Trump, on the whole, is a disaster for America‚Äôs long-term stature in the international system, making the world less orderly and more chaotic. The second is that Trump, like a broken clock that‚Äôs right twice a day, occasionally has the right instinct.

Trump, during his visit to the Middle East, came out with a devastatingly perceptive critique of his predecessors, and in particular the previous Republican president, George W. Bush. Trump said that the ‚Äúgleaming marvels‚Äù of Arabia did ‚Äúnot come from Western interventionists ‚Ä¶ giving you lectures on how to live.‚Äù Those ‚Äúso-called ‚Äònation-builders,‚Äô ‚Äòneo-cons,‚Äô or ‚Äòliberal non-profits,‚Äô‚Äù instead ‚Äúwrecked far more nations than they built.‚Äù They were, Trump said with what sounded like intellectual humility, ‚Äúintervening in complex societies that they did not even understand themselves.‚Äù

Bush, during his second inaugural address in 2005, said: ‚ÄúThe survival of liberty in our land increasingly depends on the success of liberty in other lands.‚Äù He was equating national with global interests and setting up democracy as the universal standard. ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs vital interests and our deepest beliefs are now one,‚Äù Bush went on, denying the inherent tension between realism and idealism. He then warned despots everywhere that America, ‚Äúwith the ultimate goal of ending tyranny in our world,‚Äù will ‚Äúpersistently clarify the choice before every ruler‚Äù between ‚Äúoppression, which is always wrong, and freedom, which is eternally right.‚Äù

The U.S. launched a war in Iraq and what would turn into a two-decade quagmire in Afghanistan. The blowback played a large part in defining America‚Äôs current political spectrum. At one extreme is the neo-isolationist MAGA wing of the Grand Old Party as embodied by Vice President JD Vance. In the more cerebral middle are centrist Democrats such as Jim Himes.

The passage in Trump‚Äôs speech does not reflect his statecraft. Trump was not visiting the region to end the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians, nor was he preparing an extrication of American troops and treasure from the region in the long term. Instead, he dropped in to feed his monarchical fantasies and to collect disconnected favors and deals. This is problem number one: Trump thinks in real-estate rather than geopolitical terms, confusing transactions with relationships, institutions and norms.

Trump consistently bullies America‚Äôs closest allies, such as Canada and Denmark, while rhetorically elevating its adversaries, above all Russia. He and Vance do pry in the politics of, say, Germany or South Africa.

This is morally as well as strategically suspect. Germany and South Africa are democracies that overcame dark pasts.

That brings us to problem number two: Whereas Bush was wrong (and hypocritical) to pretend that America‚Äôs interests and ideals were indivisible, Trump errs in pretending that values don‚Äôt matter. For example, U.S. intelligence services concluded that bin Salman, his host in Riyadh, ‚Äúapproved‚Äù the gruesome killing and dismemberment of a Saudi journalist in Istanbul in 2018.

The subtle interplay of interests and values shows up not only in America‚Äôs diplomatic relationships but also in its treatment of norms and institutions. They include international law, as well as the many looser ‚Äúrules‚Äù that govern international relations. They also encompass multilateral bodies such as the United Nations, NATO or the World Trade Organization, all of which the U.S. once midwifed because it wanted a more peaceful and prosperous world, but which Trump now derogates and undermines.

This points to problem number three: Trump claims to act solely in America‚Äôs national interests and then defines those interests myopically.

Trump, Vance and others in the administration have fallen for the false dichotomy that a Republican foreign policy based on ‚Äústrength‚Äù must either hew to Bush‚Äôs otherworldly idealism and zealotry or to a crude isolationism that in practice deteriorates into cynical deal-making.

resumen:
Los mercados europeos concluyeron en alza tras el anuncio de Trump, quien posterg√≥ un arancel del 50% sobre la UE hasta el 9 de julio. Inversionistas se mostraron optimistas ante la posibilidad de acuerdos comerciales.

Las acciones en los mercados europeos cerraron positivamente el lunes, mientras que los futuros de Estados Unidos se dispararon despu√©s de que el presidente Donald Trump anunciara la postergaci√≥n de la implementaci√≥n de un arancel del 50% sobre productos de la Uni√≥n Europea hasta el 9 de julio.

Trump hizo este anuncio tras una conversaci√≥n telef√≥nica con Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, quien manifest√≥ su inter√©s en entablar negociaciones serias para alcanzar un acuerdo comercial.

El principal negociador comercial de la UE destac√≥ que sostuvo "buenas llamadas" con funcionarios del gobierno de Trump y reafirm√≥ el compromiso de la UE de alcanzar un trato antes de la fecha l√≠mite del 9 de julio.

title: Trump's tariffs launched global trade wars a timeline of how we got here
content: Volley after volley of new tariffs from US President Donald Trump have plunged the country into trade wars abroad, creating uncertainty for businesses and households. Trump is no stranger to ...
resumen:
Volley after volley of new tariffs from US President Donald Trump have plunged the country into trade wars abroad, creating uncertainty for businesses and households.

Trump launched a trade war during his first term as well, taking particular aim at China by putting taxes on most of its goods. Beijing responded with its own retaliatory tariffs on a range of US products. Trump also used the threat of more tariffs to force Canada and Mexico to renegotiate a North American trade pact.

Economists stress there are greater consequences on businesses and economies worldwide under Trump's more sweeping tariffs this time around ‚Äî and that higher prices leave consumers footing the bill.

January 20: Trump is sworn into office. In his inaugural address, he promises to ‚Äútariff and tax foreign countries to enrich our citizens." He reiterates plans to create an agency called the External Revenue Service. On his first day in office, Trump says he expects to put 25 per cent tariffs on Canada and Mexico starting on February 1, while declining to immediately flesh out plans for taxing Chinese imports.

January 26: Trump threatens 25 per cent tariffs on all Colombia imports and other retaliatory measures after President Gustavo Petro's rejects two US military aircraft carrying migrants to the country. Petro announces a retaliatory 25 per cent increase in Colombian tariffs on US goods. Colombia later reversed its decision and accepted the flights carrying migrants. The two countries soon signalled a halt in the trade dispute.

February 1: Trump signs an executive order to impose tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada and China ‚Äî 10 per cent on all imports from China and 25 per cent on imports from Mexico and Canada starting February 4. Trump invoked this power by declaring a national emergency. The action prompts swift outrage from all three countries, with promises of retaliatory measures.

February 3: Trump agrees to a 30-day pause on his tariff threats against Mexico and Canada.

February 4: Trump's new 10 per cent tariffs on all Chinese imports to the US still go into effect. China retaliates the same day by announcing a flurry of countermeasures, including new duties on a variety of American goods and an anti-monopoly investigation into Google. China's 15 per cent tariffs on coal and liquefied natural gas products, and a 10 per cent levy on crude oil, agricultural machinery and large-engine cars imported from the US, take effect February 10.

February 10: Trump announces plans to hike steel and aluminum tariffs starting March 12. He removes the exemptions from his 2018 tariffs on steel, meaning that all steel imports will be taxed at a minimum of 25 per cent, and also raises his 2018 aluminum tariffs from 10 per cent to 25 per cent.

February 13: Trump announces a plan for ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs ‚Äî promising to increase US tariffs to match the tax rates that countries worldwide charge on imports.

March 4: Trump's 25 per cent tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico go into effect, though he limits the levy to 10 per cent on Canadian energy. He also doubles the tariff on all Chinese imports to 20 per cent. All three countries promise retaliatory measures. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces tariffs on more than USD 100 billion of American goods over the course of 21 days. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum says her country would respond with its own retaliatory tariffs on US goods. China imposes tariffs of up to 15 per cent on a wide array of key US farm exports, set to take effect March 10. It also expands the number of US companies subject to export controls and other restrictions by about two dozen.

March 5: Trump grants a one-month exemption on his new tariffs impacting goods from Mexico and Canada for US automakers.

March 6: Trump postpones 25 per cent tariffs on many imports from Mexico and some imports from Canada for a month.

March 10: China's retaliatory 15 per cent tariffs on key American farm products ‚Äî including chicken, pork, soybeans and beef ‚Äî take effect.

March 12: Trump's new tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports go into effect. Both metals are now taxed at 25 per cent across the board. The European Union takes retaliatory trade action promising new duties on US industrial and farm products. The measures will cover goods from the United States worth some 26 billion euros (USD 28 billion). Canada announces plans to impose more retaliatory tariffs worth CAD 29.8 billion (USD 20.7 billion) on US imports, set to go into effect March 13.

March 13: Trump threatens a 200 per cent tariff on European wine, Champagne and spirits if the European Union goes forward with its previously-announced plans for a 50 per cent tariff on American whiskey.

March 24: Trump says he will place a 25 per cent tariff on all imports from any country that buys oil or gas from Venezuela, in addition to imposing new tariffs on the South American country itself, starting April 2.

March 26: Trump says he is placing 25 per cent tariffs on auto imports. These auto imports will start being collected April 3 ‚Äî beginning with taxes on fully-imported cars. The tariffs are set to then expand to applicable auto parts in the following weeks, through May 3.

April 2: Trump announces his long-promised ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs ‚Äî declaring a 10 per cent baseline tax on imports across the board starting April 5, as well as higher rates for dozens of nations that run trade surpluses with the US to take effect April 9. Among those steeper levies, Trump says the US will now charge a 34 per cent tax on imports from China, a 20 per cent tax on imports from the European Union, 25 per cent on South Korea, 24 per cent on Japan and 32 per cent on Taiwan. The new tariffs come on top of previously-imposed levies, including the 20 per cent tax Trump announced on all Chinese imports earlier this year.

April 3: Trump's previously-announced auto tariffs begin. Prime Minister Mark Carney says that Canada will match the 25 per cent levies with a tariff on vehicles imported from the US.

April 4: China announces plans to impose a 34 per cent tariff on imports of all US products beginning April 10, matching Trump's new "reciprocal‚Äù tariff on Chinese goods, as part of a flurry of retaliatory measures. The Commerce Ministry in Beijing says it will also impose more export controls on rare earths.

April 5: Trump's 10 per cent minimum tariff on nearly all countries and territories takes effect.

April 9: Trump's higher ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù rates go into effect. But hours later, his administration says it will suspend most of these higher rates for 90 days, while maintaining the recently-imposed 10 per cent levy on nearly all global imports. China is the exception. After following through on a threat to raise levies against China

title: China, EU and ASEAN should 'deepen' trade ties
content: In the face of persistent trade tensions with the United States, China and other economies should deepen regional economic cooperation and defend the multilateral trade system, said a senior trade ...
resumen: In the face of persistent trade tensions with the United States, China and other economies should deepen regional economic cooperation and defend the multilateral trade system, said Zhao Zhongxiu, president of the University of International Business and Economics in Beijing. Washington's current economic policies, featuring sweeping tariff hikes, represent a unilateral attempt to rewrite global trade rules to its own advantage. These developments have made it more urgent for major economies ‚Äî such as the European Union, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and China ‚Äî to strengthen consensus and deepen cooperation, thereby jointly improving agility and resilience of regional and international supply chains. The so-called reciprocal tariffs have raised the average US tariff rate to nearly 30 percent. That marks a historic regression, undermining the WTO framework that took decades to build. Global tariff negotiations since 1947 have lowered duties in developed economies to 3 to 5 percent. If unchecked, the US policy reversal may trigger retaliatory cycles, pushing the world into a "jungle economy", jeopardizing 86 percent of global trade that relies on free trade rules. Since the US announced the so-called liberation-day tariffs package, China's firm stance and calibrated countermeasures have helped bring Washington back to the negotiation table. On May 12, the two countries announced a series of tariff adjustments aimed at easing trade tensions. Effective US tariffs on Chinese products remain around 50 percent, far higher than pre-2018 levels, according to Zhao. Shared pressure from US tariff measures is pushing China and the EU closer. Coordination between the two is no longer optional ‚Äî it's imperative. This is a critical window of opportunity for the two sides to deepen cooperation and strengthen economic ties. By leveraging shared interests, the two sides can push back protectionist disruptions and reinforce the multilateral trade system. China-EU collaboration could start with "small yet practical initiatives", and gradually elevate strategic dialogue to higher levels to advance broader partnership. China's commitment to green development resonates with the EU's decarbonization efforts, creating opportunity to jointly transform the EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) ‚Äî currently a unilateral carbon pricing instrument ‚Äî into a multilateral framework consistent with WTO rules and global climate responses. China and the EU share common priorities ‚Äî including digital trade facilitation, standards development and consumer protections. Deeper collaboration on emerging issues such as aligning standards in 6G networks could position China and the EU as key pillars stabilizing the multilateral digital trade system in the future, in contrast to the US' "lackluster engagement" in multilateral e-commerce initiatives. Consensus on rules regarding green or digital economy isn't just about economic gains ‚Äî it's about defending a fair and rules-based multilateral system. Resolving lingering disputes, such as the EU's tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles, is also essential for building mutual trust. China and ASEAN are strengthening industrial chain integration under the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, particularly by leveraging rules of origin to reshape regional supply chains. ASEAN can serve as a 'stabilizer' for China's economic growth amid US tariff pressures. By relocating production to ASEAN-based industrial parks, Chinese companies can supply to both local and international markets, with or without access to the US market. For ASEAN, investments from Chinese companies support local industrialization, job creation, and tax revenues. It's win-win ‚Äî as long as China is avoiding domestic industrial hollowing-out. China's ability to respond to US unilateralism and hegemony stems from its supply chain resilience, and its capacity to withstand inventory adjustment cycles. China seeks a full removal of unjustified US tariffs linked to the so-called fentanyl issue. Domestic pressures in the US ‚Äî ranging from public discontent over supply shortages, rising costs, to broader supply chain disruptions ‚Äî have pushed US negotiators to adopt a more pragmatic stance. Despite the current tariff truce, the US could reinstate suspended tariffs or attach new conditions. Washington's habitual use of the so-called 'art of the deal' risks derailing progress with unreasonable and excessive demands. The future of China-US tariff disputes remains highly uncertain. Ultimately, it is a matter of endurance. China has prioritized self-reliance in sci-tech innovation and domestic market expansion, and its new growth drivers have begun to yield results. China's value-added industrial output grew by 6.1 percent on a yearly basis in April. The manufacturing sector's value-added output increased by 6.6 percent year-on-year, with that of equipment manufacturing and high-tech manufacturing up by 9.8 percent and 10 percent, respectively.

title: Misinformation casts shadow on US-China trade truce
content: US President Donald Trump‚Äôs on-again, off-again tariffs have sent jitters through the world economy. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: A tide of misinformation is casting a shadow over a temporary trade truce between Washington and Beijing. The world‚Äôs two biggest economies agreed earlier in May to pause reciprocal tariffs for 90 days. An alternate reality is unfolding across social media platforms, including China‚Äôs Douyin and Weibo, where a surge of falsehoods fuelling anti-American sentiment could undermine the fragile truce. One online video, which garnered millions of views across those platforms and TikTok, claims to show panicked American shoppers snapping up Chinese-branded television sets in the aftermath of trade tensions. That was old footage from 2018 showing Black Friday shopping frenzy at a US supermarket. The falsehood was further amplified by Chinese state media outlets, including China Daily. Other unfounded claims emerged on Chinese platforms about Americans flying to China to shop for Chinese goods, and that US citizens ‚Äì reeling from the economic fallout of the trade war ‚Äì were queuing up to purchase supplies in bulk. Professor Andrew Mertha, director of the SAIS China Global Research Centre at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS), said these narratives are almost certainly curated by the state. Under the May 12 truce, the US agreed to temporarily reduce the tariff on Chinese imports to 30 per cent from 145 per cent, while China said it would lower its import duty on American goods to 10 per cent from 125 per cent. In April, disinformation security firm Cyabra uncovered an anti-US influence campaign on the Elon Musk-owned X involving thousands of fake or bot-operated accounts. They also targeted global brands such as Gucci, Chanel and Amazon. The accounts blamed Mr Trump‚Äôs trade policies for enabling such deceptive marketing practices, while urging consumers to ditch those brands and purchase products directly from China. Mr Dan Brahmy, chief executive of Cyabra, said a third of the accounts weren‚Äôt real, but the backlash they triggered was. In April, AFP also uncovered viral TikTok videos by Chinese content creators promoting the spurious claim that international luxury brands were secretly manufacturing their products in China. Prof Mertha from Johns Hopkins University said these narratives will continue and will evolve in parallel with strengthening the Chinese government‚Äôs negotiating position.

title: Trump‚Äôs Tariffs and Tax Bill May Derail U.S. Battery Industry
content: Domestic factories that make batteries to store power to meet America‚Äôs rising energy demand depend on Chinese components and federal subsidies.
resumen: The batteries produced at an LG Energy Solution factory in Holland, Mich., will store power to balance supply and demand on U.S. electric grids. The silver-colored pouches, roughly the size of two computer keyboards set end to end, will be placed into large battery containers that can be more than 20 feet wide. Electric utilities and other energy companies have begun spending billions of dollars to install scores of such big batteries around the country. The batteries play an increasingly central role in the electricity business, especially in states like California and Texas. President Trump‚Äôs tariffs on China may knock this fledgling industry off course. House Republicans, with Mr. Trump‚Äôs blessing, have passed a budget bill that analysts say would drastically restrict access to subsidies for making and using rechargeable batteries. Tristan Doherty, chief product officer for LG Energy Solution‚Äôs U.S. energy storage unit, Vertech, compared tariffs to a drug that can be deadly at high concentrations. What happens to the companies that make batteries and install them on American grids will affect how quickly the country is able to meet rising power demand and how much that energy will cost. Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs on China have already caused battery costs to rise sharply for U.S. buyers. When U.S. tariffs on Chinese batteries topped 150 percent for a monthlong period starting in April, companies stopped importing cells from China. LG has made batteries for vehicles at its Michigan factory for more than a decade. At the beginning of May, the plant also began making batteries typically used to store energy. The storage batteries use iron and phosphate and go by the name LFP. China makes nearly all LFP batteries. Most U.S. electric cars, by contrast, use batteries made up of materials like nickel and cobalt. The Trump administration temporarily lowered tariffs on China in mid-May, to 30 percent, though batteries face additional levies. The legislation that Republicans advanced would also make it harder to claim lucrative subsidies for making and installing batteries. If the Republican budget bill took effect in its current form, it would be ‚Äúsomething of a kill switch‚Äù for the tax credits available for making batteries, said Antoine Vagneur-Jones, an analyst at BloombergNEF. It also would quickly end tax credits for installing them on the grid. Tesla warned in April that the levies would have an ‚Äúoutsized‚Äù effect on its energy business, which relies on Chinese batteries. Fluence Energy, a company in Arlington, Va., lowered its annual revenue forecast by around 20 percent, saying it was delaying projects and putting off new contracts because of unpredictable U.S. trade policy. John Zahurancik, the company‚Äôs president of the Americas, said it‚Äôs the uncertainty around where the price will be that is the issue. Chris Wright, the energy secretary, seemed ambivalent about them in a March interview with The New York Times. The Trump administration did not directly address batteries but criticized wind and solar energy. The science behind LFP batteries was developed in the 1990s by researchers at the University of Texas at Austin. But it was China that recognized the technology‚Äôs commercial promise. Most manufacturers in the United States make batteries with nickel and cobalt. Arumugam Manthiram, a University of Texas engineering professor whose research helped pave the way for LFP batteries, said that for a long time, the U.S. was not paying too much attention. A123 Systems briefly produced LFP batteries in the United States, only to file for bankruptcy protection in 2012. A Chinese automotive supplier eventually bought most of the company‚Äôs assets. LG Energy Solution, one of the world‚Äôs biggest battery manufacturers, began making cells for cars in Holland. LG had planned to expand the factory to supply Toyota‚Äôs vehicles. The company changed its expansion plan and outfitted a new wing of the factory for LFP production, a $1.4 billion undertaking. When the new assembly lines are running at full tilt, they will make enough cells to satisfy more than a quarter of current U.S. demand for LFP batteries, according to data from LG and Benchmark Mineral Intelligence. The investment decision predated Mr. Trump‚Äôs trade policy announcements, Mr. Doherty said. Another company, AESC, also started making LFP batteries for storage systems this spring, in Tennessee. LG expects that its cells from Holland will not have any Chinese ingredients by early 2026, Mr. Doherty said. Without tax credits, it would not be profitable for LG to make cells in the United States at current battery prices, Mr. Doherty said.

title: How country pacts are driving foreign trade‚Äîand keeping globalization alive
content: The number of trade agreements between two or more countries has increased in the past two decades. And they are, increasingly, going beyond tariffs, which is a tightrope for India to walk on.
resumen:
There are currently 375 regional trade agreements (RTAs) between two or more countries in force, with another 36 in the works, according to a WTO database. Of the active RTAs, 241 have come into effect over the past two decades. The number of unique country pairings covered by these agreements stands at around 5,500.

India is part of 19 RTAs. One such is with the United Arab Emirates (UAE), beginning February 2022. In 2024-25, the UAE accounted for about $37 billion, or about 8%, of India‚Äôs exports.

Developed economies lead in entering into RTAs, having signed thrice the number of RTAs as developing ones on average. They are increasingly pressing for a reduction of non-tariff barriers in such agreements.

The share of global imports from RTA partners increased from 37% in 2010 to 52% in 2022, according to a WTO working paper by Rohini Acharya and Thakur Parajuli.

The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), which came into force in January 2022, comprises 15 East Asian and Asia-Pacific countries, led by China, Japan, South Korea and Australia. The 15 member-countries account for 30.5% of the world's GDP. The European Union accounts for 18% of global GDP.

About two-thirds of RTAs are cross-regional. They are also moving beyond tariffs to cover policy domains related to trade and foreign investments.

Overall export growth shrank by 13.8% in 2020. Among countries with no RTAs, it declined by 14.1%. But, among those with deep trade agreements, the drop was a lower 8.5%.

India is ranked 152nd, with an average depth of 7.2 among the 19 trade agreements signed with 53 countries, according to a database maintained by the WTO. China and Vietnam have an average depth of 14.6 and 15.7, respectively.

title: EE. UU. aplaza hasta el 9 de julio la entrada en vigor de aranceles para la UE
content: La pol√≠tica comercial de Donald Trump genera temores a una recesi√≥n y un brote inflacionario, cada anuncio de nuevos aranceles provoca nerviosismo y volatilidad en los mercados financieros.
resumen: El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, anunci√≥ el domingo que va a aplazar la entrada en vigor de los aranceles del 50% para los productos de la Uni√≥n Europea hasta el 9 de julio, despu√©s de una conversaci√≥n con la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea. Trump atiz√≥ la guerra comercial el viernes y anunci√≥ nuevos aranceles para la Uni√≥n Europea a partir del 1 de junio, pero tras una llamada por tel√©fono con la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, acept√≥ un aplazamiento para tener m√°s tiempo para negociar. Von der Leyen "acaba de llamarme (...) y me pidi√≥ una pr√≥rroga de la fecha del 1 de junio y me dijo que quiere entablar negociaciones serias", declar√≥ Trump a los periodistas. "Yo acept√©", a√±adi√≥. Von der Leyen report√≥ en X que tuvo una llamada positiva con Trump, pero que para llegar a un buen acuerdo, la UE necesita un aplazamiento hasta el 9 de julio. "Europa est√° dispuesta a que avancen las negociaciones de manera r√°pida y decisiva. Para llegar a un buen acuerdo, necesitaremos tiempo hasta el 9 de julio", declar√≥ en la red social X. "La UE y Estados Unidos tienen las relaciones comerciales m√°s importantes y estrechas en el mundo", a√±adi√≥. Estados Unidos y la UE estaban negociando para evitar una guerra comercial transatl√°ntica total y hab√≠an acordado suspender las medidas arancelarias hasta julio, cuando Trump anunci√≥ los aranceles el viernes. Trump lament√≥ que las negociaciones comerciales con el bloque europeo "no est√°n yendo a ninguna parte" y acus√≥ a los europeos de "aprovecharse" de Estados Unidos. El ministro de Finanzas alem√°n, Lars Klingbeil, inst√≥ el domingo a un proceso de "negociaciones serias" y dijo que habl√≥ con el secretario del Tesoro estadounidense, Scott Bessent, sobre el asunto. "No necesitamos m√°s provocaciones, sino negociaciones serias", declar√≥ Klingbeil al diario Bild. "Los aranceles estadounidenses ponen en peligro la econom√≠a estadounidense, tanto como la alemana y la europea", advirti√≥.

title: Sheinbaum y el asamble√≠smo como forma de gobierno
content: La primera vez que Donald Trump amenaz√≥ con imponer los aranceles a los productos y exportaciones mexicanas, la presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum convoc√≥ a una manifestaci√≥n para protestar contra la decisi ...
resumen:
La presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum convoc√≥ a una manifestaci√≥n en el Z√≥calo de la Ciudad de M√©xico el 9 de marzo a las 12 del d√≠a, para protestar contra la decisi√≥n de Estados Unidos de imponer aranceles a los productos y exportaciones mexicanas.

Ahora que el Congreso de los Estados Unidos est√° aprobando el impuesto a las remesas de los migrantes, la presidenta recurre a su estrategia de movilizaciones y protestas, pero esta vez no s√≥lo en territorio mexicano, sino en los Estados Unidos, donde su partido, Morena, tiene ya toda una red de militantes y activistas a los que Sheinbaum estar√≠a pidi√©ndoles que se manifestaran y protestaran contra el plan fiscal de Donald Trump que incluye el impuesto del 3.5% a sus env√≠os de dinero a M√©xico.

La pol√≠tica de ‚Äúmovilizaci√≥n‚Äù y ‚Äúprotestas‚Äù de Sheinbaum parece m√°s la de una lideresa estudiantil o partidista que la de una Jefa de Estado.

La presidenta Sheinbaum amenaza con convocar a los paisanos mexicanos a movilizarse en los Estados Unidos y a enviar cartas y correos para presionar a los congresistas del vecino pa√≠s, mientras que no puede o no quiere controlar las protestas de la CNTE, que cumple ya m√°s de una semana apostado en el Z√≥calo y el centro hist√≥rico.

title: Uni√≥n Europea y Estados Unidos reanudan di√°logo comercial tras pausa temporal de aranceles de Trump
content: La Uni√≥n Europea y Estados Unidos han estado negociando para evitar una escalada generalizada en los aranceles, porque ello abrir√≠a la puerta a una guerra comercial de consecuencias imprevisibles.
resumen:
El comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic, mantendr√° este lunes un contacto telef√≥nico con el secretario estadounidense de Comercio, Howard Lutnick, para nuevas conversaciones sobre aranceles.
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, habl√≥ el domingo con la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n, Ursula von der Leyen, y en ese di√°logo el mandatario estadounidense acord√≥ adoptar congelar hasta el 9 de julio la imposici√≥n de aranceles de 50% que anunci√≥ para el otro mes a bienes europeos que ingresen a Estados Unidos.

title: Centroam√©rica requiere de m√°s espectro para el 5G
content: La cobertura 5G est√° de manera emergente en Am√©rica Latina donde solo un 10% de las conexiones tienen esa tecnolog√≠a. En C.A. est√° presente en Guatemala y Costa Rica que empiezan, mientras los operado ...
resumen: La cobertura 5G est√° de manera emergente en Am√©rica Latina donde solo un 10% de las conexiones tienen esa tecnolog√≠a. En C.A. est√° presente en Guatemala y Costa Rica que empiezan, mientras los operadores est√°n a la espera de mayor espectro para expandirse. M√°s de un 65% de los habitantes de Am√©rica Latina usa internet m√≥vil, se√±ala Global System for Mobile Communications Association (GSMA) en su √∫ltimo reporte de la regi√≥n. Del 100% de estas conexiones, un 65% est√°n en la red 4G, y aunque se hablaba desde antes de la pandemia que se esperaba que para esta fecha la tecnologia 5G ya estuviera lista, los avances no van a un ritmo acelerado y a√∫n se encuentra en su etapa emergente, explica Alejandro Adamowicz, director de Tecnolog√≠a y Estrategia para Am√©rica Latina de GSMA. Los datos de la entidad detallan que la adopci√≥n en Am√©rica Latina est√° por debajo del 10% y que avanza de manera heterog√©nea, porque ya representa un 25% en mercados pioneros como Chile y Brasil (14%). A nivel regional, se espera que se convierta en la generaci√≥n m√≥vil dominante, con m√°s de la mitad de las conexiones m√≥viles, para 2030, dice. En Centroam√©rica, la adopci√≥n es todav√≠a m√°s lenta. En Guatemala cuenta con servicios 5G en algunas ciudades y representa un 8% de las conexiones; mientras que en Costa Rica es de apenas un 0.25%; pero a√∫n hay mercados donde la cobertura total de la 4G est√° incompleta. En El Salvador solo el 39.5% de las conexiones son 4G, en Guatemala representan el 60%; en Honduras, el 54%; en Nicaragua, el 33%; en Costa Rica, el 51% y en Panam√° alcanzan el 66%. En Centroam√©rica, la adopci√≥n del 5G est√° en proceso, con avances visibles pero a√∫n con espacio para acelerar el desarrollo. Seg√∫n an√°lisis de Vertiv, Guatemala, Panam√° y Costa Rica son actualmente los pa√≠ses que han dado pasos m√°s concretos hacia la implementaci√≥n de esta tecnolog√≠a: en Guatemala ya operan dos compa√±√≠as ofreciendo servicios 5G, Panam√° ha iniciado un plan piloto, y Costa Rica lanz√≥ una licitaci√≥n para asignar espectro, explica Germ√°n Torres, Solutions Providers & Enablement Manager de Vertiv Latam. El gobierno lanz√≥ la Agenda Digital 2020-2030, que busca promover el despliegue de tecnolog√≠as m√≥viles avanzadas, como 4G y 5G, en todo el pa√≠s; pero el despliegue de 5G todav√≠a no ha iniciado formalmente. Con la plataforma 5G un estudiante accede con mejor nivel de calidad de reproducci√≥n y de velocidad a un contenido que le ayuda a cumplir una investigaci√≥n acad√©mica; en su smartphone un m√©dico puede recibir, descargar y ver - con la rapidez o la urgencia que requiere- un video de un estudio aplicado a un paciente; y, una abuela tiene una videollamada con su nieto que vive a 16,000 kil√≥metros de distancia, sin latencia y con buena calidad de sonido y voz. Si el 4G transform√≥ la experiencia m√≥vil de los usuarios finales, el 5G va a ser la tecnolog√≠a de soporte de la 4¬∞ Revoluci√≥n Industrial. Adem√°s de velocidades ultrarr√°pidas, 5G tiene dos caracter√≠sticas principales: la posibilidad de conectar dispositivos masivamente (clave para el Internet de las Cosas - IoT) y la baja latencia (es decir, poco retraso entre el env√≠o y la recepci√≥n de informaci√≥n), agrega Adamowicz, de GSMA. La adopci√≥n de esta tecnolog√≠a implicar√° aumento en productividad y eficiencia, que generar√≠an un impacto econ√≥mico de $60,000 millones para 2030 en Am√©rica Latina, equivalente al 0.9% del PIB total de la regi√≥n. Un 43% de esos beneficios econ√≥micos ser√≠an en el sector servicios y un 29% en el sector de manufactura, impulsados por aplicaciones como f√°bricas y ciudades inteligentes. La tecnolog√≠a 5G no solo permite conectar hasta un mill√≥n de dispositivos por kil√≥metro cuadrado, sino que tambi√©n crea un entorno m√°s competitivo, con capacidad para atraer inversi√≥n extranjera directa, fomentar el emprendimiento tecnol√≥gico y generar empleos de alto valor para el talento centroamericano. Las limitaciones para la expansi√≥n del 5G coinciden a grandes rasgos con las del 4G. En el caso de Centroam√©rica, uno de los principales motivos es la escasa disponibilidad de espectro debido a falta de asignaciones a lo largo de muchos a√±os, dice Adamowicz. El espectro asignado a servicios m√≥viles alcanzaba los 250 MHz, la mitad del promedio regional de 500 MHz. En la mayor√≠a de los pa√≠ses de la regi√≥n, todav√≠a no se han licitado. Disponibilizar el espectro adecuado en las cantidades necesarias, a precios y condiciones razonables es un factor fundamental para el √©xito del 5G. La liberaci√≥n y costo del espectro, as√≠ como la necesidad de pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas que incentiven la inversi√≥n en infraestructura, incluyendo antenas, equipos y centros de datos, todos elementos esenciales para un ecosistema 5G robusto. La infraestructura actual a√∫n requiere importantes inversiones y actualizaciones para soportar 5G. Simplificaci√≥n de tr√°mites y requisitos, reconsideraci√≥n de impuestos y tasas que encarezcan el despliegue y el acceso a los servicios, y una regulaci√≥n moderna que otorgue certidumbre jur√≠dica y previsibilidad a largo plazo para las inversiones. El mayor impacto del 5G ser√° en el segmento empresarial. Se necesitan casos de uso que justifiquen las inversiones. Y eso requiere de la colaboraci√≥n entre operadores, gobierno y otras industrias para identificar las aplicaciones que hagan sentido para cada pa√≠s de acuerdo con su perfil productivo. La implantaci√≥n de la red 5G no es un proceso lineal, sino que experimenta estudios, licitaciones, ajustes, pruebas, inversiones y otras etapas que requieren tiempo y trabajo. Durante los √∫ltimos 5 a√±os, en pa√≠ses centroamericanos se han dado pasos claves para que la implantaci√≥n de redes m√≥viles 5G sea eficaz, a trav√©s de infraestructuras estrat√©gicas e incluso con tecnolog√≠as de alimentaci√≥n de energ√≠a que minimicen el impacto ambiental. Samsung Electronics tiene a la red 5G en la agenda para sumar beneficiarios en la regi√≥n a trav√©s de equipos y servicios sintonizados con la red 5G, y al mismo tiempo, apoyar las iniciativas del sector en Centroam√©rica y el Caribe. En 2013, Samsung fue una de las tres empresas que a nivel mundial desarrollaron prototipos de la red 5G. Samsung lanz√≥ el Galaxy S10 5G en 2019, el primer tel√©fono 5G disponible comercialmente en el mundo.

title: Am√©rica Latina, ¬´la guerra secundaria¬ª
content: El comercio entre China y los pa√≠ses latinoamericanos se multiplic√≥ exponencialmente, de 20.000 millones de d√≥lares a principios de siglo a casi 518.000 millones en 2024. Hoy, China es el principal ...
resumen: En 2025 la competencia global por minerales cr√≠ticos -tierras raras, litio, cobalto- y fuentes de energ√≠a -petr√≥leo, gas, renovables- est√°n reconfigurando el poder mundial. La guerra estrat√©gica entre Estados Unidos y China ha escalado, expandiendo su alcance a distintas regiones del mundo, incluida Am√©rica Latina. La presencia de China en la regi√≥n pas√≥ de ser marginal a convertirse en una fuerza dominante. El comercio entre China y los pa√≠ses latinoamericanos se multiplic√≥ exponencialmente, de 20.000 millones de d√≥lares a principios de siglo a casi 518.000 millones en 2024. China es el principal socio comercial de Sudam√©rica y el segundo de Am√©rica Latina en su conjunto. Se consolid√≥ como una fuente clave de Inversi√≥n Extranjera Directa (IED), con m√°s de 180.000 millones de d√≥lares invertidos entre 2014 y 2024, principalmente en infraestructura y extracci√≥n de recursos naturales, en muchos casos canalizadas a trav√©s de la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI). De los 33 pa√≠ses de Am√©rica Latina, 22 ya se han sumado a esta estrategia global de Pek√≠n. Am√©rica Latina se reposiciona como un espacio clave en el ajedrez geopol√≠tico del siglo XXI. Se libra una guerra h√≠brida, donde el campo de batalla no son trincheras, sino deuda externa, tratados econ√≥micos, operaciones de inteligencia, narrativas medi√°ticas y alineamientos diplom√°ticos. Una guerra secundaria, pero con consecuencias primarias. La dificultad radica en la gran desventaja americana con respecto a China demostrada en el retroceso de los aranceles de 142% a 30%. La secuencia para arribar a una cadena de suministros de tierras raras, implica para Estados Unidos un intento desesperado de mitigar su dependencia de China. Se requiere: 1. Acceso territorial a los yacimientos. 2. Capacidad de extracci√≥n. 3. Tecnolog√≠a de refinamiento. Occidente se alej√≥ del procesamiento de tierras raras por razones ambientales, China acept√≥ ese costo y construy√≥ un monopolio: controla m√°s del 90% del procesamiento global, el 60% de las reservas y domina la producci√≥n de imanes industriales. "Quien controla estas materias primas, controla el futuro tecnol√≥gico, economico y militar" y China las controla. EE.UU. recurre a una estrategia conocida, recuperar control en su esfera de influencia hist√≥rica, Am√©rica Latina, en las batallas por el control de recursos naturales vitales o por negar ese control a los rivales, a trav√©s de m√©todos m√°s sofisticados: presiones econ√≥micas, alianzas diplom√°ticas, militarizaci√≥n encubierta y guerras narrativas. La Doctrina Monroe del siglo XXI se activa con nuevos instrumentos, el FMI, el Banco Mundial, acuerdos bilaterales asim√©tricos y "cooperaci√≥n en seguridad". China despliega su propia estrategia pragm√°tica, con swaps monetarios, inversiones en infraestructura y participaci√≥n en sectores clave. El caso argentino es un ejemplo paradigm√°tico. La administraci√≥n Milei impulsa un alineamiento directo con Washington. Esto se refleja en la salida del pa√≠s del BRICS, la ausencia en la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribe (CELAC), el distanciamiento de Uni√≥n de Naciones Suramericanas (UNASUR), y un acercamiento al Comando Sur de Estados Unidos. Las relaciones con China siguen siendo indispensables. En el IV Foro China-CELAC: Brasil firm√≥ acuerdos por 5.000 millones de d√≥lares para producir combustibles sostenibles, autos el√©ctricos y centros de I+D con empresas chinas. Chile, a trav√©s del presidente Boric, defendi√≥ el Corredor Bioce√°nico Capricornio. Colombia, con Petro, se sum√≥ a la Ruta de la Seda, sin condicionalidades neoliberales. La subordinaci√≥n estructural al poder financiero y militar estadounidense no ha resuelto ninguno de los problemas fundamentales de la regi√≥n -ni la pobreza, ni la deuda, ni la desigualdad-. Los pa√≠ses latinoamericanos no pueden ser piezas pasivas. La defensa de sus recursos estrat√©gicos, la regulaci√≥n del capital transnacional, la protecci√≥n de su recursos, la soberan√≠a tecnol√≥gica y pol√≠tica son tareas urgentes.

title: Europe Secured a Tariff Delay From Trump, but Can It Now Make a Deal?
content: Officials from the European Union and the United States will start a new negotiating push, after President Trump delayed until July 9 tariffs of 50 percent.
resumen: President Trump delayed 50 percent tariffs on the European Union by more than a month. Talks will begin rapidly. The goal is for the two sides to reach some solution before July 9, when the 50 percent levies are now set to take effect ‚Äî delayed from the June 1 date Mr. Trump had set when he first announced them last week. Discussions have already resumed. Maros Sefcovic, the E.U.‚Äôs trade commissioner, had a Monday evening phone call with Howard Lutnick, the U.S. commerce secretary. The European Union ‚Äúremains fully committed to constructive and focused efforts‚Äù toward a deal. European negotiators have been hesitant to agree to many of Mr. Trump‚Äôs frequent demands. Trump negotiators also want Europe to roll back key digital regulations that affect social media and technology companies, which E.U. policymakers have said that they will not do. European Union negotiators have been hoping to reduce across-the-board tariffs that took effect in April. The current 10 percent is likely to be the new floor on tariffs. The European Union is still suggesting that both sides could cut tariffs on industrial goods to zero ‚Äî what is often called a ‚Äúzero-for-zero‚Äù strategy. The European Union is pressing forward with refining lists of retaliatory tariffs, levies that European nations could slap on American imports like machinery, soybeans and bourbon. The European Union has unveiled two lists of goods that it could hit with tariffs if negotiations fail: One set worth about $23 billion, and another of about $107 billion that is still being finalized. Mr. Trump announced in April that he would slap high across-the-board tariffs on many American trading partners, including 20 percent levies on the European Union. He then delayed those tariffs for 90 days, instead putting the 10 percent across-the-board tariff into place. Britain‚Äôs deal offered it some benefits ‚Äî like a reduction in auto tariffs ‚Äî it left the 10 percent tariff intact. Bernd Lange, who heads the committee for international trade in the European Parliament, said European negotiators were hoping that offers to reduce the trade deficit by agreeing to buy more American liquefied natural gas and advanced microchips would help to convince U.S. officials to strike a deal.

title: ASEAN leaders to show concern over US tariffs
content: The ASEAN leaders met in Kuala Lumpur as their countries, like others, are set to be hit by Trump's so-called reciprocal tariffs, with U.S. duties on the 10 members of the regional grouping ranging ...
resumen: Leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations are set to show their deep concern over "unilateral tariff measures" without mentioning the United States at their meeting in Malaysia on Monday, according to a draft of the summit chairman's statement obtained by Kyodo News. Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who is chairing the meeting, said at the outset that ASEAN has displayed resilience amid "increasingly complex and sobering global developments," adding, "The global trading system is under further strain, with the recent imposition of U.S. unilateral tariffs." Anwar said he had written to U.S. President Donald Trump to propose an ASEAN-U.S. meeting. The ASEAN leaders met in Kuala Lumpur as their countries, like others, are set to be hit by Trump's so-called reciprocal tariffs, with U.S. duties on the 10 members of the regional grouping ranging from 10 percent to 49 percent. According to the chairman's draft statement, the leaders will warn that the unilateral tariffs pose "complex and multidimensional challenges to ASEAN's economic growth, stability and integration," reaffirming the regional bloc's commitment to a "nondiscriminatory multilateral trading system, with the World Trade Organization at its core." Following Trump's announcement of the tariffs, ASEAN trade ministers held a special virtual meeting in April. Besides tariffs, the ongoing civil war in Myanmar, following a coup in February 2021 that ousted the elected government led by Aung San Suu Kyi, was believed to have been discussed at the summit, with the issue mentioned in the draft statement. The junta in Myanmar and the other members of ASEAN reached a so-called five-point consensus in April 2021, including on the need for an immediate end to violence. Further humanitarian assistance for Myanmar, the central region of which was hit by an earthquake on March 28 that killed over 3,700 people, would be stressed, the draft statement showed, including a call by the leaders for greater international financial support. Anwar said at the outset of Monday's summit that ASEAN has been able to take "positive steps" within an informal advisory group that he launched by requesting former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra to serve as an adviser. From Myanmar, Aung Kyaw Moe, permanent secretary of its Foreign Ministry, is participating in the summit as ASEAN has only allowed attendance by a nonpolitical representative from the country since October 2021, effectively excluding the junta chief. Other issues thought to have been discussed include East Timor's accession to ASEAN. The regional bloc's leaders in 2022 agreed in principle to admit the country as the 11th member once it fulfills various conditions. ASEAN groups Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.

title: Geopolitical tensions lead to increasing risks for shipping sector globally
content: Despite geopolitical headwinds: only 27 large ships lost worldwide in 2024, down by more than 20%, the industry's lowest-ever total. Progress made on traditional risks such as fires, collisions, and ...
resumen:
Geopolitical tensions are creating new risks and challenges for the shipping industry, already dealing with the energy transition and the Covid-19 pandemic. The industry faces a volatile and complex operating environment, marked by attacks against shipping, vessel detentions, sanctions, and incidents involving damage to sub-sea cables. Increasing protectionism and tariffs threaten to reshape supply chains and trade relations.

90% of international trade is transported across oceans. The industry continues to see the potential for large claims from traditional risks such as fires, collisions, and groundings, which are still the main drivers for total losses of large vessels.

The shipping industry has made significant improvements in maritime safety in recent years. In the 1990s, the global fleet lost 200+ vessels a year. This total is now down to a record low of 27 as of the end of 2024 (from 35 in 2023).

US-China trade conflict and the growing shadow fleet bring uncertainty and challenges. Approximately 18% of global maritime trade was subject to tariffs as of mid-April 2025, compared with 4% in early March. The shadow fleet has grown significantly since the start of the war in Ukraine. Around 17% of the world tanker fleet is thought to belong to the shadow fleet; estimates indicate there are close to 600 tankers trading Russian oil alone. Shadow fleet vessels have been involved in tens of incidents around the world.

Cleanup costs for an oil spill involving a shadow fleet tanker could be as much as US$1.6bn.

Many ship operators have rerouted vessels around the Cape of Good Hope, adding time and cost to transits between Asia and Europe. Rerouting adds around $1mn in costs and at least 10 days to a typical transit between China and Europe. Cargo volumes in the strait had fallen by two-thirds by September 2024, with rerouting costing the global economy some US$200bn that year.

Large vessel fires remain a major concern. There were seven total losses reported across all vessel types during 2024, the same number as a year earlier. The number of incidents overall was up year-on-year to a decade high of 250, again across all vessel types. Around 30% of these fire incidents occurred on either container, cargo or roll-on roll-off vessels (ro-ros) (69). More than 100 total losses of vessels have been caused by fires in the past decade.

There are over 100,000 ships (100GT+) in the global fleet.

title: Volvo Cars Cuts 3,000 Jobs Amid Economic Pressures
content: Volvo Cars plans to lay off 3,000 employees, primarily in Sweden, as part of a cost-cutting initiative driven by economic uncertainties and trade tensions. The automotive industry faces challenges ...
resumen: Volvo Cars plans to lay off 3,000 employees, primarily in Sweden, as part of a cost-cutting initiative driven by economic uncertainties and trade tensions. The reductions include approximately 1,200 jobs in Sweden and an additional 1,000 consultant positions, mostly in Sweden. The remaining job cuts will affect global markets, predominantly targeting office roles. The CEO, H√•kan Samuelsson, emphasized that these measures are crucial for bolstering Volvo's resilience. The automotive industry is grappling with several challenges, including heightened raw material costs and significant tariffs imposed by the US government. Owned by Geely of China, Volvo Cars employs 42,600 people and operates in Sweden, Belgium, South Carolina, and China.

title: Pharmacists stockpile medicines ahead of possible Trump tariffs on overseas drugmakers
content: They worry tariffs, aimed at bringing drug production to the United States, could instead drive companies out of business while raising prices and creating more of the drug shortages that have plagued ...
resumen: Pharmacists are stockpiling medicines due to potential tariffs on overseas drugmakers. Independent pharmacist Benjamin Jolley and his colleagues are concerned that tariffs, aimed at bringing drug production to the U.S., could raise prices and create drug shortages. President Donald Trump announced a 10% tariff on imported goods on April 2, with threats of additional tariffs targeting pharmaceuticals. The U.S. imported $213 billion worth of medicines in 2024. Pharmacists predict even the 10% tariffs will hurt. Scott Pace, a pharmacist, stocked up on the top 200 generics. Tariffs could be the death knell for independent pharmacies. Neal Smoller fears FDA firings will mean fewer federal inspections. Marta Wosi≈Ñska said narrowly focused tariffs might work in some cases. John Murphy, CEO of the Association for Accessible Medicines, said tariffs won‚Äôt incentivize generic drug makers to build new factories in the U.S. Fresenius Kabi, a German company, complained that tariffs on raw materials could lead some companies to move finished product manufacturing overseas. Tariffs on biosimilars could incentivize U.S. use of more expensive brand-name biologics. European countries pay far less than the United States for brand-name products.

title: Defensa y respuesta a Trump, los temas que Asturias pide que se traten en la Conferencia de Presidentes
content: El Ejecutivo de Barb√≥n tambi√©n plantea analizar la red de 0 a 3 y esta vez aparca la siniestralidad laboral. Moncloa cerrar√° este mi√©ercoles el orden del d√≠a de la cita d ...
resumen: El 6 de junio se celebrar√° la XXVIII Conferencia de Presidentes en el Palacio de Pedralbes, Barcelona. El Ejecutivo de Pedro S√°nchez tiene la intenci√≥n de centrarse en las pol√≠ticas de acceso a la vivienda, la Formaci√≥n Profesional y la universitaria. El Ministerio de Pol√≠tica Territorial remiti√≥ una carta a cada gobierno auton√≥mico invit√°ndoles a hacer sus propuestas antes del viernes. El Principado de Asturias respondi√≥ defendiendo un debate sobre las acciones coordinadas en materia de pol√≠tica arancelaria. El presidente asturiano, Adri√°n Barb√≥n, se reuni√≥ con representantes de Fade, UGT y CC OO para presentarles un plan de respuesta a los aranceles anunciados por Donald Trump, que aspira a movilizar 30 millones para auxiliar a las empresas que m√°s exportan a EE UU. El Ejecutivo asturiano quiere incorporar a la cita las inversiones en seguridad y defensa. Espa√±a destina un 1,28% del PIB a esta materia (unos 15.958 millones). La OTAN presiona al gobierno espa√±ol para que alcance el 5% del PIB. Asturias propone ampliar los puntos educativos propuestos por Moncloa para que se hable de la red de 0 a 3 a√±os. La anterior Conferencia de Presidentes tuvo lugar en diciembre. El Principado solicit√≥ incorporar la siniestralidad laboral, reforzar las pol√≠ticas de salud mental y la lucha contra la violencia. La XXVII cita se limit√≥ a tratar la financiaci√≥n auton√≥mica, la migraci√≥n, la vivienda y la necesidad de refuerzos de personal en el sistema sanitario. Ma√±ana mi√©rcoles tendr√° lugar la reuni√≥n del comit√© preparatorio.
