title: Hang Seng Dips, Nikkei Gains as Trade Signals Drive Divergent Moves
content: Asian stock markets mixed as Trump‚Äôs tariff threats rattle Wall Street; Hang Seng dips, Nikkei gains on U.S.-Japan trade hopes.
resumen:
China‚Äôs state media warned of a prolonged US-China trade standoff, undermining hopes of a lasting deal.
The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.40% as trade jitters pressured property and tech stocks in early Monday trading.
The ASX 200 slipped 0.09% with Aussie bank stocks under pressure from higher US Treasury yields and weak sentiment.
US markets slumped as investors reacted to President Trump‚Äôs latest tariff threat.
The Nasdaq Composite Index slid 1%, while the Dow and S&P 500 dropped 0.61% and 0.67%, respectively.
On Friday, Trump threatened the EU with a 50% tariff, effective June 1.
The negative sentiment spilled into the Asian session on Monday, May 26.
CN Wire reported: ‚ÄúChina must maintain a clear-eyed understanding of the challenges ahead, noting the U.S. may adopt delaying tactics to mitigate its economic losses. Given the enduring and complex nature of the confrontation, China must not only prepare thoroughly for negotiations but also brace for a prolonged struggle.‚Äù
Though the US and China recently agreed to a 90-day tariff pause, a lack of progress may spook investors as the deadline approaches.
Brian Tycangco, editor at Stansberry Research, commented: ‚ÄúAs I‚Äôve said previously, we just had a pause- not a deal. China isn‚Äôt under any illusion that this is an easy road to travel. Get ready for more volatility.‚Äù
The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.40% in early trade.
The Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index fell 0.10%, while the Hang Seng Tech Index rose 0.32%.
BYD Corp. (01211) and Li Auto (02015) rallied 1.97% and 1.07%, respectively.
The CSI 300 declined 0.17%, while the Shanghai Composite edged 0.05% lower.
Japan‚Äôs Nikkei 225 gained 0.88% on Monday morning as investors reacted to US-EU trade headlines.
On May 25, President Trump postponed the 50% tariff on EU goods from June 1 to July 9.
The US and Japan could resume trade talks as Japan‚Äôs top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa prepares to visit Washington.
The USD/JPY pair by 0.05% to 142.619.
Tokyo Electron (8035) and Softbank Group (9984) advancing 1.96% and 1.49%, respectively.
Australia‚Äôs ASX 200 slipped 0.09% in the morning session as elevated US Treasury yields weighed on demand for high-yielding Aussie bank stocks.
Commonwealth Bank of Australia fell 0.43%, while ANZ slid 1.08%.
Northern Star Resources rallied 0.81%, following gold‚Äôs 1.89% surge on May 23.
Volatility remains elevated amid fiscal uncertainty and tariff concerns.
US-China negotiations will remain central to near-term sentiment.
Investors should monitor stimulus cues from Beijing and global central banks.

title: Gold consolidates at pivotal area ahead of US economic data and Fed signals
content: Gold (XAU/USD) continues to be caught between fundamental pressures and technical signals. Recent political and economic developments have created uncertainty, making traders cautious about taking ...
resumen:
Gold (XAU/USD) is caught between fundamental pressures and technical signals. Recent developments have created uncertainty, making traders cautious. After a strong rally last week, gold has slowed down.

Fundamental drivers for gold remain mixed but slightly tilted in favor of the yellow metal. US President Donald Trump's decision to delay the 50% tariff on the European Union until July 9 sparked some trade optimism. This reduced immediate fears of a trade war, applying short-term downward pressure on safe-haven assets like gold. However, that optimism is being offset by mounting fiscal concerns in the US. Trump's recently passed spending bill could expand the federal deficit by $4 trillion over the next decade. This has reignited worries over the country's financial stability.

Economic indicators continue to suggest a slowing US economy. Recent softer-than-expected readings in both the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and Producer Price Index (PPI) have increased the likelihood of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Traders are now pricing in at least two 25-basis-point cuts in 2025. Since gold is a non-yielding asset, a lower interest rate environment typically boosts its appeal to investors. In addition, geopolitical tensions remain high, particularly due to the ongoing war in Ukraine and the volatile situation in the Middle East. These conflicts support safe-haven demand and help limit deeper losses in gold despite occasional price corrections.

The weakness in the US Dollar also plays a key role in supporting gold prices. The greenback has been in a consistent downtrend for the past two weeks and has just hit a fresh monthly low. Since gold is priced in dollars, a weaker dollar makes it cheaper for foreign buyers and therefore boosts demand. Traders now await upcoming economic events for clearer direction. These include the FOMC meeting minutes and key US data releases such as Durable Goods Orders, GDP, and the PCE Price Index. Until these reports are released, the fundamental picture suggests that gold may find support on dips. However, it could face resistance in pushing significantly higher in the near term.

The gold chart shows a clear descending channel in its market trend. This pattern has existed since mid-April, guiding the price action with lower highs and lower lows. The price has recently reached the upper boundary of the descending channel, which has acted as a strong resistance in past attempts. Gold is once again testing this resistance around the $3,358 level. Support remains near the channel's lower boundary, which lies just above the $3,100 level. The dashed midline of the channel shows a key area of price equilibrium. Gold recently broke above it, suggesting short-term bullishness. However, the broader bearish trend remains intact unless the price decisively breaks out of the upper trend line.

title: Trump delaying 50% tariff on European Union
content: The president said Sunday he‚Äôs agreed to delay a 50% tariff on the EU that he threatened last week, after saying negotiations with the commission were ‚Äúgoing nowhere.‚Äù ...
resumen: President Donald Trump has announced a delay on proposed tariffs on the European Union until July 9, 2025. The 50% tariff on EU goods would have kicked in starting June 1, but Trump said his agreement to an extension sets the new date at July 9, 2025. This decision followed a request from European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. Trump said he had agreed to the extension as a privilege. Trump said the 27-member bloc had been "very difficult to deal with." Trump posted on Truth Social Sunday evening, saying it was his "privilege" to have agreed to an extension, and said that von der Leyen said their talks will begin rapidly. Von der Leyen posted earlier on X that she had a "good call" with Trump. The EU and US share the world‚Äôs most consequential and close trade relationship. Europe is ready to advance talks swiftly and decisively. To reach a good deal, we would need the time until July 9. The core of Trump‚Äôs argument against the EU is that America runs a "totally unacceptable" trade deficit with the 27 member states. If implemented, a 50% tariff would be higher than the 30% tariff on China.

title: Apple has had few incentives in past to start making iPhones in US
content: Lashing out at Apple's plans to make most of its U.S. iPhones in India, President Donald Trump on Friday threatened to slap a 25 percent tariff on the popular device unless the tech giant starts ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened to slap a 25 percent tariff on the iPhone unless Apple starts building the product in the U.S.
Apple has been building most of its devices in China for decades, investing tens of billions of dollars on massive factories.
Apple CEO Tim Cook said that most iPhones sold in the U.S. during the March-June period would come from India.
Cook said the trade war would end up costing Apple an additional $900 million during the March-June period.
Industry analysts estimated the fees would drive up the cost of a $1,200 iPhone made in China to $1,500.
Analysts believe if Apple could start making iPhones in the U.S., prices would soar to at least $2,000 and possibly as high as $3,500.
The disincentives for Apple shifting its production domestically include a complex supply chain that Cook began to engineer during the 1990s.
It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build new plants in the U.S.
The price of an iPhone could triple, threatening to torpedo sales of Apple's marquee product, which generated revenue of $201 billion during the company's last fiscal year.
Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives estimated that the current $1,000 price tag for an iPhone made in China, or India, would soar to more than $3,000 if production shifted to the U.S.
Ives believes that moving production domestically likely couldn't be done until, at the earliest, 2028.
Ives predicted Cook would engage in a "game of negotiations" with Trump that would spare the iPhone from the 25 percent tariffs.
Apple executive Eddy Cue said that people may not need an iPhone 10 years from now.
Cook told investors that tariffs had a "limited impact" on the company in the March quarter.
Cook warned that it is "very difficult" to predict beyond June "because I'm not sure what will happen with tariffs."
Forrester Research analyst Dipanjan Chatterjee said that Apple continues to reap huge profit margins from the revenue generated by subscriptions and other services tied to its product, which collected $96 billion in revenue during Apple's last fiscal year.
U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick predicted tariffs would force a manufacturing shift.
Cook expressed doubt about whether the U.S. labor pool had enough workers with the vocational skills required to do the work.

title: ‚ÄòThe best chance we‚Äôve got‚Äô: Can Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent save the world from trade Armageddon?
content: As President Donald Trump conducted an impromptu news conference in Doha, Qatar, this month, surrounded by business leaders and top advisers, he made a point of singling out one person in particular.
resumen:
En una conferencia de prensa improvisada en Doha, Qatar, el presidente Donald Trump destac√≥ a Scott Bessent, Secretario del Tesoro, quien hab√≠a asegurado un acuerdo para pausar temporalmente la guerra comercial entre EE. UU. y China. Trump elogi√≥ a Bessent, afirmando que los mercados escuchan cuando √©l habla. Bessent, conocido por su discreci√≥n, respondi√≥ que ten√≠an un plan y un mecanismo para evitar la escalada comercial.

Bessent es considerado el funcionario econ√≥mico m√°s importante del mundo, siendo el principal negociador de Trump con China, liderando conversaciones comerciales con otros pa√≠ses y participando en la elaboraci√≥n de un paquete fiscal y de gasto. Tambi√©n es responsable de mantener el papel dominante de Estados Unidos en el sistema financiero global.

Bessent se ha convertido en una figura clave en la administraci√≥n, gan√°ndose la confianza de legisladores, funcionarios y ejecutivos. Ha tenido √©xito en luchas internas para consolidar su rol y es visto por Wall Street como la mejor esperanza para moderar las pol√≠ticas econ√≥micas de Trump.

Antes de unirse a la administraci√≥n, Bessent estudi√≥ la biograf√≠a de William McKinley, un √≠dolo de Trump en materia de aranceles. Aunque subestim√≥ el entusiasmo de Trump por los aranceles, escribi√≥ a inversores que era poco probable que se implementaran aranceles generalizados al mismo tiempo que se abordaba la crisis migratoria.

Bessent, ausente de la Casa Blanca y los medios de comunicaci√≥n durante una reuni√≥n de ministros de finanzas del G7 en Canad√°, fue objeto de comentarios sobre su importancia. Trump anunci√≥ la recomendaci√≥n de aranceles del 50% a la Uni√≥n Europea y del 25% a los iPhones de Apple. Bessent, en Nueva York, fue entrevistado en Fox News y Bloomberg TV.

Antes de ser Secretario del Tesoro, Bessent particip√≥ en una operaci√≥n financiera exitosa en 1992, trabajando para el fondo de cobertura de George Soros. Su experiencia incluye estudios en Yale y el trabajo con Jim Rogers, quien lo introdujo al mundo de las finanzas.

En 2017, Bessent busc√≥ entender la administraci√≥n Trump, conectando con Steve Bannon para comprender la visi√≥n econ√≥mica de Trump. Bessent don√≥ a republicanos y mantuvo relaciones positivas en Wall Street.

Bannon considera a Bessent un jugador clave en la gesti√≥n del mercado de bonos. Cuando las conversaciones lideradas por Bessent con China llevaron a una desescalada arancelaria, Bannon defendi√≥ a Bessent.

Bessent tiene una relaci√≥n de larga data con la familia Trump y ha sido un defensor de causas LGBTQ. En una entrevista, Bessent relat√≥ un momento en el Despacho Oval con su familia, donde presenciaron el trabajo del gobierno.

Bessent predijo la victoria de Trump en 2023, bas√°ndose en el an√°lisis de las acciones que suben con las malas noticias. Su decisi√≥n de ayudar a la campa√±a de Trump se bas√≥ en su preocupaci√≥n por la deuda de EE. UU.

Bessent ha influido en las pol√≠ticas de Trump, como la pausa en los aranceles. Su enfoque en el rendimiento del Tesoro a 10 a√±os es notable.

En la Conferencia Global del Instituto Milken, Bessent explic√≥ que los componentes principales de la agenda econ√≥mica de Trump (comercio, recortes de impuestos y desregulaci√≥n) son partes interconectadas de un motor dise√±ado para impulsar la inversi√≥n a largo plazo en la econom√≠a estadounidense.

Los asesores econ√≥micos de Trump enfatizan que su agenda incluye incentivos fiscales y regulatorios, junto con los aranceles, para impulsar la inversi√≥n y el crecimiento. Los aranceles est√°n dise√±ados para encajar en un marco m√°s amplio que se centra en los recortes de impuestos y la desregulaci√≥n.

La agenda busca equilibrar los incentivos fiscales y la desregulaci√≥n con los aranceles, para evitar una recesi√≥n. Si alguno de estos elementos falla, la pol√≠tica econ√≥mica podr√≠a colapsar.

title: Malasia lista para la cumbre de la ASEAN con √©nfasis en guerra comercial, Gaza y Birmania
content: Kuala Lumpur, 25 may (EFE).- Malasia tiene todo listo para la cumbre de l√≠deres de la Asociaci√≥n de Naciones del Sudeste Asi√°tico (ASEAN) que arrancar√° el lunes en Kuala Lumpur, con √©nfasis en la guer ...
resumen:
Malasia est√° lista para la cumbre de l√≠deres de la Asociaci√≥n de Naciones del Sudeste Asi√°tico (ASEAN) que arrancar√° el lunes en Kuala Lumpur, con √©nfasis en la guerra comercial iniciada por Estados Unidos, la continuaci√≥n de los ataques israel√≠es sobre Gaza y la crisis en Birmania (Myanmar).

El ministro de Exteriores malasio, Datuk Seri Mohamad Hasan, adelant√≥ que la cumbre de este a√±o incluye por primera vez un espacio trilateral en el que la ASEAN conversar√° sobre seguridad con China y el Consejo de Cooperaci√≥n del Golfo (CCG), conformado por Bar√©in, Kuwait, Om√°n, Catar, Arabia Saudita y los Emiratos √Årabes Unidos.

El canciller malasio llam√≥ a fortalecer urgentemente la integraci√≥n econ√≥mica regional para hacer frente a los aranceles anunciados por el presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, -congelados hasta julio- y a la competencia entre las superpotencias, en alusi√≥n a las tensiones entre Pek√≠n y Washington. La ASEAN debe asumir un papel activo para afrontar ‚Äúlas turbulencias de los pr√≥ximos a√±os‚Äù y ‚Äúproteger mejor‚Äù la regi√≥n, en la que viven cerca de 700 millones de personas y en la que se proyecta que el producto interior bruto (PIB) colectivo crezca un 4,7 % este a√±o, en comparaci√≥n con el 4,2 % de 2024.

El consejo econ√≥mico de la ASEAN celebr√≥ una reuni√≥n para abordar este tema y reconoci√≥ la necesidad de ‚Äúromper con el enfoque tradicional y adoptar estrategias m√°s audaces, √°giles y con visi√≥n de futuro para salvaguardar y promover los intereses socioecon√≥micos‚Äù de estos pa√≠ses.

En asuntos internacionales, el canciller malasio inst√≥ a la ASEAN a ‚Äúexpresarse con firmeza y cohesi√≥n en defensa del derecho internacional‚Äù en casos como los ataques israel√≠es sobre Gaza. La comunidad regional ‚Äúno debe permanecer al margen ante las injusticias globales‚Äù y, por el contrario, debe ‚Äúhacer o√≠r su voz en el escenario internacional para defender a los oprimidos y promover soluciones basadas en el derecho internacional‚Äù.

El canciller malasio dijo: ‚ÄúEl asedio total de Gaza por parte de las fuerzas israel√≠es est√° causando hambrunas y muertes masivas. Las atrocidades cometidas contra el pueblo palestino siguen reflejando indiferencia y dobles raseros‚Äù.

Indonesia, la naci√≥n con la mayor poblaci√≥n musulmana del mundo, se ha plegado al llamamiento de Malasia.

Los cancilleres de la ASEAN reiteraron la necesidad de continuar con los esfuerzos para restablecer la normalidad en Birmania, que vive un conflicto armado entre los militares que detentan el poder y grupos prodemocr√°ticos y guerrillas √©tnicas.

El canciller malasio dijo: ‚ÄúInstamos a las partes interesadas a cesar las hostilidades y a extender y ampliar el alto el fuego, para facilitar el largo y dif√≠cil camino hacia la recuperaci√≥n y aliviar el sufrimiento del pueblo‚Äù, en alusi√≥n a la situaci√≥n del pa√≠s luego del terremoto del 28 de marzo, que dej√≥ cerca de 3.800 muertos.

title: Trump threatens Apple with 25% tariff: Is now a good time to buy an iPhone?
content: In addition to promising a 50% tariff on the European Union, unless E.U. leaders come to an agreement with the Trump administration within approximately nine days, the president threatened Apple with ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened Apple with 25% tariffs on any iPhone sold, and not made, in the U.S.

Trump posted on Truth Social, his social-media platform, on Friday: "I have long ago informed Tim Cook of Apple (AAPL) that I expect their iPhone's [sic] that will be sold in the United States of America will be manufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else."

Ming-Chi Kuo, TF International Securities analyst, said the costs would likely make such a move prohibitive.

A 25% tariff would mean hundreds of additional dollars on an iPhone price tag.

Prices for the iPhone product line start at $799 and go as high as $1,599 for the iPhone 16 Pro Max.

The iPhone 16 is powered by an "A18 Bionic" chip, integrates artificial intelligence into its camera control and has 85% recycled content.

Alex Kidman, who writes Alex Reviews Tech, said the iPhone 16's 60Hz screen at this price is "indefensible," and cited "inconsistent battery life and overly hot Qi2 charging." (60Hz means the screen updates 60 times every second.).

Some 36% of iPhone buyers in the 12 months ending December 2024 reported having their previous phone for two years or less, compared with 31% in the prior year.

The household savings rate in the U.S. fell to 3.9% in March from 4.1% in February. It averaged 8.4% from 1959 until 2025, reaching an all-time high of 32% in April 2020 and a record low of 1% in July 2005, according to Trading Economics.

Andrzej Skiba, head of U.S. fixed income at RBC Global Asset Management, said the environment surrounding Trump's trade approach may also ensure that borrowing costs remain elevated. "The Fed," he said, "won't likely be able to cut rates in this environment."

title: Trump‚Äôs EU tariff threat could cause economic damage beyond Europe
content: President Donald Trump's threat to impose a 50% tariff on all goods coming into the United States from the European Union starting next weekend was the latest zag after several zigs on trade policy ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 50% tariff on all goods coming into the United States from the European Union starting next weekend.
Agathe Demarais, a senior policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations, stated that no one was expecting this and they don‚Äôt have a clue as to what it means.
Carsten Brzeski, chief eurozone economist at ING, a Dutch bank, warned that such tariff levels could lead to a combination of higher inflation and slower growth in the United States.
Europe could be pushed into a recession, and global growth would fall.
Julian Hinz, a trade researcher at the Kiel Institute for the World Economy, calculated that U.S. economic growth would drop 1.5%.
Neil Shearing, chief economist at Capital Economics, said the scale of the increase in tariffs, the capricious manner in which they were threatened and the growing size of U.S. budget deficits are unsettling financial markets.
Moody‚Äôs downgraded the U.S. credit rating.
Mary E. Lovely, an emeritus professor of economics at Syracuse University, said companies across the board are already raising their assessments of the riskiness of investments in the United States.
Maurice Obstfeld, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics and a former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, said that if you hit back hard, markets will get nervous, and the president will back off.
European officials have prepared a raft of countermeasures in response to higher U.S. tariffs.
Roughly a fifth of EU exports go the United States, and about the same share of American exports go to the European Union.
The European Union has threatened to put tariffs on the American services sector.
If Trump does end up imposing 50% tariffs on June 1, Ireland would be hit the hardest, with an estimated 4% decline in total economic output, according to Capital Economics.
Germany‚Äôs gross domestic product is projected to shrink by around 1.5%, Italy‚Äôs by 1.2%, France by 0.75% and Spain by 0.5%.
Mark Blyth, a political economist at Brown University, said that in 2008, both the U.S. and Europe had the same size economies.
Now, Europe‚Äôs economy is one-third smaller.

title: Trump confirma que retrasa hasta el 9 de julio los aranceles del 50% a la UE
content: Von der Leyen recalca que "la UE y Estados Unidos tienen la relaci√≥n comercial m√°s relevante y estrecha del mundo" ...
resumen:
Donald Trump, presidente de Estados Unidos, ha aceptado retrasar hasta el 9 de julio los aranceles del 50% a la Uni√≥n Europea (UE).

La decisi√≥n se anunci√≥ tras una conversaci√≥n telef√≥nica con Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea.

Trump declar√≥ en su plataforma Truth Social: "He recibido una llamada de Ursula von der Leyen solicitando una pr√≥rroga del plazo del 1 de junio sobre el arancel del 50% con respecto al comercio y la Uni√≥n Europea. He accedido a la pr√≥rroga -9 de julio-".

Von der Leyen inform√≥ que mantuvo una "buena conversaci√≥n" con Trump, abordando las negociaciones comerciales en curso.

Von der Leyen public√≥ en su cuenta de la red social X que "la UE y Estados Unidos tienen la relaci√≥n comercial m√°s relevante y estrecha del mundo".

Von der Leyen a√±adi√≥ que "Europa est√° lista para avanzar r√°pida y firmemente en las conversaciones. Necesitaremos hasta el 9 de julio para alcanzar un buen acuerdo".

Lars Klingbeil, ministro de Finanzas alem√°n, expres√≥ "cauto optimismo" sobre las posibilidades de acuerdo.

Paula Pinho, portavoz jefa de la Comisi√≥n Europea, indic√≥ que Trump y Von der Leyen acordaron acelerar las negociaciones comerciales y mantenerse en estrecho contacto.

Pinho dijo que "hablamos de la relaci√≥n comercial m√°s grande y cercana del mundo; estos asuntos son complejos y llevan tiempo".

Pinho precis√≥ que la llamada con Trump "la inici√≥" Von der Leyen y que no abordaron otros asuntos como la guerra en Ucrania sino que "el foco estuvo en las discusiones comerciales".

Trump public√≥ en su red social Truth Social: "Pa√≠ses de todo el mundo quieren hacer acuerdos comerciales con nosotros. ¬°Es maravilloso! ¬°Estados Unidos pronto experimentar√° un crecimiento tremendo y ser√° m√°s fuerte que nunca!".

Carlos Cuerpo, ministro de Econom√≠a, afirm√≥ que algunos de los aranceles que ya aplica Estados Unidos est√°n afectando a empresas europeas y hay que "conseguir llegar a un acuerdo equilibrado lo antes posible".

Cuerpo a√±adi√≥ que la UE pondr√° todos los esfuerzos necesarios para alcanzar un acuerdo antes del 9 de julio, pero con un "punto de firmeza".

Trump advirti√≥ el pasado viernes que las negociaciones comerciales con la UE "no van a ninguna parte", por lo que amenaz√≥ con imponer un arancel del 50% sobre los productos europeos desde el 1 de junio.

title: Aguascalientes registr√≥ inversiones por 222 mdd
content: Los anuncios registrados este a√±o provienen de M√©xico, Jap√≥n, Francia, Estados Unidos, Italia y Canad√°; son principalmente proyectos industriales.
resumen:
De enero a abril del 2025, el estado de Aguascalientes sum√≥ anuncios de inversi√≥n por 222 millones de d√≥lares, casi 4,444 millones de pesos, con base en los registros internos de la Secretar√≠a de Desarrollo Econ√≥mico, Ciencia y Tecnolog√≠a del estado (Sedecyt).

Ese monto reflej√≥ una disminuci√≥n de 62.6% frente a los 594 millones de d√≥lares que se acumularon en el mismo lapso del a√±o previo.

Los anuncios registrados este a√±o provienen de M√©xico, Jap√≥n, Francia, Estados Unidos, Italia y Canad√°; son principalmente proyectos industriales, en los sectores de tecnolog√≠as de la informaci√≥n, automotriz, el√©ctrico y gesti√≥n de residuos industriales.

El secretario de Desarrollo Econ√≥mico, Ciencia y Tecnolog√≠a de Aguascalientes, Esa√∫ Garza de Vega, explic√≥ que en el primer cuatrimestre del a√±o fue positiva la confirmaci√≥n de inversiones en Aguascalientes, atrayendo proyectos tanto internacionales como nacionales.

En abril se anunciaron inversiones originarias de Estados Unidos, de Canad√°, entre otros pa√≠ses.

Hay proyectos que est√°n en pausa hasta tener m√°s claridad en la pol√≠tica arancelaria de Estados Unidos, el principal socio comercial de M√©xico.

Algunos capitales que fueron anunciados el a√±o pasado, comenzaron a concretarse en este 2025, se reflejan en aquellas empresas que est√°n contratando personal y est√°n pr√≥ximas a iniciar operaciones.

Aguascalientes, adem√°s de recibir proyectos extranjeros, tambi√©n est√° recibiendo capitales nacionales.

El desarrollo de proveedores locales y nacionales es una de las acciones que emprende el estado como parte de su estrategia para atraer inversiones, explic√≥ el titular de la Sedecyt.

Tambi√©n se busca atraer proyectos que est√°n relacionados con los procesos productivos que necesita la entidad.

Est√°n priorizando captar inversiones que tengan un enfoque en el cuidado al medio ambiente y que incentiven el desarrollo de las comunidades donde se instalan.

title: The bad economic vibes are causing more people to stock up on gold
content: Gold bugs are popping up on a wider scale, with global demand for gold bars rising 13% year-over-year in the first quarter.
resumen: The bad economic vibes are causing more people to stock up on gold. Demand for physical gold jumped 13% in the first quarter, according to the World Gold Council. Gold dealers say clients are worried about the dollar's decline, a debt crisis, and other scenarios. Marc Faber, a longtime investor, has been buying gold for decades and telling other people to stock up. He's eyeing a debt crisis, a plunge in asset prices, and soaring inflation. Faber said he buys gold regularly, with the metal comprising 25% of his overall portfolio. Global demand for gold bars climbed to 257 metric tons in the first quarter of 2025, up 13% in a year, according to the World Gold Council. Joe Cavatoni, a market strategist at the World Gold Council, said he believes concerns about the US dollar, economic weakness in the US, and the government's debt and deficit are several reasons gold demand is rising. Genesis Gold Group, a gold dealer, says it's seen intense interest in gold in the last few quarters. Jonathan Rose, the CEO of Genesis, says demand for prepper bars briefly surged after the presidential election and then jumped 20% in the first quarter of 2025. Rose said the number of the firm's clients who insist on holding physical gold has risen to 70%, up from 20% in past years. The price of bullion has climbed 25% in 2025. The S&P 500 is down by about 1% year-to-date. Goldman Sachs recently lowered its recession outlook from 45% to 35%, while Barclays recently removed its forecast for a mild recession. Michael Brown, a senior research strategist at Pepperstone, told BI this week. Michael Boutros, a senior technical strategist at StoneX, told BI. The World Gold Council's Cavatoni added.

title: Long-term bond yields surge around the world
content: WASHINGTON: Around the world, yields on longer-dated sovereign debt have soared as investors question the ability of governments to cover massive budget deficits.
resumen:
Around the world, yields on longer-dated sovereign debt have soared as investors question the ability of governments to cover massive budget deficits.

In the United States, 30-year bond yields last week approached levels last seen in 2007 as President Donald Trump‚Äôs tax bill is poised to swell the budget deficit.

Those in Japan exceeded the highest on record in data since 1999, with auctions in both countries drawing tepid demand.

Long-dated bonds in Britain, Germany and Australia also faced selling pressure.

Banks in China lowered their benchmark lending rates for the first time in seven months, and Australia‚Äôs central bank cut its key interest rate for a second time this year in a bid to mitigate the impact of US tariffs.

A pullback by central banks and pension funds from bond markets has marginalised a once-dependable source of funding.

The giants of corporate America, from Pfizer Inc to Alphabet Inc, are borrowing in euros like never before as the anxiety triggered by Trump‚Äôs tariff threats pushes them to hunt for alternative funding avenues in case their home market freezes up.

In addition to the decisions by Australian and Chinese banks, Iceland, Jamaica, Sri Lanka, Egypt and Indonesia lowered rates.

Officials in Angola, Nigeria, Zambia, Ghana and Paraguay kept borrowing costs unchanged.

Europe UK inflation jumped more than forecast to its highest rate in over a year.

Services inflation accelerated to 5.4% from 4.7%.

Private-sector activity in the euro area unexpectedly shrank in May as services recorded their worst performance in 16 months.

Bulgaria is close to clearing a major hurdle toward euro adoption, putting the Black Sea nation on course to join the currency area next year.

US Chinese shipments of Apple Inc‚Äôs iPhone and other mobile devices to the United States dived to their lowest levels since 2011 in April.

Mexico‚Äôs annual inflation accelerated more than expected early this month in a report that likely won‚Äôt deter central bankers from cutting interest rates again in June.

Argentina‚Äôs economy grew less than expected in March.

title: Why Trump lashed out at Europe over trade
content: President Trump‚Äôs surprise tariff threat against the European Union came in the midst of deepening frustration on his economic team over the 27-nation bloc‚Äôs approach to taxes, regulations and China.
resumen: President Trump threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European imports starting June 1. Trump signaled that he plans to follow through on his threat, saying he is ‚Äúnot looking for a deal" with the EU. Trump‚Äôs economic team has been frustrated by what it says is the slow pace of talks. Trump‚Äôs advisers have privately expressed irritation to European officials that EU member nations‚Äô differing trade priorities have slowed down the talks. They have complained about what they see as Europe‚Äôs cautious approach to the negotiations and what they call the EU‚Äôs reluctance to make concrete offers that address U.S. concerns, such as fees on streaming services, value-added taxes, automotive regulations and fines imposed against U.S. companies in antitrust cases. The U.S. has so far not secured a commitment from EU leaders to place new tariffs on Chinese industries. As part of separate trade negotiations with the U.S., the U.K. agreed to move toward imposing tariffs on Chinese steel. That helped seal the U.S.-U.K. trade deal that Trump announced this month. The U.S.-EU tensions boiled over Friday morning. In February, Trump said the EU ‚Äúwas formed in order to screw the United States.". The EU trade chief, Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç, spoke on a call with U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick hours after Trump‚Äôs Truth Social post. After Friday‚Äôs call, ≈†efƒçoviƒç said the EU is fully engaged in trade talks with the U.S., but is ready to defend its interests. The U.K. reached a deal with the U.S. this month that kept in place Trump‚Äôs 10% across-the-board tariffs on U.K. goods. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent raised concerns about the pace of trade talks to EU officials during a meeting of finance ministers in Canada this past week. The EU previously approved tariffs for 21 billion euros of U.S. imports, equivalent to around $24 billion, but put those duties on hold after the Trump administration announced its 90-day pause on some U.S. tariffs. It also proposed targeting a second set of goods, worth up to 95 billion euros, if negotiations with the U.S. break down. In a Fox News interview Friday, Bessent said he hoped the threat of 50% tariffs would ‚Äúlight a fire under the EU.". The EU‚Äôs trade chief traveled to Washington in April armed with proposals to cut both sides‚Äô industrial tariffs and for the EU to buy more American energy and soybeans, but left empty-handed.

title: Emmanuel Macron touts France as ‚Äòreliable‚Äô partner for south-east Asia
content: French president‚Äôs visit to Vietnam, Indonesia and Singapore will portray Paris as more respectful than US or China ...
resumen: French President Emmanuel Macron has begun a six-day visit to Vietnam, Indonesia and Singapore. He will tout France and Europe as trade and security partners for a region buffeted by tensions between China and the US. Macron arrived in Vietnam late on Sunday. The push for closer trade and security co-operation from Macron is intended to contrast with an increasingly militarily assertive China and the imposition of tariffs by US President Donald Trump on export-reliant countries in the region. An official in the Elys√©e palace said, ‚ÄúFrance, along with the European Union, represents a partner that is both reliable, committed to issues of sovereignty, and respectful of their independence.‚Äù Trump last month hit Vietnam, Indonesia and other south-east Asian countries with some of his highest ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariff rates after China. The region‚Äôs search for new trade opportunities could strengthen ties with the EU. The French official said Macron would emphasise that the EU still backs international trade rules, unlike the current US administration. ‚ÄúWe do not want a jungle where the law of the strongest prevails,‚Äù the official said. Security concerns will also be high on the agenda, given China‚Äôs increasingly assertive naval presence in the South China Sea and tensions with Taiwan. Macron has in the past focused diplomatic efforts on countries including China ‚Äî where he made a state visit in 2023 ‚Äî India and Japan, as part of his strategy of positioning France as an Indo-Pacific power. France has several overseas territories in the Indo-Pacific, including la Reunion and Mayotte, which are home to about 1.7mn people. Its naval frigates conduct patrols in the South China Sea and the country has several military bases in the vast region. Vietnam and Singapore already have free trade agreements with the EU, while Indonesia has been in talks to establish one. Vietnam, in October upgraded relations with France to the status of ‚Äúcomprehensive strategic partnership‚Äù ‚Äî the highest level of diplomatic ties offered by Hanoi. Vietnam is stepping up efforts to diversify trade from the US, which accounts for a third of its exports, and to sign free trade agreements with countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America. In Hanoi, Macron is expected to discuss co-operation on economy, defence, security, and energy, according to Vietnamese state media. An agreement on a power transmission line is among one of the deals expected to be signed. After Vietnam, Macron will head to resource-rich Indonesia, where President Prabowo Subianto is seeking foreign investments to spur a slowing economy. Indonesia has previously bought French defence equipment, including Rafale fighter jets and Scorp√®ne submarines. ‚ÄúThere may be other contracts announced during the trip,‚Äù said C√©line Pajon, who heads Japan and Indo-Pacific research at the French Institute of International Relations think-tank. ‚ÄúFrance and Indonesia intend to raise the defence partnership into something long-term and structural.‚Äù The Indonesian government said in a statement this month that Macron‚Äôs visit reflected ‚Äúthe commitment of both countries to enhance co-operation in facing global challenges‚Äù. Macron plans to discuss diversification of France‚Äôs access to materials critical for production of smartphones and semiconductors while in Indonesia. During his final stop of the trip in Singapore, Macron will give a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue, Asia‚Äôs largest defence forum. ‚ÄúIt is the first time a European leader has been invited to give this speech, and it is in recognition of how Macron has developed a real Indo-Pacific strategy. He also encouraged the EU to adopt one as well,‚Äù Pajon said.

title: US-EU trade tensions 'to heighten economic uncertainty' as EU trade commissioner urges 'respect not threats' from US
content: Concerns over a US-EU trade war have been rising over the weekend as the US threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on the EU and the bloc refused to back down, shaking global markets. The US-EU ...
resumen: US-EU trade tensions are rising as the US threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on the EU, and the bloc refused to back down, shaking global markets. The US-EU trade tensions will add more economic uncertainty to the world, according to a Chinese expert. The EU trade commissioner, Maro√Ö¬° √Ö¬†ef√Ñ¬çovi√Ñ¬ç, said any potential trade deal between Brussels and Washington must be based on "respect not threats." The US president claimed that "the EU, which was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the US on TRADE, has been very difficult to deal with," and recommended a straight 50 percent Tariff on the EU, starting on June 1, 2025. The US president later escalated his message to the EU - "I'm not looking for a deal," he said. The tariff threat came amid stalled negotiations, with Washington demanding unilateral concessions from Brussels to open up to US business, while the EU has been seeking an agreement that offers mutual gain. The US president's latest remarks follow his April 2 "Liberation Day" announcement of a 39 percent tariff on European goods. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Friday he hopes a new tariff threat from the president would speed along talks with the EU regarding a new trade deal. In a Friday interview with Fox News, Bessent accused the EU of not engaging in "good faith" trade negotiations with the White House. Zhou Mi, a senior research fellow at the Chinese Academy of International Trade and Economic Cooperation, said the US seems eager to ramp up pressure on the EU, possibly due to growing concerns about its domestic economy. The S&P 500 lost 0.7 percent Friday and had its worst week in the last seven. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6 percent, and the Nasdaq composite sank 1 percent. The benchmark STOXX 600 index was down 0.93 percent. Germany's DAX fell by 1.54 percent and France's CAC index slid 1.65 percent. The US was the largest partner for EU exports of goods in 2024, making up 20.6 percent of exports, according to Eurostat. Petroleum oils, medicinal and pharmaceutical products were the EU's most exported group to the US last year. Zhou said that the current unpredictability - driven by tit-for-tat rhetoric - is putting stress on businesses on both sides, including American companies. The French trade minister, Laurent Saint-Martin, said the US' new threats did nothing to help negotiations. Irish Taoiseach Miche√É¬°l Martin described the US proposal of imposing 50 percent tariffs on the EU as "extremely disappointing." Huo Jianguo, a vice chairman of the China Society for World Trade Organization Studies in Beijing, said the EU is one of the US' largest economic partners and remains a significant global power and the US' threat of a 50 percent tariff reflects its eagerness to reach a deal with the EU. A Harris Poll for Bloomberg News found that a majority of US adults, 56 percent, said their household finances would be better off if the US tariffs had not been implemented. The World Economic Situation and Prospects as of mid-2025 recently released by the UN mentioned that higher tariffs and trade policy uncertainty have weakened the global economic outlook for 2025.

title: Trump says he will delay tariffs on European Union until July 9
content: MORRISTOWN, N.J. ‚Äî President Donald Trump said Sunday that he would delay tariffs that were set to be imposed next week on the European Union until July 9.

title: Trump Delays E.U. Tariffs Until July 9
content: President Trump said he would give the European Union more time to negotiate a trade deal before 50 percent tariffs take effect.
resumen:
President Trump said on Sunday that he would delay imposing 50 percent tariffs on all imports from the European Union until July 9 to allow more time for trade negotiations.

Mr. Trump said that he had spoken to Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, about his recent threat to enact the tariffs on June 1 if a trade deal could not be reached in the next week.

Mr. Trump has expressed frustration over negotiations with the E.U., saying that the union has been slow to offer trade concessions during a 90-day window to reach a deal that satisfies the administration.

On Sunday, Mr. Trump appeared to relent, at least for now.

‚ÄúThe Commission President said that talks will begin rapidly,‚Äù Mr. Trump wrote, referring to Ms. von der Leyen.

Ms. von der Leyen, in a separate social media post on Sunday, said that she had a ‚Äúgood call‚Äù with Mr. Trump and had conveyed to him that the E.U. needed extra time to reach a trade deal. She said that talks would advance ‚Äúswiftly and decisively.‚Äù

The extension is the latest turnabout by Mr. Trump.

While announcing his recommendation for 50 percent E.U. tariffs on Friday, the president had assailed Europe‚Äôs negotiating tactics and expressed no interest in reaching a deal.

Friday‚Äôs threat of 50 percent tariffs came after Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent met with European counterparts as part of the Group of 7 meetings in Canada.

Mr. Bessent had given no indication to his counterparts that new tariffs were coming, but he defended them on Friday.

The Treasury Secretary said that Europe has a ‚Äúcollective action‚Äù problem and that individual countries in the E.U. did not know how Brussels was negotiating.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariff threat against the E.U. came weeks after he agreed to partially pause the 145 percent tariffs he had imposed on Chinese imports.

European officials held a call with their American counterparts for trade talks on Friday, and had earlier submitted a term sheet detailing their offers to secure a deal.

European leaders have offered to reduce tariffs on industrial goods to zero if the United States does the same, and to increase purchases of U.S. energy, among other commitments.

In a post on Truth Social Friday morning, Mr. Trump wrote that discussions with the European Union were ‚Äúgoing nowhere‚Äù and that he was recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1.

Mr. Trump also threatened a 25 percent tariff on imports of smartphones made by Apple and other companies on Friday, saying they should be made in the United States.

Economists at Oxford Economics said that if implemented, the E.U. tariffs and the phone tariffs, combined, would reduce economic growth by 0.2 percentage points, raise inflation by 0.2 percentage points, and increase the unemployment rate by a tenth of a percentage point.

The economists, Ryan Sweet and Bernard Yaros, wrote that the proposed tariffs on the E.U. highlight a key forecast risk, whereby tariffs remain an ongoing tool to be wielded by the Trump administration whenever negotiations hit a snag.

title: Japanese Yen and Aussie Dollar Forecasts: Trade and Central Bank Pivots in Focus
content: AUD/USD climbs on tariff fears, but recession risks linger. RBA and Fed cues, US-China trade headlines, and Beijing policy in sharp focus.
resumen:
Trade tensions spike as Trump threatens 50% EU tariffs, sending USD/JPY down 1.01% on risk-off sentiment.
USD/JPY dropped below 143 on risk-off sentiment.
AUD/USD faces downside risk as US-China trade tensions may weigh on Aussie exports and RBA policy outlook.
Japan‚Äôs economy will be in focus on Monday, May 26, influencing the Bank of Japan rate path and USD/JPY trends.
According to preliminary data, the Leading Economic Index dropped from 108.2 in February to 107.7 in March.
A downward revision may temper bets on a Q3 2025 BoJ rate hike, potentially lifting USD/JPY.
A higher print could revive speculation of a Q3 hike, especially after April‚Äôs hotter-than-expected core inflation.
A more hawkish BoJ stance may drag the USD/JPY lower.
Economists had already pared back Q3 rate hike bets ahead of Friday‚Äôs inflation figures due to escalating tariff concerns.
A Reuters poll (May 7‚Äì13) showed: 67% of economists (39 of 58) anticipate no policy change in Q3, up from 36% in April.
52% forecast a 25-basis-point rate hike in 2025.
USD/JPY dropped 1.01% on Friday after President Trump threatened a 50% tariff on EU imports, boosting demand for safe-haven assets like the Yen.
Later in the session, Fed speakers will influence US dollar demand and USD/JPY trends.
Support for a Q3 2025 Fed rate cut could weigh on the US dollar and send USD/JPY toward the 140.309 support level.
Calls to delay rate cuts to assess inflationary impacts from tariffs may drive the pair toward the May 20 high of 145.507.
Bearish USD/JPY Scenario: Rising trade tensions, strong Japanese economic data, or dovish Fed rhetoric could drag USD/JPY toward 140.309.
Bullish USD/JPY Scenario: Easing trade friction, weak Japanese economic indicators, or hawkish Fed cues may lift USD/JPY toward 145 and potentially the 50-day EMA.
On May 26, US-China trade headlines and policy updates from Beijing will influence AUD/USD price action.
On Sunday, May 25, CN Wire reported that Chinese state media emphasized the unresolved nature of the US-China trade conflict, warning that talks would be ‚Äúprotracted and arduous.‚Äù
The commentary cited US delay tactics and the risk of renewed escalation if US political and economic pressures ease.
The report concluded that China must prepare for prolonged negotiations and a sustained confrontation.
A prolonged trade war may impact Aussie trade terms, given China accounts for one-third of Australian exports.
With a trade-to-GDP ratio above 50%, weaker demand from China could pressure the RBA into adopting a more dovish stance.
RBA Governor Michele Bullock recently warned that a worsening trade war could push Australia into recession.
She noted: ‚ÄúAustralia‚Äôs economy could easily be compromised if a trade war between the US and China escalates‚Ä¶ The market path is reflecting a possibility of a really bad outcome, pointing to a lower RBA cash rate.‚Äù
Rising recession fears and a more dovish RBA rate path may weigh on AUD/USD.
Bearish Aussie dollar Scenario: Renewed US-China tensions, Beijing withholds fresh stimulus, or dovish RBA cues may send AUD/USD toward the 200-day EMA.
Bullish Aussie dollar Scenario: Easing US-China trade tensions, Beijing stimulus, or hawkish RBA signals could send the pair toward the May 14 high of $0.65008.
Later today, US monetary policy will also affect AUD/USD.
Hawkish Fed rhetoric may widen the US-Aussie interest rate differential, potentially pulling AUD/USD toward the 200-day EMA.
Dovish cues favoring a Q3 Fed rate cut would narrow the rate differential, sending the pair toward $0.65008.
Traders should also monitor US fiscal risks and global trade rhetoric.
On May 23, AUD/USD rose 1.29% to $0.64914 as markets digested Trump‚Äôs tariff threat on EU imports and growing concerns over US debt levels.
Key Market Drivers to Watch Today: USD/JPY: US-Japan trade talks, Japanese economic data, and BoJ signals.
USD/JPY and AUD/USD: Fed speeches, US economic data, and global trade headlines.
AUD/USD: US-China relations, RBA commentary, and Beijing‚Äôs policy stance.

title: President Trump Vows to Prioritize American Interests in World Trade Week Proclamation
content: President Trump's proclamation for World Trade Week focuses on prioritizing American workers and industries in trade policies.
resumen: Como parte de la observancia anual de la Semana Mundial del Comercio, el presidente Donald Trump enfatiz√≥ recientemente el enfoque de su administraci√≥n en la recalibraci√≥n de las pol√≠ticas comerciales para priorizar los intereses estadounidenses. En una proclamaci√≥n, Trump destac√≥ medidas destinadas a fomentar relaciones comerciales equilibradas y rec√≠procas y expres√≥ su apoyo a los trabajadores estadounidenses que, seg√∫n √©l, han sido marginados previamente debido a la globalizaci√≥n. "Durante demasiado tiempo, las √©lites globalistas vendieron al trabajador estadounidense y permitieron que otros pa√≠ses tomaran injustamente nuestras f√°bricas, nuestros empleos y nuestros sue√±os. Esos d√≠as terminaron", declar√≥ el Presidente en una proclamaci√≥n emitida por la Casa Blanca. El Presidente subray√≥ su dedicaci√≥n a la creaci√≥n de un entorno m√°s propicio para la creaci√≥n de empleo nacional y el fortalecimiento industrial. Se√±al√≥ que su administraci√≥n ha sido proactiva en revertir la tendencia de la deslocalizaci√≥n, mediante la promulgaci√≥n de aranceles y otras medidas comerciales. "Mi Administraci√≥n est√° entregando ese futuro", dijo Trump, refiri√©ndose a una visi√≥n que articul√≥ mientras hac√≠a campa√±a para el cargo. "Desde que asum√≠ el cargo, he tomado medidas para proporcionar una vida mejor para todos los estadounidenses y especialmente para los millones de estadounidenses que quedaron en el camino a medida que los empleos se enviaban al extranjero", seg√∫n la Casa Blanca. La proclamaci√≥n de la Casa Blanca tambi√©n detall√≥ los movimientos de pol√≠tica comercial destinados a frenar la importaci√≥n de fentanilo y a promover la competitividad estadounidense en el extranjero. Elogi√≥ la introducci√≥n de nuevos acuerdos comerciales, como el acuerdo comercial entre Estados Unidos y el Reino Unido, que buscan crear oportunidades para las empresas estadounidenses a nivel internacional. El Presidente se comprometi√≥ a combatir las pr√°cticas comerciales desleales que afectan a una amplia franja de la poblaci√≥n estadounidense, desde "agricultores y pescadores hasta empresarios y todos los dem√°s", seg√∫n la Casa Blanca. Trump expres√≥ una firme determinaci√≥n de perpetuar una estrategia de "Estados Unidos primero" en todas las negociaciones comerciales y el desarrollo de pol√≠ticas. "Como Presidente, siempre pondr√© los intereses de Estados Unidos primero", afirm√≥. "Juntos, construiremos una nueva Edad de Oro para Estados Unidos con un fuerte crecimiento econ√≥mico y pol√≠ticas comerciales de Estados Unidos primero que protejan a nuestros trabajadores, fortalezcan nuestras industrias y desbloqueen el Sue√±o Americano para todos los ciudadanos". El domingo pasado hasta ayer fueron designados como la Semana Mundial del Comercio, invitando a la celebraci√≥n de las contribuciones del comercio estadounidense bajo la directiva de Trump, seg√∫n lo detallado por la Casa Blanca.

title: Tariff Uncertainties, Part 3: The Bond Markets
content: There are five important Treasury market anomalies to consider.
resumen:
The Treasury Bond market experienced significant volatility following the announcement of new high-tariff policies on April 2, with the market briefly appearing to be on the verge of collapse. The "queasiness" in the Treasury market was cited as the reason that tariff proposals were quickly put on hold on April 9. The market recovered, suggesting the relationship between tariffs and bond market turmoil had been demonstrated.

However, this conclusion is likely false for two reasons:

1.  **Scale:** The projected impact of tariffs on inflation or growth is small relative to the economy.
2.  **Treasury market anomalies:** The Treasury market has been behaving strangely for several years, unrelated to tariffs or trade policy.

There are five important Treasury market anomalies to consider:

1.  The Treasury market experienced its longest and deepest yield curve inversion ever, from July 2022 to September 2024, which did not lead to or predict a recession.
2.  This inversion was closely tied to reversals in Federal Reserve monetary policy, which had not happened in previous inversions.
3.  In September, the Treasury market broke a decades-long relationship between the Fed‚Äôs official interest rates and yields on Treasury bonds, potentially indicating the Fed's interest rate policy lever may have ceased to function.
4.  In early April, the Treasury bond market deviated from the usual crisis-response pattern, with a massive bond sell-off.
5.  Complex trading strategies like swap-spreads and ‚Äúbasis trades‚Äù have changed the tenor of the market in the direction of greater speculation, increased leverage, rising volatility, sometimes intensely crowded trades, and heightened sensitivity to external shocks.

The "Liberation Day" tariff shock set the stock market ringing like a bell, with the worst two-day decline in history, followed by a gain, and then more back and forth. Volatility exploded. The 10-Year Treasury Bond yield rose 64 basis points in two days, and Treasurys lost more than 5% in value in one week. Bond market volatility, as measured by the MOVE Index, surged more than 3 standard deviations above its recent average. Technical symptoms of bond market stress appeared, including a "significant" deterioration in liquidity. Contagion spread to global bond markets. The turbulence stirred fears that the Treasury market could seize up. The market deviated from the established crisis-response script.

Then, the storm blew over. The Vix returned to normal. The stock market recovered its losses rapidly. The Treasury bond market stabilized. Daily trading volatility returned to normal. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fluctuated on average just 4 basis points per day. Even the dollar was up 3%. The MOVE Index was back to its pre-April 1 average. The normal economic indicators are coming in with generally positive readings. Corporate earnings have been strong. The Fed reported that ‚Äúeconomic activity has continued to expand at a solid pace.‚Äù

The real impact of tariffs, if implemented, would not likely be large enough to unhinge the massive Treasury bond market. The imposition of tariffs would amount to a scattering of one-time taxes across the economy. The Tax Foundation calculated that the 2018 tariffs resulted in tariff duties of about $200-300 per household annually‚Äì about 0.3% of the median household income. The Peterson Institute estimated that Liberation Day tariffs would cost consumers about $1200-1500 per household. The Penn Wharton Budget model forecast a similar reduction of about 0.4% of GDP in 2030. The Yale Budget Lab‚Äôs maximalist estimate of the impact of the tariffs included in the Liberation Day proposal was higher ‚Äì $4800 per household, or about 2.1% of GDP.

The Treasury bond market is currently valued at 95% of U.S. GDP. It is the deepest, most liquid, and most efficient financial market in the world. It embodies an immense power to determine the price of credit everywhere. Treasurys set the rate of return on trillions of dollars of bonds held in the reserves of all major central banks, and trillions more in the portfolios of investors here and abroad ‚Äì almost $29 Tn in all. The market trades more than $1 Tn per day.

The bond market is responding more to the Fed policy than to tariff talk. The Federal Reserve seems currently unable to move market interest rates in the desired policy direction. The "preconditions" in the bond market ‚Äì especially the unwinding of the ‚Äúbasis trade‚Äù ‚Äì were the major contributors to the market turbulence. Tariff talk was a trigger, but the large-scale market-clearing of Treasurys in a short time feels much more like a crowded trade unwinding than a response to the substantive economics of tariffs.

title: How American Retailers Are Navigating Trump‚Äôs Volatile Trade Policy
content: Observer spoke with dozens of retail CEOs and founders, consumer experts and supply chain strategists about how they are navigating tariffs.
resumen:
In 2025, tariffs have emerged as a new "force majeure" for American retailers due to erratic tariff policies tied to Trump‚Äôs second-term agenda. Businesses are facing a high-stakes guessing game in navigating pricing, planning, and logistics, with trade alliances dissolving overnight and tariff schedules changing rapidly. Preserving optionality is now a survival skill.

Companies are reengineering operations and supply chains to withstand what many call a ‚ÄúTrump majeure.‚Äù Bill London, an international attorney at Kimura London & White, notes that businesses are revisiting contracts to insert renegotiation clauses and price adjustment mechanisms triggered by tariff shifts.

Charlie Youakim, CEO and co-founder of Sezzle, observes that pure e-commerce retailers, especially those reliant on Chinese manufacturing, are scrambling, reworking logistics, and repricing inventory. While there's no panic, there is urgency.

Ross Widmoyer, CEO of Faribault Mill, has embraced a hyper-local model, sourcing inputs domestically, which has provided insulation and agility. Faribault Mill employs around 100 people and brings in nearly $20 million in annual revenue.

Steve Skillings, founder of BusyBox, faces shutting down due to skyrocketing component costs from tariffs.

Jason Wingate, co-founder of Zlumber, emphasizes the need for structural flexibility, including diversified suppliers, agile freight partners, and manufacturing options.

Many companies have relied on China for manufacturing, but this reliance is becoming precarious. Lee Mayer, CEO of Havenly Brands, is skeptical of rapid re-shoring due to price hikes. David‚Äôs Bridal has restructured its global supply chain, shifting production away from China. Mattel has reduced its manufacturing reliance on China. Ben Koren, CEO of Frameology, re-shored production years ago.

Companies are responding in different ways: shifting production, building structural flexibility, leaning into innovation, or engaging in policy advocacy. Emily Hosie, founder of REBEL, is lobbying for tariff exemptions on baby products. Keegan Nesvacil, CEO of Woodland Tools, describes a ‚Äúdesign-for-resilience‚Äù model.

Many large brands have opted to stock up on inventory.

Resilience now depends on agility, optionality, and the recognition that there‚Äôs no cookie-cutter playbook.

title: Trump Agrees To Extend 50% Tariffs On Europe Until July 9: 'It Was My Privilege To Do So'
content: Trump agreed to extend tariff deadline to July 9, 2025 after receiving call from Ursula von der Leyen, amid ongoing trade tensions between US and EU.
resumen: Donald Trump announced on Sunday that he received a call from Ursula von der Leyen, the President of the European Commission, requesting an extension on the impending 50% tariff deadline. The original deadline was set for June 1, but Trump agreed to extend it to July 9, 2025. Trump stated on Truth Social that the Commission President assured him that negotiations would commence swiftly. Trump expressed his willingness to grant the extension, describing it as his ‚Äúprivilege to do so.‚Äù Von der Leyen said on X that she had a ‚Äúgood call‚Äù with Trump. She had requested time until July 9 to reach a ‚Äúgood deal.‚Äù Trump‚Äôs decision to extend the deadline follows his previous threat to impose a 50% tariff on all European Union imports.

title: Las consecuencias econ√≥micas de las pol√≠ticas de Trump
content: Mientras el presidente estadounidense siembra confusi√≥n e incertidumbre en todo el mundo, es comprensible que las perturbaciones a corto plazo acaparen la mayor parte de la atenci√≥n. Pero es probable ...
resumen: El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, introdujo aranceles, que luego puso en pausa. Algunos de los efectos de las pol√≠ticas de Trump sobre la econom√≠a de Estados Unidos y del mundo son previsibles. Algunas √°reas de Estados Unidos sufrir√°n escasez de bienes importados, sobre todo de procedencia asi√°tica. La demanda agregada se deprimir√°. El acuerdo entre China y Estados Unidos para la suspensi√≥n de los aranceles por 90 d√≠as no resuelve por completo la incertidumbre. Las importaciones solo suponen un 14% del PIB, y las exportaciones algo m√°s del 11%. La agenda desreguladora de la administraci√≥n Trump puede estimular el crecimiento liberando una ola de inversi√≥n local. La econom√≠a estadounidense equivale al 25% del PIB mundial. El Fondo Monetario Internacional predice que el impacto de los aranceles de Trump sobre el crecimiento ser√° mayor en Estados Unidos (-0,9%), seguido por Canad√° y China (-0,6%) y luego Jap√≥n (-0,5%). El FMI tambi√©n pronostica una ca√≠da del 0,5% para Reino Unido, y para las principales econom√≠as de Europa continental se prev√© p√©rdidas del 0,3% o menos. A largo plazo, es probable que los efectos de la pol√≠tica arancelaria de Trump sean mayores. Los l√≠deres pol√≠ticos, los funcionarios y las empresas han comenzado a actualizar sus estrategias en busca de resiliencia y seguridad. Europa ha iniciado un marcado aumento del gasto en defensa. Muchas econom√≠as diversificar√°n sus intercambios comerciales. Canad√° buscar√° ampliar sus v√≠nculos comerciales y de inversi√≥n y reducir barreras internas al comercio. La estabilidad a largo plazo de la econom√≠a y del sistema financiero estadounidenses corren riesgo. Los flujos de inversi√≥n extranjera se alejen de Estados Unidos. La crema del talento cient√≠fico y tecnol√≥gico quiera irse a otra parte. La presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, formul√≥ una invitaci√≥n expl√≠cita a investigadores para que se radiquen en Europa. Las instituciones y marcos multilaterales se deb√≠an una modernizaci√≥n. Los l√≠deres de las dem√°s econom√≠as desarrolladas (y casi todas las emergentes) siguen comprometidos con una versi√≥n de vinculaci√≥n multilateral. Los intentos de construir un multilateralismo nuevo y m√°s complejo continuar√°n, con escaso aporte de Estados Unidos. La Uni√≥n Europea y las principales econom√≠as emergentes (en particular China) llevar√°n la delantera. El papel destacado de Estados Unidos en los esquemas de seguridad asi√°ticos complicar√° este proceso. Los efectos a m√°s largo plazo de algunas de las pol√≠ticas de la administraci√≥n Trump ser√°n m√°s significativos, amplios y s√≥lo parcialmente reversibles.

content: CIUDAD DE M√âXICO, 25 de mayo de 2025.-M√©xico puede ser un puente para reforzar los lazos de Europa con Am√©rica del Norte y del Sur, dijo el ministro de Asuntos Exteriores y de Cooperaci√≥n ...
resumen:
El ministro de Asuntos Exteriores y de Cooperaci√≥n Internacional de la Rep√∫blica Italiana, Antonio Tajani, de visita en la UNAM, dijo que M√©xico puede ser un puente para reforzar los lazos de Europa con Am√©rica del Norte y del Sur.

Tajani ofreci√≥ la conferencia magistral Geopol√≠tica Europa y Am√©rica Latina, ante estudiantes de Relaciones Internacionales, profesores, investigadores y funcionarios universitarios reunidos en el auditorio del tercer piso de la Torre de Rector√≠a.

Tajani propuso trabajar por la paz en el mundo, reforzando la estructura de la Organizaci√≥n de las Naciones Unidas (ONU); impulsar el comercio mundial; y defender la democracia como modelo pol√≠tico.

Tajani se√±al√≥ que M√©xico puede ser un puente para reforzar las relaciones de Europa con Am√©rica del Norte y del Sur.

Tajani consider√≥ que China tiende a ser la reina de la civilizaci√≥n internacional, m√°s a nivel econ√≥mico que militar.

Tajani coment√≥ que hay que considerar a India, con m√°s habitantes que China y relaciones muy buenas con rusos, chinos y estadounidenses; as√≠ como a √Åfrica, un continente con poblaciones pobres, pero con materias primas fundamentales para todos los pa√≠ses industriales.

Tajani apunt√≥ que el bloque de Am√©rica del Norte (Canad√°, Estados Unidos y M√©xico) va a ser siempre una figura importante del mundo.

Tajani sostuvo que trabajar para un gran mercado econ√≥mico libre -M√©xico, Canad√°, Estados Unidos y Europa- ser√≠a la mejor soluci√≥n contra la pobreza y para ayudar a todas las empresas.

Alejandro Chanona Burguete, director de la Facultad de Ciencias Pol√≠ticas y Sociales, resalt√≥ que la UNAM se distingue por su vocaci√≥n universal, su compromiso con la democracia y los derechos humanos, as√≠ como su permanente inter√©s en el an√°lisis cr√≠tico de los fen√≥menos pol√≠ticos globales.

Chanona Burguete se√±al√≥ que la trayectoria pol√≠tica y humana de Tajani encaja justamente en esos valores.

title: Di√°logo sobre la crisis de Hait√≠ y la inmigracion indocumentada
content: El se√±or Presidente de la Rep√∫blica, Luis Abinader Corona hace algunas semanas se reuni√≥ en el Ministerio de Defensa (MIDE), con los ex presidentes Leonel Fern√°ndez Reyna, Danilo Medina e Hip√≥lito Mej ...
resumen: El se√±or Presidente de la Rep√∫blica, Luis Abinader Corona, se reuni√≥ en el Ministerio de Defensa (MIDE) con los ex presidentes Leonel Fern√°ndez Reyna, Danilo Medina e Hip√≥lito Mej√≠a para tratar de buscar una salida de consenso a la crisis generada en el pa√≠s por la gran inmigraci√≥n de indocumentados haitianos. Esta situaci√≥n se ha originado por la ola de violencia en Hait√≠ y la grave crisis econ√≥mica, pol√≠tica, social e institucional que lo sacude, incrementada tras el magnicidio de su presidente, Jovenel Moise. El di√°logo se llevar√° al Centro Econ√≥mico y Social (CES) con la participaci√≥n de todos los sectores y organizaciones que forman parte de este organismo. Sectores agr√≠colas y de la construcci√≥n presionan para regularizar a unos 15 mil haitianos indocumentados, argumentando la necesidad de mano de obra, especialmente para la cosecha de arroz y la construcci√≥n. El ministro de Agricultura, Limber Cruz, utiliza a cientos de haitianos indocumentados en sus fincas, al igual que otros funcionarios del gobierno. La mano de obra haitiana indocumentada es preferida por pagar un menor salario, no entregar prestaciones laborales, no cumplir con el pago de la Seguridad Social ni con los impuestos, as√≠ como con el art√≠culo 135 del C√≥digo Laboral (80/20). Los trabajadores haitianos indocumentados suelen tener hijos y mujeres que utilizan las maternidades y escuelas dominicanas. No existe control por la Direcci√≥n General de Migraci√≥n (DGM) ni de los ayuntamientos, y no son repatriados. El empresario que utilice mano de obra indocumentada haitiana debe ser responsable de ella, controlando su ubicaci√≥n y cumpliendo con sus responsabilidades legales y econ√≥micas. El Estado dominicano no puede seguir cargando con responsabilidades ajenas. El autor, Alfredo Cruz Polanco, es Contador P√∫blico Autorizado, M√°ster en Relaciones Internacionales, Ex diputado al Congreso Nacional y Miembro de la C√°mara de Cuentas 2010-2016.

title: Trump‚Äôs Pincer Strategy: Squeezing EU on Trade and Defense
content: The European Union (EU) faces significant pressure from the United States under President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration, driven by two distinct but ...
resumen:
The European Union (EU) faces pressure from the United States under President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration, driven by aggressive tariff threats and demands for increased NATO defense spending. These policies reflect Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmerica First‚Äù approach.

Trump announced a plan to impose a 50% tariff on EU imports starting June 1, 2025, citing stalled trade negotiations and a US trade deficit. He introduced a 20% tariff on EU goods in April 2025, paused for 90 days. The new 50% tariff threat surpasses the earlier 39% rate. Trump has threatened a 25% tariff on imported smartphones, including iPhones, by the end of June 2025.

The EU is preparing for potential retaliation. The European Commission, led by President Ursula von der Leyen, has vowed to respond ‚Äúfirmly and immediately‚Äù to any unjustified tariffs, with countermeasures worth approximately $28 billion already planned.

Economic analyses provide varied estimates of the tariffs‚Äô impact. The Kiel Institute predicts a 20% drop in EU exports to the US and a 6% price increase for US consumers. Bruegel suggests a manageable GDP reduction of 0.11% for the EU. The German automobile industry faces particular risk, with potential export declines of nearly 20%. The Tax Foundation estimates a $1,200 tax increase per US household in 2025.

Trump has intensified pressure on NATO allies, particularly the 23 EU member states, to increase defense spending to 5% of GDP, a significant leap from the 2% target set in 2014. This demand reflects Trump‚Äôs view that Europe relies too heavily on US security guarantees.

In 2024, NATO‚Äôs European allies and Canada spent $485 billion on defense, equivalent to 2.02% of their combined GDP, with 22 of 32 allies meeting the 2% target. Poland led with 4.12%, followed by Estonia at 3.43%, while the US spent 3.38%. Projections for 2025 estimate EU NATO members‚Äô spending at 2.04%.

European leaders have called Trump‚Äôs 5% target unrealistic. Germany‚Äôs Chancellor Olaf Scholz and others emphasize strengthening defense capabilities without committing to specific percentages. Some allies propose redefining defense spending to include nontraditional items like cybersecurity, aiming for a combined target of 3.5% military and 1.5% defense-related spending by 2032. Sweden plans to reach 2.4% in 2025 and 2.6% by 2028.

If implemented, Trump‚Äôs tariffs could trigger a trade war, reducing EU exports and increasing prices for US consumers. The German auto industry faces significant risks, with potential export declines of 20%. Retaliatory tariffs from the EU could further disrupt US exports. The CEPR estimates a modest EU GDP reduction of less than 1% over four years.

Trump‚Äôs NATO demands could push the EU toward greater defense self-reliance. A more militarized Europe could alter global security dynamics, particularly in countering Russia. The proposed redefinition of defense spending offers a compromise, but failure to meet Trump‚Äôs expectations could lead to US threats to scale back NATO commitments.

The dual pressures signal a shift toward a transactional US-EU relationship, where cooperation depends on EU concessions on trade and defense. This could weaken the alliance if European resentment grows. The outcome hinges on diplomatic efforts, with EU leaders like von der Leyen and Tusk emphasizing cooperation over conflict.

Saeed Minhas is the author.

title: Trump y la hegemon√≠a de EU
content: El dominio de un imperio se puede entender observando hasta donde llega su moneda. Durante el Imperio Romano las monedas con la cara del C√©sar llegaban hasta donde ten√≠a influencia. Lo mismo ocurre co ...
resumen: El dominio de un imperio se puede entender observando hasta donde llega su moneda. Durante el Imperio Romano las monedas con la cara del C√©sar llegaban hasta donde ten√≠a influencia. Lo mismo ocurre contempor√°neamente con Estados Unidos, cuya moneda es utilizada hasta en Cuba, as√≠ sea en los mercados negros. Este es un ejemplo de hegemon√≠a econ√≥mica que este pa√≠s ejerce en el mundo entero. Las estad√≠sticas econ√≥micas de los principales organismos internacionales presentan indicadores tanto en moneda local como en d√≥lares americanos, un ejemplo m√°s del poder gringo. Otras manifestaciones tambi√©n llegan a todo el orbe, como el cine de Hollywood y la m√∫sica que hacen, como la de Sinatra, Elvis o Billy Joel. La literatura es otro tanto: literatura como El Gran Gatsby o Las uvas de la ira son parte de la literatura universal. Casi por doquier se puede observar la hegemon√≠a del pa√≠s de las barras y las estrellas. La educaci√≥n, en particular la superior, es otro ejemplo de ello: las escuelas y facultades tienen un elevado porcentaje de estudiantes internacionales que, dicho sea de paso, aprenden en este pa√≠s el modo de vida norteamericano y, cuando regresan a su pa√≠s de origen, en gran medida replican lo aprendido. En el terreno econ√≥mico, en el extremo se llega decir que la ‚Äúmejor Pol√≠tica Econ√≥mica es la ausencia de √©sta‚Äù, porque as√≠ lo dicen los libros de texto en que muchos funcionarios p√∫blicos estudiaron econom√≠a. Como la Historia Econ√≥mica est√° en franco declive y es observada, en el mejor de los casos, como un distractor, no aprenden que los pa√≠ses desarrollados no florecieron siguiendo las pol√≠ticas que dicen los libros de texto. Pero eso se sigue ense√±ando y llevando a otros pa√≠ses, no donde se ense√±a como EU o Inglaterra, es decir, en materia econ√≥mica se aplica la m√°xima: que se cumpla lo que dice el libro de texto, pero en los bueyes de nuestros vecinos. Por lo anterior es que llama poderosamente la atenci√≥n lo que el actual presidente de nuestro vecino del Norte est√° haciendo con la educaci√≥n: de modo deliberado pretende acabar con la hegemon√≠a educativa del pa√≠s que gobierna. De tener √©xito, estar√≠a poniendo en riesgo la formaci√≥n de futuros cuadros de especialistas que regresar√≠an a sus pa√≠ses de origen a aplicar lo aprendido en las universidades del pa√≠s de las barras y las estrellas. Posiblemente la edad ya nubl√≥ la visi√≥n de este presidente. En materia de cine, al establecer aranceles a pel√≠culas producidas en el extranjero estar√≠a evitando que muchas pel√≠culas fueran hechas en locaciones fuera de su pa√≠s. Por lo tanto, adi√≥s a escenas en Europa, Am√©rica, As√≠a, India y √Åfrica. No por nada la industria cinematogr√°fica est√° en desacuerdo con la posible aplicaci√≥n de esta medida. Evitar la internacionalizaci√≥n del cine tambi√©n fracturar√≠a la hegemon√≠a de Norteam√©rica. Otro error. Afortunadamente la presidencia s√≥lo durar√° cuatro a√±os, y ya llevamos varios meses. Seguramente algunas instituciones se desmantelar√°n como es el caso de la USAID, otro organismo promotor del modo de vida norteamericano, pero otros sobrevivir√°n y otros se rescatar√°n o surgir√°n nuevos. Es poco probable que la pesadilla dure m√°s de cuatro a√±os. En ese tiempo el pa√≠s no se acabar√°, pero su hegemon√≠a quedar√° fracturada y otros pa√≠ses, como China, podr√≠a salir beneficiadas por la pol√≠tica seguida por el actual presidente.

title: Desde el mercado hasta la gasolina: ¬øC√≥mo los habitantes de Florida est√°n sintiendo los aranceles de Trump?
content: Los nuevos aranceles de Trump impactan a Florida, elevando precios en productos importados como caf√© y materiales de construcci√≥n. Peque√±as empresas enfrentan costos crecientes y falta de alternativas ...
resumen:
Los nuevos aranceles de Trump impactan a Florida, elevando precios en productos importados como caf√© y materiales de construcci√≥n. Peque√±as empresas enfrentan costos crecientes y falta de alternativas locales.

En abril de 2025, Donald Trump lanz√≥ un ambicioso paquete arancelario con el objetivo declarado de ‚Äúrecuperar la soberan√≠a econ√≥mica‚Äù de Estados Unidos. Entre las medidas clave est√°n un arancel universal del 10% sobre todas las importaciones, en vigor desde el 5 de abril. Adem√°s, incluye aranceles espec√≠ficos por pa√≠ses.

Florida, con m√°s de 117 mil millones de d√≥lares en importaciones anuales, es el d√©cimo mayor importador de EE.UU., y depende en gran medida de productos como madera (de Brasil y Canad√°), caf√© (de Colombia y M√©xico), y materiales de construcci√≥n. Gran parte de estos est√°n sujetos a los nuevos aranceles.

El due√±o del popular Blind Tiger Caf√©, Roberto Torres, importa caf√© y vasos de papel, todos ahora m√°s costosos por los impuestos comerciales.

Abigail StClair, fundadora de TeBella Tea Company, debi√≥ pagar 11,000 d√≥lares adicionales por un pedido de t√©.

Empresarios como Torres y StClair est√°n optando por compras anticipadas, l√≠neas de cr√©dito y reajustes en sus planes de expansi√≥n.

Expertos como Sean Snaith, de la Universidad de Florida Central, se√±alan que la verdadera barrera es la falta de claridad.

La confianza del consumidor ha ca√≠do tres meses consecutivos, seg√∫n datos de la Oficina de Investigaci√≥n Econ√≥mica y Empresarial de la Universidad de Florida.

El aumento de precios en el supermercado, en la gasolina y en productos cotidianos como el caf√© o el alcohol comienza a hacerse evidente, especialmente para comunidades de clase media y trabajadora.

Los aranceles de Trump han provocado un aumento de precios en Florida, afectando productos como la gasolina, el caf√© y materiales de construcci√≥n. Esto se debe a la imposici√≥n de un arancel universal del 10% sobre todas las importaciones y tarifas espec√≠ficas por pa√≠ses.

Empresas en Florida est√°n optando por compras anticipadas, l√≠neas de cr√©dito y reajustes en sus planes de expansi√≥n para enfrentar el impacto de los aranceles.

El aumento de precios en la gasolina en Florida es significativo debido a los aranceles del 10% y 25% impuestos al petr√≥leo de Canad√° y M√©xico, respectivamente.

A largo plazo, los aranceles de Trump podr√≠an frenar el crecimiento econ√≥mico en Estados Unidos.
