title: Pe√±a habla con presidente de la emirat√≠ DP World sobre proyectos portuarios y log√≠sticos
content: Asunci√≥n, 25 may (EFE).- El Presidente de Paraguay, Santiago Pe√±a, mantuvo este domingo un encuentro con el presidente de la multinacional emirat√≠ DP World, Sultan Ahmed Bin Sulayem, donde expuso las ...
resumen: El Presidente de Paraguay, Santiago Pe√±a, mantuvo un encuentro con el presidente de la multinacional emirat√≠ DP World, Sultan Ahmed Bin Sulayem, donde expuso las ‚Äúoportunidades‚Äù que ofrece su pa√≠s en materia portuaria y log√≠stica, como parte de su visita oficial en Emiratos √Årabes Unidos (EAU). Pe√±a est√° en una gira por Asia que tambi√©n incluy√≥ visitas a Jap√≥n y Singapur. Habl√≥ con el empresario ‚Äúespecialmente‚Äù sobre el proyecto del Corredor Vial Bioce√°nico, que conectar√° el sur brasile√±o sobre el Atl√°ntico con los puertos chilenos en el Pac√≠fico. Este megaproyecto, que naci√≥ en 2015, es una ruta terrestre que unir√° el centro oeste de Brasil, pasa por 532 kil√≥metros del Chaco paraguayo, las provincias argentinas de Salta y Jujuy, hasta llegar al norte de Chile a los puertos en Antofagasta, Mejillones e Iquique. Tambi√©n conversaron sobre la Hidrov√≠a Paraguay-Paran√°, el corredor natural que conecta al pa√≠s suramericano con el Atl√°ntico y por donde se transporta cerca del 80 % de su comercio exterior. DP World, especializada en log√≠sticas de carga y operaci√≥n de terminales portuarias, ‚Äúopera en m√°s de 40 pa√≠ses y mueve m√°s de 70 millones de contenedores al a√±o‚Äù. Pe√±a se reuni√≥ con el ministro de Econom√≠a de EAU, Abdulla Bin Touq Al Marri, y con empresarios del sector log√≠stico y tecnol√≥gico de ese pa√≠s como Terminals Holding y el gigante de la industria de la inteligencia artificial G42. Abordaron la posibilidad de exportar productos paraguayos a trav√©s de un corredor log√≠stico y sobre ‚Äúalianzas estrat√©gicas para aprovechar la energ√≠a limpia‚Äù de Paraguay y desarrollar centros de datos. Pe√±a se ha mostrado favorable a las negociaciones de un acuerdo de libre comercio entre EAU y el bloque del Mercosur, que adem√°s integran Brasil, Argentina, Uruguay y Bolivia (en proceso de adhesi√≥n plena), y ha respaldado la apertura de mercados en Asia.

title: Unlocking the Philippines‚Äô potential
content: The BusinessWorld Economic Forum 2025, ‚ÄúUnlocking the Philippines‚Äô potential,‚Äù held on May 22, focused on assessing the Philippine economy (where are we now?), exploring key risks, emerging ...
resumen:
The BusinessWorld Economic Forum 2025, ‚ÄúUnlocking the Philippines‚Äô potential,‚Äù held on May 22, focused on assessing the Philippine economy, exploring key risks, emerging opportunities and the evolving landscape across sectors.

Department of Economy, Planning, and Development (DEPDev) Secretary Arsenio M. Balisacan said the Philippine economy stands at a crossroads, affected by various developments and trends. He boasted of the full-year 2024 GDP growth rate of 5.6% and the decline of inflation to 1.4% as of April 2025. He noted that the Philippines' growth has relied more on factor accumulation while its ASEAN neighbors‚Äô formula has been Total Factor Productivity (TFP). He emphasized the need to revise strategies for the medium to long term, focusing on quality education, food security, connectivity, and innovation.

ASEAN+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO) Senior Economist Andrew Tsang concurred that boosting the Philippines‚Äô economic productivity is key to achieving a higher income status. The more critical growth measure of gross national income (GNI) per capita ($4,230 in 2023, up from $3,950 in 2022) places the Philippines in the lower-middle income status. Mr. Tsang said the Philippines could get upper middle-income country (UMIC) status by 2026 if GNI per capita increases by 6.8% from the 2023 level. World Bank Group Lead Economist and Program Leader for the Prosperity Unit for Brunei, Malaysia and the Philippines Gonzalo Varela earlier said the Philippines is more likely to achieve UMIC status by 2027. Mr. Balisacan has said the economy needs to grow by 6% until next year to achieve their targeted UMIC status.

Frederick Go, special assistant to the President for investment and economic affairs, cited the Philippine Development Plan (PDP) 2023-2028, which aims ‚Äúfor deep economic and social transformation to reinvigorate job creation and accelerate poverty reduction by steering the economy back on a high-growth path.‚Äù The Public Financial Management (PFM) Reforms Roadmap 2024-2028 also seeks to harmonize policies across government agencies and promotes transparency in the use of public funds, in line with PDP 2023-2028. It addresses 11 strategic focus areas that cover all PFM aspects. Secretary Go proffered the Corporate Recovery and Tax Incentives for Enterprises to Maximize Opportunities for Reinvigorating the Economy (CREATE MORE) law.

The three keynote speakers worried about shifting global alliances and trade relationships, geopolitical shifting and the trend towards protectionism.

Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) former Deputy Governor Diwa Guinigundo explained that Trump had domestic economic problems to address, for which he envisioned the drastic tariff increases on foreign trade partners to be the solution. He pointed out that the 17% reciprocal tariff rate imposed by Trump on the Philippines as of May 22 is the lowest in the ASEAN 5, except for Singapore.

Economist Bernardo M. Villegas said: ‚ÄúThe Philippines will be one of the least negatively impacted by the global economic slowdown that will be precipitated by the tariff wars that US President Donald Trump has already launched so very early in his presidency.‚Äù The Philippines' low export-to-GDP ratio, currently at 27%, is a strength during times of crisis. Consumers will continue to have purchasing power from the $40 billion of OFW remittances.

Energy Undersecretary Rowena Guevara and Energy Regulatory Commission CEO Monalisa Dimalanta assured the conference that the government has defined and strategized energy needs and directions of the country.

Ruben J. Pascual, secretary-general of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry, stressed ‚Äúthe importance of digital infrastructure, connectivity, digital education, skills and digital governance sovereignty to strengthen the country‚Äôs position in areas such as trade, technology and human capital development.‚Äù Mr. Pascual deplored the weakness of the agricultural sector and the decline of the manufacturing sector. He summarized the compounded failures of the Arroyo, Aquino, Duterte and Marcos administrations in: 1. Poverty and inequality: metrics versus inclusive development; bureaucratic delays and corruption. 2. Infrastructure deficits: slogans versus performance. 3. Fiscal irresponsibility: corruption.

Alfredo Panlilio, president of the Management Association of the Philippines (MAP), and Eduardo Francisco, president of BDO Capital, agreed with Mr. Pascual that skill set changes are needed to educate and retrain the workforce.

On the same day, breaking news announced that President Ferdinand ‚ÄúBongbong‚Äù R. Marcos, Jr. had asked his entire Cabinet and direct-report assistants to the President to submit courtesy resignations. The Presidential Communications Office (PCO) said the request for resignations would give Mr. Marcos ‚Äúelbow room to evaluate the performance of each department and determine who will continue to serve in line with his administration‚Äôs recalibrated priorities. The move comes following the poor performance of administration-backed senatorial candidates in the May 12 midterm elections, and amid global uncertainties due to trade concerns that could threaten the Philippine economy.‚Äù

title: Malasia impulsa a naciones del sudeste asi√°tico a negociar en bloque aranceles con Trump
content: El primer ministro de Malasia, Anwar Ibrahim, anunci√≥ que las naciones del sudeste asi√°tico buscan negociar como bloque los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos, destacando la dependencia econ√≥mica ...
resumen:
El primer ministro de Malasia, Anwar Ibrahim, anunci√≥ que las naciones del sudeste asi√°tico buscan negociar como bloque los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos, destacando la dependencia econ√≥mica de la regi√≥n.

Anwar declar√≥ que ha solicitado una reuni√≥n conjunta con el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, con el objetivo de discutir los aranceles. Se espera que esta reuni√≥n pueda concretarse m√°s adelante en el a√±o. Malasia ejerce actualmente la presidencia de la ASEAN.

La ASEAN ha constituido un grupo de trabajo para coordinar una respuesta a los aranceles de Estados Unidos, mientras algunos pa√≠ses miembros optan por negociar bilateralmente. La asociaci√≥n incluye econom√≠as significativas como Singapur, Indonesia, Malasia, Tailandia, Filipinas, adem√°s de Vietnam, Camboya, Laos y Myanmar.

La regi√≥n depende en gran medida de las exportaciones hacia Estados Unidos, y los aranceles impuestos por el gobierno de Trump oscilan entre el 10% para Singapur y el 49% para Camboya. En abril, Trump anunci√≥ una pausa de 90 d√≠as en los aranceles para gran parte del mundo, y este mes lleg√≥ a un acuerdo similar con su principal competidor, China.

Anwar anticipa que la reuni√≥n de l√≠deres de ASEAN con el primer ministro chino, Li Qiang, junto con el Consejo de Cooperaci√≥n del Golfo (GCC), posiblemente por primera vez, podr√° fomentar nuevas formas de cooperaci√≥n para proteger la econom√≠a de la ASEAN. El GCC abarca a Bahr√©in, Kuwait, Om√°n, Qatar, Arabia Saudita y Emiratos √Årabes Unidos.

M√°s tarde, los l√≠deres de la ASEAN presentar√°n un nuevo plan de 20 a√±os con el fin de profundizar su integraci√≥n econ√≥mica y social.

El presidente de Filipinas, Ferdinand Marcos Jr., expres√≥ en la cumbre de ASEAN que un ‚Äúc√≥digo de conducta‚Äù que actualmente se encuentra en negociaciones entre la ASEAN y China para gestionar el transitado mar debe ser vinculante.

Sobre la situaci√≥n en Myanmar, Anwar se√±al√≥ que Malasia ha logrado algunos ‚Äúprogresos‚Äù tras establecer un grupo asesor informal liderado por un exl√≠der tailand√©s. Anwar se reuni√≥ el mes pasado con el jefe militar de Myanmar y mantuvo di√°logos virtuales con el Gobierno de Unidad Nacional de la oposici√≥n.

La guerra en Myanmar ha resultado en miles de muertes y millones de desplazados, lo que se ha convertido en un desaf√≠o significativo para la ASEAN.

title: Trump Agrees to Extend Deadline After Threatening E.U. With 50% Tariff, With Talks Set to ‚ÄòBegin Rapidly‚Äô

title: Trump Delays EU Tariffs to July 9 After Call With von der Leyen
content: U.S. President Donald Trump announced on Sunday that he would delay the implementation of proposed 50% tariffs on European Union imports until July 9, 2025. The decision followed a phone call with ...
resumen: U.S. President Donald Trump announced on Sunday that he would delay the implementation of proposed 50% tariffs on European Union imports until July 9, 2025. The decision followed a phone call with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, who requested an extension to the original June 1 deadline. Trump said in a post on Truth Social that he agreed to the extension to July 9, 2025, and that trade talks with the EU will begin "rapidly." Von der Leyen confirmed the call, saying it was ‚Äúgood‚Äù and that Europe is ready to move forward with negotiations ‚Äúswiftly and decisively.‚Äù The 50% tariff, initially set for June 1, was part of a broader push for what Trump calls ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù trade measures. It remains unclear if the 50% levy would be added to the previously proposed 20% tariffs scheduled for early July. In April, he unveiled a series of tariffs against key U.S. trading partners but delayed them by three months.

title: Impuesto a remesas, TPS incierto y aranceles, ¬øCu√°l es la pol√≠tica de Castro?
content: Honduras enfrentar√° casi todo su segundo semestre del 2025 a tres amenazas, que, de concretarse, provocar√°n un golpe devastador a su econom√≠a y, se prev√©, tensar√°n sus relaciones con Estados Unidos, s ...
resumen:
Honduras enfrentar√° casi todo su segundo semestre del 2025 a tres amenazas: impuesto a las remesas, aplicaci√≥n de un arancel a sus exportaciones y la perspectiva de un final al Estatus de Protecci√≥n Temporal (TPS).

El golpe a la econom√≠a entre impuesto a las remesas y aranceles estar√≠a entre los 550 a 700 millones de d√≥lares en caso de concretarse.

Las tres iniciativas de la actual administraci√≥n del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump encendieron las alarmas entre el gobierno, los empresarios y economistas independientes.

Hay tres millones de personas que dependen de las remesas enviadas por los 1.5 millones de hondure√±os que residen en Estados Unidos, el 10 % a los aranceles impactar√° al sector exportador, y el TPS implicar√≠a a 55 mil hondure√±os y sus respectivas familias.

El BCH en su Programa Monetario de este 2025 estim√≥ en 10 mil millones de d√≥lares las remesas que el pa√≠s recibir√°.

El proyecto en discusi√≥n impone un impuesto del 3.5 % al env√≠o de remesas, el cual debe ser pagado por el remitente y cobrado por la remesadora que luego lo entrega al Tesoro de Estados Unidos.

Para la economista Liliana Castillo, expresidenta del Colegio Hondure√±o de Economistas (CHE), de aprobarlo el Senado el impacto del impuesto ser√° entre 350-500 millones de d√≥lares.

El Consejo Hondure√±o de la Empresa Privada (Cohep) calific√≥ la medida como un golpe directo a las familias m√°s vulnerables, recordando que m√°s de un mill√≥n de hogares hondure√±os dependen de las remesas para sobrevivir.

El ministro de Econom√≠a, Fredy Cerrato, dijo a Proceso Digital que ‚Äúlos aranceles est√°n suspendidos‚Äù actualmente.

En 2024 Honduras export√≥ 2,003.8 millones de d√≥lares al mercado estadounidense, lo que significa que de mantenerse el arancel del 10 % para ingresar a suelo norteamericano los productos hondure√±os pagar√≠an 200.3 millones de d√≥lares a la aduana de Washington.

El actual permiso TPS vence el 5 de julio del 2025.

Alrededor de 55 mil familias hondure√±as se encuentran en agon√≠a, ya que el gobierno estadounidense no comunic√≥ nada sobre si extender√≠a el permiso de residencia temporal o TPS a los beneficiados con esta medida, efectiva desde enero de 1999.

El Departamento de Seguridad Nacional (DHS, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) no emiti√≥ comunicado alguno.

title: Trump, muchas ventanas de trabajo abiertas
content: Aranceles de 50% a la Uni√≥n Europea desde el 1¬∞ de junio es la nueva jugada de Estados Unidos con la que busca mejorar el d√©ficit, pero ante todo hacer ...
resumen:
Donald Trump puede ser rotulado como el ‚Äúgran proteccionista‚Äù. Ha vuelto a agitar su bandera arancelaria.
Estados Unidos busca mejorar el d√©ficit y hacer m√°s competitivos sus productos.
Trump anunci√≥ un arancel de 50% para los productos europeos desde el 1¬∞ de junio.
El temor sobre nuevas sanciones a pa√≠ses y a empresas estadounidenses, como Apple, est√° sobre la mesa.
Trump ha tratado de nivelar el terreno comercial que Estados Unidos ten√≠a con otros pa√≠ses.
Su estrategia de negociaci√≥n se ha hecho evidente, m√©todo que revel√≥ hace casi 40 a√±os en su libro ‚ÄòTrump: el arte de la negociaci√≥n‚Äô, (Grijalbo, 1988), escrito por el Presidente y Tony Schwartz.
Trump planteaba que su mejor manera de alcanzar los objetivos en las negociaciones es apuntar muy alto y disparar cuantas veces sea necesario para lograr el objeto.
Trump puso en cintura a sus socios econ√≥micos m√°s importantes: Canad√°, M√©xico y China.
A los europeos los asust√≥ con anexar a Groenlandia y a los latinoamericanos en retomar el Canal de Panam√°, adem√°s de hacer deportaciones masivas por motivos de seguridad nacional.
Trump est√° logrando sus objetivos con China y Europa.
El gobierno Petro debe caminar muy suave en estas relaciones porque el grueso del comercio colombiano se hace con Estados Unidos.
La balanza comercial de Colombia con Estados Unidos es deficitaria, ha registrado d√©ficit de unos US$2.000 millones.
Trump tiene muchas ventanas abiertas por ejecutar: Harvard, Apple, Europa.
Esto le impone a Colombia un rol de prudente silencio en estos momentos en los que al creciente negocio del narcotr√°fico puede ser un argumento para descertificar o sancionar una econom√≠a sin grado de inversi√≥n.

title: FAP ajusta el rumbo en un entorno vol√°til y apuesta por mayores rendimientos
content: El Fondo de Ahorro de Panam√° (FAP) diversific√≥ su plan de inversiones para 2025-2026, modificando la asignaci√≥n de fondos y agregando nuevas categor√≠as que no estaban el a√±o pasado, como deuda emitida ...
resumen:
El Fondo de Ahorro de Panam√° (FAP) ajust√≥ su portafolio en un contexto de alta volatilidad global, manteniendo una estrategia de largo plazo que le permiti√≥ obtener ganancias durante el primer trimestre de 2025.

El FAP diversific√≥ su plan de inversiones para 2025-2026, modificando la asignaci√≥n de fondos y agregando nuevas categor√≠as que no estaban el a√±o pasado, como deuda emitida por el Estado paname√±o.

Abdiel Santiago, secretario ejecutivo del Fondo, explic√≥ que el objetivo es lograr una mayor diversidad en un entorno internacional que se prev√© continuar√° desafiante, tras un primer trimestre que calific√≥ como de ‚Äúvolatilidad excepcionalmente alta‚Äù.

En el plan de inversiones del FAP 2025-2026 se observa un ajuste en la estrategia, con una reducci√≥n en los activos de corta duraci√≥n (de 15% a 10%) y en la renta fija global (de 41% a 34%), a cambio, se incrementa la exposici√≥n a bonos de alto rendimiento (de 7% a 10%) y a renta variable global (de 20% a 25%).

El secretario ejecutivo del FAP, Abdiel Santiago, explic√≥ que el nuevo plan de inversiones no busca asumir m√°s riesgos, sino alcanzar mayores rendimientos manteniendo el objetivo principal del fondo: preservar su capital.

Se incorpora una nueva categor√≠a con 4% asignado a bonos de la Rep√∫blica de Panam√°. Las asignaciones a bonos indexados a inflaci√≥n (2%) e inversiones alternativas (15%) se mantienen sin cambios.

El nuevo plan de inversiones mantiene intacto el mandato principal del Fondo, que es preservar su capital fundacional, el cual inici√≥ con $1,234 millones y que a la fecha se acerca a los $1,700 millones en activos totales.

El FAP fue creado en 2012 en reemplazo del Fondo Fiduciario para el Desarrollo, establecido en 1995.

‚ÄúEl cambio en la asignaci√≥n responde a una estrategia de diversificaci√≥n, no a una mayor agresividad. Los bonos de alto rendimiento y los activos privados ofrecen mejores retornos esperados dentro de un marco de control adecuado del riesgo‚Äù, se√±al√≥.

En un mundo m√°s caro e inflacionario, activos como el efectivo o la renta fija de corto plazo pierden efectividad.

Durante los primeros meses de 2025, los activos l√≠quidos como el efectivo y la renta fija de corto plazo perdieron atractivo porque la Reserva Federal (Fed) de Estados Unidos decidi√≥ mantener su tasa de inter√©s sin cambios. En su reuni√≥n del 7 de mayo de 2025, mantuvo esa pol√≠tica, dejando la tasa entre 4.25% y 4.5%.

Los bonos del Tesoro de EU a 10 a√±os se cotizan cerca del 4.5%, uno de los niveles m√°s altos en 17 a√±os.

El 16 de mayo de 2025, Moody‚Äôs rebaj√≥ la calificaci√≥n crediticia de EU de ‚ÄòAaa‚Äô a ‚ÄòAa1‚Äô.

El secretario ejecutivo del FAP coment√≥ que este aumento en las tasas impacta el costo del dinero y limita el desempe√±o de otros activos, por lo cual el FAP sigue de cerca el comportamiento del mercado, pero con una visi√≥n de largo plazo.

La junta directiva del FAP se√±ala que podr√° considerar una colocaci√≥n t√°ctica o posicionamiento de corto a mediano plazo del portafolio, en respuesta a movimientos de diversos mercados financieros, aplicando en todo momento un razonamiento econ√≥mico y financiero, conforme a los principios que rigen las Directrices de Inversi√≥n para la protecci√≥n de los activos del Fondo.

Entre enero y marzo, el √≠ndice VIX, que mide la volatilidad esperada en los mercados burs√°tiles, alcanz√≥ su segundo nivel m√°s alto en la √∫ltima d√©cada.

La volatilidad registrada en los mercados burs√°tiles durante el primer trimestre del a√±o fue, en gran medida, consecuencia de la pol√≠tica comercial y exterior impulsada por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump.

El S&P 500 mostr√≥ una dispersi√≥n diaria superior al 10%.

A pesar de la volatilidad del primer trimestre, el FAP report√≥ una ganancia bruta preliminar de 14.5 millones de d√≥lares, lo que represent√≥ un rendimiento de 0.80%.

En los √∫ltimos 12 meses, el rendimiento anualizado fue de 5.58%, y en los √∫ltimos 24 meses, de 7.03%.

Desde su creaci√≥n, el Fondo ha logrado un rendimiento promedio anual de 3.46%, superando en 43 puntos b√°sicos a su √≠ndice de referencia compuesto.

Al final del primer trimestre, las inversiones del FAP se concentraron en un 49% en renta fija, 26% en instrumentos l√≠quidos de corta duraci√≥n, 16% en acciones y 9% en inversiones alternativas.

El principal reto durante el primer trimestre fue mantener el rumbo estrat√©gico en un entorno de gran incertidumbre.

El FAP est√° dise√±ado con un horizonte de inversi√≥n de 10 a√±os.

Durante el primer trimestre de 2025, el FAP aument√≥ sus inversiones en el mercado asi√°tico y redujo su exposici√≥n en Europa. Adem√°s, destin√≥ un 1% a √Åfrica y mantuvo el 90% de sus inversiones en Norteam√©rica.

‚ÄúNuestro portafolio global y diversificado‚Äîque incluye activos p√∫blicos y privados‚Äîtuvo un desempe√±o s√≥lido, con una rentabilidad bruta del 0.80% en el trimestre‚Äù, destac√≥.

Para finales de marzo, el 90% de las inversiones del Fondo estaban enfocadas en Norteam√©rica, 3% en Europa, 3% en Asia y Latinoam√©rica, y 1% en Ocean√≠a y √Åfrica.

title: La raz√≥n del poder escupe para arriba
content: Trump anda en viajes de ensue√±o, en √°ulicos castillos de emperadores, reyes, emires, sultanes, recibiendo regalos, lo mismo diamantes que aviones, llevando poderosas empresas √°rabes a EU, e inscribi√©n ...
resumen:
En el M√©xico actual, se vive bajo la "raz√≥n del poder" en lugar de la "raz√≥n". En otros pa√≠ses como Venezuela, Nicaragua, Rusia, Israel, Ir√°n y Estados Unidos, tambi√©n se soporta la "raz√≥n del poder".

Estados Unidos, que antes era ejemplo de democracia, ahora enfrenta tiempos dif√≠ciles con un presidente que se comporta de manera cuestionable.

La presidente Sheinbaum critica a Donald Trump, exigiendo informaci√≥n sobre la familia de Ovidio Guzm√°n y el tema de la extradici√≥n. Tambi√©n se opone a un impuesto sobre las remesas y anuncia acciones para combatirlo.

El art√≠culo 11 de la Carta Magna garantiza a la familia de Ovidio el derecho a entrar y salir del pa√≠s.

Sheinbaum es acusada de contradecir sus propios principios, como unidad, honestidad, sencillez, no amiguismo, formaci√≥n pol√≠tica, defensa de los derechos del pueblo, austeridad, candidatos por encuestas, no colusi√≥n con la delincuencia y no machismo.

Sheinbaum afirma que "M√©xico no es pi√±ata de nadie", pero el art√≠culo sugiere que Estados Unidos la ha convertido en una.

Se aconseja a Sheinbaum que resuelva el problema de los maestros del pa√≠s y se menciona la colisi√≥n del barco escuela Cuauht√©moc contra el puente de Brooklyn, sugiriendo que Sheinbaum podr√≠a ser responsable si la causa es una falla de mantenimiento.

title: ASEAN must deepen integration and stay united to tackle tariffs: Malaysia
content: Southeast Asian nations must accelerate regional economic integration, diversify their markets and stay united to tackle the fallout from global ...
resumen:
Southeast Asian nations must accelerate regional economic integration, diversify their markets and stay united to tackle the fallout from global trade disruptions resulting from sweeping US tariff hikes, Malaysian Foreign Minister Mohamad Hasan said on Sunday.

Mohamad, opening a meeting of foreign ministers from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, (ASEAN) also reiterated the bloc‚Äôs call to warring parties in Myanmar to cease hostilities.

‚ÄúASEAN nations are among those most heavily affected by the US-imposed tariffs. The US-China trade war is dramatically disrupting production and trade patterns worldwide. A global economic slowdown is likely to happen,‚Äù Mohamad said. ‚ÄúWe must seize this moment to deepen regional economic integration, so that we can better shield our region from external shocks.‚Äù

ASEAN countries, many of which rely on exports to the US, are reeling from tariffs imposed by the Trump administration ranging from 10% to 49%. Six of the association‚Äôs 10 member nations were among the worst-hit with tarrifs ranging from 32% to 49%.

ASEAN unsuccessfully sought an initial meeting with the US as a bloc. When US President Donald Trump last month announced a 90-day pause on the tariffs, countries including Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam swiftly began trade negotiations with Washington.

The meeting of foreign ministers preceded a planned ASEAN leaders‚Äô summit Monday in Malaysia, the bloc‚Äôs current chair. A summit is expected to follow on Tuesday with Chinese Premier Li Qiang and leaders from the Gulf Cooperation Council comprising Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

ASEAN‚Äôs unity is crucial as the region grapples with impacts of climate change and disruption from the malevolent use of artificial intelligence and other unregulated techologies, Mohamad said, adding that ASEAN‚Äôs centrality will be tested by external pressure, including a superpower rivalry.

‚ÄúExternal pressures are rising, and the scope of challenges has never had higher stakes,‚Äù he said. ‚Äú‚ÄùIt is therefore crucial that we reinforce the ties that bind us, so as to not unravel under external pressures. For ASEAN, unity is now more important than ever.‚Äù

ASEAN members have refused to take sides, engaging the U.S. and China, which are both key regional trading and investment partners.

ASEAN remained committed to help war-torn Myanmar, which is recovering from a March earthquake that killed more than 3,700 people, Mohamad said.

Myanmar‚Äôs military leaders were barred from attending ASEAN meetings after refusing to comply with ASEAN‚Äôs peace plan, which includes negotiations and delivery of humanitarian aid.

‚ÄúWe call on the stakeholders in Myanmar to cease hostilities, and to extend and expand the ceasefire, to facilitate the long and difficult path towards recovery,‚Äù Mohamad said.

Myanmar‚Äôs crisis has challenged the credibility of ASEAN, which has been hampered by its long-held policy of non-interference in each other‚Äôs affairs.

After informal consultations with bloc members, Mohamad said Saturday that ASEAN has to step up efforts as Myanmar‚Äôs problems had spilled over borders with a growing number of refugees fleeing to neighboring nations and rising transborder crime.

Malaysia‚Äôs efforts now focus on de-escalation of violence and greater access to humanitarian aid, but he said plans for political dialogue between the conflicting parties would be challenging due to a ‚Äútrust deficit.‚Äù

Meanwhile, Chinese Premier Li Qiang met with Indonesia‚Äôs President Prabowo Subianto on Sunday to discuss ways to expand trade and investment during the U.S. global trade war and as economic globalization faces headwinds.

Li arrived in Indonesia‚Äôs capital, Jakarta, on Saturday afternoon for a three-day visit to Southeast Asia‚Äôs largest economy. It was the first stop of his first overseas visit this year.

Indonesia and China are member states of the Group 20 major developing countries and emerging economies and of BRICS.

Li brought 60 Chinese prominent businesspeople for his address to the Indonesia-China Business Reception on Sunday evening. He emphasized in his remarks that China‚Äôs economy has achieved rapid growth this year despite increasing external challenges.

‚ÄúThe current international situation is a stalemate,‚Äù Li said at the event which was also attended by Subianto, ‚ÄúUnilateralism and protectionism are on the rise, bullying behavior is increasing.‚Äù

Li noted that this year marks the 70th anniversary of the Non-Aligned Movement which was held by Asian and African countries in Indonesia‚Äôs Bandung city, when the world was at a historical crossroads more than seven decades ago.

The Bandung spirit of solidarity, friendship and cooperation has played a pivotal role in the unity and cooperation of the Global South countries, Li said.

‚ÄúMore than seven decades later, the world is once again at an important crossroads,‚Äù Li said.

He called on all countries to seek common ground while resolving differences through dialogue and peaceful coexistence.

title: Trade war tremors: A Q and A with a Kansas economist about tariffs, manufacturing and the workforce
content: The act passed in June 1930, under President Herbert Hoover, and it increased U.S. tariffs on agricultural imports and thousands of imported goods. Many economists credit it with deepening the Great ...
resumen:
Bekah Selby-Leach, director of the Wichita State University Center for Economic Development and Business Research, considers the trade war and the future of U.S. manufacturing.

A tariff is a tax on businesses bringing goods and services into the country, levied against domestic businesses to encourage them to produce locally.

The goal of putting tariffs in place could address trade imbalances. About one-third of goods and services are being produced out of the China region, putting them at a huge advantage in terms of their control of global markets, and the United States wants to reclaim some of that control.

Selby-Leach and economists nationwide are seeing slow-downs indicative of an approaching recession.

The short-term China trade deal led some analysts to reconsider but that news was quickly followed by a U.S. credit rating downgrade from Moody‚Äôs. That news caused mortgage rates to jump up near 7%. Yet inflation also increased at a lower-than-expected rate, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.

If Trump trade deals don‚Äôt go right, it could very well lead to a deepening recession.

Current tariff policies in the United States are reminiscent of a similar situation from the past. The Smoot-Hawley Act, passed in June 1930, under President Herbert Hoover, increased U.S. tariffs on agricultural imports and thousands of imported goods. Many economists credit it with deepening the Great Depression because of retaliatory tariffs and causing decreased U.S. exports.

Tariffs almost always lead to inflation in prices.

Almost all goods the United States consumes have some portion of their supply chain that will be affected by tariffs.

Global economic power has shifted toward China for some time, and pulling some of that back would add more democracy to the global markets, with less centralization in one country.

Consumers will ‚Äúmost certainly‚Äù see rising costs of items typically purchased from abroad, even if companies move manufacturing to the United States.

Bringing manufacturing back to the U.S. isn‚Äôt as simple as it may appear to be.

Most of the richest countries in the world do not have a lot of production.

High-tech manufacturing can be considered its own new industry.

China has been working on advanced manufacturing for at least a decade. Advanced manufacturing refers to the use of robotics, artificial intelligence, automation and other high-tech advances. They have some production centers that have 500,000 workers. That‚Äôs the entire city of Wichita.

Low unemployment rates already create challenging workforce issues. There aren‚Äôt people who know how to do those things in the United States because we haven‚Äôt done them for so long. So you‚Äôd have to go through a huge human training program to develop those skills. That will take at least a couple of years.

There isn‚Äôt an available labor pool to reskill and place into newly created manufacturing jobs.

Places like Wichita, with its highly skilled workforce in the aerospace industry and other advanced manufacturers, would have an advantage.

Uncertainty has a very known effect and people tend to consume less and save more. They tend to invest less and hold onto their money in what they consider to be more stable places, such as a savings account, or even cash and assets like that.

The way we measure economic activity is through spending.

title: Trump agrees to delay U.S. tariffs on EU until July 9
content: President Donald Trump on Sunday said he has agreed to delay imposing a 50% tariff on European goods until July 9 to allow more time for trade negotiations.
resumen: President Donald Trump announced on Sunday, May 25, 2025, that he has agreed to delay imposing a 50% tariff on European goods until July 9 to allow more time for trade negotiations. He made the decision following a call with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, who had requested the extension. Trump announced the decision in a post on his Truth Social media platform. Von der Leyen said they would need until July 9 to reach a "good" trade deal. Trump had originally announced 20% tariffs on EU imports in April, then reduced those tariffs to 10% for 90 days. On Friday, Trump announced that a 50% tariff on EU goods would go into effect June 1. According to the U.S. Trade Representative, the U.S. goods trade deficit with the EU last year was $235.6 billion, an increase of nearly 13% from the year prior.

title: El rey de las monedas
content: El valor del d√≥lar estadounidense como moneda de reserva internacional ha vuelto al centro del debate, luego de que la administraci√≥n Trump ha expresado su preocupaci√≥n por su supuesta sobrevaloraci√≥n ...
resumen: El valor del d√≥lar estadounidense como moneda de reserva internacional ha vuelto al centro del debate, luego de que la administraci√≥n Trump ha expresado su preocupaci√≥n por su supuesta sobrevaloraci√≥n. El secretario del Tesoro, Bessent, advirti√≥ que el d√≥lar deber√≠a seguir siendo la moneda de reserva global, junto con una reserva estrat√©gica de criptomonedas y el uso de ‚Äústablecoins‚Äù. Seg√∫n Stephen Miran, el jefe del Council of Economic Advisers del gobierno, la intenci√≥n ser√≠a depreciar deliberadamente el d√≥lar, bajo la premisa de que su fortaleza ha contribuido a la desindustrializaci√≥n de EEUU, al encarecer las exportaciones y abaratar las importaciones. Se busca mantenerlo ‚Äìjunto con las criptomonedas controladas por EEUU‚Äì como el ancla de intercambio de bienes, servicios y capitales en el mundo. Donald Trump amenaz√≥ con aplicar severas sanciones a los pa√≠ses que, como China o los BRICS, quieran competir con o dejar de utilizar el d√≥lar. Declar√≥ que ‚Äúrequerimos un compromiso de estos pa√≠ses de que no crear√°n una nueva moneda BRICS, ni respaldar√°n ninguna otra moneda para reemplazar al poderoso d√≥lar estadounidense, o enfrentar√°n aranceles de 100%, y deber√≠an olvidarse de vender en la maravillosa econom√≠a de Estados Unidos‚Äù. El rol del d√≥lar como moneda de reserva internacional surgi√≥ hace 80 a√±os, tras la Segunda Guerra Mundial con el Acuerdo de Bretton Woods en 1944 firmado por 44 pa√≠ses, incluidos EEUU, Reino Unido, Francia y Canad√°. Este acuerdo estableci√≥ al d√≥lar como ancla global, fijado al oro a una tasa fija de 35 d√≥lares por onza, mientras que pa√≠ses signatarios fijaban sus monedas al d√≥lar. EEUU garantizaba la convertibilidad del d√≥lar en oro. En 1971, EEUU, reconoci√≥ que ya no pod√≠a sostener la convertibilidad del d√≥lar en oro, y el presidente Richard Nixon puso fin al patr√≥n oro. El d√≥lar es la principal moneda de reserva internacional. Su hegemon√≠a se ha mantenido gracias a su liquidez, estabilidad econ√≥mica, la transparencia de los mercados financieros y su uso en el comercio internacional, en especial de los commodities. El euro es una alternativa que, sin embargo, carece del mismo alcance. Las crisis financieras de Grecia y Chipre, sumadas a la fragmentaci√≥n de pol√≠ticas, han dificultado su adopci√≥n universal. El fracaso del oro como respaldo monetario mostr√≥ los l√≠mites de basar un sistema financiero en activos escasos. Algo similar podr√≠a ocurrir con los pa√≠ses que intenta adoptar criptomonedas como reserva de valor, dada que la ‚Äúescasez‚Äù es una constante en las criptomonedas, que no necesariamente acompa√±an la expansi√≥n de la econom√≠a.
tags: ['moneda de reserva', 'econom√≠a internacional', 'pol√≠tica monetaria', 'valuaci√≥n de divisas', 'estabilidad financiera']

title: Indian benchmark indexes set to open higher after Trump delays EU tariffs
content: India's benchmark indexes are set to open marginally higher on Monday, after U.S. President Donald Trump extended the deadline for trade talks with the European Union, easing near-term tensions.
resumen:
India's benchmark indexes are set to open marginally higher on Monday. Gift Nifty futures were trading at 24,935.5 as of 8:09 a.m. IST, indicating that the Nifty 50 will open above its Friday's close of 24,853.15.

Trump extended the deadline for trade talks with the European Union until July 9.

The Nifty 50 has climbed 5.7% since early April. The index remains 5.4% below its record high of September 27, 2024.

Foreign portfolio investors purchased 17.95 billion rupees ($211.14 million) worth of Indian equities on Friday, bringing May‚Äôs net inflows to $1.64 billion.

India‚Äôs Q4 GDP data is due on May 30 and the RBI‚Äôs policy decision on June 6.

title: How French industries are adapting to US tariffs
content: The trade war initiated by Donald Trump and his frequent policy shifts are plunging French companies into uncertainty. While some attempt to pass the increase in tariffs onto their customers, others ...
resumen: The trade war initiated by Donald Trump and his frequent policy shifts are plunging French companies into uncertainty. Some attempt to pass the increase in tariffs onto their customers, while others are beginning to rethink their value chains and increase their production in the US. Sylvie Grandjean, chief executive of Redex, attended the industrial machinery manufacturers' trade fair in Atlanta, Georgia, for several years. In the 2025 edition, which began on Monday, May 12, the increase in tariffs of 10% for goods exported from Europe, and up to 25% for cars and steel and aluminum products, decreed by US President Donald Trump in March and April, was a major topic of conversation. Redex manufactures measuring instruments for various sectors, including aerospace, and notably works with SpaceX, Elon Musk's space venture. Redex produces in France as well as in Germany, but 90% of its turnover comes from exports, including 15% from the United States. Its American subsidiary, with about 20 employees, has been based in New Jersey since the 1980s and focuses on customer services. The clients have agreed to absorb most of the additional cost of the 'Trump tariffs,' which will be reflected in consumer sales prices. Many French companies have been navigating in fog for weeks. They are trying to cope with the present situation while anxiously awaiting July 9, the end of the 90-day-pause decreed on April 9 by Trump, to determine the exact level of tariff increases. Alexandre Saubot, president of France Industrie, an organization representing major French industrial groups, stated that uncertainty and confusion prevail.

title: La innovaci√≥n y la especializaci√≥n fortalecen a las empresas ante la incertidumbre econ√≥mica
content: El anuncio del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump del 2 de abril de 2025 marca el cambio de direcci√≥n m√°s importante de los √∫ltimos 50 a√±os para el comercio internacional: una lista de aranceles g ...
resumen:
El anuncio del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump del 2 de abril de 2025 marca el cambio de direcci√≥n m√°s importante de los √∫ltimos 50 a√±os para el comercio internacional: una lista de aranceles globales.

La innovaci√≥n es el ant√≠doto para afrontar los aranceles. Un producto innovador ofrece un efecto sorpresa que aumenta la disposici√≥n a pagar m√°s.

Los que tengan una brecha menor entre el coste de fabricaci√≥n y el precio de venta del producto se encuentran inmersos en la trampa del bajo coste y est√°n cada vez m√°s expuestos a la incertidumbre.

Las empresas deben buscar siempre estar en la frontera. La mayor√≠a de los directivos se encuentran atrapados en una inercia de enfocarse en la reducci√≥n de costos, lo que se convierte en una anorexia empresarial.

La expresi√≥n competitivo se asocia con la reducci√≥n de precios pero, en su origen, la palabra competitividad estaba asociada con retar los paradigmas existentes.

Al reducir costes, se acaba recortando los salarios.

La pol√≠tica de recortes aplicada durante el desarrollo del Boeing 737MAX hizo que el avi√≥n fuera menos seguro y, seg√∫n los investigadores, contribuy√≥ a los accidentes del vuelo 610 de Lion Air (2018) y del vuelo 302 de Ethiopian Airlines (2019).

El estallido en 2010 de la plataforma petrol√≠fera Deepwater Horizon en el Golfo de M√©xico ‚Äìy el posterior derrame de hidrocarburo m√°s importante de la historia‚Äì, tuvo entre sus causas la reducci√≥n de costes.

Poner el foco en la innovaci√≥n es una estrategia dif√≠cil porque basar el liderazgo empresarial en ese concepto requiere el esfuerzo adicional de dedicar ‚Äìy pagar‚Äì tiempo para pensar.

Las empresas enfocadas en la innovaci√≥n son capaces de absorber costes adicionales.

La cerveza mexicana Corona se posicion√≥ con el precio m√°s alto del mercado, compitiendo directamente con Heineken.

La inversi√≥n dedicada la investigaci√≥n se ha desplomado en los √∫ltimos 40 a√±os.

La innovaci√≥n permite aumentar el nivel de sofisticaci√≥n y el valor de los productos y, en consecuencia, que tengan mayores precios. Un precio alto es, en realidad, un derecho que se gana la compa√±√≠a que innova.

Cada regi√≥n del mundo puede, y debe, identificar cu√°l es su ventaja natural y encontrar la mejor manera de desarrollarla y aprovecharla para mejorar su posici√≥n frente a otras empresas de su sector.

Se identificaron cinco patrones que comparten las empresas y regiones que han logrado aumentar el valor de sus productos y, por ende, aumentar el diferencial entre el precio y sus costes:

1.  Enfocarse en los segmentos de alto valor de los diferentes mercados.
2.  Profundizar en la ciencia detr√°s del negocio.
3.  Expandirse hacia otros productos e industrias.
4.  Orquestar la cooperaci√≥n p√∫blica-privada a trav√©s del dise√±o de una robusta pol√≠tica industrial.
5.  Buscar ideas en lugares punteros.

La imposici√≥n de aranceles universales por parte del gobierno estadounidense obliga a repensar las estrategias para competir en el mercado. Aquellas empresas que ponen el acento en unos costes de producci√≥n bajos no ser√°n capaces de absorber los aranceles.

Promover el desarrollo econ√≥mico a trav√©s de la innovaci√≥n y la especializaci√≥n, aumentando el valor de los productos y dando a sus productores una singularidad que les fortalece, deber√≠a ayudar a disminuir los riesgos provocados por esta guerra econ√≥mica.

title: Trump Administration Live Updates: Trump Delays Imposing 50 Percent Tariffs on E.U.
content: President Trump told cadets in a commencement address at the United States Military Academy at West Point on Saturday that they were the first graduates to serve in a ‚Äúgolden age‚Äù of the nation that ...
resumen:
President Trump said he would delay imposing 50 percent tariffs on all imports from the European Union until July 9 to allow more time for trade negotiations.

In a post on Truth Social, Mr. Trump said that he had spoken to Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, about his recent threat to enact the tariffs on June 1 if a trade deal could not be reached in the next week.

Mr. Trump has expressed frustration over negotiations with the E.U., saying that the union has been slow to offer trade concessions during a 90-day window to reach a deal that satisfies the administration.

On Sunday, Mr. Trump appeared to relent, at least for now.

Ms. von der Leyen, in a separate social media post on Sunday, said that she had a ‚Äúgood call‚Äù with Mr. Trump and had conveyed to him that the E.U. needed extra time to reach a trade deal. She said that talks would advance ‚Äúswiftly and decisively.‚Äù

The extension is the latest turnabout by Mr. Trump, whose trade policies have injected substantial uncertainty into the global economy.

When asked if there was anything Europe could do to avoid tariffs, he had responded, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, we‚Äôre going to see what happens,‚Äù adding, ‚Äúthey‚Äôve treated us very badly over the years.‚Äù

Friday‚Äôs threat of 50 percent tariffs came after Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent met with European counterparts as part of the Group of 7 meetings in Canada.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariff threat against the E.U. came weeks after he agreed to partially pause the 145 percent tariffs he had imposed on Chinese imports.

European leaders have offered to reduce tariffs on industrial goods to zero if the United States does the same, and to increase purchases of U.S. energy, among other commitments.

In a post on Truth Social Friday morning, Mr. Trump wrote that discussions with the European Union were ‚Äúgoing nowhere‚Äù and that he was recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1.

Mr. Trump also threatened a 25 percent tariff on imports of smartphones made by Apple and other companies on Friday, saying they should be made in the United States.

Economists at Oxford Economics said that if implemented, the E.U. tariffs and the phone tariffs, combined, would reduce economic growth by 0.2 percentage points, raise inflation by 0.2 percentage points, and increase the unemployment rate by a tenth of a percentage point.

President Trump continued his criticism of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for unleashing a deadly offensive against Ukraine instead of focusing on a cease-fire, writing on social media that Putin ‚Äúhas gone absolutely CRAZY‚Äù and was shooting missiles and drones into Ukraine‚Äôs cities ‚Äúfor no reason whatsoever.‚Äù

Trump who has largely focused on trade and other benefits to Russia if it ended its war against Ukraine, also wrote that Putin‚Äôs continued incursion could have dire consequences.

Speaking to reporters on Sunday, President Trump sounded an optimistic note on negotiations about the future of Iran‚Äôs nuclear program, which last took place on Friday in Rome and would resume ‚Äúvery soon,‚Äù he said.

Washington is demanding that Iran halt all uranium enrichment and dismantle all of its centrifuges.

President Trump on Sunday condemned the decision by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to unleash one of the largest offensives in Russia‚Äôs war against Ukraine, and said he was considering imposing more sanctions on Russia in response.

Mr. Trump said he was ‚Äúnot happy‚Äù with Mr. Putin escalating his attacks.

He added, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in the middle of talking, and he‚Äôs shooting rockets into Kyiv and other cities.‚Äù

Mr. Trump continued criticizing Mr. Putin hours later, writing on social media that his Russian counterpart ‚Äúhas gone absolutely CRAZY‚Äù and was shooting missiles and drones into Ukraine‚Äôs cities, ‚Äúfor no reason whatsoever.‚Äù

Mr. Trump, who has largely focused on trade and other benefits to Russia if it ended its war against Ukraine, also wrote that Mr. Putin‚Äôs continued incursion could have dire consequences.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs remarks came after Russia carried out one of its largest drone and missile barrages of the war on Ukraine overnight, killing at least 12 people and injuring dozens across the country.

Asked whether he was considering levying additional sanctions against Russia, which he has threatened several times, Mr. Trump responded: ‚ÄúAbsolutely, he‚Äôs killing a lot of people."

Mr. Trump, who has largely sided with Russia in the war, said he was ‚Äúsurprised‚Äù by the escalation, continuing to downplay the fact that it was Russia that initiated the war with an unprovoked invasion.

But Mr. Trump also had harsh words for President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.

Mr. Trump said that Mr. Zelensky was ‚Äúdoing his country no favors by talking the way he does.‚Äù

President Trump sharply criticized President Vladmir V. Putin over Russia‚Äôs bombardment of Ukraine.

Trump also said he was ‚Äúabsolutely‚Äù considering more sanctions against Russia, something he‚Äôs threatened before but not gone through with as he sought to get Putin to agree to a cease-fire.

President Trump said that he is extending the deadline to impose 50 percent tariffs on the European Union to July 9, from June 1, following a request from Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission.

Von der Leyen said in a separate post that Europe is ready to advance trade talks ‚Äúswiftly and decisively.‚Äù

Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, said on social media that she had a phone call with President Trump and that Europe was ready to advance trade negotiations ‚Äúswiftly and decisively‚Äù but would need until July 9 to reach a deal.

The European Commission is the executive arm of the 27-nation European Union.

President Trump has expressed outright hostility to civil rights protections.

But in recent weeks, Mr. Trump has turned to those same measures ‚Äî not to help groups that have historically been discriminated against, but to remedy what he sees as the disenfranchisement of white men.

The White House has defended its actions as part of an effort to put merit ahead of diversity.

On Monday, the administration said it had opened a civil rights investigation into the city of Chicago to see if its mayor or others had engaged in a pattern of discrimination by hiring a number of Black people to senior positions.

The Office for Civil Rights at the Education Department is investigating whether Chicago‚Äôs public school system is violating the Civil Rights Act with its ‚ÄúBlack Students Success Plan,‚Äù alleging that it favors one group of academically underperforming students over others.

Last month, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission launched an investigation at Harvard University, alleging that the school had engaged in discriminatory hiring because it showed a significant increase in the percentage of minority, female and nonbinary faculty earning tenure over the past decade while the rates for white men declined.

In a letter sent to the university on April 25, the acting chairwoman of the E.E.O.C., Andrea R. Lucas, said she had started the investigation based on the university‚Äôs expressed desire for ‚Äúdemographic diversification of the faculty.‚Äù

title: Aranceles: ¬øhay que cambiar
content: ¬øPodr√≠amos pensar medidas fiscales y monetarias agresivas para impulsar oportunidades, para Colombia? | Opini√≥n | Portafolio.co ...
resumen:
La pol√≠tica arancelaria de Donald Trump representa un desaf√≠o para la econom√≠a global. El FMI ha reducido sus proyecciones de crecimiento global para este a√±o y 2026 debido a la incertidumbre y la disputa entre las dos econom√≠as m√°s grandes del mundo.

Algunos creen que el contexto actual generar√° oportunidades para algunos pa√≠ses. Se menciona que las pol√≠ticas de EE.UU. podr√≠an impulsar a Europa, como lo demuestra el anuncio de Alemania de crear un fondo de infraestructura, defensa y tecnolog√≠a por 500.000 millones de euros. China ha anunciado medidas fiscales y monetarias agresivas para impulsar la actividad.

Se plantea la pregunta de si Colombia podr√≠a hacer lo mismo. Se sugiere aprovechar la posici√≥n geogr√°fica estrat√©gica de Colombia y diversificar su comercio internacional, que actualmente est√° muy expuesto a EE.UU.

Se argumenta que la guerra comercial dejar√° exhaustos a muchos gobiernos, lo que podr√≠a llevar a pa√≠ses europeos y asi√°ticos a buscar nuevos socios o fortalecer sus relaciones con ciertos pa√≠ses. Se destaca que pa√≠ses como Brasil, Chile y Per√∫ tienen a China como su principal socio comercial, pero tambi√©n est√°n estrechando lazos con pa√≠ses de r√°pido crecimiento como India, Indonesia o Vietnam.

Se concluye que ser√° necesaria una articulaci√≥n entre el sector privado y el gobierno, lo que implicar√° que los empresarios deban cambiar su enfoque y el gobierno deber√° implementar pol√≠ticas de Estado a largo plazo. Se menciona que adherirse a la Ruta de la Seda podr√≠a traer oportunidades.

Daniel Velandia, Managing Director y Economista Jefe de Research de Credicorp Capital, es el autor del art√≠culo.

title: Una visi√≥n pol√≠tica y econ√≥mica para el 2025
content: La semana pasada Desarrollo en Democracia (Dende) present√≥ su an√°lisis sobre las perspectivas pol√≠ticas y econ√≥micas para este a√±o 2025, teniendo como tel√≥n de fondo las graves tensiones geopol√≠ticas ...
resumen: La semana pasada Desarrollo en Democracia (Dende) present√≥ su an√°lisis sobre las perspectivas pol√≠ticas y econ√≥micas para este a√±o 2025, teniendo como tel√≥n de fondo las graves tensiones geopol√≠ticas que sacuden al mundo. El epicentro de estas tensiones se encuentra en las pol√≠ticas de Trump que, por medio de la fijaci√≥n de aranceles de importaci√≥n a los productos fabricados fuera de los Estados Unidos, busca la reindustrializaci√≥n de su pa√≠s. Esta pol√≠tica es un palo en la rueda al comercio internacional que, seg√∫n el Banco Mundial, ha sido el motor del crecimiento econ√≥mico, la generaci√≥n de empleo y la reducci√≥n de la pobreza, en las √∫ltimas d√©cadas. Durante el periodo de la ‚Äúhiperglobalizaci√≥n‚Äù desde el a√±o 1990 hasta el 2008 el comercio global creci√≥ a tasas promedio del 6,6% y el PIB mundial al 4%. Hoy este crecimiento se ha debilitado y el FMI proyecta para este a√±o un crecimiento global de apenas el 2,8%. Para dimensionar el impacto que tendr√° este escenario en la econom√≠a paraguaya, tenemos que saber que de las exportaciones mundiales solamente el 10% son productos agr√≠colas y el 15% son combustibles y minerales; mientras que el 75% son productos industriales (la mitad productos terminados y la otra mitad componentes industriales). A este segmento industrial es adonde apuntan todos los ca√±ones de Trump y por eso, a pesar de la turbulencia, los precios de las materias primas contin√∫an estables y‚Ä¶ eso es lo que el Paraguay exporta. Los shocks de Trump no est√°n afect√°ndonos por ahora, pero van a afectarnos directa o indirectamente en el mediano plazo. Ante esta incertidumbre global, el Paraguay debe priorizar m√°s que nunca sus relaciones con los pa√≠ses de la regi√≥n, espec√≠ficamente con el Mercosur y muy especialmente con el Brasil. Nuestro desarrollo industrial es muy dependiente de nuestra integraci√≥n a las cadenas productivas del Brasil y por eso nos preocupan las tensas relaciones diplom√°ticas que hoy tenemos con nuestro vecino. Hemos retirado a nuestro embajador en Brasilia a ra√≠z del espionaje que ha tomado estado p√∫blico, hemos recibido un fuerte golpe del Brasil con su rechazo a la candidatura de Rub√©n Ram√≠rez a la OEA y lo m√°s grave es que la negociaci√≥n del nuevo Anexo C de Itaip√∫, que era una prioridad en el 2023, hoy se encuentra empantanada y sin visos de soluci√≥n. En el frente interno a pesar del enorme ruido pol√≠tico y del prematuro electoralismo, la econom√≠a paraguaya cerrar√° el a√±o con un buen crecimiento, que ser√° del 3,5% seg√∫n el Banco Mundial, del 4% seg√∫n el BCP y del 3,6% seg√∫n Dende. Sin embargo, en este buen escenario aparece en el horizonte una luz roja que es el d√©ficit de la Caja Fiscal, que crece mucho m√°s r√°pido que lo proyectado, que pone en peligro el cumplimiento de las metas de d√©ficits definidas por el MEF y que dificultar√° la obtenci√≥n del Grado de Inversi√≥n, por parte de una segunda empresa calificadora. Resumiendo, el mundo se encuentra en guerra militar y econ√≥mica entre las grandes potencias y consecuentemente el crecimiento mundial ser√° m√°s lento en los pr√≥ximos a√±os. Nosotros para seguir creciendo tenemos que centrarnos en el vecindario, especialmente en el mercado brasile√±o, con quien hoy no tenemos las mejores relaciones diplom√°ticas. Tambi√©n para seguir creciendo tenemos que hacer nuestros deberes internos, cumpliendo este gobierno su promesa de ‚Äúrealizar todas las reformas pendientes‚Äù. Lo hizo creando la DNIT y el MEF y ya estamos recogiendo los frutos, pero las reformas m√°s importantes y pol√≠ticamente m√°s dif√≠ciles, como las de la seguridad social, la salud y la educaci√≥n, se encuentran pendientes. Nos hemos demorado en la realizaci√≥n de las reformas y hoy ya estamos sumergidos en un electoralismo desenfrenado, que har√° muy dif√≠cil llevarlas adelante. Esta es nuestra visi√≥n pol√≠tica y econ√≥mica para este a√±o 2025.

title: Breaking News Live Updates: Trump says he will delay EU tariffs until July 9
content: US President Donald Trump said Sunday that he would pause his threatened 50 percent tariffs on the European Union until July 9, after a "very nice call" with EU chief Ursula von der Leyen.
resumen: US President Donald Trump said Sunday that he would pause his threatened 50 percent tariffs on the European Union until July 9, after a "very nice call" with EU chief Ursula von der Leyen. Trump had threatened on Friday to invoke the steep tariffs as soon as June 1, saying talks with the European Union over his previous levies were "going nowhere." Von der Leyen "just called me... and she asked for an extension on the June 1st date, and she said she wants to get down to serious negotiation," Trump told reporters before boarding Air Force One in Morristown, New Jersey. Von der Leyen had earlier said on X that she held a "good call" with Trump, but that "to reach a good deal, we would need the time until July 9." Brussels and Washington have been negotiating in a bid to avert an all-out transatlantic trade war, and had agreed to suspend tariff action on both sides until July.

title: Indice aprobaci√≥n de Trump se sit√∫a en el 47%, seg√∫n encuesta
content: WASHINGTON.- El √≠ndice de aprobaci√≥n del presidente Donald Trump se sit√∫a en el 47% (un punto menos que abril de 2025), seg√∫n una encuesta de Harvard CAPS/Harris de mayo. El estudio determin√≥ que Trum ...
resumen:
El √≠ndice de aprobaci√≥n del presidente Donald Trump se sit√∫a en el 47%, seg√∫n una encuesta de Harvard CAPS/Harris de mayo.

El estudio determin√≥ que Trump cuenta con la aprobaci√≥n del 87% de los votantes republicanos y la desaprobaci√≥n del 83% de los dem√≥cratas y el 50% de los independientes.

La aprobaci√≥n es mayor entre los hombres que entre las mujeres, con una brecha de g√©nero de 17 puntos, y entre los votantes blancos, rurales de 25 a 64 a√±os.

Trump recibi√≥ la mayor aprobaci√≥n en inmigraci√≥n (51%), retorno de Estados Unidos a sus valores (51%), gesti√≥n de la inflaci√≥n (43%) y aranceles, pol√≠tica comercial (42%).

El 42% de los votantes dice que Estados Unidos va por buen camino (3 puntos m√°s que en abril de 2024).

El 34% de los votantes afirma que su situaci√≥n financiera personal est√° mejorando, el 39% dice que su situaci√≥n est√° empeorando, el porcentaje m√°s bajo desde octubre de 2021.

Entre los miembros del gabinete de Trump, los votantes tienen una opini√≥n m√°s favorable de Robert F. Kennedy Jr. (+9 favorable neto), Marco Rubio (+4) y Tulsi Gabbard (+4), y una opini√≥n m√°s desfavorable de Elon Musk (-8) y Pete Hegseth (-4). Los votantes est√°n divididos entre Trump y el vicepresidente J.D. Vance.

El 40% de los votantes dijo que la inflaci√≥n es el tema m√°s importante.

Los votantes siguen apoyando las pol√≠ticas de inmigraci√≥n y eficiencia gubernamental de Trump, pero se oponen a los l√≠mites a Medicaid y a los aranceles a China, M√©xico y Canad√°. Asimismo, el 70% apoya aumentar la tasa m√°xima de impuesto a la renta.

El 84% apoya la reducci√≥n de los precios de los medicamentos recetados para los beneficiarios de Medicare y los pacientes de bajos ingresos.

El 59% de los votantes considera a Trump responsable del estado de la econom√≠a actual.

Los votantes est√°n divididos sobre si Trump est√° haciendo buenos o malos acuerdos arancelarios en nombre del pa√≠s, pero el 60% cree que llegar√° a un acuerdo comercial con China.

resumen:

title: Trump delaying 50% tariff on European Union
content: The president said Sunday he‚Äôs agreed to delay a 50% tariff on the EU that he threatened last week, after saying negotiations with the commission were ‚Äúgoing nowhere.‚Äù ...
resumen: President Donald Trump has announced a delay on proposed tariffs on the European Union until July 9, 2025. This decision followed a request from European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. Speaking to reporters in Morristown, New Jersey, President Trump says that he had agreed to the extension as a privilege and noted that rapid trade talks would commence. The U.S. will delay implementation of a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union. The tariffs were set to begin June 1, but are delayed to July 9 now for negotiations. The president of the European Commission said she was ready to "advance talks" after Trump had said the 27-member bloc had been "very difficult to deal with." Trump‚Äôs European Union tariffs delayed. The 50% tariff on EU goods would have kicked in starting June 1, but Trump said his agreement to an extension sets the new date at July 9, 2025. If implemented, a 50% tariff would be higher than the 30% tariff on China. Trump posted on Truth Social Sunday evening, saying it was his "privilege" to have agreed to an extension, and said that von der Leyen said their talks will begin rapidly. US President Donald Trump speaks to journalists before boarding Air Force One from Morristown Municipal Airport in Morristown, New Jersey, May 25, 2025. Von der Leyen posted earlier on X that she had a "good call" with Trump. The EU and US share the world‚Äôs most consequential and close trade relationship. Europe is ready to advance talks swiftly and decisively. To reach a good deal, we would need the time until July 9. Last week, Trump said on social media that trade talks with the European Union nations were "going nowhere" and called for a 50% tariff to go into effect June 1. He said the 27-member bloc had been "very difficult to deal with." The EU has proposed mutually cutting tariffs to zero even as the president has publicly insisted on preserving a baseline 10% tax on most imports. Trump‚Äôs tariffs currently in place: 30% tariffs on China for a 90-day period, down from 145%. As high as 25% tariffs on Mexico and Canada. Universal baseline tariff of 10% on most countries. Trump is working trade deals with various countries in coming weeks. Trump has also placed various import taxes on autos, steel and aluminum and plans to do so on pharmaceutical drugs, among other products.

title: The weekender: out of the deficit frying pan, back into the tariff fire
content: Ending Tariff Carousel. The tariff carousel just cranked back into overdrive, and markets‚Äîlulled into a false sense of calm‚Äîsnapped back to attention. President Trum ...
resumen: The tariff carousel cranked back into overdrive, and markets snapped back to attention. President Trump threatened a 50% tariff on European Union imports and signaled that iPhones assembled outside U.S. borders could face punitive levies. Apple got the first slap, sliding over 2%. U.S. and European equities sold off, though not in panic mode. Treasuries reversed earlier weakness, with 10-year yields sinking back to 4.51% and 30-year yields retreating below 5.04%. Gold surged over 2%, while haven currencies‚Äîyen and Swiss franc‚Äîsqueezed higher, even the euro rallied. After a week dominated by fears over the U.S. fiscal trajectory‚Äîcourtesy of a CBO-scored $500 billion annual deficit injection for the next four years‚Äîthe market barely had time to digest the long-term damage before Trump reignited the trade war. The clearest signal wasn‚Äôt even in yields‚Äîit was in the sell America unison: stocks tanked, the dollar sagged, and safe havens went rogue as risk smouldered with intent. Finance chiefs from the world‚Äôs most powerful economies issued a joint statement so sanitized it could have been written in advance by AI. EU officials reportedly pushed hard for stronger language but ran into the same American wall that now seems to prefer tariffs as diplomacy by other means. Trump wasn‚Äôt looking for a deal, he said, and signaled further escalation if Europe didn‚Äôt play ball. Apple was just the beginning. Samsung, other handset makers, and likely pharma firms are all potentially in the crosshairs. The U.S. is constructing a tariff scaffold around its own economy‚Äîand the world is watching whether it‚Äôs scaffolding for renovation or a gallows for the dollar‚Äôs credibility. The U.S. is heading back to the tariff well while piling on trillions in new deficits‚Äîwithout the growth bang to offset the fiscal buck. Germany is now ramping up fiscal support that‚Äôs set to bite in 2026. Eurozone balance of payments data shows massive repatriation of foreign equities back into euro assets‚Äînearly ‚Ç¨40 billion in March alone. The euro, increasingly, is the only viable liquid alternative to a dollar that looks overvalued, overleveraged, and overexposed to political risk. In Asia, the yen is regaining relevance as rising inflation and hawkish signals from the BoJ put a July rate hike firmly on the table. Japanese core CPI just hit its fastest pace in two years. The markets‚Äô behaviour on Friday showed a fragile equilibrium. Markets are navigating blindfolded through a minefield where the next detonation could come from tariffs, deficits, central bank missteps, or geopolitical drift. The U.S. appears determined to go it alone, walling itself off with trade barriers, while the rest of the world tentatively sketches out new alignments. The fear isn‚Äôt just inflation or rates or trade‚Äîit‚Äôs irrelevance. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index is down another 0.8% on Friday and more than 7% on the year. CFTC data show hedge funds are still stacked net-short. Trump‚Äôs threat to slap a 50% levy on EU imports has traders re-pricing everything from recession odds to risk premia. The result? A broad G10 stampede higher. Kiwi and Aussie dollars vaulted over 1%; Canada‚Äôs loonie clawed back to seven-month highs. Traditional safe havens like the yen and Swiss franc flexed as capital tiptoed out of U.S. assets. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent hinted at ‚Äúbig‚Äù trade deals in the pipeline. Senate wrangling over a tax-and-spend bill could stuff hundreds of billions more into the deficit while bumping the debt ceiling right up against a late-summer deadline. Gold prices are hovering around $3,356 as of May 23. Consensus forecasts now peg gold climbing to $3,700 per troy ounce by the end of 2025. Since March, gold holdings have surged. Central banks are building long-term positions. Developed economies have 70% or more of their reserves in gold. Emerging market central banks are still underweight. China has less than 10% of its reserves in gold.

title: Harris warns US of risks with investigation of pharma, semiconductor sectors
content: T√°naiste Simon Harris has written to US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick to warn against US investigations into the pharmaceutical and semiconductor sectors.
resumen:
T√°naiste Simon Harris has warned the US administration of the negative consequences of imposing tariffs on imported pharmaceuticals and microchips.

Mr. Harris wrote to US Secretary for Commerce Howard Lutnick following the latter's instigation of two investigations examining whether the US' reliance on foreign imports in those sectors poses a risk to national security.

The outcome of the investigations could result in significant tariffs being imposed on pharmaceutical and semiconductors sold into the US from abroad.

In his letter to Mr. Lutnick earlier this month, Mr. Harris said Ireland and the US enjoys a "mutually advantageous economic bilateral relationship".

He acknowledged US foreign direct investment in Ireland is concentrated in a number of sectors, including pharma and semiconductors.

Mr. Harris stressed Ireland's approach on national security is "closely aligned" with Washington's, as he signalled a "desire to work closely with the US on economic security issues".

On pharma, he highlighted the focus of production is primarily on ingredients, rather than final products.

On microchips, he said Ireland has built an "extensive and technology-rich semiconductor industry".

Mr. Harris said Ireland's "highly-skilled, flexible workforce", and its "long-standing political and economic stability" attract US companies.

Approximately 60% of Irish pharmaceutical exports go to non-US markets, said Mr. Harris.

The supply chains between Ireland and the US have been built up over decades and "supported by the existing zero-for-zero tariff arrangement".

Mr. Harris said that another key factor of the relationship between the two countries was "our close regulatory cooperation", with a long-track record of pharmaceutical companies in Ireland securing recognition from the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

He said he was of the "strong view" that the Irish pharmaceutical sector "supports the health of the American people, and to impose tariffs on this sector risks not only the strides that need to be made in future innovation but also threatens the resilient supply chains needed to provide products to the US that have developed over recent decades".

In conclusion, Mr. Harris wrote: "I appreciate that you are undertaking these investigations due to national security concerns. Ireland's trade with the US helps support resilient supply chains and diversifications, and providing certainty of supply. Increasing costs on two strategic sectors that face growing competition from other regions will not aid in supporting US interests."

Minister of State for European Affairs Thomas Byrne has warned that if President Donald Trump follows through on his threat to impose a 50% tariff on EU goods, it would "effectively stop trade" between the two blocs.

Minister of State John Cummins said a US-EU trade war is not inevitable.

Social Democrats TD Rory Hearne said the task of concluding a trade agreement with the US was "extremely difficult" given what he termed the "completely erratic" behaviour of President Trump.

title: Trump‚Äôs tariffs cast $1.25 billion shadow over Victoria‚Äôs budget
content: A major economic downturn fuelled by US President Donald Trump‚Äôs trade wars could deliver a $1.25 billion hit to Victoria‚Äôs budget in one year, alternative government modelling shows.
resumen:
A major economic downturn fueled by US President Donald Trump‚Äôs trade wars could deliver a $1.25 billion hit to Victoria‚Äôs budget in one year, alternative government modelling shows.

State Treasury is forecasting a rebound in household spending and real wage growth this financial year, but last week‚Äôs budget papers also detail the significant risks to the economy associated with tariffs imposed by Trump.

The United States is Victoria‚Äôs second-biggest global customer for goods, narrowly behind China, making up 17 per cent of exports in this category last year.

Out of about $6 billion in exports to the US in 2024, pharmaceuticals and beef were the two biggest categories by value of goods shipped.

Victoria‚Äôs real gross product is forecast to grow by 2.5 per cent in 2025-26, but this figure could have been higher if the budget wasn‚Äôt expecting net trade to detract from the result.

In the 2023-24 financial year, Victoria imported $123.9 billion in goods and exported $37.6 billion, according to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

In sensitivity analysis in the recent budget papers, Treasury modelled alternative scenarios that could throw out the budget‚Äôs forecasts.

The analysis shows that if local spending does not grow as expected, and international growth stalls by as much as 1 per cent, Victoria would suffer a $1.25 billion loss to its revenue.

The government considers this scenario less likely than the economic conditions forecast in the budget papers, but the analysis highlights potential impacts of the 2025 US trade wars on Victoria.

The budget papers say: ‚ÄúRisks to the Victorian outlook from global conditions have increased amid a highly uncertain global backdrop.‚Äù

The US has imposed a 10 per cent baseline tariff on most imported goods. Most Australian products are subject to this tariff, with some limited exceptions and a higher charge on steel and aluminium.

In Treasury‚Äôs modelling of a worst-case scenario, global demand for exports would be 1 per cent lower than forecast coupled with sharp falls in confidence that weigh down investment and consumer spending.

If this occurred, the government is forecast to lose $1.25 billion from its bottom line in 2025-26, endangering Victoria‚Äôs expected $600 million operating surplus, the first since before the pandemic.

Another $564 million could be lost over the forward estimates, with most of the damage to the budget happening in the first two years.

By comparison, last year‚Äôs budget papers modelled a domestic slowdown and forecast a $600 million hit to the budget over four years.

In a more positive scenario modelled by Treasury, a higher-than-expected recovery in household spending in 2025-26 would add an extra $975 million to government income that year, adding up to $1.9 billion in extra revenue across the forward estimates.

Treasurer Jaclyn Symes said the government was looking at the impact of tariffs on pharmaceuticals and beef, but a lack of confidence across other countries would have the biggest impact on the economy.

The government is spending $35 million on programs to boost exports and support businesses with international trade. Another $18.1 million will maintain the state‚Äôs global network of trade and investment offices. A further $627 million is put towards delivering the Economic Growth Statement, a policy document released in late 2024.

Paul Zalai, director of the Freight & Trade Alliance and secretariat of the Australian Peak Shippers Association, said it was impossible to predict the full impact of US tariffs.

Hamish McFarlane, director of Te Mania Angus in south-west Victoria, said Victoria needed to maintain a relationship with the US because of America‚Äôs high demand for secondary cuts.

Victorian Farmers Federation president Brett Hosking agreed weather conditions were the biggest concern for farmers, but US tariffs had also caused anxiety.

The unemployment rate is forecast to rise to 4.75 per cent in the next financial year.

title: Aranceles de Donald Trump: las empresas que subir√°n los precios de sus productos debido a la medida
content: En un intento por proteger la industria nacional, las pol√≠ticas arancelarias de Trump han generado un efecto b√∫meran.
resumen:
Desde que Donald Trump asumi√≥ su segundo mandato, la pol√≠tica arancelaria se convirti√≥ en una pieza central de su estrategia comercial. El presidente impuso una serie de aranceles generalizados que han terminado por encarecer el costo de vida. Un arancel base del 10% para la mayor√≠a de importaciones y un 30% sobre productos chinos son solo el inicio de un complejo rompecabezas econ√≥mico que est√° afectando el bolsillo de millones de estadounidenses.

Empresas de todos los tama√±os y rubros han advertido que no est√°n dispuestas a absorber los costos adicionales, desmintiendo as√≠ la idea de que los aranceles castigan √∫nicamente a los pa√≠ses exportadores. En realidad, quien paga el precio m√°s alto es el consumidor final.

**Empresas que subir√°n los precios de sus productos debido a los aranceles:**

1.  **Walmart:** Su director ejecutivo Douglas McMillon dej√≥ en claro que, aunque intentar√°n mantener los precios bajos, no podr√°n resistir la presi√≥n que generan estos nuevos aranceles. Se estima que el alza de precios ser√° a√∫n m√°s notoria a partir de junio, afectando principalmente productos fabricados en China.
2.  **Mattel:** Su CEO Ynon Kreiz fue tajante: hasta un 50% de sus productos seguir√°n costando 20 d√≥lares o menos, pero no todos lograr√°n mantenerse en ese rango. Trump incluso amenaz√≥ con imponer aranceles del 100% sobre sus productos.
3.  **Best Buy:** La marca advirti√≥ que los ‚Äúproveedores de toda nuestra gama trasladar√°n parte de los costos de los aranceles a los minoristas, lo que hace muy probable que haya un aumento de precios para los consumidores estadounidenses‚Äù.
4.  **Shein y Temu:** Temu anunci√≥ un ajuste de precios a partir del 25 de abril de 2025. Por ejemplo, dos sillas de jard√≠n listadas en Temu ten√≠an un precio de 61 d√≥lares en abril, y hoy se pueden encontrar por 70 d√≥lares.
5.  **Ford y Subaru:** Ford ya anunci√≥ incrementos de hasta 1,5% en sus precios para la segunda mitad de 2025. Subaru tom√≥ una ruta similar, argumentando que los ajustes son necesarios para compensar los mayores costos.
6.  **Procter & Gamble, Stanley Black & Decker:** Procter & Gamble anticip√≥ aumentos ‚Äúprobables‚Äù en algunas categor√≠as. Stanley Black & Decker ya subi√≥ sus precios y anunci√≥ una segunda ronda de aumentos para m√°s adelante este a√±o.
7.  **Adidas:** Adidas anticipa precios m√°s altos debido a la volatilidad arancelaria.
