title: Can you get a stimulus check in 2025? Here's Trump stimulus check status update
content: Are we getting a stimulus check in 2025? Here's a status update on Trump stimulus checks and how to track your IRS checks by social security number ...
resumen: During the COVID-19 pandemic, the government approved three economic impact payments, or stimulus checks, in March 2020, December 2020, and March 2021. The opportunities to file or claim these stimulus checks have now passed. If you didn't get the full amount of the third stimulus check, you were eligible to receive the $1,400 Recovery Rebate Credit of 2021. The deadline to file for this last payment was April 15, 2025. Even if you received a tax extension, you still needed to file your 2021 tax return by the April 15, 2025 deadline to claim that last payment. There are no extensions or appeals available for missed deadlines, and any unclaimed stimulus payments become the property of the U.S. Treasury. While there have been rumors about a fourth stimulus check of $2,000, there has been no official confirmation from Congress or the IRS to support this claim. President Donald Trump said in February that he would consider a plan to pay out $5,000 stimulus checks to taxpayers in the form of a ‚ÄúDOGE dividend,‚Äù he has not shared any further specifics or details about the possible ‚ÄúDOGE stimulus‚Äù since then. Any form of stimulus payment has to be approved by Congress. That number was also based on the original DOGE goal of $2 trillion, which has since been revised to $150 billion. At a rally in Wisconsin in March, Elon Musk said that the checks may not come. New York is issuing checks between $150 to $400 to some households. California and Colorado are also sending checks to some taxpayers, according to Nasdaq. If you filed your federal taxes electronically and included your banking information, then you may expect a direct deposit within 21 days. If you did not include banking information, then you may expect a paper check refund via the mail within 6-8 weeks. Amended returns can take four weeks or more, and, if your return needs corrections or extra review, it could take even longer. You will know it is accepted once you see a "Refund Sent" alert when you check your tax return status online. Once the IRS approves your refund, it could hit your bank account within days via the direct deposit option. The IRS has an online tool called "Where's My Refund" that allows you to check on the status of your refund. You can start checking the status of your refund within 24 hours after you e-filed your current-year return. The refund information is updated on the IRS website once a day, overnight. The online tool requires you to enter your Social Security number, filing status and exact refund amount on the return. It will then respond with a return received (processing), refund approved (preparing to issue refund by date shown) or refund sent (sent to your bank or in the mail). The other way to check on the status is to call the IRS at 800-829-1954. If your taxes were electronically filed and accepted by April 15, it is estimated that you may expect a direct deposit federal refund from the IRS by May 6 or later if by mail. Most states have created dedicated online portals for tracking income tax returns. In most cases, you can check the status of your state refund by providing the tax year, your SSN or ITIN, and refund amount.

title: Hang Seng Index: Gains on PBoC Rate Cut and Easing Trade Tensions ‚Äì Weekly Recap
content: Hang Seng extends gains amid PBoC rate cuts, easing US-China tensions, and tech earnings misses. Trade, debt, and policy risks stay in focus.
resumen:
China‚Äôs April retail sales slowdown led the PBoC to cut rates, lifting Hong Kong stock demand.
The Hang Seng Index posted its sixth consecutive weekly gain, supported by auto stocks but capped by tech losses.
Japan‚Äôs inflation rise and stronger Yen dragged the Nikkei 225 lower.
US markets fell in the week ending May 23 as renewed trade tensions and US debt worries triggered a flight to safety.
US President Trump recommended a 50% tariff on EU goods.
The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 2.47%, while the Dow and the S&P 500 dropped 2.47% and 2.61%, respectively.
10-year US Treasury yields soared to a high of 4.627% before settling at 4.509%.
Moody‚Äôs downgraded the US sovereign credit rating from Aaa to Aa1.
Economic data from China raised concerns about China‚Äôs economic momentum on May 19.
Retail sales growth slowed sharply in April.
The People‚Äôs Bank of China (PBoC) cut the 1-year and 5-year loan prime rates (LPR) by 10 basis points to 3% and 3.5%, respectively.
Easing US-China trade tensions also bolstered demand for Hong Kong-listed stocks.
CN Wire reported a meeting between China‚Äôs Vice Premier He Lifeng and JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon.
Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Ma Zhaoxu held a call with US Deputy Secretary Kurt Campbell on May 22.
The Hang Seng Index advanced 1.10% in the week ending May 23, marking its sixth consecutive weekly gain.
BYD Company Ltd. (01211) surged 7.14%, while Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd. (00175) gained 2.84%.
Alibaba (09988) sliding 3.73%.
The CSI 300 slipped 0.18%, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.57%.
Gold rallied 4.84%, closing the week at $3,356.66.
WTI crude oil fell 0.53% to settle at $61.375.
Iron Ore spot declined 1.44%.
The ASX 200 advanced 0.21% in the week.
The S&P/ASX All Technology Index climbed 1%.
Northern Star Resources soared 9.82%.
Commonwealth Bank of Australia rose 2.46%, while National Australia Bank advanced 1.86%.
The Nikkei 225 Index lost 1.1%.
Underlying inflation accelerated from 3.2% in March to 3.5% in April, while inflation ex-food and energy rose from 2.9% to 3%.
USD/JPY down 2.11% at 142.551 for the week.
Nissan Motor Corp. (7201) fell 0.81%, while Softbank Group (9984) and Tokyo Electron (8035) slid 3.43% and 3.03%, respectively.
Trump‚Äôs proposed EU tariffs will influence global sentiment.
Australia‚Äôs CPI and retail sales will impact RBA policy expectations and Aussie-listed stocks.

US GDP, inflation, and consumer confidence data will steer Fed rate cut bets and regional market trends, including the Hang Seng Index.

title: What is behind Donald Trump's 50% tariff on EU imports to the US?
content: What is behind the US president Donald Trump's 50% tariff on EU imports to the US? RT√â's Washington correspondent Sean Whelan looks at the latest developments on both sides of the Atlantic as well as ...
resumen: Donald Trump announced a 50% tariff on EU imports to the US, which caused a reaction in financial markets. The policy shift came unexpectedly, with the tariff starting on June 1st. Trump stated that there would be no tariff if the EU built plants in the US. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the 50% suggestion was to speed up negotiations and force the EU to make a "high quality offer." Bessent also mentioned that the EU proposals have not been of the same quality as other trading partners. The US has accused the EU of not negotiating in good faith. The EU's approach is not to escalate tensions, engage in megaphone diplomacy, or try to remove emotion from the equation. The general EU tariff rate of 20% has been raised by Mr. Trump to 50%. Euro zone government bond yields fell sharply following Donald Trump's announcement. Trump said the EU has not treated the US properly and that they banded together to take advantage of the US. He also mentioned a $17 billion lawsuit from Apple. The US president also announced a 25% Tariff on Apple iphones, unless they are made in the USA. The EU needs to help the US find ground which they can easily take and then declare victory, before a real and deeply damaging trade war begins. The US is looking for fundamental change, and it is most unlikely - certainly not within the very tight negotiating deadlines the president has set. The two sides cannot even agree on the extent of the trade surplus the EU runs with the US. The EU side includes the trade in services, where the US has a big surplus that reduces the trade gap to about $150 billion in the EU‚Äôs favour. The Americans say the gap is more like $250 billion. The EU needs a more dynamic financial services sector. The EU has a whole book of detailed analysis and recommendations on the topic, one commissioned by the EU‚Äôs political leaders, the heads of state and government, called the Draghi report - after its author, former ECB President and former Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi.

title: Duro golpe de Trump: C√°mara baja aprueba impuesto del 3,5% a las remesas de inmigrantes indocumentados en EEUU
content: El tributo a las remesas, que aplicar√≠a para los inmigrantes en EE. UU., afectar√≠a a millones de hogares en Am√©rica Latina, particularmente en pa√≠ses como Honduras y El Salvador.
resumen:
La C√°mara de Representantes de EE. UU. aprob√≥ el ‚ÄúOne Big Beautiful Bill Act‚Äù, que incluye un impuesto del 3,5% sobre remesas de inmigrantes indocumentados.
La votaci√≥n fue de 215 a 214.
El proyecto abarca casi 900 p√°ginas e incluye recortes fiscales, restricciones sociales, medidas de seguridad fronteriza.
La propuesta original contemplaba un gravamen del 5%, pero este fue reducido tras negociaciones.
La medida no aplicar√≠a para estadounidenses, pues se enfoca en inmigrantes sin ciudadan√≠a ni residencia permanente.
De ser aprobada en el Senado, esta medida marcar√≠a la primera vez en la historia reciente de EE. UU. que se impone un impuesto a las remesas.
Expertos advierten que el impuesto podr√≠a tener efectos significativos en varios pa√≠ses centroamericanos, donde las remesas representan entre una cuarta y una tercera parte del Producto Interno Bruto (PBI).
El nuevo tributo se aplicar√≠a a todos los migrantes que no cuenten con una "green card", incluidos quienes poseen visas temporales como las H-2B, F-1 o L-1.
En la pr√°ctica, esto significar√≠a un cargo adicional de US$35 por cada US$1.000 enviados al extranjero.
La implementaci√≥n del impuesto quedar√≠a a cargo del Servicio de Impuestos Internos (IRS), que tendr√° un plazo de 90 d√≠as tras la promulgaci√≥n para definir c√≥mo se comprobar√° el estatus migratorio en las transferencias.
En 2024, los inmigrantes enviaron m√°s de US$160.000 millones desde Estados Unidos a Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe, seg√∫n el Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo.
Otras medidas impulsadas por Donald Trump en el paquete de leyes incluye que los inmigrantes pierdan los siguientes beneficios:
Cr√©dito Tributario por Hijos (CTH): actualmente, ni√±os ciudadanos pueden recibir hasta US$2.000 al a√±o.
Subsidios de Obamacare: los subsidios para seguros de salud bajo la Ley de Atenci√≥n M√©dica Asequible dejar√≠an de estar disponibles para muchos inmigrantes legales.
Cr√©ditos educativos: el Cr√©dito Tributario de Oportunidad Estadounidense de hasta US$2.500 y el Cr√©dito de Aprendizaje Permanente de US$2.000 no ser√≠an v√°lidos si no poseen un n√∫mero de Seguro Social v√°lido.
Exenciones en la deuda de pr√©stamos estudiantiles: la deuda perdonada por discapacidad o fallecimiento no se considera ingreso tributable, pero esta exenci√≥n quedar√≠a restringida.
Restricciones a beneficios por ITIN: los inmigrantes que presentan impuestos con ITIN no podr√≠an reclamar estos cr√©ditos.

title: Trump threatens Apple with 25% tariff: Is now a good time to buy an iPhone?
content: In addition to promising a 50% tariff on the European Union, unless E.U. leaders come to an agreement with the Trump administration within approximately nine days, the president threatened Apple with ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened Apple with 25% tariffs on any iPhone sold, and not made, in the U.S.

Trump posted on Truth Social, his social-media platform, on Friday: "I have long ago informed Tim Cook of Apple (AAPL) that I expect their iPhone's [sic] that will be sold in the United States of America will be manufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else."

Ming-Chi Kuo, TF International Securities analyst, said the costs would likely make such a move prohibitive.

A 25% tariff would mean hundreds of additional dollars on an iPhone price tag.

Prices for the iPhone product line start at $799 and go as high as $1,599 for the iPhone 16 Pro Max.

The iPhone 16 is powered by an "A18 Bionic" chip, integrates artificial intelligence into its camera control and has 85% recycled content.

Alex Kidman, who writes Alex Reviews Tech, said the iPhone 16's 60Hz screen at this price is "indefensible," and cited "inconsistent battery life and overly hot Qi2 charging.".

Some 36% of iPhone buyers in the 12 months ending December 2024 reported having their previous phone for two years or less, compared with 31% in the prior year.

The household savings rate in the U.S. fell to 3.9% in March from 4.1% in February. It averaged 8.4% from 1959 until 2025, reaching an all-time high of 32% in April 2020 and a record low of 1% in July 2005, according to Trading Economics.

Andrzej Skiba, head of U.S. fixed income at RBC Global Asset Management, said the environment surrounding Trump's trade approach may also ensure that borrowing costs remain elevated. "The Fed," he said, "won't likely be able to cut rates in this environment."

title: Trump y sus amenazas de aranceles, tema en semana de EEUU
content: Washington, 24 may.- La amenaza del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles a los productos de la Uni√≥n Europea (UE) y al gigante Apple, destac√≥ en la agenda medi√°tica de ...
resumen:
La amenaza del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles a los productos de la Uni√≥n Europea (UE) y al gigante Apple, destac√≥ en la agenda medi√°tica de la semana que finaliza.

Trump reactiv√≥ su guerra comercial tras sugerir que podr√≠a aplicar grav√°menes del 50 por ciento a la UE, por la falta de progreso en los acuerdos comerciales, y del 25 por ciento para Apple si la producci√≥n de tel√©fonos m√≥viles iPhone no se traslada a territorio estadounidense.

Trump afirm√≥: ‚Äú¬°Nuestras conversaciones con ellos (la UE) no nos est√°n llevando a ninguna parte!‚Äù. Por lo tanto, recomend√≥ un arancel directo del 50 por ciento a la Uni√≥n Europea, a partir del 1 de junio de 2025.

Los tres principales √≠ndices burs√°tiles europeos se precipitaron despu√©s de los comentarios de Trump, pues el DAX de Alemania y el CAC de Francia descendieron un 2,6 por ciento y un 2,8 por ciento, respectivamente. El FTSE de Londres baj√≥ un 1,3 por ciento, mientras los futuros de las acciones de Estados Unidos tambi√©n se desplomaron, en este caso los relacionados con el Dow Jones que cayeron m√°s de 600 puntos (1,7 por ciento).

La actual propuesta de Trump significa que podr√≠a establecer una tarifa a la UE m√°s del doble del arancel ‚Äúrec√≠proco‚Äù inicial del 20 por ciento que estuvo vigente en abril de forma ef√≠mera, antes de que dispusiera una pausa para las negociaciones, que expirar√° el 9 de julio.

Sobre los tel√©fonos apunt√≥: ‚ÄúHace tiempo que inform√© a Tim Cook, de Apple, que espero que sus iPhone que se venden en Estados Unidos se fabriquen y construyan en Estados Unidos, no en India ni en ning√∫n otro lugar‚Äù. ‚ÄúSi ese no es el caso, un arancel de al menos el 25 por ciento debe ser pagado por Apple a Estados Unidos‚Äù.

Otro tema de la semana fue la licencia administrativa que dio el Gobierno de Trump a m√°s de un centenar de funcionarios del Consejo de Seguridad Nacional (NSC, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) de la Casa Blanca. La medida es parte de una reestructuraci√≥n dispuesta por el asesor interino de Seguridad Nacional y secretario de Estado, Marco Rubio.

title: El Despacho Oval, el nuevo suplicio para los l√≠deres mundiales
content: Danny KEMP Para los l√≠deres mundiales ser invitados al Despacho Oval sol√≠a ser un gran honor, pero con Donald Trump el famoso recinto de la Casa Blanca se ...
resumen:
Para los l√≠deres mundiales ser invitados al Despacho Oval sol√≠a ser un gran honor, pero con Donald Trump el famoso recinto de la Casa Blanca se ha convertido en escenario de brutales emboscadas pol√≠ticas.

El presidente sudafricano Cyril Ramaphosa es la v√≠ctima m√°s reciente de una larga lista que inici√≥ con el notorio enfrentamiento de Trump con el presidente ucraniano Volod√≠mir Zelenski, en febrero.

Con el republicano, el Sal√≥n Oval ha pasado de ser premio diplom√°tico durante el gobierno de su predecesor, Joe Biden, a ser una encerrona pol√≠tica donde por horas se ponen a prueba los nervios de l√≠deres mundiales. Y todo televisado en vivo.

El presidente sudafricano Cyril Ramaphosa se re√∫ne con Donald Trump el mi√©rcoles en medio de las tensiones por el reasentamiento en Washington de afrik√°ners blancos que, seg√∫n el presidente estadounidense, son v√≠ctimas de ¬´genocidio¬ª.

El presidente estadounidense har√° de anfitri√≥n encantador, mostrar√° la lujosa decoraci√≥n chapada en oro que orgullosamente ha instalado en la Oficina Oval, desafiar√° a su invitado con aranceles, asuntos comerciales o de ayuda militar, o simplemente va a destrozarlo.

Cuando las c√°maras acceden al prestigioso sal√≥n de la Casa Blanca, pueden verse envueltos en la m√°s peligrosa cuerda floja pol√≠tica de sus carreras.

El calor y el confinamiento del espacio del Despacho Oval se suman al ambiente de olla a presi√≥n donde el impredecible Trump busca los pasos en falso de sus invitados para tener la ventaja.

El republicano dej√≥ una muestra muy clara cuando recibi√≥ a Zelenski el 28 de febrero. Las fuertes tensiones por el repentino giro de Trump hacia Rusia salieron a la luz cuando con la cara roja el presidente estadounidense reprend√≠a al l√≠der ucraniano, al que trat√≥ de desagradecido por la ayuda militar que ha recibido su pa√≠s.

El vicepresidente JD Vance pareci√≥ intervenir para desencadenar la disputa al decirle ¬´irrespetuoso¬ª al ucraniano.

La visita de Ramaphosa al Despacho Oval el mi√©rcoles estuvo demasiado cerca de repetir la escena.

Ramaphosa acudi√≥ al encuentro con dos famosos golfistas sudafricanos, Ernie Els y Retief Goosen, con la esperanza de suavizar las afirmaciones infundadas de Trump, un fan√°tico del golf, sobre un ¬´genocidio¬ª contra agricultores blancos en su pa√≠s.

Trump de repente orden√≥ a sus asistentes: ¬´Apaguen las luces¬ª.

En video proyect√≥ a pol√≠ticos sudafricanos de extrema izquierda entonando ¬´matemos al agricultor¬ª, un c√°ntico de la √©poca del Apartheid durante la lucha contra la minor√≠a blanca.

A diferencia de Zelenski quien respondi√≥ a un cada vez m√°s iracundo Trump, el presidente sudafricano estuvo bastante calmado mientras discut√≠a el caso. Tampoco le pidieron que abandonara la Casa Blanca, como s√≠ ocurri√≥ con Zelenski.

El primer ministro canadiense Mark Carney, pese a algunos signos de nerviosismo mantuvo su gallard√≠a al afirmar que su pa√≠s ¬´nunca estar√° en venta¬ª ante las m√∫ltiples declaraciones de Trump sobre hacer de Canad√° el estado n√∫mero 51 de Estados Unidos.

El primer ministro brit√°nico, Keir Starmer, convenci√≥ a Trump con una carta del propio rey Carlos III, mientras que el presidente franc√©s, Emmanuel Macron, mantuvo su ¬´bromance¬ª con muestras p√∫blicas de afecto y elogios rec√≠procos con su par estadounidense.

El presidente de El Salvador, Nayib Bukele, recibi√≥ grandes muestras de afecto en la Oficina Oval luego de acordar la detenci√≥n de migrantes en una megaprisi√≥n del pa√≠s centroamericano.

El primer ministro de Israel, Benjam√≠n Netanyahu, fue recibido de forma calurosa como el primer invitado extranjero en el segundo mandato del republicano, pero la historia fue muy diferente cuando regres√≥ en abril.

Las c√°maras en el Despacho Oval captaron su cara de sorpresa cuando Trump anunci√≥ que Washington estaba en el inicio de negociaciones directas con Ir√°n.

Trump brome√≥ al final de la reuni√≥n con Zelenski al decir que ¬´va a ser televisi√≥n genial¬ª, y uno de sus asesores sigui√≥ en esa l√≠nea tras la reuni√≥n con Ramaphosa.

title: Trump‚Äôs E.U. Tariff Threat Could Cause Economic Damage Beyond Europe
content: A 50 percent tax on European imports would hit the continent hard, hurt the U.S. economy and slow growth globally.
resumen:
President Trump threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on all goods coming into the United States from the European Union starting next weekend.

Agathe Demarais, a senior policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations, stated that no one was expecting this and they don‚Äôt have a clue as to what it means.

Carsten Brzeski, chief eurozone economist at ING, warned that such tariff levels could lead to a combination of higher inflation and slower growth in the United States, potentially pushing Europe into a recession and causing global growth to fall.

Julian Hinz, a trade researcher at the Kiel Institute for the World Economy, calculated that U.S. economic growth would drop 1.5 percent.

The magnitude of this latest tariff is significantly higher than the 20 percent ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariff that Mr. Trump announced for the European Union in April and later paused.

Neil Shearing, chief economist at Capital Economics, said the scale of the increase in tariffs, the capricious manner in which they were threatened, and the growing size of U.S. budget deficits are unsettling financial markets.

Mary E. Lovely, an emeritus professor of economics at Syracuse University, said companies are already raising their assessments of the riskiness of investments in the United States.

Mr. Trump imposed high global tariffs and then quickly postponed them when the bond market shuddered. He threatened China with exorbitant tariffs of 145 percent. When China hit back with a 125 percent tariff on U.S. goods, Mr. Trump took a step back. Two weeks ago, the two governments issued joint statements that they would suspend the highest tariffs for 90 days and negotiate.

Maurice Obstfeld, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics and a former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, said that the Europeans have absorbed the message that if you hit back hard, markets will get nervous, and the president will back off.

European officials have prepared a raft of countermeasures in response to higher U.S. tariffs. Roughly a fifth of E.U. exports go the United States, and about the same share of American exports go to to the European Union.

The European Union has threated to put tariffs on the American services sector.

If Mr. Trump does end up imposing 50 percent tariffs on June 1, Ireland would be hit the hardest, with an estimated 4 percent decline in total economic output, according to Capital Economics. Germany‚Äôs gross domestic product is projected to shrink by around 1.5 percent, Italy‚Äôs by 1.2 percent, France by 0.75 percent and Spain by 0.50 percent.

Mark Blyth, a political economist at Brown University, said the policy swings coming out of the White House may simply depend on which adviser was the last to speak to the president.

In 2008, both the U.S. and Europe had the same size economies, but now, Europe‚Äôs economy is one-third smaller.

title: Trump carga ahora contra las empresas americanas: amenaza a Amazon, Apple y Walmart
content: Las grandes empresas de Estados Unidos, como Amazon, Apple, Mattel y Walmart, se han convertido en una de las dianas del presidente americano.
resumen:
Las grandes empresas de Estados Unidos, como Amazon, Apple, Mattel y Walmart, se han convertido en una de las dianas del presidente americano.

El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunci√≥ que aplicar√° un arancel del 50% a todos los productos importados desde la Uni√≥n Europea.

Trump amenaz√≥ a Apple de imponerles un arancel del 25% si la empresa estadounidense no traslada toda su producci√≥n a Estados Unidos.

Trump us√≥ la misma red social para lanzar un mensaje similar a Walmart, donde pr√°cticamente amenazaba a la multinacional si a esta se le ocurr√≠a aumentar los precios de sus productos como consecuencia de los aranceles aplicados a China.

Trump dijo: "Walmart deber√≠a DEJAR de culpar a los aranceles como la raz√≥n del aumento de precios en toda la cadena".

El director ejecutivo de Walmart, Doug McMillon, dijo que los aranceles impuestos por Trump eran "demasiado altos" y que "aranceles m√°s altos redundar√°n en precios m√°s altos".

El primer ataque se produjo el 29 de abril a la gigante multinacional Amazon.

La secretaria de prensa de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, calific√≥ la medida como un "acto hostil y pol√≠tico".

Trump llam√≥ a Jeff Bezos, el due√±o de Amazon, para quejarse de todo esto.

Trump amenaz√≥ con un arancel del 100% a Mattel, el fabricante de las mu√±ecas Barbie o de los coches de juguete Hot Wheels.

Trump dijo: "Le aplicaremos un arancel del 100% a sus juguetes, y no vender√° ni un solo juguete en Estados Unidos, que es su mayor mercado".

title: Pivoting From Tax Cuts to Tariffs, Trump Ignores Economic Warning Signs
content: Since taking office, Mr. Trump has raced to enact his economic vision, aiming to pair generous tax cuts with sweeping deregulation that he says will expand America‚Äôs economy. He has fashioned his ...
resumen:
President Trump has ignored repeated warnings that his agenda could worsen the debt, harm the poor and contribute far less growth than the White House contends.

One day after House Republicans approved an expensive package of tax cuts, President Trump pivoted back to his other signature policy priority, unveiling a battery of tariff threats that further spooked investors and raised the prospects of higher prices on American consumers.

The decision to escalate his global trade war on Friday appeared curious and costly. It capped off a week that saw Mr. Trump ignore repeated warnings that his agenda could worsen the nation‚Äôs debt, harm many of his own voters, hurt the finances of low-income families and contribute far less in growth than the White House contends.

The president threatened 50 percent tariffs on the European Union, and a 25 percent tariff on Apple. Other tech companies, he said, could face the same rate.

Mr. Trump has raced to enact his economic vision, aiming to pair generous tax cuts with sweeping deregulation that he says will expand America‚Äôs economy. He has fashioned his steep, worldwide tariffs as a political cudgel that will raise money, encourage more domestic manufacturing and improve U.S. trade relationships.

So far, bond markets are not buying his approach. Where Mr. Trump sees a ‚Äúgolden age" of growth, investors see an agenda that comes with more debt, higher borrowing costs, inflation and an economic slowdown. Investors who once viewed government debt as a relatively risk-free investment are now demanding that the United States pay much more to those who lend America money.

Businesses, including Walmart, say they may have to raise prices as a result of the president‚Äôs global trade war.

The onslaught of policy changes has also left the Federal Reserve frozen in place, unsure as to when the economy will call for lower interest rates in the face of persistent uncertainty. As a result, borrowing costs for mortgages, car loans and credit cards remain onerous for Americans.

The White House released data showing that its tax cuts could increase U.S. output as much as 5.2 percent in the short term, compared with the gains it would have achieved if the bill is not adopted. The administration has stood largely alone in offering such rosy predictions about the effects of Mr. Trump‚Äôs policies on businesses, average workers and the nation‚Äôs fiscal future.

Economists this week predicted that Mr. Trump‚Äôs signature tax package could add well over $3 trillion to the national debt. Some found that the measure is unlikely to deliver substantial economic growth, and could enrich the wealthiest Americans while harming the poorest, millions of whom could soon lose access to federal aid for food and health insurance.

The tax cuts are largely an extension of ones that Congress passed in 2017, meaning that few taxpayers will see an increase to their after-tax income. Many of the lowest earners may even see about $1,300 less on average under the Republican bill in 2030, according to the nonpartisan Penn Wharton Budget Model, which factored in the proposed cuts to federal safety-net programs.

Stephen Miran, the chairman of the president‚Äôs Council of Economic Advisers, said in an interview, stressing that Mr. Trump‚Äôs agenda would ‚Äúgrow the economy.‚Äù

Eric Winograd, an economist at the investment firm AllianceBernstein, said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs possible that you‚Äôre going to get a big benefit to growth, but the costs are so obvious and so clear that I think it‚Äôs hard to put a lot of faith in that at the moment.‚Äù

While economists do not expect the economy to tip fully into a recession, they say Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs in particular have raised the odds of a downturn, as both businesses and consumers begin to cut back.

Stephen Moore, a conservative economist who served as one of Mr. Trump‚Äôs advisers during his first term, said: ‚ÄúSo many of these problems are the result of low growth.‚Äù Mr. Trump is aiming to get growth back up to 3 percent, Mr. Moore added.

The House Republicans voted to advance a bill that would extend the set of tax cuts enacted in the president‚Äôs first term. The measure also included Mr. Trump‚Äôs campaign promises to eliminate taxes on tips and overtime pay.

An analysis released Thursday by the Joint Committee on Taxation, a nonpartisan advisory arm of Congress, found that the new Republican measure may raise the average rate of growth in U.S. output by only 0.03 percentage points compared with current expectations through 2034. The joint committee also said the president‚Äôs tax package could add $3.7 trillion to the nation‚Äôs debt over the next decade.

Mr. Miran maintained on Friday that congressional analysts and others had underestimated the effects of Mr. Trump‚Äôs initial tax cuts, and had done the same this year.

Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, said on Fox News on Thursday that there was ‚Äúa lot of spending reduction in this bill,‚Äù adding that the Trump administration would seek additional savings as the bill moved through the Senate.

Moody‚Äôs Ratings downgraded the U.S. credit rating, citing Republican tax cuts and the proclivity of past G.O.P. administrations to spend.

Mr. Trump sent markets into another tailspin on Friday as he abruptly shifted his attention to tariffs. He attacked the European Union and threatened to raise tariffs on its exports to a flat rate of 50 percent. He signaled a mixed appetite for negotiations, telling reporters in the Oval Office: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. We‚Äôre going to see what happens.‚Äù

The president also took aim at Apple, signaling he would impose a 25 percent import tax on iPhones. Mr. Trump later suggested his new tariffs might also apply to Samsung.

The S&P 500 fell nearly a percentage point on Friday and pushed the U.S. dollar lower against a basket of its peers.

Some companies, including Walmart, have said they may have to raise prices as a result of the president‚Äôs global trade war.

A report this week from Allianz found that many businesses are trying to push the added tariff costs onto suppliers or consumers, with roughly half of its survey respondents saying they may increase prices.

Austan Goolsbee, the president of the Chicago Fed and a voting member on this year‚Äôs rate-setting committee, told CNBC on Friday: ‚ÄúThe bar for me is a little higher for action in any direction while we‚Äôre waiting to get some clarity.‚Äù

resumen:
Los aranceles impuestos por el gobierno del presidente Trump, especialmente con M√©xico y Canad√°, podr√≠an obstaculizar la soluci√≥n a la crisis en Hait√≠, un tema que la Organizaci√≥n de Estados Americanos (OEA) podr√≠a incluir en su agenda.

El canciller norteamericano Marco Rubio, con miras a las elecciones de 2028, est√° enfocado en resolver la crisis haitiana, donde las bandas criminales afectan al pa√≠s y a su r√©gimen provisional.

Las dificultades entre Estados Unidos y M√©xico por los aranceles y la frontera com√∫n, influyen en el desinter√©s del gobierno de Trump hacia Hait√≠.

Se han levantado opiniones sobre la necesidad de regularizar la fuerza de trabajo haitiana y renovar los permisos laborales para evitar el encarecimiento de construcciones y productos agr√≠colas, ya que los obreros dominicanos no desean esos trabajos.

El capit√°n de empresas Frank Rainieri se√±al√≥ que los trabajadores haitianos realizan trabajos que los dominicanos no quieren, como construcci√≥n, servicios dom√©sticos y motoconcho, por lo que rechazar su presencia sin soluciones viables es insuficiente.

title: Trump‚Äôs wild tariff tactics risk giving everyone a bad case of burnout
content: Trump threatened a 50% duty on goods coming out of the European Union and a 25% tariff on Apple, sending markets reeling.
resumen: On Friday, Trump threatened a 50% duty on goods coming out of the European Union and a 25% tariff on Apple, sending markets reeling. The prez threatened a 50% duty on goods coming out of the European Union to begin next month, raging that trade discussions ‚Äúare going nowhere,‚Äù and that the EU ‚Äúwas formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE.‚Äù Trump warned Apple that failing to move its manufacturing back home would prompt a tariff of ‚Äúat least 25%.‚Äù In response, the Dow dropped 256 points in a volatile day. Luxury automaker Volvo warned that prices on cars are going to spike. 57% say that tariffs are hurting the economy; 26% think they‚Äôre the biggest mistake of Trump‚Äôs second term.

title: Europe‚Äôs Been Negotiating by the Book, but Trump‚Äôs Tearing It Up
content: The Trump administration sees tariff talks as a chance to pressure a rival into concessions. E.U. officials have acted as though they were dealing with an ally.
resumen:
President Trump announced in a Truth Social post on Friday morning that he is recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1, claiming that the bloc‚Äôs trade barriers, taxes, corporate penalties and other policies had contributed to a trade imbalance with the United States that was ‚Äútotally unacceptable.‚Äù

Mr. Trump wrote, ‚ÄúThe European Union, which was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE, has been very difficult to deal with,‚Äù adding, ‚ÄúOur discussions with them are going nowhere!‚Äù

The surprise announcement comes after months of back-and-forth talks between the two enormous economies.

Mr. Trump has imposed round after round of tariffs on the 27-nation economic bloc and the world since taking office in January.

In talks, the bloc‚Äôs policymakers have suggested what they have billed as win-win solutions, including a plan to drop tariffs on industrial products to zero and buying more American gas.

American negotiators have been looking for one-way offers, diplomats, officials and people familiar with the negotiations have said, and White House officials themselves have implied this is not a give and take.

Scott Bessent, the U.S. Treasury secretary, said on Fox News on Friday, ‚ÄúI believe the president believes that the E.U. proposals have not been of the same quality that we‚Äôve seen from our other important trading partners.‚Äù

Mr. Trump wants European nations to nix their Value-Added Tax system, a key consumption tax ‚Äî which negotiators say is not on the table.

Administration officials have suggested that they want Europe to change food sanitation standards so that it imports more American beef.

Administration officials have also come after Europe for its regulation of digital services and social media companies ‚Äî also policies that European officials have been unwilling to reconsider.

Europe‚Äôs trading relationship with the United States is the largest in the world, by some measures. Nearly $5 billion in goods and services cross the Atlantic between the two partners every single day, by E.U. estimates.

The goods trade deficit was about $180 billion in 2023.

Maros Sefcovic, the E.U. trade commissioner, and his colleagues have traveled repeatedly to Washington to talk with Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, and Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative.

Mr. Sefcovic talked to his counterparts in the United States on Friday after Mr. Trump‚Äôs threat, and posted on social media afterward that ‚ÄúEU-US trade is unmatched & must be guided by mutual respect, not threats. We stand ready to defend our interests.‚Äù

The second set of countertariffs ‚Äî which would target 95 billion euros-worth of American goods that could range from bourbon to soybeans ‚Äî is still being refined.

‚ÄúThere are some countries that are impossible, like the European Union,‚Äù Mr. Lutnick said at an Axios event earlier this week.

The European Union currently faces 10 percent across-the-board tariffs on its exports, like other nations. After the 90-day pause expires in July, the bloc was expecting to face 20 percent tariffs, based on what the United States had previously announced.

‚ÄúThe president will decide if they‚Äôve made us an offer worthy of modifying their tariff terms,‚Äù Mr. Lutnick said earlier this week. ‚ÄúIf they haven‚Äôt made us an offer that modifies it, the president will write them a letter saying, ‚ÄòDear country A, we deeply appreciate doing business with you. Here‚Äôs your tariff rate.‚Äô‚Äù

And, he said, ‚Äúthere will be no floor below 10.‚Äù

content: La posesi√≥n de Daniel Noboa se destac√≥ por la presencia de figuras del corre√≠smo, entre ellas Marcela Holgu√≠n.

Marcela Holgu√≠n y Fausto Jarr√≠n, figuras con v√≠nculos con el corre√≠smo, asistieron al evento. La presencia de Marcela Holgu√≠n, quien inici√≥ su carrera pol√≠tica en 2017 en la Revoluci√≥n Ciudadana (RC) y fue una voz prominente del movimiento liderado por Rafael Correa, gener√≥ atenci√≥n. Antes de su carrera legislativa, Holgu√≠n fue periodista en varios medios televisivos. En las horas previas a la posesi√≥n, Holgu√≠n fue designada gerente de los medios p√∫blicos, lo que gener√≥ pol√©mica. Fausto Jarr√≠n, abogado de Rafael Correa en el caso Sobornos, tambi√©n estuvo presente. Jarr√≠n fue asamble√≠sta entre 2021 y 2022. Otros excorre√≠stas como Ferdinand √Ålvarez y Soledad Padilla tambi√©n asistieron. La ceremonia concluy√≥ con el compromiso de Noboa de trabajar por un Ecuador unido y pr√≥spero.

title: Trade war's impact, key growth indicators: How global economy will shape up next week
content: US trade-policy fingerprints are expected to become more apparent as soon as next month, according to many economists ...
resumen:
The US trade-policy fingerprints are expected to become more apparent as soon as next month, according to many economists. US economic growth is expected to cool over the course of the year. The Federal Reserve will continue to suggest interest rates are on hold until they better understand the coming impact of US trade policy. The US personal consumption expenditures price index excluding food and energy is projected to have risen 0.1% in April.

In Canada, the economy appears likely to miss the Bank of Canada‚Äôs forecast of 1.8% annualized growth in the first quarter.

Key growth indicators from India and Taiwan as well as central bank decisions in South Korea and New Zealand will be released. Hong Kong‚Äôs April trade data is due on Monday. Sri Lanka publishes trade figures for April on Wednesday. Thailand and the Philippines release data on April exports and imports Friday. China on Tuesday is set to report industrial profits for April. India releases industrial production figures on Wednesday. South Korea and Japan report April industrial production on Friday. South Korea‚Äôs central bank is seen cutting rates on Thursday by a quarter point, to 2.5%. New Zealand‚Äôs monetary authorities are expected to lower the key policy rate by a quarter point to 3.25% on Wednesday. South Korea also releases April retail sales and May consumer confidence in the coming week. Japan reports a ream of data on the rest of the economy. India‚Äôs first-quarter GDP reading on Friday is forecast to have strengthened. Australia will get April readings on consumer price inflation and retail sales.

The European Central Bank is lining up for a further rate cut in June. President Christine Lagarde will speak on Monday. Inflation numbers are scheduled in all four of its top economies, starting with France on Tuesday. The other three are scheduled for Friday, with results at 1.9% anticipated in Italy and 2% in both Spain and Germany. Bank of England chief economist Huw Pill will speak on Wednesday, and Deputy Governor Sarah Breeden and Governor Andrew Bailey on Thursday. Switzerland will release export numbers for April on Tuesday. Sweden‚Äôs economic tendency survey comes the same day, while the Riksbank will release its financial stability report on Wednesday. Swedish GDP numbers are due on Friday. Turkey‚Äôs economic growth remained muted in the first quarter.

Brazil‚Äôs mid-month consumer price report posted Tuesday is the second-to-last inflation reading before the central bank‚Äôs June meeting. In Mexico, the central bank‚Äôs quarterly inflation report is keenly awaited. Banxico will also publish the minutes of its May 15 meeting. Brazil, Chile, Colombia and Mexico will report April labor market figures. Brazil on Friday posts first-quarter output data. The Getulio Vargas Foundation‚Äôs GDP Monitor estimated Brazil‚Äôs January-March quarter-on-quarter expansion was 1.6%.

title: Daniel Noboa fue investido para su segundo mandato en Ecuador, en ausencia del corre√≠smo que grita ‚Äúfraude‚Äù
content: El presidente anunci√≥ que profundizar√° su ‚Äúguerra‚Äù contra el crimen organizado, la apertura comercial y las inversiones extranjeras. La izquierda brill√≥ por su ausencia.

**Situaci√≥n conyugal en Uruguay:**

title: Daniel Noboa se posiciona como el presidente con mayor aceptaci√≥n en Sudam√©rica, seg√∫n la Consultora CB
content: Daniel Noboa lidera el ranking de presidentes sudamericanos con mayor aceptaci√≥n, seg√∫n la √∫ltima encuesta de la Consultora CB.
resumen: Daniel Noboa se posiciona como el presidente con mayor aceptaci√≥n en Sudam√©rica, seg√∫n la Consultora CB. La imagen positiva de Daniel Noboa alcanza el 52,1%, ubic√°ndolo como el presidente mejor valorado de Sudam√©rica, seg√∫n la reciente encuesta de la Consultora CB. Daniel Noboa, lidera el ranking de presidentes con con mayor aceptaci√≥n en Sudam√©rica, seg√∫n informaci√≥n reciente revelada por la Consultora CB, de Argentina. La reciente encuesta indica que Daniel Noboa encabeza el ranking con un 52,1% de imagen positiva, superando a sus pares de la regi√≥n. Javier Milei, presidente de Argentina, ocupa el segundo puesto con un 49% de imagen positiva. Yamand√∫ Orsi cae al tercer lugar con un 48,8%. Lula da Silva, de Brasil, desciende al cuarto puesto con un 47,4% de aprobaci√≥n. Su aprobaci√≥n creci√≥ 2,2 puntos. El 27,3% de los encuestados considera su gesti√≥n como ‚Äúmuy buena‚Äù y un 24,8% la califica de ‚Äúbuena‚Äù. La imagen negativa de Noboa se sit√∫a en el 45,7%, mientras que solo un 2,2% no sabe o no contesta. Javier Milei registra el mayor crecimiento en imagen positiva, con un aumento de 2,7 puntos respecto a abril. Dina Boluarte, de Per√∫, experimenta la mayor ca√≠da, perdiendo 5,1 puntos y quedando √∫ltima con apenas 19,8% de aprobaci√≥n. Yamand√∫ Orsi desciende al tercer puesto tras una baja de m√°s de dos puntos porcentuales. En Uruguay, la valoraci√≥n de Orsi se distribuye entre un 25,5% de imagen ‚Äúmuy buena‚Äù y un 23,3% ‚Äúbuena‚Äù, pero la suma de opiniones negativas alcanza el 47,2%.

title: Cuando el menudo mata a la papeleta
content: En la filosof√≠a popular se usa con frecuencia el refr√°n ‚Äúpapeleta mat√≥ a menudo‚Äù, una manera de expresar como queda minimizado el dinero en monedas cuando entran en juego las denominaciones en papel.
resumen:
En la filosof√≠a popular se usa con frecuencia el refr√°n ‚Äúpapeleta mat√≥ a menudo‚Äù, una manera de expresar como queda minimizado el dinero en monedas cuando entran en juego las denominaciones en papel.

Seg√∫n los n√∫meros como pa√≠s marchamos en un barco viento en popa y como los atletas m√°s exitosos, con n√∫meros r√©cords cada mes.

Un informe anual divulgado por la Red Mundial contra las Crisis Alimentarias, integrada por la Uni√≥n Europea, el Banco Mundial y agencias de la Organizaci√≥n de las Naciones Unidas (ONU), revel√≥ que 295,3 millones de personas sufrieron hambre aguda en 53 pa√≠ses durante el 2024.

La mayor parte de esa poblaci√≥n que padeci√≥ hambre extrema el a√±o pasado a escala planetaria est√° en Sud√°n y en la Franja de Gaza, pero tambi√©n, aunque con menor dramatismo, en Mal√≠ y en Hait√≠.

De las 295,3 millones de personas golpeadas por el hambre aguda en el mundo el a√±o pasado, 1,9 millones estaban al borde de la hambruna, algo nunca visto desde que se empez√≥ a elaborar este informe en 2016.

Las perspectivas para el presente a√±o no son muy alentadoras, a causa de los conflictos y la disminuci√≥n de la cooperaci√≥n internacional.

Rein Paulsen, director de la oficina de emergencias y de resiliencia en la Organizaci√≥n de las Naciones Unidas para la Alimentaci√≥n y la Agricultura (FAO).

La inseguridad alimentaria crece a pasos agigantados, situaci√≥n que podr√≠a ser m√°s dram√°tica por la guerra econ√≥mica que impulsa el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, con su pol√≠tica de imposici√≥n de aranceles.

Ya se ha anunciado incluso un arancel para las zonas francas, un importante sector de la econom√≠a dominicana, y no se puede descartar que la guerra arancelaria afecte tambi√©n en un momento a nuestro ‚Äúpujante‚Äù sector tur√≠stico.

Jennifer Contreras, la madre de las ni√±as Grismeily Ben√≠tez Contreras, de 13 a√±os, y Nathalia Ben√≠tez Contreras, de 11 a√±os, a quienes ella no puede suplir el tratamiento para enfrentar una rara enfermedad llamada epiderm√≥lisis, conocida popularmente como "Piel de cristal".

La Organizaci√≥n Mundial de la Salud (OMS), en la 78 Asamblea Mundial de la Salud, celebrada en Ginebra, Suiza, aprob√≥ una resoluci√≥n que declara a las enfermedades raras como "una prioridad mundial de salud p√∫blica".

La OMS anunci√≥ que elaborar√° un plan estrat√©gico global de diez a√±os para mejorar el diagn√≥stico, tratamiento, investigaci√≥n y atenci√≥n integral a m√°s de 300 millones de personas en el mundo que viven con estas patolog√≠as.

title: Two against Trump: how China is exploiting Russia in its great game against the USA
content: The Chinese leader has recently visited the Russian capital, where he behaved like the host and leader of a major power that is poised to challenge the United States‚Äô posture as global leader. Beijing ...
resumen: Beijing has assigned Russia the role of thorn in the flesh and troublemaker for Washington. Over decades of Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin leading their respective countries, a special ‚Äúchemistry‚Äù has developed in relations between them, and several informal protocol rules have emerged. The Chinese leader visits Moscow in odd-numbered years, while the Russian ruler travels to Beijing in even-numbered years. In 2022, Putin arrived in Beijing for the Winter Olympics opening ceremony on February 4, less than three weeks before his army invaded Ukraine. That visit was significant in that Beijing and Moscow signed a treaty on a strategic partnership ‚Äúwithout limits,‚Äù effectively creating an alliance of two countries united by a common desire to undermine Western leadership of the liberal international order and set up new rules of international coexistence. Xi‚Äôs regular visit to Russia in March 2023 was of exceptional importance for both countries, but primarily for Moscow. During that Moscow trip by the Chinese leader, key agreements were concluded behind closed doors, which became a lifeline for the Putin regime that effectively helped it stay afloat. Beijing had actually turned on the aid tap to the Russian defense-industrial sector as China launched massive supplies of industrial tooling machines suitable for production of weapons, along with chemical and other dual-capability products to defense industries in Russia. The Chinese authorities also permitted Russia to use the yuan in foreign trade settlements and significantly increase supplies of oil, gas and other resources as well Russian products to China. Xi's most recent visit to Moscow, his 11th since taking office as Chinese leader in 2013, was, like Putin's previous visit to Beijing in May last year, much less significant. It re-affirmed the "iron friendship" between the leaders of the two countries and can be seen as a tribute to informal protocol and an investment in Putin's upcoming trip to China in September. In Moscow, the Chinese leader received the highest honors. The official outcomes of the talks were likewise modest: the two major countries and strategic partners ‚Äúwithout limits‚Äù drew up 28 secondary documents for the meeting of their leaders, but not a single agreement on economic cooperation or investments was signed. Bilateral Sino-Russian trade has been breaking records since the war began. An intergovernmental agreement on the facilitation and mutual protection of investments appeared among the signed documents. According to statistics for Q1 2025, trade between the two countries fell down by approximately 7 percent year-on-year. Western economy analysts are saying that bilateral trade between China and Russia has already reached a plateau and may continue to grow modestly, or, most likely, will begin to decline. In bilateral trade, payment settlement between the PRC and sanctioned Russian financial institutions and companies remains a major problem. Another significant challenge facing the Russian Federation is increasing oil and natural gas exports to the PRC. When the administration of U.S. President Joe Biden imposed large-scale sanctions against Russian oil at the end of its term, 180 tankers of the Russian shadow fleet were blacklisted. The situation is more complicated with regard to increasing Russian gas exports to China, as this would require the construction of new gas pipelines. Moscow has suggested its ‚ÄúPower of Siberia 2‚Äù project with a yearly capacity of up to 50 million cubic meters of gas. Beijing is demanding that the Russians lay a pipe to the border with China at their own expense, and each cubic meter of gas should be priced at the level of internal prices for Russian consumers. The Chinese government is pursuing a green transition program aimed to abandon fossil fuels in favor of renewable energy generation. For the Ukrainians, the biggest threat comes from cooperation between Beijing and Moscow in the defense and defense industrial sectors, namely China‚Äôs purported intention to transfer to Russia weapons and missiles for use in its ‚Äúspecial military operation‚Äù in Ukraine. Defense Minister Andrei Belousov, Head of the Federal Service for Military-Technical Cooperation Dmitry Shugaev, and Deputy Prime Minister in charge of the Russian defense-industrial complex Denis Manturov were included in the Russian delegation to the talks. Some Western analysts suggest that in the presence of the heads of state, they agreed to increase imports from China of tooling machines and components to replace outdated equipment, as well as to outfit new enterprises of the Russian defense-industrial sector. The talks, perhaps, also covered the reciprocal export to China of Russian weapons and related engineering documentation and manuals. The reason for Xi‚Äôs presence alongside Putin on Mausoleum podium during the latest Victory Day parade was not at all to celebrate the 80th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany, but to signal to Trump that China is ready to respond to any attempts to pressure it, whether militarily or economically, or through tariffs. Moscow will not hesitate to support Beijing -- such an informally legalized alliance of two countries against one ‚Äì the United States of America. The statements made during Xi‚Äôs most recent visit to Moscow and the agreements reached, at least those that the parties have announced publicly, will not have a direct impact on the war Russia is waging against Ukraine. For Ukrainians, what is important in this whole story is what President Trump will do next, how he will react to the anti-American alliance between Beijing and Moscow after they have laid down an explicit challenge to the United States.

title: Tregua arancelaria de Trump alcanza su ecuador con pocos avances y m√°s amenazas a la UE
content: Donald Trump se mostr√≥ convencido de que esta nueva amenaza har√° que Europa "quiera lograr un acuerdo con todas sus fuerzas" ...
resumen:
La tregua arancelaria de 90 d√≠as declarada por el presidente Donald Trump alcanz√≥ este s√°bado su ecuador con escasos avances m√°s all√° de un acuerdo de m√≠nimos con Reino Unido y una necesaria tregua paralela con China, a lo que hay que sumar nuevas amenazas contra la Uni√≥n Europea (UE).

El viernes, pocos d√≠as despu√©s de que Washington y Bruselas acordaran intensificar las negociaciones t√©cnicas para llegar a un acuerdo, Trump volvi√≥ a endurecer su apuesta con la UE.

Con el argumento de que las conversaciones ‚Äúno est√°n yendo a ning√∫n lado‚Äù, afirm√≥ que activar√° grav√°menes del 50% sobre todos los bienes de la UE a partir del 1 de junio.

El mandatario se mostr√≥ convencido de que esta nueva amenaza har√° que Europa ‚Äúquiera lograr un acuerdo con todas sus fuerzas‚Äù y confi√≥ en que finalmente no le ser√° necesario imponer esos aranceles, porque ‚Äúlo que har√°n es enviar sus empresas a Estados Unidos y construir sus plantas‚Äù.

Horas despu√©s el comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic, dijo que la UE est√° dispuesta a defender sus intereses.

Tras mantener una conversaci√≥n telef√≥nica con el representante estadounidense de Comercio, Jamieson Greer, marcada por las nuevas advertencias de la Casa Blanca, el diplom√°tico eslovaco inst√≥ a su vez a que las relaciones comerciales bilaterales ‚Äúse gu√≠en por el respeto mutuo y no por las amenazas‚Äù.

Sefcovic recalc√≥ que la UE est√° ‚Äúplenamente‚Äù comprometida a alcanzar un acuerdo arancelario y est√° dispuesta ‚Äúa trabajar de buena fe‚Äù, pero muchos dudan de si nueve d√≠as ser√°n suficientes para pactar algo.

Lo acordado en la reuni√≥n de hace dos semanas en Suiza entre representantes estadounidenses y chinos es probablemente la mejor noticia que se ha producido en el tiempo transcurrido desde el pasado 9 de abril.

Fue esa la fecha en la que Trump, hostigado por las reacciones de los mercados y los rendimientos de la deuda estadounidense, decidi√≥ pausar su bater√≠a de lo que √©l describe como ‚Äúaranceles rec√≠procos‚Äù para todos sus socios comerciales.

Las dos principales econom√≠as del mundo, enfrascadas desde abril en un agresivo conflicto arancelario, lograron sentarse a la mesa y acordar una tregua paralela de 90 d√≠as que entr√≥ en vigor el 14 de mayo.

La tregua con Pek√≠n implica, entre otras cosas, que China reducir√° del 125% al 10% los aranceles sobre productos estadounidenses y que EE.UU. rebajar√° los suyos del 145% al 30%.

Establece adem√°s un mecanismo por el cual podr√°n celebrarse alternativamente nuevas reuniones en cualquiera de los dos pa√≠ses o incluso en un tercer estado, y tambi√©n consultas de trabajo sobre cuestiones t√©cnicas.

Washington solo ha logrado sellar un acuerdo: el anunciado con el Reino Unido el pasado 8 de mayo.

El pacto implica la entrada de una partida razonable de autom√≥viles brit√°nicos con un gravamen de solo el 10%, elimina impuestos aduaneros a los escasos vol√∫menes de acero y aluminio que el Reino Unido env√≠a a EE.UU y cancela tambi√©n los aranceles que Washington aplicaba a sus componentes de aviaci√≥n.

Todo a cambio de un futuro acuerdo de compra de aviones de Boeing por parte de British Airways y una mayor entrada de productos bovinos estadounidenses al Reino Unido.

Washington ha alcanzado este acuerdo con un aliado cercano con el que mantiene un super√°vit comercial.

Queda tambi√©n por saber si EE.UU. lograr√° alcanzar en estos 90 d√≠as acuerdos con econom√≠as asi√°ticas de peso y un m√∫sculo exportador destacado, como Jap√≥n, Corea del Sur o Indonesia.

Como China o la UE, esos pa√≠ses tienen grandes super√°vits con la primera potencia mundial y pueden verse seriamente perjudicados si Trump activa finalmente los aranceles que les adjudic√≥ inicialmente (de un 24%, 25% y 32%, respectivamente).

content: Recientemente, cayeron los precios de las acciones en la Bolsa de Valores de Nueva York despu√©s de que el presidente de Estados Unidos (EE. UU.), Donald Trump, amenazara con imponer aranceles del 50 ...
resumen: Los precios de las acciones en la Bolsa de Valores de Nueva York cayeron despu√©s de que el presidente de Estados Unidos (EE. UU.), Donald Trump, amenazara con imponer aranceles del 50 % a la Uni√≥n Europea (UE). El S&P 500 perdi√≥ 39,19 puntos, o 0,7 %, para quedar en cinco mil 802,82 y cerrar su peor semana de las √∫ltimas siete. El promedio industrial Dow Jones cay√≥ 256,02 puntos, o 0,6 %, y se ubic√≥ en 41 mil 603,07, mientras que el compuesto Nasdaq retrocedi√≥ 188,53 unidades, o 1 %, y cerr√≥ en 18 mil 737,21. Trump amenaz√≥ con los aranceles antes de que abriera el mercado de valores en Estados Unidos, y afirm√≥ en su plataforma Truth Social que las conversaciones comerciales con la Uni√≥n Europea ‚Äúno iban a ninguna parte‚Äù y que aranceles ‚Äúdirectos del 50 %¬ª podr√≠an entrar en vigor el 1 de junio. La UE es uno de los mayores socios comerciales de Estados Unidos. Las acciones cayeron inmediatamente despu√©s en Europa: el √≠ndice CAC 40 de Francia perdi√≥ 1,7 %. El mercado norteamericano tambi√©n dio un giro r√°pido a la baja, y los futuros de los √≠ndices burs√°tiles estadounidenses cayeron despu√©s de registrar solo movimientos modestos al inicio de las operaciones. Adem√°s, se concret√≥ la venta de bonos del Tesoro por un valor de 16 mil millones que registr√≥ una demanda deficiente. Ante esta ca√≠da del Wall Street, los bonos del Tesoro alcanzaron m√≠nimos de la sesi√≥n despu√©s de que la subasta de bonos a 20 a√±os en EE. UU. registrara un rendimiento superior al 5 %.

title: Mapfre recompone el negocio y adelanta en Bolsa al sector europeo
content: La acci√≥n se acerca al r√©cord con una ganancia acumulada del 40% en el a√±o. El 50% de los analistas recomienda comprar ...
resumen:
Mapfre se revaloriza un 40% en el a√±o, la m√°s alta de las aseguradoras europeas.
Desde julio de 2022 se ha revalorizado el 131% ‚Äìfrente al 70% del Stoxx Insurance‚Äì y avanza hacia el r√©cord de 2007.
En el primer trimestre de 2025, Mapfre gan√≥ un 27% m√°s.
La empresa anunci√≥ en la junta de accionistas una revisi√≥n al alza de la rentabilidad sobre fondos propios (ROE) para los dos pr√≥ximos a√±os hasta el 11% y 12%, y la ratio combinado lo situ√≥ entre el 94% y 95%.
Bestinver Securities apoya su decisi√≥n en ‚Äúla fuerte recuperaci√≥n de la ratio combinado de Iberia (pas√≥ del 99,7% de 2024 al 95,6% y supuso el 28,5% de las primas del primer trimestre), junto con los mensajes positivos sobre Estados Unidos y Brasil (8,7% y 15% de las primas).
El analista de Bestinver Securities, Javier Beldarrain, ha mejorado el resultado un 22% para 2025 y 2026 (1.162 y 1,230 millones de euros) y el 16% para 2027 (1.256 millones).
Beldarrain acaba de elevar un 25% el precio objetivo, hasta 3,9 euros, el 12% m√°s.
Divacons Alphavalue ha tomado la decisi√≥n de elevar las previsiones y la recomendaci√≥n a a√±adir.
Los expertos advierten que podr√≠a surgir cierta volatilidad en los beneficios debido a Mapfre Re.
Para Ignacio Albizuri, director de mercados de Miraltabank, el camino ascendente de Mapfre se est√° producido por un cambio de escenario.
Mapfre mantiene el apoyo de los analistas con el 50% de los consejos de compra y el 21,4% de mantener, aunque las de venta alcanzan el 28,6%.
Fitch ha dado apoyo a la compa√±√≠a al elevar la perspectiva del rating de estable a positiva.
El precio objetivo recogido por Bloomberg de 3,08 euros est√° por debajo de la cotizaci√≥n.
Bankinter tiene la recomendaci√≥n de comprar, por ‚Äúla atractiva rentabilidad por dividendo‚Äù (4,6%) y por los m√∫ltiplos de valoraci√≥n, con un PER 2025 de 8,7 veces, frente a las m√°s de 10 veces que presenta el sector en Europa.
El pr√≥ximo 29 de mayo pagar√° un dividendo de 0,095 euros.

title: Why Vietnam Ignored Its Own Laws to Fast-Track a Trump Family Golf Complex
content: As President Trump blurs the lines between politics and business ‚Äî and threatens steep tariffs on trade partners ‚Äî governments feel compelled to favor Trump-related projects.
resumen:
On Wednesday, a groundbreaking ceremony was held for a Trump golf project in Vietnam. Attendees included Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh, businessman Dang Thanh Tam, and Eric Trump and Lara Trump.

The $1.5 billion golf complex outside Hanoi, as well as plans for a Trump skyscraper in Ho Chi Minh City, are the Trump family‚Äôs first projects in Vietnam.

To fast-track the Trump development, Vietnam has ignored its own laws, granting concessions more generous than what even the most connected locals receive. Vietnamese officials explicitly stated that the project required special support from the top ranks of the Vietnamese government because it was ‚Äúreceiving special attention from the Trump administration and President Donald Trump personally.‚Äù

Eric Trump was in Vietnam to break ground for the golf project on Wednesday, less than a year after meeting a local building partner, Dang Thanh Tam. Inside a tent with a gold facade, Mr. Trump told guests, including the country‚Äôs prime minister, that ‚Äúthe Trump family is going to make you very, very proud.‚Äù

President Trump‚Äôs financial disclosure report shows that he still personally benefits financially from most of these ventures.

Vietnamese officials say that prioritizing Trump projects assists the country‚Äôs economic rise.

With trade negotiations intensifying, Vietnamese officials have allowed the Trump project to break ground without completing at least a half-dozen legally required steps, from securing all the land and financing to conducting environmental reviews.

Initial planning documents were filed only three months before Wednesday‚Äôs event, which was held on newly leveled land under an archway announcing ‚ÄúTHE GROUNDBREAKING CEREMONY OF TRUMP INTERNATIONAL, HUNG YEN.‚Äù

Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh instructed the provincial authorities to ensure that those who sacrificed property would ‚Äúhave a new livelihood and new home better than their old ones.‚Äù He also said the project would ‚Äúreceive maximum support‚Äù to ‚Äúfurther strengthen the relationship between Vietnam and the U.S.‚Äù He promised that it would be completed in 2027.

The first Trump project in Vietnam got its start with the efforts of two former Marine Corps platoon commanders: Billy Birdzell and David Lewis.

In January 2024, Birdzell texted ‚Äúa friend‚Äù who was interested in real estate in Vietnam, which was Eric Trump.

Mr. Lewis reached out to Mr. Tam, the founder of the industrial construction firm Kinh Bac City, who embraced the idea immediately.

In a promotional photo from that day, Eric Trump sits on one side, Mr. Tam on the other. The past and future president occupies the center, smiling in front of two American flags.

Vietnam‚Äôs government sees Mr. Trump‚Äôs administration and the Trump Organization as one.

The groundbreaking occurred just a few days after the Trump administration‚Äôs trade negotiator, Jamieson Greer, met with Vietnam‚Äôs trade minister, Nguyen Hong Dien, in South Korea.

title: EE.UU. considera que Daniel Noboa es "incorruptible", se√±ala el Gobierno ecuatoriano
content: Quito, 24 may (EFE).- Estados Unidos considera que Daniel Noboa, presidente de Ecuador, que este s√°bado jur√≥ su nuevo mandato hasta 2029, es "incorruptible", se√±al√≥ la Presidencia del pa√≠s andino en u ...
resumen:
Estados Unidos considera que Daniel Noboa, presidente de Ecuador, es ‚Äúincorruptible‚Äù, seg√∫n el Gobierno ecuatoriano.
Daniel Noboa jur√≥ su nuevo mandato hasta 2029.
Tras jurar el cargo, Noboa recibi√≥ a representantes de delegaciones internacionales, incluyendo al secretario de Salud y Servicios Humanos de los Estados Unidos, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
El funcionario estadounidense mencion√≥ que para el Gobierno de Donald Trump, el nuevo periodo presidencial de Noboa ser√° clave para mantener las relaciones bilaterales.
Seg√∫n un comunicado de la Presidencia, el funcionario estadounidense agreg√≥ que ‚Äúsu personalidad, al ser incorruptible, lo destaca como un nuevo l√≠der para el pa√≠s y en la regi√≥n‚Äù.
Noboa asever√≥ que su administraci√≥n se regir√° por la transparencia y la lucha contra las mafias del crimen organizado y la corrupci√≥n.
Noboa, heredero de una de las mayores fortunas del pa√≠s, anticip√≥ que defraudar√° ‚Äúa las oligarqu√≠as que siempre se enriquec√≠an a costa del Estado‚Äù.
Noboa, hijo del magnate del sector bananero y cinco veces candidato presidencial √Ålvaro Noboa, dijo que se crear√° ‚Äúun ambiente seguro, estable y competitivo que protege las inversiones y garantiza oportunidades reales‚Äù.
En los encuentros de Noboa con los delegados internacionales, se reforzaron lazos de amistad, cooperaci√≥n y compromiso para defender la democracia en la regi√≥n y mantener la apertura comercial en beneficio de Ecuador y naciones cooperantes, indic√≥ la Presidencia.
La presidenta de Per√∫, Dilma Boluarte, felicit√≥ a Noboa por iniciar su segundo mandato presidencial.
Noboa recibi√≥ a Thani bin Ahmed Al Zeyoudi, ministro de Comercio de Emiratos √Årabes Unidos, para dialogar sobre oportunidades de inversi√≥n en Ecuador.
El presidente recibi√≥ a la delegaci√≥n de Rep√∫blica Dominicana.

title: ‚ÄúNosotros no hablamos y anunciamos, mostramos los resultados‚Äù, asegur√≥ el canciller Lubetkin en entrevista con El Pa√≠s
content: El ministro asegura que en este corto tiempo ya hay resultados para mostrar. Se espera que este a√±o se ratifique el acuerdo entre Mercosur y UE, la apertura de un consulado en Hong Kong que, augura, a ...
resumen:
**El futuro de la colonizaci√≥n:**

*   El 20 de mayo de 2024, se llev√≥ a cabo la primera reuni√≥n del Consejo Asesor de la Comisi√≥n de Colonizaci√≥n de la C√°mara de Representantes.
*   El objetivo principal es analizar el futuro de la colonizaci√≥n en Uruguay.
*   Se busca actualizar la normativa vigente, que data de 1948, para adaptarla a las necesidades actuales.
*   Se abordar√°n temas como la tenencia de la tierra, el acceso al cr√©dito y la infraestructura.
*   Participaron en la reuni√≥n el presidente de la Comisi√≥n de Colonizaci√≥n, el diputado Juan Mart√≠n Rodr√≠guez, y representantes de diversas instituciones.
*   Entre las instituciones presentes se encontraban el Ministerio de Ganader√≠a, Agricultura y Pesca (MGAP), el Instituto Nacional de Colonizaci√≥n (INC), el Banco de la Rep√∫blica Oriental del Uruguay (BROU), la Asociaci√≥n Rural del Uruguay (ARU), la Federaci√≥n Rural del Uruguay (FRU), la Comisi√≥n Nacional de Fomento Rural (CNFR) y la Federaci√≥n Uruguaya de Magisterio (FUM).

**Rendici√≥n de Cuentas:**

title: Amid Trump tariffs, ASEAN summit to prioritise new trade links with other powers: Analysts
content: The 46th ASEAN Summit in Kuala Lumpur this week could see steps towards greater cooperation with China and Gulf states, experts say. Malaysia Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has urged ASEAN to engage ...
resumen:
The 46th ASEAN Summit in Kuala Lumpur this week will likely prioritize new trade links with other powers.

Malaysia Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has urged ASEAN to engage ‚Äúnew partners‚Äù such as India, Pakistan, Russia and the European Union.

The US will not be present at the summits held at the Kuala Lumpur Convention Centre on Monday (May 26) and Tuesday.

The ASEAN summit seeks new partnerships and closer ties with other major powers to cushion the impact from United States President Donald Trump's tariffs and isolationist policies.

Abdul Rahman Yaacob, a research fellow in the Southeast Asia programme at the Lowy Institute think tank in Australia, said that Malaysia, as the ASEAN chair, may push for ASEAN to diversify economic partnerships to minimise the impact of Trump's tariffs.

Leaders of the 10 ASEAN member states could discuss a potential expansion of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).

The ASEAN-driven RCEP comprises the 10 ASEAN countries as well as Australia, China, India, Japan, South Korea and New Zealand.

The first-ever ASEAN-Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC)-China summit will also be held on Tuesday, with Chinese Premier Li Qiang attending.

The GCC comprises six Arab states including major oil producers Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Qatar.

The GCC's total commodity trade with China reached almost US$298 billion in 2023.

The bloc accounted for 36 per cent of China's total crude oil imports that year, according to United Nations figures.

Malaysia Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said ASEAN will discuss Timor-Leste‚Äôs potential membership, the Myanmar issue, improving intra-ASEAN trade, as well as economic collaboration amid the US tariffs.

Anwar said ASEAN will discuss Timor-Leste‚Äôs potential membership, the Myanmar issue, improving intra-ASEAN trade, as well as economic collaboration amid the US tariffs.

Anwar called on ASEAN to engage ‚Äúnew partners‚Äù such as China, India, Pakistan, Russia and the European Union.

According to a draft statement expected to be issued by ASEAN leaders after they meet on Monday, the bloc will express "deep concern" over Trump's tariff blitz.

The first ASEAN-GCC summit took place in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia in 2023.

A joint statement from that summit agreed to ‚Äúenhance trade and investment flows‚Äù.

Chinese Premier Li Qiang is expected to attend the summit.

Malaysia and the United Arab Emirates signed a Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement on Jan 14 this year.

Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto announced that Qatar is set to invest US$2 billion in his country‚Äôs new sovereign wealth fund Danantara.

Sharon Seah, senior fellow and coordinator of the ASEAN Studies Centre at Singapore‚Äôs ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute, said the ASEAN-GCC-China summit is the first time that one of ASEAN‚Äôs inter-regional summits has been expanded to involve a dialogue partner.

Malaysia as ASEAN chair could discuss an expansion of RCEP membership to include more of ASEAN‚Äôs major trading partners, such as the United Kingdom and European Union.

The Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), comprises 12 economies: Australia, Brunei Darussalam, Canada, Chile, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, Singapore, the United Kingdom and Vietnam.

Malaysia‚Äôs Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Abdul Aziz said ASEAN is seeking to expand its membership in RCEP and CPTPP.

The US tariffs have had a significant impact on intra-ASEAN trade dynamics as well as that with trading partners.

ASEAN could think of spearheading a supply-chain resilience network with its most important trading partners like China, Japan, South Korea and the European Union.

Ninety per cent of ASEAN‚Äôs enterprise landscape comprises small- and medium-sized enterprises (SME).

Malaysia is expected to call on members to speed up regional economic integration, roll back protectionist behaviour, and commit to ‚Äúaggressively remove‚Äù non-tariff barriers among members.

Malaysia is also expected to push for supply chain diversification, acceleration of RCEP implementation, and the Digital Economy Framework Agreement (DEFA) as a digital economic counterweight.

ASEAN members are hoping to conclude discussions on its DEFA by the end of 2025.

During his four-day visit to Russia earlier in May, Anwar had invited Russian President Vladimir Putin to attend the East Asia Summit in October.

In January this year Indonesia became the first ASEAN member to formally join BRICS.

Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam are partner countries.

title: DOJ and FTC Join Texas AG Paxton in Antitrust Suit Against Asset Giants Over Alleged Coal Market Manipulation
content: DOJ and FTC back Texas AG Paxton's lawsuit alleging collusion by BlackRock, State Street, and Vanguard in the coal market.
resumen: El Departamento de Justicia y la Comisi√≥n Federal de Comercio, brazos legales de la administraci√≥n Trump, se est√°n involucrando en una disputa contra gigantes financieros con el Fiscal General de Texas, Ken Paxton, a la cabeza. En la mira est√°n BlackRock, State Street y Vanguard, acusados de esfuerzos colusorios en el mercado del carb√≥n en busca de agendas de energ√≠a verde, a un costo, argumenta Paxton, para la independencia estadounidense y los consumidores. La demanda de Paxton, presentada en noviembre pasado, alega que al aprovechar su considerable influencia en el mercado, los principales administradores de activos conspiraron para reducir a la mitad la producci√≥n de carb√≥n para 2030 al servicio de objetivos ambientales. Esta litigaci√≥n fue reforzada recientemente por la intervenci√≥n de agencias federales, con el apoyo del Departamento de Justicia y la Comisi√≥n Federal de Comercio a la causa de Paxton. El Fiscal General Ken Paxton, agradecido por el apoyo de la administraci√≥n del expresidente Donald Trump, declar√≥: "Estoy agradecido de que la Administraci√≥n Trump se haya unido a mi esfuerzo por responsabilizar a los principales administradores de activos por armar la industria financiera para controlar ilegalmente los mercados energ√©ticos y forzar una destructiva ideolog√≠a de 'energ√≠a verde' en el pueblo estadounidense". Esta demanda afirma que los acusados, a trav√©s de su supuesta manipulaci√≥n, han disparado los costos de la electricidad para los hogares mientras engrosan sus propias arcas financieras. El quid de la cuesti√≥n, seg√∫n Paxton, radica en el uso del poder de mercado para disminuir artificialmente la oferta, lo que desencadena saltos de precios y aprovecha los impulsos pol√≠ticos bajo la bandera de la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico. Se dice que las t√°cticas corporativas infringen varias regulaciones estatales y federales que tienen como objetivo prevenir las travesuras anticompetitivas y el comportamiento comercial enga√±oso. Para la industria del carb√≥n y el sector energ√©tico en general, la demanda simboliza un retroceso cr√≠tico contra el peso de los inversores institucionales que dirigen las tendencias del mercado bajo la apariencia de inversi√≥n socialmente responsable, especialmente en lo que respecta a los recursos energ√©ticos y su costo para los consumidores. "Juntos, el presidente Donald Trump y yo haremos que estas corporaciones rindan cuentas", afirm√≥ el Fiscal General Paxton.

title: Guerra comercial: UE y fabricantes de tel√©fonos en la mira de Trump
content: El presidente de EEUU reactiv√≥ este viernes la guerra comercial con la amenaza de imponer aranceles a la Uni√≥n Europea, Apple, Samsung y otros fabricantes de tel√©fonos inteligentes.
resumen: El presidente de EEUU, Donald Trump, reactiv√≥ la guerra comercial con la amenaza de imponer aranceles a la Uni√≥n Europea, Apple, Samsung y otros fabricantes de tel√©fonos inteligentes. Trump insisti√≥ en que impondr√° un 50% de aranceles a la UE porque las negociaciones no avanzan. Amenaz√≥ con sobretasas del 25% a todas las empresas que fabrican tel√©fonos inteligentes fuera de Estados Unidos, incluida Apple. Trump anunci√≥ en su red Truth Social que recomienda ‚Äúimponer 50% de aranceles a la Uni√≥n Europea a partir del 1 de junio‚Äù. Trump dijo que todos los fabricantes ser√°n impactados por esos aranceles, que entrar√≠an en vigor a finales de junio. Trump amenaz√≥ con imponer aranceles de al menos 10% a la mayor√≠a de los productos que ingresan a Estados Unidos. El comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcofic, sostuvo que la UE ‚Äúest√° plenamente comprometida para llegar a un acuerdo beneficioso para ambas partes‚Äù. El primer ministro de Irlanda, Micheal Martin, consider√≥ el anuncio como ‚Äúdecepcionante‚Äù. El ministro delegado franc√©s de Comercio Exterior, Laurent Saint-Martin, escribi√≥ en X: ‚ÄúDesescalada, pero estamos listos para responder‚Äù. Trump amenaz√≥ a Apple con nuevos aranceles si no traslada a Estados Unidos la producci√≥n de celulares. Trump inform√≥ a Tim Cook (presidente) de Apple que espera que sus iPhones que se vendan en Estados Unidos sean fabricados en Estados Unidos. El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, dijo que la tasa m√≠nima del 10% estaba ‚Äúsupeditada a que los pa√≠ses y bloques comerciales vinieran y negociaran de buena fe‚Äù.

title: Trump: El de siempre (IV)
content: Al margen de la confusi√≥n sobre los por qu√© y para qu√© de los aranceles y sobre la metodolog√≠a para su determinaci√≥n, lo que hay que decir es que los aranceles se sit√∫an en el centro de una ...
resumen:
Los aranceles se sit√∫an en el centro de una pol√≠tica econ√≥mica global destinada a reindustrializar Estados Unidos. Trump quiere transformar el sistema econ√≥mico internacional presionando el d√≥lar a la baja para acabar con las asimetr√≠as que enfrenta el comercio estadounidense afectando negativamente a su industria manufacturera.

Trump ha decidido imponer tres tipos de aranceles:

a) Un arancel mundial (global) del 10 % destinado a ser permanente.
b) Aranceles "rec√≠procos" que son en realidad "correctivos" para reequilibrar la balanza comercial de los pa√≠ses con los que Estados Unidos tiene un d√©ficit.
c) Aranceles dirigidos espec√≠ficamente contra China como parte de la intenci√≥n de revocar el estatus de China como pa√≠s beneficiario del r√©gimen de relaciones comerciales normales permanentes (PNTR) y tras el objetivo de "China Out".

Trump presiona a M√©xico y Canad√° para que redefinan sus aranceles con China de acuerdo con el objetivo estadounidense de "China Out".

Se trata de imponer:

a) Un arancel mundial permanente para abrir paso a la producci√≥n manufacturera estadounidense, mejorar los salarios de sus decenas de miles de obreros mal pagados y dar ocupaci√≥n a los que, se dice, viven de la mendicidad y las drogas.
b) Un arancel permanente para China para desacoplar su econom√≠a de la estadounidense y acabar con la presencia China en el mundo.
c) Aranceles "rec√≠procos" como medio de presi√≥n para alentar a los socios comerciales de EEUU a tomar decisiones pol√≠ticas para reducir los d√©ficits.

El arancel mundial del 10 % se aplicar√° sobre casi todas las importaciones. Eximir a M√©xico y Canad√° del 10% se debe a que estos dos pa√≠ses est√°n sujetos a otros aranceles espec√≠ficos y a la decisi√≥n trumpiana de querer renegociar el Acuerdo Estados Unidos-M√©xico-Canad√° (USMCA).

Los aranceles "correctivos", responden a la l√≥gica: ¬øQuieres un arancel m√°s bajo? ¬°Corrige tu desequilibrio! Pueden negociarse pa√≠s por pa√≠s. Son temporales.

Trump, ha recogido las sugerencias de sus asesores econ√≥micos, pero ha primado su impronta beligerante y confrontacional.

Corea del Sur, por boca de su primer ministro interino Han Duck-soo, ha dicho que su pa√≠s est√° "dispuesto a hacer concesiones para complacer a Trump porque EEUU ha hecho mucho por su crecimiento y desarrollo". Y ha marcado distancia con China para contrarrestar los aranceles.
