resumen:
La tregua global de los aranceles llega a su ecuador sin apenas avances.

Donald Trump solo ha llegado a un acuerdo de m√≠nimos con Reino Unido, un pa√≠s cercano y con el que tiene super√°vit.

No se conocen progresos en el di√°logo con Jap√≥n, Corea del Sur y la UE.

Donald Trump amenaza a la UE con un arancel del 50% a partir de junio.

Bruselas pide "respeto, no amenazas".

La tregua de 90 d√≠as declarada por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, para negociar nuevos pactos arancelarios alcanz√≥ su ecuador con escasos avances m√°s all√° de un acuerdo de m√≠nimos con Reino Unido y una necesaria tregua paralela con China, a lo que hay que sumar nuevas amenazas del neoyorquino contra la Uni√≥n Europea (UE).

Trump volvi√≥ a endurecer su envite diciendo que las conversaciones ‚Äúno est√°n yendo a ning√∫n lado‚Äù y que por ello activar√° grav√°menes del 50 % sobre todos los bienes de la UE a partir del 1 de junio.

El comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic, dijo que la UE est√° dispuesta a defender sus intereses.

El diplom√°tico eslovaco inst√≥ a que las relaciones comerciales bilaterales ‚Äúse gu√≠en por el respeto mutuo y no por las amenazas‚Äù.

Lo acordado en la reuni√≥n de hace dos semanas en Suiza entre representantes estadounidenses y chinos es probablemente la mejor noticia.

Las dos principales econom√≠as del mundo lograron sentarse a la mesa y acordar una tregua paralela de 90 d√≠as que entr√≥ en vigor el 14 de mayo.

La tregua con Pek√≠n implica, entre otras cosas, que China reducir√° del 125 % al 10 % los aranceles sobre productos estadounidenses y que EE.UU. rebajar√° los suyos del 145 % al 30 %.

Establece adem√°s un mecanismo por el cual podr√°n celebrarse alternativamente nuevas reuniones en cualquiera de los dos pa√≠ses o incluso en un tercer Estado y tambi√©n consultas de trabajo sobre cuestiones t√©cnicas.

Washington solo ha sellado un acuerdo con Londres en estos primeros 45 d√≠as del periodo de suspensi√≥n de los ‚Äúaranceles rec√≠procos‚Äù.

El acuerdo con Reino Unido es en realidad un marco muy esquem√°tico sobre el que ambas partes te√≥ricamente deben seguir trabajando.

El pacto implica la entrada de una partida razonable de autom√≥viles brit√°nicos con un gravamen de solo el 10 %, elimina impuestos aduaneros a los escasos vol√∫menes de acero y aluminio que el Reino Unido env√≠a a EEUU y cancela tambi√©n los aranceles que Washington aplicaba a sus componentes de aviaci√≥n.

Todo a cambio de un futuro acuerdo de compra de aviones de Boeing por parte de British Airways y una mayor entrada de productos bovinos estadounidenses al Reino Unido cuyo alcance no est√° del todo claro.

Washington ha alcanzado este acuerdo con un aliado cercano con el que mantiene un super√°vit comercial.

EEUU debe alcanzar en estos 90 d√≠as acuerdos con econom√≠as asi√°ticas de peso y un m√∫sculo exportador destacado, como Jap√≥n, Corea del Sur o Indonesia, pa√≠ses que, como China o la UE, tienen grandes super√°vits con la primera potencia mundial y que pueden verse seriamente perjudicados si Trump activa finalmente los aranceles que les adjudic√≥ inicialmente (un 24 %, 25 % y 32 %, respectivamente).

title: Trade war reload: Trump threatens EU with massive tariff
content: Economic projections estimate a potential 1.5 per cent drop in US GDP if the tariff is implemented and Capital Economics projects that Ireland could see a 4 per cent hit to its output, with Germany, ...
resumen:
On May 23, US President Donald Trump announced plans to impose a 50 per cent tariff on all European Union (EU) imports starting June 1, unless the bloc makes major concessions in ongoing trade talks.

Trump stated that the EU has been difficult to deal with, citing trade barriers, VAT taxes, corporate penalties, non-monetary trade barriers, monetary manipulations, and lawsuits against American companies, leading to a trade deficit with the US of more than $250,000,000 a year.

The comments marked a dramatic shift after weeks of de-escalation and a temporary 90-day pause in reciprocal tariffs.

The markets responded with immediate volatility. US and European stocks plunged, with Germany‚Äôs DAX down 2.4 per cent, France‚Äôs CAC falling 2.2 per cent, and the STOXX600 sliding 1.7 per cent. The US dollar weakened sharply, while gold prices surged.

The White House‚Äôs plan to double down on tariffs was reportedly driven by frustration over slow EU negotiations. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the president is dissatisfied with the EU‚Äôs offers.

In 2024, the EU exported goods worth approximately ‚Ç¨500 billion ($566 billion) to the US, led by Germany (‚Ç¨161 billion), Ireland (‚Ç¨72 billion), and Italy (‚Ç¨65 billion). The US ran a $236 billion goods trade deficit with the EU in 2024.

Trump had previously lowered his 145 per cent tariff on Chinese goods to 30 per cent and retained a 10 per cent baseline tariff on most global imports.

EU trade chief Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç emphasized that Brussels remains committed to a deal but will defend its interests if provoked. French Trade Minister Laurent Saint-Martin criticised Trump‚Äôs comments as ‚Äúunhelpful‚Äù, and Irish Prime Minister Miche√°l Martin warned the tariffs would ‚Äúgrievously damage one of the world‚Äôs most dynamic and significant trading relationships.‚Äù

The EU has already paused tariffs on ‚Ç¨23 billion ($26.15 billion) worth of US goods and has prepared up to ‚Ç¨95 billion ($1.08 trillion) in countermeasures if talks fail.

Julian Hinz, a researcher at the Kiel Institute for the World Economy, estimated that a 50 per cent tariff could reduce US GDP by 1.5 per cent, while Capital Economics projected Ireland could see a 4 per cent hit to its economy.

The Trump administration is pushing the EU to align more closely with US policy on China.

The EU has suspended tariffs on $26 billion worth of US goods and has prepared retaliatory measures on up to $108 billion in exports should negotiations break down.

The Kiel Institute for the World Economy estimates a potential 1.5 per cent drop in US GDP if the tariff is implemented. Capital Economics projects that Ireland could see a 4 per cent hit to its output, with Germany, Italy, France, and Spain also suffering notable slowdowns.

Moody‚Äôs recently downgraded the US credit outlook.

title: Emerging From Conflict, India Faces Trade And Investment Headwinds
content: India is emerging after a brief conflict with Pakistan, with a ceasefire thankfully appearing to hold for now. This is welcome news for the business community and the public at large, many of whom too ...
resumen: India is emerging from a brief conflict with Pakistan, with a ceasefire holding. Indian policymakers are returning to address economic policy priorities, including accelerating economic growth (higher than the current 6% pace), concluding a free trade agreement with America, and attracting foreign investment inflows away from China, with Apple being a top priority. India is likely to face considerable headwinds on each of these fronts. The recent India-Pakistan conflict serves as a reminder that while India enjoys relatively high growth rates, investors have ‚Äúseveral options‚Äù when looking at changes to global supply chains. The Modi government‚Äôs third term has largely been devoid of significant reforms compared to its first two terms. The Commerce Ministry hopes to complete negotiations with America on an FTA in July. The government has been encouraged by Apple CEO Tim Cook‚Äôs recent comments that India was well-positioned to become a major manufacturing hub for the company‚Äôs iPhones. India‚Äôs promiscuous moves to conclude FTAs with major trading partners in record time will likely boost short-term growth. India‚Äôs entrenched business elite is notoriously protectionist. The Modi government had to withdraw controversial legislation to reform farming and lower tariffs agreed on specific sectors. The Modi government‚Äôs ‚ÄúMake in India‚Äù manufacturing plan is contingent upon Apple significantly scaling production of iPhones in the country. CEO Tim Cook recently told analysts that a majority of iPhones sold in America will have India as their country of origin. This comment drew an immediate rebuke from President Trump, who told Cook that ‚Äúwe‚Äôre not interested in you building in India.‚Äù The U.S. President followed that threat by posting on social media that he would introduce a 25% tariff on any smartphone imported into America. India needs plenty of Apple-like production facilities to lift manufacturing share of GDP (currently at 16% compared with China‚Äôs hefty 26%) as well as to provide quality jobs for millions of young people entering the job market each year. India‚Äôs vast population and internal market can remain the growth driver if trade and foreign investment initiatives falter. The government will have to introduce significant reforms designed at making the economy more productive, competitive, and inclusive. The overwhelming message for Indian policymakers therefore should be to focus less on the noise (Trump tariffs) and more on the signal (faltering growth in the absence of reforms).

title: U.S. Exports Top $522 Billion, A Record Pace Being Set For 2025
content: Seven of the top 10 U.S. exports are at record levels. Not yet reflected in the government data are Trump‚Äôs April 2 tariffs on the world.
resumen:
U.S. exports totaled $522.61 billion through March, with seven of the top 10 exports at record levels. The two biggest winners through the first quarter are the primary aircraft category, up 20.59% to $34.32 billion, and LNG and other natural gases, increasing $5.70 billion to $21.79 billion, a 35.46% gain. The biggest losers are oil and gasoline, down 9.65% from the record pace of 2024, and passenger vehicles, down 6% from the record pace set in 2023. U.S. imports totaled $948.10 billion, and total U.S. trade came in at $1.47 trillion. The U.S. deficit stood at $425.49 billion. The balance of trade is down four percentage points from 2024, with exports accounting for just 36% of all U.S. trade this year. The top 10 exports accounted for 35.89% of the total.

The top 10 exports are:
1.  Aircraft, parts: up 20.59% to $34.32 billion.
2.  Oil: down 9.65% from the record pace of 2024.
3.  Refined petroleum: down 7.33% to $26.22 billion.
4.  LNG: increasing $5.70 billion to $21.79 billion, a 35.46% gain.
5.  Passenger vehicles: $13.83 billion, down 6%.
6.  Low-value shipments: a 1.09% increase to $13.67 billion.
7.  Vaccines, plasma: grew 6.06% when compared to the first three months of 2024, an increase of $768.02 million.
8.  Computer chips: a 27.56% increase to $13.30 billion.
9.  Computers: a 46.40% increase to $11.85 billion.
10. Gold: $11.55 billion, a 19.31% increase over the same three months of 2024.

Exports to China are down 72.35% for oil since the first quarter of 2018, down 72.60% for passenger vehicles since the first quarter of 2018, and down 39.53% for computers since the onset of the trade war in 2018. Exports to Germany since 2022 have increased 5.81 million percent.

title: Trump threatens 50% tariffs on EU imports amid growing tensions over trade and China
content: White House frustration with Europe‚Äôs pace and position in trade talks leads to surprise tariff warning ahead of June 1 deadline.
resumen: Donald Trump threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European Union imports starting June 1. This move was in response to the EU's handling of trade talks, regulation, and its stance on China. The Wall Street Journal reported the news. Trump officials have been pressing European diplomats to address US concerns over digital taxes, auto regulations, and antitrust penalties, while also pushing the EU to impose tariffs on Chinese goods. The UK accepted this measure in its recent deal with the US. Trump posted his 50% tariff warning on Truth Social. Trump told reporters later in the Oval Office that he intends to proceed unless the EU meets US expectations swiftly. The Trump administration demands coordinated tariffs on Chinese industries, particularly in steel and tech. US negotiators want the EU to join a broader front to pressure Beijing over subsidies and market interference. EU officials remain wary of provoking a trade war with China. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told Fox News that the threat of tariffs was intended to ‚Äúlight a fire under the EU.‚Äù EU trade chief Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç warned that ‚Äúmutual respect, not threats,‚Äù must guide negotiations. The EU is ready to engage but would defend its interests if talks collapse. The 27-member bloc is considering retaliatory options. The EU has also prepared a second list targeting up to ‚Ç¨95 billion in US exports should talks fail. The June 1 deadline looms as a critical turning point.

title: Trump launches a new trade offensive against Europe
content: On Friday, May 23, the US president threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European products. The 27 member states of the European Union, whose unity remains fragile, have not yet implemented any ...
resumen: On Friday, May 23, 2025, US President Donald Trump threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European products. The partial truce declared by Donald Trump in his trade war with the European Union was set to expire on July 8. Trump said on his social network, Truth Social, "I am recommending a straight 50% Tariff on the European Union, starting on June 1, 2025". He explained that the European Union was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE and has been very difficult to deal with. He accused Europeans of "Trade Barriers, Vat Taxes, ridiculous Corporate Penalties, Non-Monetary Trade Barriers, Monetary Manipulations, unfair and unjustified lawsuits against Americans Companies." In the Oval Office, the US president insisted he was not "looking for a deal" with the EU. Trump has denounced European trade surpluses ‚Äì about ‚Ç¨150 billion in industrial goods and ‚Ç¨50 billion when accounting for the US surplus in services, according to the European Commission.

title: Trump tariff tensions test Southeast Asian leaders at regional summit as bloc caught in midst of US-China trade war
content: Southeast Asian leaders will express deep concern over US President Donald Trump's tariff blitz when they meet at a summit Monday, warning that the move poses huge challenges to economic growth and ...
resumen:
Southeast Asian leaders will express deep concern over US President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariff blitz when they meet at a summit Monday, warning that the unilateral move poses huge challenges to economic growth and stability in the region, according to a draft statement seen by AFP.

The leaders from the 10-member ASEAN bloc are scrambling for ways to limit the fallout on their trade-dependent economies.

The bloc is also caught between the trade battle between their biggest trading partners, the United States and China, on which Washington has heaped the highest tariffs.

According to a draft statement expected to be issued by ASEAN leaders after they meet on Monday, they express ‚Äúdeep concern‚Ä¶ over the imposition of unilateral tariff measures‚Äù.

Trump‚Äôs measures ‚Äúpose complex and multidimensional challenges to ASEAN‚Äôs economic growth, stability, and integration‚Äù, according to the draft of the ASEAN chairman‚Äôs statement seen by AFP.

The leaders also ‚Äúreaffirmed ASEAN‚Äôs collective commitment‚Äù to the global free trading system, it said.

After the bloc‚Äôs meeting on Monday, the leaders are to hold a one-day summit with China and Middle Eastern oil producers.

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has called for a joint ASEAN action plan to address the growing tariff threat.

Anwar said at a pre-summit briefing that, while bilateral talks between member states and the United States would continue, the bloc must present a united front.

The group, Anwar said, ‚Äúhad very practical policies‚Ä¶ and what to me is of critical importance is to build that cohesion within ASEAN‚Äù.

The pressure to shift ASEAN‚Äôs ‚Äúfriend to all‚Äù posture will likely intensify during the follow-up summit on Tuesday when Chinese Premier Li Qiang joins the bloc‚Äôs leaders and officials from oil-rich Gulf states.

Beijing has been courting closer ties with Southeast Asia, positioning itself as a ‚Äúreliable trading partner‚Äù despite tensions with ASEAN members over rival claims in the South China Sea.

Li will attend the first-time summit between ASEAN, Beijing and oil-producing nations including Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Saudi Arabia.

Chinese President Xi Jinping urging greater cooperation between Beijing and Malaysia ‚Äúto safeguard the bright prospects of our Asian family‚Äù during a Southeast Asian diplomatic charm offensive in April.

Anwar said in return that Malaysia would ‚Äúremain an unwavering and principled friend to China‚Äù.

A diplomatic source said that ASEAN countries ‚Äúwon‚Äôt automatically fall in China‚Äôs arms‚Äù.

James Chin, professor of Asian studies at the University of Tasmania, warned that playing to both the United States and China was a ‚Äúhigh-risk strategy‚Äù.

S. Munirah Alatas, a geopolitics specialist at the University of Malaya‚Äôs Allianz Centre for Governance, said the bloc still faced tough unresolved challenges, including ‚Äúhostilities in Myanmar and recurring tensions in the South China Sea‚Äù.

title: Chinese investors keep their cool as trade tensions roil US and EU markets
content: Still, Chinese markets have taken all the trade cross-winds in their stride, bolstered by the government rolling out more economic stimulus measures. On Tuesday, China announced a 0.1 percentage point ...
resumen:
China's stock markets showed less volatility than overseas bourses amid continuing headwinds from US-initiated global trade and geopolitical tensions.

US President Donald Trump said the US would impose a tariff of 50 percent on EU imports and a 25 percent tariff on iPhones sold in the US that are manufactured overseas.

The Dow Jones, S&P and Nasdaq indexes in the US all lost more than 2 percent this week.

China condemned the Trump administration's decision this week to revoke visas for foreign students at Harvard.

Chinese students comprise the largest population of foreign visa holders on the campus, estimated at more than 2,000.

Investors were also rattled by US renewed attempts to ban Chinese chips and a new European Union new rule imposing a 2-euro flat tax on delivery of low-value parcels, most of which come from China.

The Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.57 percent this week, while the Shenzhen Component Index lost 0.46 percent.

Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 1.1 percent in the week.

The Nikkei index in Japan lost 1.6 percent this week.

Gold rose almost 2 percent on Friday, and bitcoin hit a record high this week.

On Tuesday, China announced a 0.1 percentage point cut in both one-year and five-year prime loan rates.

title: NUEVO EMBAJADOR DE ESTADOS UNIDOS
content: ‚ÄúLa colaboraci√≥n entre nuestros pa√≠ses mejorar√° la vida de nuestros pueblos‚Äù: Ronald Johnson. La presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum recibi√≥ las cartas credenciales del nuevo embajador de Estados Unidos envi ...
resumen:
El 23 de mayo de 2025, la presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum recibi√≥ las cartas credenciales del nuevo embajador de Estados Unidos en M√©xico, Ronald Johnson, enviado por el presidente Donald Trump.

Johnson asever√≥ que la colaboraci√≥n entre ambos pa√≠ses mejorar√° la vida de sus pueblos.

Ambos gobiernos deben colaborar sobre la base de la responsabilidad compartida y el respeto mutuo, aprovechando los v√≠nculos econ√≥micos y las coincidencias pol√≠ticas, que se han hecho latentes mediante siete comunicaciones telef√≥nicas que ha sostenido la presidenta con Trump en los m√°s recientes meses.

M√©xico es el segundo socio comercial de Estados Unidos, el primer destino de las exportaciones de California, Arizona y Texas, y el segundo mercado para otros 20 estados de la Uni√≥n Americana.

Aproximadamente seis millones de empleos en Estados Unidos dependen del comercio con M√©xico y cada minuto se comercia cerca de un mill√≥n de d√≥lares; la frontera de tres mil 140 kil√≥metros que los une es la m√°s transitada del mundo, con un mill√≥n de personas y 300 mil veh√≠culos que cruzan diariamente sus l√≠neas divisorias.

Ronald Johnson es un veterano de la Agencia Central de Inteligencia (CIA), ha sido Boina Verde y fue embajador en El Salvador.

El 16 de mayo, el canciller Juan Ram√≥n de la Fuente se reuni√≥ con Johnson en t√©rminos cordiales, con un di√°logo franco y directo donde ambos convinieron conducir la relaci√≥n bilateral con base en los principios de cooperaci√≥n y respeto.

El 19 de mayo, Sheinbaum anunci√≥ que recibir√≠a las cartas credenciales de Johnson.

Sheinbaum y Johnson hablaron de temas como las relaciones comerciales, migraci√≥n y seguridad, acordando mantener una buena coordinaci√≥n.

Sheinbaum expres√≥ la inconformidad de M√©xico frente a la pretensi√≥n en el Congreso estadunidense de aprobar una reforma para gravar las remesas.

Johnson afirm√≥ que la colaboraci√≥n entre ambos pa√≠ses mejorar√° las vidas de sus pueblos.

Johnson destac√≥ los valores que aprendi√≥ en Alabama, orientados a servir a su pa√≠s y trabajar por la libertad en todo el mundo.

M√©xico y Estados Unidos comparten una relaci√≥n econ√≥mica y lazos culturales, adem√°s de resaltar su labor en el combate al crimen organizado.

Johnson trabajar√° con Sheinbaum para lograr el bienestar y la prosperidad de ambas naciones.

La Casa Blanca reconoci√≥ los esfuerzos de Sheinbaum contra la migraci√≥n ilegal y el tr√°fico de estupefacientes.

Marco Rubio reconoci√≥ a la administraci√≥n de Sheinbaum por los resultados en la cooperaci√≥n en materia de combate al narcotr√°fico y contenci√≥n de los flujos migratorios.

Sheinbaum y Trump han tratado de acordar un impulso a mecanismos para equilibrar la relaci√≥n comercial bilateral y abordar asuntos pendientes entre las dos naciones.

Se acord√≥ que las negociaciones t√©cnicas quedar√°n en manos del secretario de Hacienda, Edgar Zamora, y su hom√≥logo del Tesoro estadunidense, Scott Bessent, adem√°s del secretario de Econom√≠a, Marcelo Ebrard, y el titular de Comercio de EU, Howard Lutnick.

Otro tema es la plaga del gusano barrenador de ganado.

Ambas administraciones alcanzaron un acuerdo para atender el tema de las asignaciones de agua del R√≠o Bravo.

En la m√°s reciente llamada telef√≥nica que realiz√≥ con Trump el pasado jueves 22, Sheinbaum inform√≥ sobre el comercio y los aranceles, y sobre la reducci√≥n del gravamen a las remesas del 5% al 3.5%.

Ronald Johnson fue confirmado por el Senado de Estados Unidos como embajador en M√©xico el 9 de abril.

Johnson ha trabajado para el gobierno estadunidense durante m√°s de cuatro d√©cadas.

title: Clara Mattei, economista: "Con los aranceles, Trump busca dividir a los trabajadores de otros pa√≠ses y unir a sus bases"
content: Clara Mattei, economista: "Con los aranceles, Trump busca dividir a los trabajadores de otros pa√≠ses y unir a sus bases" ...
resumen:
Clara Mattei, economista, afirma que con los aranceles, Trump busca dividir a los trabajadores de otros pa√≠ses y unir a sus bases. Define la austeridad como la forma en que "el dinero y el poder se quedan en manos de muy pocos".

Clara Mattei es profesora de Econom√≠a y directora del Centro de Econom√≠a Heterodoxa de la Universidad de Tulsa, Oklahoma. Es autora de El orden del capital: c√≥mo los economistas inventaron la austeridad y allanaron el camino hacia el fascismo.

Mattei explica que la austeridad es un medio pol√≠tico y violento de gestionar una sociedad capitalista, y que es crucial para el capitalismo porque proporciona el marco fundamental para subordinar a la mayor√≠a de las personas a su condici√≥n de trabajadores asalariados. La austeridad debilita a las personas, las empobrece, hace que dependan m√°s del mercado.

Trump est√° recortando gastos sociales y cupones de alimentos, mientras reduce los impuestos a las empresas y a la riqueza y propone un aumento en el presupuesto del Pent√°gono. La militarizaci√≥n es importante para entender su estrategia.

Trump insiste en un mensaje: "Voy a devolver los empleos a los Estados Unidos". Los aranceles lo ponen en la situaci√≥n de negar el conflicto de costos. Est√° enfrentando a los trabajadores estadounidenses contra otros trabajadores de otros lugares del mundo, por lo que es una muy buena estrategia para, en √∫ltima instancia, dividir.

Mattei considera que Trump est√° intentando afirmar su poder subvirtiendo el orden mundial.

title: Costa Rica destaca logros tras 4 a√±os en la OCDE y apunta a un mayor liderazgo
content: San Jos√©, 23 may (EFE).- Costa Rica cumple cuatro a√±os como integrante de la Organizaci√≥n para la Cooperaci√≥n y el Desarrollo Econ√≥micos (OCDE) con la mirada puesta en ejercer un papel de m√°s liderazg ...
resumen:
Costa Rica cumple cuatro a√±os como integrante de la Organizaci√≥n para la Cooperaci√≥n y el Desarrollo Econ√≥micos (OCDE) con la mirada puesta en ejercer un papel de m√°s liderazgo y de compartir sus experiencias en √°mbitos como el comercio, el medio ambiente, el turismo y la atracci√≥n de inversiones.

El ministro de Comercio Exterior de Costa Rica, Manuel Tovar, dijo que Costa Rica da un paso adelante para liderar y que hay confianza en Costa Rica y una estrecha relaci√≥n con todos los pa√≠ses.

El 25 de mayo de 2021 Costa Rica se convirti√≥ en el cuarto pa√≠s latinoamericano en ingresar a la OCDE -tras M√©xico, Chile y Colombia- y despu√©s de un proceso de adhesi√≥n que se extendi√≥ por 9 a√±os y que requiri√≥ la aprobaci√≥n de 22 comit√©s de la organizaci√≥n.

El ministro Tovar afirm√≥ que es un ‚Äúhonor‚Äù para Costa Rica formar parte de la OCDE pero tambi√©n una ‚Äúgran responsabilidad‚Äù que requiere una ‚Äúevaluaci√≥n continua‚Äù de las pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas del pa√≠s.

Costa Rica presidir√° el pr√≥ximo 3 y 4 de junio la Reuni√≥n del Consejo Ministerial de la OCDE en Par√≠s, bajo el lema 'Liderando el camino hacia una prosperidad resiliente, inclusiva y sostenible a trav√©s del comercio basado en normas, la inversi√≥n y la innovaci√≥n'.

Entre los objetivos de este encuentro sobresalen reforzar los mercados abiertos y un sistema de comercio internacional basado en normas; impulsar la econom√≠a digital para conseguir un crecimiento en favor de una prosperidad compartida; y fomentar un crecimiento econ√≥mico sostenible e inclusivo mediante pol√≠ticas innovadoras.

Tovar coment√≥ que Costa Rica quiere promover varias acciones espec√≠ficas encaminadas a est√°ndares internacionales para regular la gobernanza de la inteligencia artificial.

En materia comercial ‚Äúrecalcar la importancia de un sistema internacional basado en reglas, abordar temas relevantes como seguridad econ√≥mica, de las cadenas de suministros, evitar distorsiones de mercado; la seguridad energ√©tica mundial y las energ√≠as limpias‚Äù, dijo el ministro.

Otro objetivo ser√° trabajar en un ‚Äúmarco estrat√©gico de colaboraci√≥n‚Äù de la OCDE con Latinoam√©rica y el Caribe para compartir experiencias positivas en modelos de reformas estructurales de los pa√≠ses.

El ministro destac√≥ que durante los 4 a√±os en la OCDE, Costa Rica conseguido implementar reformas en diversas √°reas como el comercio, las finanzas, la banca, lucha contra la corrupci√≥n, educaci√≥n, competencia, entre otras, aprendiendo de buenas pr√°cticas de otros pa√≠ses.

El ministro indic√≥ que adem√°s de aprender de las experiencias de otros pa√≠ses, Costa Rica tambi√©n ha compartido sus avances en √°reas en las que es reconocido a nivel internacional como sus pol√≠ticas ambientales, el turismo sostenible, la atracci√≥n de inversiones y la apertura de mercados.

title: Trump amenaza con nuevos aranceles a la Uni√≥n Europea y Apple
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos dijo que las negociaciones comerciales con los pa√≠ses de la Uni√≥n Europea "no est√°n dando frutos".
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, renov√≥ su ofensiva comercial con amenazas de aranceles de hasta 50% a los productos de la Uni√≥n Europea (UE). Trump anunci√≥ en su red Truth Social que recomienda ‚Äúimponer 50% de aranceles a la Uni√≥n Europea a partir del 1 de junio‚Äù. Trump dijo que las negociaciones comerciales con los pa√≠ses de la Uni√≥n Europea "no est√°n dando frutos". Los aranceles actuales est√°n situados en una media de 12,5% (2,5% ya vigentes antes de la investidura de Trump y un 10% adicional desde abril). El ministro delegado franc√©s de Comercio Exterior, Laurent Saint-Martin, escribi√≥ en X: ‚ÄúNos mantenemos en la misma l√≠nea: desescalada, pero estamos listos para responder‚Äù. El ministro alem√°n de Relaciones Exteriores, Johann Wadephul, sostuvo que esos ‚Äúaranceles no ayudan a nadie y solo conducen a que el desarrollo econ√≥mico de ambos mercados se resienta‚Äù. Las bolsas europeas cerraron en rojo el viernes, Par√≠s cedi√≥ 1,65%, Fr√°ncfort 1,54%, Mil√°n 1,94% y Madrid 1,18%. Londres solo perdi√≥ 0,24%. Trump amenaz√≥ con imponer aranceles de al menos 10% a la mayor√≠a de los productos que ingresan a Estados Unidos. Las tarifas aduaneras para China llegaron a 145% (en ciertos productos al 245%), a las que Pek√≠n respondi√≥ con aranceles del 125%. Trump denunci√≥ el d√©ficit comercial de Estados Unidos con Europa, que estima entre 300.000 y 350.000 millones de d√≥lares. Seg√∫n los datos del representante de la Casa Blanca para Comercio (USTR), el d√©ficit comercial de Estados Unidos con el bloque europeo se elev√≥ a 235.000 millones de d√≥lares en 2024. La Comisi√≥n Europea cuestiona esas cifras y habla de 150.000 millones de euros (unos 160.000 millones de d√≥lares), y √∫nicamente 50.000 millones de euros si se integra el excedente comercial estadounidense en t√©rminos de servicios. El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, dijo que la tasa m√≠nima del 10% estaba ‚Äúsupeditada a que los pa√≠ses y bloques comerciales vinieran y negociaran de buena fe‚Äù. Un portavoz de la UE dijo a la AFP que estaba prevista una llamada este viernes entre el comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic y el Representante de Comercio estadounidense, Jamieson Greer. Trump tambi√©n amenaz√≥ a Apple con nuevos aranceles. Trump amenaz√≥: ‚ÄúHace tiempo inform√© a Tim Cook (presidente) de Apple que espero que sus iPhones que se vendan en Estados Unidos sean fabricados en Estados Unidos, no en India ni en otros lugares. Si no es el caso, Apple deber√° pagar un arancel de al menos 25%‚Äù. El analista Dan Ives, de la consultora Wedbush Securities, dijo que mudar la producci√≥n del iPhone para Estados Unidos es ‚Äúun cuento de hadas inviable‚Äù. Si se fabricaran en Estados Unidos, los iPhones costar√≠an unos 3.500 d√≥lares, y mudar toda la producci√≥n demorar√≠a hasta 10 a√±os.

title: From El Salvador to Honduras, why authoritarians gain from USAID cuts
content: USAID cuts have hurt international development work ‚Äì but they‚Äôre also hampering civil society groups dedicated to preserving democracy.
resumen:
In El Salvador, Kara Wilson Garc√≠a's child care-focused NGO, Project RED, was promised $50,000 in USAID money, but it evaporated after the January 20 announcement of a freeze on the U.S. Agency for International Development. The crackdown under President Nayib Bukele's ‚Äústate of exception‚Äù has seen homicides plummet since launching in 2022, but has simultaneously left thousands of children and adolescents forcibly abandoned by imprisoned caregivers.

USAID cuts have hurt international development work and are hampering civil society groups dedicated to preserving democracy in Central America. Civil society organizations are cutting staff and programming, and in some cases closing their doors. On May 20, El Salvador‚Äôs Legislative Assembly passed a new ‚Äúforeign agents‚Äù law that imposes a 30% tax on all individuals and organizations receiving foreign funds.

Enrique Roig, former deputy assistant secretary in the U.S. State Department‚Äôs Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor, says the withdrawal of USAID funding ‚Äúleaves a lot of very important democracy work much more vulnerable.‚Äù

Four of seven Central American countries sit at the bottom half of the Global State of Democracy Initiative. Nicaragua ranks 143rd, and not far behind are El Salvador (94th), Honduras (91st), and Guatemala (83rd).

In Honduras, the Forest Conservation Institute lost a project scheduled to start in March. Domestic electoral observation work by churches and universities in Honduras have been suspended due to the USAID cuts. The Washington Office on Latin America conducted an informal survey of 21 partner organizations across Central America in April, finding 70% of local organizations had to cut staff, half reported a ‚Äúserious‚Äù impact on their budget, and 25% reported a ‚Äúvery serious‚Äù impact on their budget.

In El Salvador, 97% of USAID funding went to projects supporting issues like improving access to clean water, halting illegal migration, and training security forces. In Guatemala, Catholic Relief Services and Save The Children have been the two biggest recipients of USAID funds over the past 25 years.

Nicaraguan journalists, exiled in Costa Rica, launched a crowdfunding campaign following the U.S. cuts.

President Donald Trump announced on Feb. 3, ‚ÄúUSAID has been run by a bunch of radical lunatics and we‚Äôre getting them out.‚Äù Secretary of State Marco Rubio announced the cancellation of 83% of USAID programs.

The White House underscored specific examples of how the funds were spent inappropriately, including "$2 million for sex change operations in Guatemala.‚Äù

Asociaci√≥n Lambda, an LGBTQ+ organization in Guatemala, received a $2 million grant for a project. The project‚Äôs objective was to provide legal advice and psychological counseling. U.S. federal records show only 25% of the grant was disbursed before funding was cut.

Due to the U.S. funding cuts, the number of people Lambda provides psychological support to through this project fell from 200 to 20. Their ability to shelter members of the LGTBQ+ community dropped by 50%.

Mr. Bukele has stood behind the Trump administration‚Äôs cuts. He posted on X in February, ‚ÄúThe majority of these [USAID] funds are funneled into opposition groups, NGOs with political agendas, and destabilizing movements.‚Äù

Only 2.5% of USAID funds since 2019 went toward programs that supported media in El Salvador, yet this industry was hit particularly hard. Some 11 media organizations were affected by the cuts and 50 journalists lost their jobs, according to the Salvadoran Journalists‚Äô Association.

On May 20, the Legislative Assembly passed a law that now requires NGOs in El Salvador to register under a newly created Foreign Agents Registry, which prohibits them from ‚Äúcarrying out activities for political purposes or others that subvert public order, threaten national security, or undermine social and political stability.‚Äù Any foreign funding of civil society will be taxed 30%.

Mr. Roig says that combined with slowing global economic growth and ‚Äúa lack of democratic governability ... the projections do not bode well‚Äù for Central America‚Äôs future.

title: Aranceles a Apple tambi√©n van contra Samsung y otros fabricantes de smartphones: Trump
content: Tras amenazar con aranceles del 25% a Apple, Trump dijo que la medida se extender√° a fabricantes de smartphones que produzcan fuera de EU, como Samsung.
resumen: Tras amenazar con aranceles del 25% a Apple, Trump dijo que la medida se extender√° a fabricantes de smartphones que produzcan fuera de Estados Unidos, como Samsung. El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, intensific√≥ este viernes su presi√≥n sobre los principales fabricantes de tel√©fonos inteligentes, al advertir que impondr√° aranceles del 25% a todas las compa√±√≠as que produzcan fuera de Estados Unidos, incluyendo a Apple y Samsung. Durante una aparici√≥n en la Casa Blanca, Trump explic√≥ que los nuevos aranceles no se limitar√°n a Apple, sino que tambi√©n alcanzar√°n a ‚ÄúSamsung y cualquiera que fabrique ese producto‚Äù, en referencia a los tel√©fonos inteligentes ensamblados en el extranjero. Trump se√±al√≥ que estas medidas comenzar√≠an a aplicarse a finales de junio, como parte de su estrategia para forzar a las compa√±√≠as tecnol√≥gicas a relocalizar su producci√≥n en territorio estadounidense. Horas antes, en una publicaci√≥n en Truth Social, Trump ya hab√≠a amenazado con imponer un arancel del 25% a los iPhone fabricados fuera del pa√≠s, si Apple no trasladaba sus operaciones desde el extranjero a Estados Unidos. Sus declaraciones posteriores en el Despacho Oval confirmaron que la medida tambi√©n incluir√≠a a otros gigantes del sector, como la surcoreana Samsung Electronics. ‚ÄúCualquiera que fabrique ese producto fuera del pa√≠s deber√° pagar‚Äù, reiter√≥ Trump, reforzando su mensaje de reindustrializaci√≥n nacional y protecci√≥n del empleo local. La propuesta representa un nuevo episodio en la pol√≠tica comercial del presidente, caracterizada por el uso de aranceles como herramienta de presi√≥n sobre empresas extranjeras y estadounidenses que operan fuera de las fronteras. Aunque Apple ha aumentado su inversi√≥n en Estados Unidos en los √∫ltimos a√±os, la mayor parte de sus productos ‚Äîincluido el iPhone‚Äî sigue fabric√°ndose en China y otros pa√≠ses asi√°ticos. Samsung, por su parte, produce gran parte de sus dispositivos en Corea del Sur, Vietnam y la India. Los analistas advierten que este tipo de medidas podr√≠a tener efectos negativos para los consumidores, al encarecer los productos tecnol√≥gicos y alimentar una nueva ola de tensiones comerciales, especialmente con pa√≠ses asi√°ticos clave para la cadena de suministro global. La amenaza de Trump tambi√©n se produce en un contexto pol√≠tico m√°s amplio, donde busca reafirmar su agenda econ√≥mica nacionalista de cara al ciclo electoral, apelando al discurso de ‚Äútraer los empleos de vuelta a casa‚Äù. Mientras tanto, las acciones de Apple ca√≠an 2.75% a menos de una hora del cierre del mercado.

title: Ecuador espera cerrar en junio acuerdo con EE. UU. para eliminar arancel del 10 %
content: Ecuador espera tener en junio cerrada la negociaci√≥n con Estados Unidos sobre un acuerdo que revierta el 10 % de arancel que impuso el presidente Donald Trump a los productos ecuatorianos. Lea: Ecuado ...
resumen: Ecuador espera cerrar en junio la negociaci√≥n con Estados Unidos sobre un acuerdo que revierta el 10 % de arancel que impuso el presidente Donald Trump a los productos ecuatorianos. El sector bananero ten√É¬≠a 0 % arancel y con la decisi√É¬≥n de Estados Unidos subi√É¬≥ a 10%, igual que el camar√É¬≥n. El sector pesquero que ten√É¬≠a aranceles de hasta el 35 % subi√É¬≥ al 45 %. title: El mercado de las criptomonedas se alista para afrontar el impacto de las tensas negociaciones comerciales globales de Trump.
content: El mercado de las criptomonedas vive momentos de incertidumbre ante las negociaciones tarifarias de Trump Las criptomonedas han experimentado una ca√≠da significativa en medio de nuevas tensiones comer ...
resumen: El mercado de las criptomonedas vive momentos de incertidumbre ante las negociaciones tarifarias de Trump. Las criptomonedas han experimentado una ca√≠da significativa en medio de nuevas tensiones comerciales entre Estados Unidos y la Uni√≥n Europea. La decisi√≥n del presidente Donald Trump de proponer aranceles del 50% ha generado nerviosismo en el mercado, repercutiendo en la cotizaci√≥n de activos digitales como Bitcoin y Ethereum. El Bitcoin (BTC), que recientemente alcanz√≥ un m√°ximo hist√≥rico de 111,814 d√≥lares, sufri√≥ una ca√≠da del 4%, seguida por Ethereum (ETH), que vio una disminuci√≥n del 3.2% despu√©s de que Trump publicara en Truth Social que las negociaciones con la UE ¬´no estaban llevando a ninguna parte¬ª. M√°s de 300 millones de d√≥lares en posiciones apalancadas fueron liquidadas. Trump ha hecho la propuesta de imponer un arancel del 50% sobre las importaciones de la UE, as√≠ como un 25% espec√≠ficamente sobre los iPhones producidos en el extranjero. La expiraci√≥n de la pausa tarifaria en julio ejerce presi√≥n sobre las negociaciones en curso. Ethereum (ETH) no ha escapado a la volatilidad del mercado, manteniendo un nivel de soporte en 2,500 d√≥lares, pero enfrentando dificultades para superar la resistencia de 2,700 d√≥lares, con p√©rdidas diarias extendi√©ndose, tambi√©n, al 4%. La popular criptomoneda Pi Coin mostr√≥ signos de crecimiento a principios de este mes, pero no logr√≥ sostener sus ganancias despu√©s de caer por debajo de 1.23 d√≥lares. Las acciones de empresas tecnol√≥gicas en EE.UU. tambi√©n han reflejado el descenso de las criptomonedas, con Apple experimentando ca√≠das. La implicaci√≥n personal de Trump en el sector de las criptomonedas ha a√±adido una capa inesperada de controversia, destac√°ndose en un g√°lano muy medi√°tico para los principales poseedores del memecoin TRUMP. Tras el gala, el token TRUMP vio un incremento hasta alcanzar los 16 d√≥lares para luego caer a 13.81 d√≥lares.

title: Trump Turns Back to His Trade War, Threatening Europe and Apple
content: The president threatened both Apple and the European Union with higher tariffs on Friday, saying trade talks with the Europeans had stalled.
resumen:
President Trump threatened to revive his global trade wars on Friday.

Mr. Trump said he would apply a steep tax to European exports starting in just over a week and warning Apple and other phone manufacturers that their products made outside the United States would face a 25 percent tariff, most likely beginning next month.

The president wrote on Truth Social on Friday morning that discussions with the European Union ‚Äúare going nowhere‚Äù and that he was recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1.

Mr. Trump wrote, ‚ÄúThe European Union, which was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE, has been very difficult to deal with.‚Äù

He claimed the bloc‚Äôs trade barriers, taxes, corporate penalties and other policies had contributed to a trade imbalance with the United States that was ‚Äútotally unacceptable.‚Äù

In an earlier social media post, the president also targeted Tim Cook, the chief executive of Apple.

The president wrote that iPhones sold in the United States should be ‚Äúmanufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else.‚Äù

On Friday afternoon, Mr. Trump told reporters in the Oval Office that the 25 percent tariff on iPhones might be limited not just to Apple, but also to Samsung or any other smartphone company that makes its product outside the United States.

He said the tariffs would start ‚ÄúI guess the end of June.‚Äù

The president also denied that he was looking for a deal with Europe.

U.S. markets opened sharply lower, with the S&P 500 index falling more than 1 percent as trading began, before ending the day down less than 1 percent.

Apple shares dropped 3 percent.

Shares in Stellantis and Mercedes-Benz fell about 4.5 percent, and shares in Volkswagen and Porsche were down more than 3 percent.

Estimates by the Kiel Institute for the World Economy showed that the tariffs would lead to a 20 percent drop in exports from the European Union to the United States in the short term, as well as a more than 6 percent increase in prices in the United States.

Austan Goolsbee, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, warned on CNBC on Friday that the proposed import taxes raised the risk of higher prices and lower growth.

The Trump administration has been holding trade talks with over a dozen governments, including the European Union, to try to reach some kind of trade agreement before many tariffs are set to snap back into effect in early July.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that trade offers from Europe had ‚Äúnot been of the same quality‚Äù that the United States had received from other countries.

The European Union‚Äôs trade commissioner, Maros Sefcovic, held a call with Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, on Friday.

Mr. Sefcovic said in a post after the meeting that ‚Äúthe EU‚Äôs fully engaged, committed to securing a deal that works for both,‚Äù but added that ‚ÄúEU-US trade is unmatched & must be guided by mutual respect, not threats. We stand ready to defend our interests.‚Äù

Officials from the 27-nation European Union have been negotiating for weeks with their American counterparts, hoping to reduce a 10 percent tariff that Mr. Trump has applied to countries globally and to reduce or avert the sector-specific tariffs he has imposed or proposed on products like cars and pharmaceuticals.

To placate Mr. Trump, the European Union has offered to reduce tariffs on industrial goods to zero, if America does the same, and increase purchases of U.S. energy.

Mr. Bessent claimed on Fox News on Friday that the countries in the European Union ‚Äúdon‚Äôt even know what the E.U. is negotiating on their behalf.‚Äù

Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, described the European Union as one of the governments that have been challenging to negotiate with.

Mr. Lutnick said, ‚ÄúThere are some countries that are impossible, like the European Union.‚Äù

Mr. Lutnick praised Mr. Trump‚Äôs negotiating strategy.

Xi Jinping, the president of China, held a telephone call with Friedrich Merz, the chancellor of Germany.

Mr. Xi offered China as a reliable economic partner to Germany and the European Union.

Within four days in early April, after Mr. Trump announced tariffs of up to 145 percent on products made in China, Apple lost $770 billion in market value.

Apple has promised to spend more than $500 billion in the United States over the next four years.

Apple has said it will buy 19 billion artificial intelligence chips made in the United States and begin manufacturing A.I. servers in Houston.

Mr. Trump said on Friday that Apple had been building plants in India, and that he had told Mr. Cook that the company should expect to face tariffs selling into the United States.

By the end of this year, an estimated 25 percent or more of iPhones will be made in India.

title: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq fall as Trump tariff threats roar back, US deficit anxiety deepens
content: Wall Street is assessing President Trump''s tariff salvo on Apple and what his giant tax bill means for the deficit and the economy.
resumen:
US stocks fell on Friday to register weekly losses. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) sank 0.6%. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) also fell roughly 0.7%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) backed off about 1%. All three major averages fell more than 2% for the week. The three indexes trimmed steeper losses that followed Trump's comment on Friday that Apple (AAPL) must pay a 25% tariff on iPhones sold but not made in the US. Apple shares fell about 3%. Trump implied the tariffs would apply to other cell phone manufacturers. Trump threatened to hike the tariff on EU imports to "a straight 50%" beginning June 1. The president's warnings shattered a more muted mood on Wall Street as investors wound down to the Memorial Day trading break on Monday. Stocks have suffered this week as deficit worries pushed up Treasury yields. The 30-year yield (^TYX) eased but held above the key level of 5% on Friday. Wall Street's attention has also begun to turn to Nvidia (NVDA) earnings, due Wednesday after the bell.

Stocks closed out the week in the red on Friday as renewed threats from President Trump against the European Union and iPhone maker Apple (AAPL) reignited concerns that the trade war is far from over. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) sank 0.3% for the session, but was down more than 2% for the week. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) and tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) also registered weekly losses of more than 2%. Shares of US Steel (X) skyrocketed more than 20% in the last half hour of trading on Friday after President Trump announced the American company will form a partnership with Nippon Steel of Japan. Apple shares fell nearly 3% after President Trump said the company must pay at least a 25% tariff unless iPhones sold in the US are manufactured domestically. Trump also threatened to hike tariffs on EU imports to "a straight 50%" beginning June 1. The market slumped this week as 10-year and 30-year Treasury bond prices declined.

Next week's trading will be shortened due to Memorial Day. The stock market will be closed on Monday. The big focus next week will be on Nvidia (NVDA). The AI chip giant will report its earnings on Wednesday, after the bell.

President Trump reiterated his demand that Apple (AAPL) ‚Äî and potentially other smartphone manufacturers ‚Äî produce devices in the United States if they intend to sell them domestically. Otherwise, they could face tariffs. Apple (AAPL) stock fell more than 2% mid-morning Friday after President Trump said the company faces at least a 25% tariff, unless its iPhones sold in the US are made domestically. Tesla (TSLA), Meta (META), Alphabet (GOOGL, GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), and Nvidia (NVDA) all declined roughly 1% during the session.

Nuclear stocks rallied after President Trump signed executive orders to revive the industry. Nuclear-related stocks Oklo (OKLO), Constellation Energy (CEG), and Nano Nuclear (NNE) all rose by double-digit percentages.

Solar stocks rebounded on Friday but were still on track to close out the week with steep losses. SolarEdge (SEDG), Sunrun (RUN), Complete Solaria (SPWR), and Enphase Energy (ENPH) were among the biggest decliners this week, all down double-digit percentages.

Bitcoin (BTC-USD) dropped nearly 2% from its recent record high to hover near $109,000. Crypto-related stocks also sank on Friday. Shares of Strategy (MSTR) dropped more than 3%. Mara Holdings (MARA) and Riot Platforms (RIOT) dropped more than 5% and 3%, respectively.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) sank 1%, or over 400 points. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) fell 1.3%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) backed off 1.2%. Apple shares sank after Trump said the iPhone maker would face at least 25% tariffs if it did not make its iPhones sold in the US domestically. He also threatened to hike the tariff on EU imports to "a straight 50%" beginning June 1.

Volvo Cars (VOLCAR-B.ST) warned that it's customers may have to pay a large part of the company's tariff related cost increases. Shares in the company fell over 4%.

Europe's broad Stoxx (^STOXX) 600 index fell as much as 2% before recouping some of those losses.

Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average (YM=F) dropped 1.4%, or nearly 600 points, while those tied to the S&P 500 (ES=F) fell 1.6%. Contracts on the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 (NQ=F) sank 1.9%.

Shares of nuclear power companies soared in premarket after Reuters reported that President Trump will soon sign executive orders aimed at jump-starting the nuclear energy industry. Shares of Oklo (OKLO), a nuclear start-up backed by OpenAI's Sam Altman, surged 19%. Other big gainers included Nano Nuclear Energy (NNE) and NuScale Power (SMR), both up around 17%. Among nuclear utilities, Constellation Energy (CEG) put on 5%, Vistra (VST) gained 4%, and GE Vernova (GEV) added 3%.

Deckers Outdoor (DECK) said late Thursday it won't provide annual guidance because of uncertainty around the economic impact of US tariffs. The maker of Hoka and UGG footwear also posted a disappointing quarterly sales forecast, helping drive its shares 17% lower in premarket.

The yield on the 30-year Treasury (^TYX) has risen above 5%.

title: Trump firma ordenes ejecutivas para impulsar el desarrollo de la energ√≠a nuclear
content: El presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, firm√≥ este viernes tres √≥rdenes ejecutivas que buscan impulsar el crecimiento de la energ√≠a nuclear en su pa√≠s, lo ...
resumen: El presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, firm√≥ este viernes tres √≥rdenes ejecutivas que buscan impulsar el crecimiento de la energ√≠a nuclear en su pa√≠s, lo que incluye el desarrollo de nuevos tipos de reactores compactos, incrementar la producci√≥n de combustible o aumentar las exportaciones del sector. Una de las √≥rdenes busca atajar la futura demanda energ√©tica que se espera que tengan en EE.UU. los sectores de inteligencia artificial (IA) y defensa y para ello acelerar√° los procesos regulatorios para el desarrollo y la adopci√≥n de nuevos tipos de unidades de fisi√≥n, como los llamados reactores modulares peque√±os (SMR por sus siglas en ingl√©s), que a√∫n no tienen uso comercial. Este edicto tambi√©n crea un puesto de enviado especial para la exportaci√≥n de tecnolog√≠a nuclear e insta al Departamento de Energ√≠a a aprobar marcos para que aumente el enriquecimiento de uranio en EE.UU., pa√≠s que obtiene del exterior m√°s de un tercio de su combustible at√≥mico. La segunda orden ejecutiva busca reformar la Comisi√≥n Reguladora Nuclear (NRC) para eliminar lo que la Administraci√≥n Trump considera barreras para la construcci√≥n y uso comercial de reactores at√≥micos ¬´con el objetivo final de cuadruplicar la producci√≥n de energ√≠a nuclear en las pr√≥ximas dos d√©cadas y media¬ª. A su vez, la tercera orden ejecutiva incluye la invocaci√≥n de la llamada Ley de Producci√≥n de Defensa para impulsar la cooperaci√≥n con el sector privado de cara a garantizar el futuro suministro de combustible nuclear. Las tres √≥rdenes ¬´permiten realizar pruebas de dise√±o de reactores en los laboratorios del Departamento de Energ√≠a, allanan el camino para la construcci√≥n (de plantas) en suelo federal para proteger la seguridad nacional y econ√≥mica y eliminan las barreras regulatorias al requerir que la NRC emita licencias de manera oportuna¬ª, explic√≥ la Casa Blanca en un comunicado posterior.

title: Con mal d√≠a en el mundo, hubo rueda de estudio en la Argentina
content: Trump volvi√≥ a la carga. Amenaz√≥ con ponerle aranceles a la Uni√≥n Europea y a Apple y eso alter√≥ las tasas norteamericanas, debilit√≥ al d√≥lar global e hizo bajar a Wall Street y a las Bolsas europeas.
resumen:
El mercado argentino comenz√≥ a tratar de asimilar las facilidades entregadas por el ministro Luis Caputo para que los d√≥lares salgan del colch√≥n, para generar m√°s actividad y permitir que el Banco Central sume reservas, y las primeras reacciones fueron positivas, aunque con dudas de parte de tributaristas especializados.

El d√≥lar baj√≥ en el mundo, hasta su menor nivel en dos a√±os, lo que ayud√≥ a que casi todas las cotizaciones del billete verde en Argentina apuntaran hacia abajo. El BCRA pudo recuperar reservas, con bonos y riesgo pa√≠s que siguen sin reacci√≥n, pero con acciones argentinas al alza, a contramano de otro d√≠a en rojo en Wall Street y en las Bolsas europeas.

Donald Trump amenaz√≥ con aplicar aranceles del 50% a lo que llegue a Estados Unidos desde la Uni√≥n Europea y del 25% para Apple, si no hay novedades en los pr√≥ximos siete d√≠as.

Citibank pronostic√≥ que el d√≥lar global va a seguir perdiendo valor.

Las tasas largas de EE.UU. se aplanaron: se pag√≥ 4,2% anual a 1 a√±o de plazo, 4,1% anual a 5 a√±os, 4,5% anual a 10 a√±os y 5% anual a 30 a√±os.

El d√≥lar cay√≥ contra todas las monedas: perdi√≥ 1% contra el franco suizo, 1% en Jap√≥n, 0,9% contra la libra, 0,8% contra el euro, 0,4% en M√©xico y 0,3% en Brasil, Chile y China.

El d√≥lar oficial cotiz√≥ a $1.157,43. El BCRA no intervino en el mercado, pero sum√≥ US$ 329 millones a las reservas.

El d√≥lar blue subi√≥ $5 hasta $1.170. El Senebi baj√≥ $1,14 hasta $1.160,56, el MEP baj√≥ $3,48 hasta $1.142,52 y el contado con liqui baj√≥ $10,46 hasta $1.157,54. La brecha entre el oficial y el blue fue del 1% y la del CCL con el mayorista fue del 2%.

Tributaristas se manifestaron a favor de las medidas de Caputo, pero dudan sobre qu√© har√° que la gente gaste el ahorro que tiene a resguardo.

El Gobierno est√° negociando un nuevo Repo por US$ 2.000 millones para pagar la deuda del 9 de julio pr√≥ximo.

Las tasas a vencimiento de los t√≠tulos p√∫blicos argentinos se ubican entre 9% y 12% anual, con bonos internacionales que pagan entre 5% y 7% con mucho menos riesgo. El riesgo pa√≠s sigue congelado en 651 puntos b√°sicos.

El Dow baj√≥ 0,6%, el S&P perdi√≥ 0,7% y el Nasdaq achic√≥ 1%. La Bolsa de San Pablo subi√≥ 0,4% y la de M√©xico mejor√≥ 0,9%.

La Bolsa de Buenos Aires subi√≥ 1,3%, con $74.403 millones operados en acciones y $60.121 millones en Cedears. Los ADR argentinos estuvieron mixtos, con subas del 1% al 3% para Loma Negra, Bioceres, Cresud, BBVA, TGS, Macro, Telecom e YPF; con bajas del 1% al 4% para Mercado Libre y Supervielle.

El petr√≥leo subi√≥ 0,8%. Los metales b√°sicos tuvieron un mejor clima con precios hacia arriba. Los granos sufrieron. El Bitcoin baj√≥ 2,4%, con descensos de hasta el 4% en el resto de ese panel.

El 29 de mayo de 2024, el Consejo de Ministros aprob√≥ el proyecto de Ley de Eficiencia del Sector P√∫blico, que busca mejorar la gesti√≥n y el funcionamiento de las administraciones p√∫blicas. La ley se estructura en tres t√≠tulos:

*   **T√≠tulo I: Medidas de eficiencia organizativa.** Incluye la creaci√≥n de la Oficina Nacional de Supervisi√≥n y Evaluaci√≥n de la Gesti√≥n P√∫blica, que evaluar√° el desempe√±o de las entidades del sector p√∫blico. Tambi√©n se promueve la simplificaci√≥n administrativa y la colaboraci√≥n entre administraciones.
*   **T√≠tulo II: Medidas de eficiencia en la gesti√≥n de los recursos humanos.** Se establecen mecanismos para optimizar la planificaci√≥n de plantillas y la gesti√≥n del talento en el sector p√∫blico.
*   **T√≠tulo III: Medidas de eficiencia en la gesti√≥n econ√≥mica y financiera.** Se busca mejorar la gesti√≥n presupuestaria, la contrataci√≥n p√∫blica y la utilizaci√≥n de los fondos europeos.

La ley se enviar√° al Congreso de los Diputados para su tramitaci√≥n parlamentaria.

title: Apple has had few incentives till now to start making iPhones in the United States
content: It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build plants in the United States to make iPhones here. If that happens, prices could skyrocket.
resumen:
Apple has had few incentives till now to start making iPhones in the United States.
It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build plants in the United States to make iPhones here.
If that happens, prices could skyrocket.
President Donald Trump threatened Friday to slap a 25% tariff on the popular device unless the tech giant starts building the product in its home country.
Apple has been building most of its devices in China, where it has invested tens of billions of dollars in massive factories that rely on a vast network of local suppliers.
Apple CEO Tim Cook said this month that most iPhones sold in the United States during March through June would come from India.
Cook said the trade war would end up costing the company an additional $900 million during the March-June period.
Industry analysts estimated the fees would drive up the cost of a $1,200 iPhone made in China to $1,500.
If Apple somehow could suddenly start making iPhones in the United States, prices for the devices would soar to at least $2,000 and possibly as high as $3,500.
The disincentives for Apple shifting its production domestically include a complex supply chain that Cook began to engineer in the 1990s while working for his predecessor, company co-founder Steve Jobs, who died in 2011.
It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build plants in the United States.
The price of an iPhone could triple, threatening to torpedo sales of Apple‚Äôs marquee product, which brought revenue of $201 billion during the company‚Äôs latest fiscal year.
Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives estimated that the current $1,000 price tag for an iPhone made in China, or one made in India, would soar to more than $3,000 if production shifts to the United States.
Moving production domestically likely couldn‚Äôt be done until, at the earliest, 2028.
Ives predicted that Cook would engage in a ‚Äúgame of negotiations‚Äù with Trump that would spare the iPhone from the 25% tariffs.
As AI becomes more sophisticated, the technology might spawn a wave of hands-free and screen-free devices that lower demand for smartphones.
Apple executive Eddy Cue said this month during a trial about the Justice Department‚Äôs proposed breakup of Google for running an illegal monopoly in search, ‚ÄúYou may not need an iPhone 10 years from now, as crazy as it sounds.‚Äù
Cook told investors tariffs had a ‚Äúlimited impact‚Äù on the company in the March quarter because Apple was able to optimize its supply chain.
Cook warned that it is ‚Äúvery difficult‚Äù to predict beyond June ‚Äúbecause I‚Äôm not sure what will happen with tariffs.‚Äù
Many analysts are predicting Apple will raise iPhone prices come fall, when the latest models are typically released.
Apple continues to reap huge profit margins from the revenue generated by subscriptions and other services tied to its product, according to Forrester Research analyst Dipanjan Chatterjee.
That division collected $96 billion in revenue during Apple‚Äôs last fiscal year.
Apple can absorb some of the tariff-induced cost increases without significant financial impact, at least in the short term.
Apple is facing a significant decline in its service revenue after a federal judge recently issued an order prohibiting it from collecting commissions on transactions within iPhone apps that are processed on other payment systems other than its own.
Unless Apple prevails in an appeal, the decision could cost the company billions of dollars a year.

title: Pro-Trump TV Ad Overstates His Second-Term Economic Record
content: A TV ad from a group supportive of President Donald Trump makes misleading claims, and uses outdated data, to argue that he is "fixing" an economy "ruined" by Democrats.
resumen:
A TV ad from a group supportive of President Donald Trump makes misleading claims, and uses outdated data, to argue that he is ‚Äúfixing‚Äù an economy ‚Äúruined‚Äù by Democrats.

The ad says that ‚Äúinflation and gas prices‚Äù are now ‚Äúat four-year lows,‚Äù based on data from March. National average gasoline prices have increased since then and are several cents higher than when Trump took office. Economists have warned that inflation also may soon increase again because of Trump‚Äôs tariff policies.

The ad also says that ‚ÄúTrump‚Äôs plan‚Äù is to provide ‚Äúmiddle-class tax cuts.‚Äù The Republican budget bill would benefit middle-income taxpayers by extending the 2017 tax cuts ‚Äî on average, every income group would get some tax relief. However, a nonpartisan tax policy organization has found that the majority of the tax cut benefits would go to the wealthiest 20% of households.

Securing American Greatness, the nonprofit group behind the 30-second ad, paid in the ‚Äúhigh seven figures‚Äù to run the commercial for two weeks in 20 targeted congressional districts nationwide, on cable TV and online. The ad started airing May 12.

The ad begins with a narrator saying that ‚Äúthey‚Äôve ruined our economy,‚Äù as photos of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, Rep. Nancy Pelosi and former President Joe Biden, all Democrats, are shown on screen. ‚ÄúPresident Trump is fixing it,‚Äù the narrator later says.

The economy wasn‚Äôt the best it‚Äôs ever been when Trump took office again in January ‚Äì but it also wasn‚Äôt in ruin. Trump inherited an economy experiencing significant annual growth, monthly job and stock market gains, plus much lower inflation than in 2022. Gary Cohn, director of the White House National Economic Council during Trump‚Äôs first term, said in a December interview on ‚ÄúFace the Nation‚Äù that Trump was inheriting from Biden a ‚Äúvery stable economy.‚Äù

The ad‚Äôs narrator mentions ‚Äúmiddle-class tax cuts.‚Äù The House-passed budget reconciliation bill would reduce taxes for middle-income households compared with what they would pay if the individual income tax cuts in a 2017 tax law are allowed to expire at the end of the year.

‚ÄúMiddle-income households would receive an average tax cut of about $1,800, or about 2.4 percent of their after-tax income,‚Äù according to Tax Policy Center estimates. Those households have incomes between about $66,800 and $119,200.

The TPC also found that ‚Äú60 percent of the tax cuts would go to the top 20 percent of households and more than one-third would go to those making $460,000 or more.‚Äù The ‚Äúbiggest beneficiaries,‚Äù the TPC said, would be households making between $460,000 and $1.1 million, whose taxes would be reduced by an average of nearly $21,000, or 4.3% of their after-tax income.

The bottom 20% of households, who make about $35,000 or less, would get a tax cut of less than 1%, or about $160 on average.

An analysis of the budget bill by the Penn Wharton Budget Model says that the benefits disparity is even larger when factoring in the bill‚Äôs cuts to safety net programs like Medicaid and supplemental food assistance. According to PWBM, even when considering the bill‚Äôs tax relief, in the long-term ‚Äúlower-income households and some in the middle class are worse off, despite positive economic effects.‚Äù The top 10% of the income distribution receives about 70 percent of the total value of the legislation.

The narrator of the ad claims that ‚Äúwe‚Äôre already seeing results‚Äù from Trump‚Äôs economic plan, as text on screen says ‚ÄúTrump‚Äôs Tariffs ‚Ä¶ Delivered Results.‚Äù

The quote attributed to the New York Times isn‚Äôt about results for the economy. The March 5 story highlighted in the ad was about tariffs that Trump announced this year on imports of Mexican goods that got Mexico to produce results for the U.S. on illegal immigration and fentanyl smuggling.

The Times reported that ‚ÄúSheinbaum dispatched thousands of National Guard troops to the state of Sinaloa, the hub of fentanyl trafficking, where they seized vast amounts of the synthetic opioid and busted hundreds of laboratories.‚Äù Then she ‚Äúsent thousands more‚Äù troops to the U.S. border, ‚Äúcontributing to a plunge in the number of illegal crossings,‚Äù the story said.

Mexico had ‚Äúagreed to send more than two dozen alleged cartel heads to be tried in the United States,‚Äù reversing the Mexican government‚Äôs position on extraditions.

The ad‚Äôs narrator says that ‚Äúthe cost of living is coming down,‚Äù adding that ‚Äúinflation and gas prices [are] at four-year lows.‚Äù

The ad refers to core inflation, which is a measure of the change in the price of goods excluding food and energy items. The April 10 Forbes article cited in the ad reported that the annual rate of core inflation was 2.8% in March, the lowest since March 2021. Core CPI was also 2.8% in April, the most recent data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The same Forbes article noted that tariffs that Trump implemented in early April, and ones that are currently on a 90-day pause, could end up increasing inflation again. It said that ‚ÄúGoldman forecasted the core CPI rate,‚Äù influenced by Trump‚Äôs tariffs, ‚Äúwould jump to 3.7% by the end of 2025, which would be a level not seen since March 2024.‚Äù

Average prices for regular gasoline are not at a four-year low. The claim appears to be based on a March 13 Inc article. Inc reported that average retail gasoline prices in early March ‚Äúslid to a multi-year low, according to GasBuddy data.‚Äù At the time, GasBuddy, which tracks fuel prices, said that the national average cost had fallen to about $3.03 per gallon, ‚Äúthe lowest March level since the pandemic.‚Äù

As of the week ending May 19, the average price of gasoline nationally was about $3.17 per gallon, according to the Energy Information Administration. That was up from about $3.11 when Trump took office, according to EIA figures.

The ad‚Äôs narrator says ‚Äúwages are up‚Äù while viewers see the words ‚Äúhourly earnings increased,‚Äù which is a quote from the April 4 CNBC article cited in the ad.

CNBC reported that the one-month increase in average hourly earnings for private workers was 0.3% in March, the news outlet said that the annualized growth rate of 3.8% was the lowest level since July 2024. Then average hourly earnings increased 0.2% month over month in April, and, again, the year-over-year increase was 3.8%, according to the BLS.

As of April, average hourly earnings had increased 0.6% since Trump took office again.

title: European plastics industry could suffer under Trump's threatened 50% tariffs
content: Plastics machinery could be "collateral damage" in a trade war between the United States and the European Union under new tariffs proposed to start June 1.
resumen:
President Donald Trump is threatening a straight 50 percent tariff on goods from the European Union starting June 1.

Trump said trade talks with the EU, which covers 27 member countries, aren't going anywhere in a May 23 post on his Truth Social network.

Trump posted that the EU was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE, and that the EU has trade barriers, Vat Taxes, ridiculous Corporate Penalties, Non-Monetary Trade Barriers, Monetary Manipulations, unfair and unjustified lawsuits against Americans Companies, and more, have led to a Trade Deficit with the U.S. of more than $250,000,000 a year.

Plastics News' Economics Editor Bill Wood noted that the trade deficit with the EU is closer to $250 billion than the $250 million in Trump's post ‚Äî and that the U.S. has a trade deficit when it comes to plastics machinery.

Perc Pineda, chief economist of the Plastics Industry Association in Washington, said that imposing high tariffs on manufacturing inputs could raise production costs and hinder domestic manufacturing competitiveness in the near term.

Pineda said that for machinery that is no longer produced domestically, tariff rates should remain low.

The U.S. is the largest export region and investment location outside of Europe for the VDMA, a mechanical engineering industry association based in Germany with 3,600 members in Europe.

VDMA Chief Economist Johannes Gernandt said that the current blanket import tariffs of 10 percent on almost all product groups ‚Äî including machinery and equipment ‚Äî announced by the U.S. government in early April already was causing additional uncertainty in foreign trade.

Gernandt said that the USA is their largest single market and that new trade barriers come at an inopportune time.

Gernandt appealed to politicians to keep markets open.

Pineda said European companies should consider increasing value-added activities within the U.S. rather than relying solely on exports and distribution.

Wood said that a reset between the U.S. and its trade partners is long overdue.

title: Trump‚Äôs tariff threats clash with Apple iPhone's global supply chain reality
content: Trump told reporters later on Friday that the 25% tariff would also apply to Samsung 005930.KS and other smartphone makers.
resumen: President Donald Trump threatened on Friday to impose a 25% tariff on Apple for any iPhones sold, but not made, in the United States, as part of his administration's goal of re-shoring jobs. He expects the tariffs to go into effect at the end of June. The 25% tariff would also apply to Samsung and other smartphone makers. Trump had an understanding with Apple CEO Tim Cook that he wouldn't be doing this. Cook said he's going to India to build plants. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said the work of "millions and millions of human beings screwing in little, little screws to make iPhones" would come to the United States and be automated, creating jobs for skilled trade workers such as mechanics and electricians. Lutnick said Cook told him that doing so requires technology not yet available. Dan Ives, an analyst at Wedbush, said moving production to the United States could take up to a decade and could result in iPhones costing $3,500 each. Apple's top-of-the-line iPhone currently retails for around $1,200. Brett House, an economics professor at Columbia, said a tariff on iPhones would increase consumer costs by complicating Apple's supply chain and financing. Sally Stewart Laing, a partner at Akin Gump in Washington, said there's no clear legal authority that permits company-specific tariffs, but the Trump administration may try to shoehorn it under its emergency power authorities. Tim Meyer, an international law professor at Duke University, said in the administration's view, as long as he enacts the ritual of declaring an emergency and pronouncing it unusual or extraordinary, there is nothing a court can do.
